    Le tableau présente les progrès réalisés par Allianz en vue d'atteindre ses objectifs intermédiaires pour 2030 dans différents domaines, notamment ses propres opérations, ses investissements propriétaires et ses activités d'assurance. Les données incluent les valeurs de référence, les performances pour 2023 et 2024, ainsi que les écarts par rapport aux valeurs de référence en pourcentage. Les objectifs pour 2030 sont également indiqués, accompagnés des écarts prévus par rapport aux valeurs de référence.
    - Allianz Own Operations : Les émissions de CO₂ par employé ont diminué de 61,5 % par rapport à la valeur de référence, avec un objectif de réduction de 65 % d'ici 2030. - Proprietary Investments : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros investi ont baissé de 46,5 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 50 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ des entreprises cotées ont diminué de 50,7 %, avec un objectif similaire pour 2030. - Les émissions de CO₂ par m² pour l'immobilier sont en cours de suivi, avec un objectif d'environ 20 kg CO₂e/m² d'ici 2030. - Insurance : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros de primes d'assurance commerciale ont baissé de 11,7 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 45 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ pour le secteur automobile de détail ont diminué de 6,8 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 30 % d'ici 2030.

  • Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les **exigences de divulgation** concernant les politiques de rémunération et les systèmes d'incitation liés aux **objectifs de durabilité** pour les membres des organes administratifs, de gestion et de supervision. Les colonnes incluent les intitulés **"Disclosure Requirement"**, **"Reference"** et **"Annotation"**, et les informations sont issues du **"Remuneration Report"** et de la section **"Determination of the remuneration system"**. Les points clés incluent : 1. Les **systèmes d'incitation** intègrent des objectifs de durabilité, notamment des cibles de décarbonisation pour les investissements, les assurances et les opérations internes, bien qu'aucun pourcentage fixe ne soit lié aux considérations climatiques. 2. Les **cibles spécifiques** incluent la satisfaction client (e.g., **digital Net Promoter Score**), l'engagement des employés (**Allianz Engagement Survey**) et la qualité du leadership, avec des aspects comportementaux comme l'intégrité et la réduction des émissions de CO2. 3. Environ **un tiers des facteurs de contribution individuels** est lié aux objectifs de durabilité, influençant la rémunération variable jusqu'à **14 %** positivement ou négativement, avec une portée totale de **28 %**. 4. Les **politiques de rémunération** sont approuvées et mises à jour au niveau de l'entreprise, mais certaines descriptions restent non détaillées. Le tableau met en évidence l'intégration des objectifs de durabilité dans les politiques de rémunération, tout en soulignant des lacunes dans certaines descriptions. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Disclosure Requirement Reference Annotation
    Incentive schemes and remuneration policies linked to sustainability matters for members of administrative, management, and supervisory bodies exist Remuneration Report Sustainability matters are included by incorporating them into the individual contribution factor of the target achievement (for BoM members). This extends to the decarbonization targets for proprietary investments, insurance, and own operations. However, there is no fixed percentage for remuneration linked to climate considerations. The remuneration of the members of the Supervisory Board does not factor in climate-related considerations and is not linked to our progress on decarbonization. A target achievement factor as well as a sustainability check factor is incorporated into the variable pay component.
    Description of key characteristics of incentive schemes Remuneration Report -
    Description of specific sustainability-related targets and (or) impacts used to assess performance of members of administrative, management, and supervisory bodies Remuneration Report Sustainability targets: Non-financial sustainability targets take into account customer satisfaction (e.g., digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS), employee engagement (e.g., Allianz Engagement Survey), and leadership quality. The individual leadership quality assessment process also includes a review of behavioral aspects, such as customer orientation, collaborative leadership, entrepreneurship, and trust (e.g., corporate social responsibility, integrity, diversity, and sustainability as measured by the greenhouse gas reduction of Allianz companies and by the development of a roadmap to reduce CO2 emissions in the context of capital allocation).
    Disclosure of how sustainability-related performance metrics are considered as performance benchmarks or included in remuneration policies Remuneration Report Please also note information on the Board of Management target process in the Board of Management target process section.
    Percentage of variable remuneration dependent on sustainability-related targets and (or) impacts Remuneration Report Compliance with sustainability requirements is factored into the individual contribution factor, which can increase or decrease the achievement of targets for the annual bonus and long-term compensation by 20 %. Therefore, the contribution factor has a total range of up to 40 %. Approximately one-third of the individual contribution factor is tied to sustainability goals. Since the variable component constitutes 70 % of the target compensation, the individual contribution factor can affect the total compensation by a maximum of 14 % positively or negatively. The overall range is 28 %. This applies to the entire variable compensation, including the annual bonus and long-term variable compensation.
    Description of level in undertaking at which terms of incentive schemes are approved and updated Remuneration Report – Determination of the remuneration system -

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation concernant les politiques de rémunération et les systèmes d'incitation liés aux objectifs de durabilité pour les membres des organes administratifs, de gestion et de supervision. Il détaille les caractéristiques des systèmes d'incitation, les cibles spécifiques liées à la durabilité, et la manière dont ces cibles sont intégrées dans les politiques de rémunération. Les annotations expliquent que les objectifs de durabilité sont pris en compte dans les facteurs de contribution individuels, influençant la rémunération variable. Environ un tiers de ces facteurs est lié aux objectifs de durabilité, avec un impact maximal de 14 % sur la rémunération totale. Certaines sections restent non détaillées.

  • Résumé du tableau : Le tableau détaille les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité, ainsi que les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. Les exigences "matérielles" incluent : 1. **ESRS 2 GOV-1** : Diversité de genre au sein du conseil (paragraphe 21 (d)) et pourcentage de membres indépendants du conseil (paragraphe 21 (e)), liés au rôle des organes administratifs, de gestion et de supervision. 2. **ESRS 2 GOV-4** : Déclaration sur la diligence raisonnable (paragraphe 30). 3. **ESRS E1-1** : Plan de transition vers la neutralité climatique d'ici 2050 (paragraphe 14) et exclusion des benchmarks alignés sur Paris (paragraphe 16 (g)), liés à la stratégie climatique et à la transition vers le net zéro. 4. **ESRS E1-4** : Objectifs de réduction des émissions de GES (paragraphe 34), couvrant les portefeuilles d'assurance, d'investissement et les opérations propres d'Allianz. 5. **ESRS E1-5** et **ESRS E1-6** : Consommation énergétique et mix énergétique (paragraphe 37), émissions totales de GES (paragraphe 44), et intensité des émissions de GES (paragraphes 53 à 55), liés aux métriques climatiques du groupe Allianz. Les exigences "non matérielles" ou "non pertinentes" concernent les activités liées aux combustibles fossiles, à la production chimique, aux armes controversées, au tabac (paragraphe 40 (d)), ainsi que les crédits carbone (paragraphe 56). and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Disclosure requirement and related datapoint Materiality Sub-section/sub-sub-section
    ESRS 2 GOV-1 Board's gender diversity paragraph 21 (d) Material Role of the administrative, management, and supervisory bodies
    ESRS 2 GOV-1 Percentage of board members who are independent paragraph 21 (e) Material Role of the administrative, management, and supervisory bodies
    ESRS 2 GOV-4 Statement on due diligence paragraph 30 Material Statement on due diligence
    ESRS 2 SBM-1 Involvement in activities related to fossil fuel activities paragraph 40 (d) Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS 2 SBM-1 Involvement in activities related to chemical production paragraph 40 (d) Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS 2 SBM-1 Involvement in activities related to controversial weapons paragraph 40 (d) Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS 2 SBM-1 Involvement in activities related to cultivation and production of tobacco paragraph 40 (d) iv Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E1-1 Transition plan to reach climate neutrality by 2050 paragraph 14 Material Climate change strategy and net-zero transition
    ESRS E1-1 Undertakings excluded from Paris-aligned Benchmarks paragraph 16 (g) Material Climate change strategy and net-zero transition
    ESRS E1-4 GHG emission reduction targets paragraph 34 Material Targets related to climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio, Targets related to climate change mitigation for our investment portfolio and Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz own operations
    ESRS E1-5 Energy consumption from fossil sources disaggregated by sources (only high climate impact sectors) paragraph 38 Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E1-5 Energy consumption and mix paragraph 37 Material Climate-related metrics for the Allianz Group
    ESRS E1-5 Energy intensity associated with activities in high climate impact sectors paragraphs 40 to 43 Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E1-6 Gross Scope 1, 2, and 3 Total GHG emissions paragraph 44 Material Climate-related metrics for the Allianz Group
    ESRS E1-6 Gross GHG emissions intensity, paragraphs 53 to 55 Material Climate-related metrics for the Allianz Group
    ESRS E1-7 GHG removals and carbon credits, paragraph 56 Not relevant Not applicable, since not relevant

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité, ainsi que les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. Les éléments jugés "matériels" concernent principalement la diversité de genre au sein du conseil, l'indépendance des membres du conseil, la diligence raisonnable, les plans de transition vers la neutralité climatique, les objectifs de réduction des émissions de GES, et les métriques liées au climat pour le groupe Allianz. Les éléments "non matériels" ou "non pertinents" incluent les activités liées aux combustibles fossiles, à la production chimique, aux armes controversées, au tabac, et aux crédits carbone.

Les informations fournies indiquent que l'entreprise a fixé des objectifs de réduction alignés avec une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C, conformément aux Accords de Paris. Les objectifs de réduction des émissions de GES sont basés sur des scénarios climatiques limitant l'augmentation de la température à 1,5°C d'ici la fin du siècle, comme recommandé par l'IPCC et d'autres organismes. Des réductions intermédiaires sont fixées pour 2030, avec des objectifs de réduction de l'intensité des émissions de GES de 65% d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019. Ces objectifs s'inscrivent dans le cadre des scénarios de décarbonation sectorielle et transsectorielle.

L'entreprise mentionne également l'utilisation du protocole de fixation des objectifs de la NZOAI, qui est aligné sur les scénarios climatiques pertinents pour limiter le réchauffement à 1,5°C. Bien que l'entreprise ne fasse pas explicitement référence aux objectifs SBTi dans les informations fournies, elle affiche une orientation claire vers le respect des Accords de Paris et des objectifs de neutralité carbone en conformité avec ces recommandations.

En résumé, les objectifs de l'entreprise sont alignés avec une trajectoire de 1,5°C, en accord avec les Accords de Paris, bien que la mention spécifique des SBTi ne soit pas présente dans les documents fournis.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM2 :
  • In line with our net-zero commitment, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, which are further underpinned by actions toward achieving our targets. Our emission targets are aligned with credible, science-backed climate scenarios – such as those provided by the IPCC’s 6th Assessment Report. Further scenarios include the International Energy Agency (IEA)’s Net-Zero by 2050 and the One Earth Climate Model; these limit global warming in 2100 to 1.5°C with only a limited or no overshoot of this temperature during this century. While the individual scenarios differ in their assumptions and narratives (including global future economic and public and private policy developments), they agree on a necessary emission reduction range for CO₂ emissions of 36% to 69% from 2020 to 2030, with a median reduction of 48%. For GHG emissions, the range is 34% to 60%, with a median of 43%. All our existing sub-portfolio targets for our operations, proprietary investments, and Property-Casualty In line with our net-zero commitment, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, which are further underpinned by actions toward achieving our targets. Our emission targets are aligned with credible, science-backed climate scenarios – such as those provided by the IPCC’s 6th Assessment Report. Further scenarios include the International Energy Agency (IEA)’s Net-Zero by 2050 and the One Earth Climate Model; these limit global warming in 2100 to 1.5°C with only a limited or no overshoot of this temperature during this century. While the individual scenarios differ in their assumptions and narratives (including global future economic and public and private policy developments), they agree on a necessary emission reduction range for CO₂ emissions of 36% to 69% from 2020 to 2030, with a median reduction of 48%. For GHG emissions, the range is 34% to 60%, with a median of 43%. All our existing sub-portfolio targets for our operations, proprietary investments, and Property-Casualty
  • # Targets related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio We deem the framework of the NZOAI Target-Setting Protocol (TSP) as best practice for setting GHG emission reduction targets. The TSP was developed with a strong reference to IPCC’s climate scenarios, limiting temperature increase by the end of the century to 1.5°C with no or limited overshoot during the century. The TSP was aligned with relevant stakeholders, including academia, and vetted in a public consultation. Thus, we generally follow its recommendations for our intermediate decarbonization targets. It should be noted that while the NZOAI TSP defines targets for engagements, sectors, and low-carbon solutions, we display these as actions in line with regulatory definitions in EFRS E1. When setting these targets, we considered potential future developments in large industries, especially the E.U. and the U.S., based on the latest climate laws and regulations. # Targets related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio We deem the framework of the NZOAI Target-Setting Protocol (TSP) as best practice for setting GHG emission reduction targets. The TSP was developed with a strong reference to IPCC’s climate scenarios, limiting temperature increase by the end of the century to 1.5°C with no or limited overshoot during the century. The TSP was aligned with relevant stakeholders, including academia, and vetted in a public consultation. Thus, we generally follow its recommendations for our intermediate decarbonization targets. It should be noted that while the NZOAI TSP defines targets for engagements, sectors, and low-carbon solutions, we display these as actions in line with regulatory definitions in EFRS E1. When setting these targets, we considered potential future developments in large industries, especially the E.U. and the U.S., based on the latest climate laws and regulations.
  • ## Targets Related to Climate Change Mitigation for Allianz Own Operations ### Overarching GHG Reduction Target(s) In our inaugural Net-Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year-end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50%, 65%, and 70% respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year-end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year-end 2029). The 2030 target aims to cut our GHG emissions per employee by 65% across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations). The decarbonization and removal offsets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP. ## Targets Related to Climate Change Mitigation for Allianz Own Operations ### Overarching GHG Reduction Target(s) In our inaugural Net-Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year-end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50%, 65%, and 70% respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year-end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year-end 2029). The 2030 target aims to cut our GHG emissions per employee by 65% across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations). The decarbonization and removal offsets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP.
  • While the decision to define an intensity target allows us to reflect the expected growth of our portfolio by 2030 in a dynamic way, we have ensured that our targeted reduction is still within the scenario range to limit global warming to 1.5°C. Specifically, we have aimed to set an emission reduction target in the ranges of the IPCC net-zero scenarios by 2030. We also considered a growth in premium to simulate business growth while considering the resulting increase in insurance-associated emissions. In addition to factoring in expected portfolio growth, our target definition was also informed by the anticipated real economy decarbonization, which we modeled using authoritative scenarios such as the STEPS scenario of the IEA and publicly available and verified company commitments. The targets were developed with the support of dedicated teams at AGCS and finally approved by the Group Sustainability Board. While the decision to define an intensity target allows us to reflect the expected growth of our portfolio by 2030 in a dynamic way, we have ensured that our targeted reduction is still within the scenario range to limit global warming to 1.5°C. Specifically, we have aimed to set an emission reduction target in the ranges of the IPCC net-zero scenarios by 2030. We also considered a growth in premium to simulate business growth while considering the resulting increase in insurance-associated emissions. In addition to factoring in expected portfolio growth, our target definition was also informed by the anticipated real economy decarbonization, which we modeled using authoritative scenarios such as the STEPS scenario of the IEA and publicly available and verified company commitments. The targets were developed with the support of dedicated teams at AGCS and finally approved by the Group Sustainability Board.
  • Our target setting is aligned with pathways to limit global warming to 1.5°C and was informed by market decarbonization, modeled using scenarios from an external data partner. The pathways simulated developments in the motor market and ranged from an “as is” status to a “net-zero” status by 2050. We took a conservative view on potential emission reductions from continued real-world changes and focused on developing decarbonization levers to bridge the gap between market changes and the total required emission reduction to align with our 2030 targets. When setting the targets, we considered future developments such as: decarbonization of the real economy and implementation of government decarbonization commitments, as well as changes in customer behavior such as driving less or the increased use of public transport/mobility. When considering potential initiatives, we took into account future projections in the nine in-scope markets, including energy usage, vehicle usage, and vehicle Our target setting is aligned with pathways to limit global warming to 1.5°C and was informed by market decarbonization, modeled using scenarios from an external data partner. The pathways simulated developments in the motor market and ranged from an “as is” status to a “net-zero” status by 2050. We took a conservative view on potential emission reductions from continued real-world changes and focused on developing decarbonization levers to bridge the gap between market changes and the total required emission reduction to align with our 2030 targets. When setting the targets, we considered future developments such as: decarbonization of the real economy and implementation of government decarbonization commitments, as well as changes in customer behavior such as driving less or the increased use of public transport/mobility. When considering potential initiatives, we took into account future projections in the nine in-scope markets, including energy usage, vehicle usage, and vehicle
  • ### END TABLE 1. Coverage as per Transition Pathway Initiative universe and metrics. 2. As outlined in the Inaugural transition plan, we have no set sector target for automobiles. However, this target covers Scope 3 (cat 11) emissions only, and those thereof are directly attributed to our emission reduction target. Hence, we do not pursue this target further. 3. We have updated our 2030 target values to the 2028 Transition Pathway Initiative benchmark values, which are appropriate as they reflect the one-year time lag in our emission data. --- 86 --- These targets build on the recommendations of the NZAOA TSP. They further incorporate potential and expected public and private policy developments which would close the gap towards the net-zero scenario. The targets trigger three types of actions: sector engagements, restrictions, and moving from climate laggards to climate leaders within the respective sectors. ### END TABLE 1. They further incorporate potential and expected public and private policy developments which would close the gap towards the net-zero scenario. The targets trigger three types of actions: sector engagements, restrictions, and moving from climate laggards to climate leaders within the respective sectors.
  • ## Environmental ### Decarbonization - Ensure sustainable solutions in proprietary investments and products - **Achievement 2024**: Growth achieved in both sustainable investments and sustainable insurance solutions in Property-Casualty; Sustainable Life Savings product and offering framework - **More Details**: For further insights, please refer to the sections Integrating sustainability in insurance and Integrating sustainability in proprietary investments sections - Follow through on the transition plan to reach the net-zero commitments of our business and operations - **Achievement 2024**: GHG emissions from operations reduced (62%) - **More Details**: For further insights, please refer to section E1 Climate change ## Environmental ### Decarbonization - Ensure sustainable solutions in proprietary investments and products - **Achievement 2024**: Growth achieved in both sustainable investments and sustainable insurance solutions in Property-Casualty; Sustainable Life Savings product and offering framework - **More Details**: For further insights, please refer to the sections Integrating sustainability in insurance and Integrating sustainability in proprietary investments sections - Follow through on the transition plan to reach the net-zero commitments of our business and operations - **Achievement 2024**: GHG emissions from operations reduced (62%) - **More Details**: For further insights, please refer to section E1 Climate change
  • The combined GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% is anchored to and governed by the FRSO. The FRSO ensures the achievement of the Renewable Electricity, Energy Efficiency, Green Fleet, and the Business Travel (excl. fleet) targets. The GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% for 2030 versus 2019 baseline includes Allianz Own Operations' activities in Scope 1, 2, and selected Scope 3 activities as it is an overall reduction target. All the targets governed by the FRSO are Group targets, including data from all Allianz Group subsidiaries and global lines within the environmental reporting scope. The main stakeholders involved in setting the targets were the Allianz Group Centers, such as Group Sustainable Operations, Group Accounting & Reporting, and Global Sustainability, through the establishment of a working group to jointly design the targets, set our ambition level, and ensure compliance. The Group Sustainability Board advised on the targets. Delivery against the The combined GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% is anchored to and governed by the FRSO. The FRSO ensures the achievement of the Renewable Electricity, Energy Efficiency, Green Fleet, and the Business Travel (excl. fleet) targets. The GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% for 2030 versus 2019 baseline includes Allianz Own Operations' activities in Scope 1, 2, and selected Scope 3 activities as it is an overall reduction target. All the targets governed by the FRSO are Group targets, including data from all Allianz Group subsidiaries and global lines within the environmental reporting scope. The main stakeholders involved in setting the targets were the Allianz Group Centers, such as Group Sustainable Operations, Group Accounting & Reporting, and Global Sustainability, through the establishment of a working group to jointly design the targets, set our ambition level, and ensure compliance. The Group Sustainability Board advised on the targets. Delivery against the
  • # Climate policy dialogue Achieving our net-zero commitment is contingent upon multilateral efforts with public policy and the real economy, as the necessary changes require widespread support. Our net-zero commitment and ability to implement decarbonization actions depend significantly on governments fulfilling the ambitious goals of the Paris Agreement through swift, stable, and reliable public policies, action plans, and regulations. This includes the need for adequate frameworks and market incentives to enable the transition of the global economy along 1.5°C pathways. The private sector needs to play an important role in supporting actions toward this transition. In pursuit of this, we actively engage with policymakers and regulators to support sustainable financing and achieve goals outlined in the Paris Agreement. We are advocating for effective global climate policy which should achieve the following: # Climate policy dialogue Achieving our net-zero commitment is contingent upon multilateral efforts with public policy and the real economy, as the necessary changes require widespread support. Our net-zero commitment and ability to implement decarbonization actions depend significantly on governments fulfilling the ambitious goals of the Paris Agreement through swift, stable, and reliable public policies, action plans, and regulations. This includes the need for adequate frameworks and market incentives to enable the transition of the global economy along 1.5°C pathways. The private sector needs to play an important role in supporting actions toward this transition. In pursuit of this, we actively engage with policymakers and regulators to support sustainable financing and achieve goals outlined in the Paris Agreement. We are advocating for effective global climate policy which should achieve the following:
  • Human-made climate change has already caused significant adverse impacts for nature and people. The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels by the end of the century. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), to restrict warming to 1.5°C, emissions need to be almost halved every decade and reach net-zero emissions by the middle of the century to maintain a reasonable chance of achieving this goal. However, if current emission trends persist, climate scientists estimate the greenhouse gas (GHG) budget will be exceeded before 2030, which necessitates urgent climate mitigation efforts from policymakers and businesses. Human-made climate change has already caused significant adverse impacts for nature and people. The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels by the end of the century. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), to restrict warming to 1.5°C, emissions need to be almost halved every decade and reach net-zero emissions by the middle of the century to maintain a reasonable chance of achieving this goal. However, if current emission trends persist, climate scientists estimate the greenhouse gas (GHG) budget will be exceeded before 2030, which necessitates urgent climate mitigation efforts from policymakers and businesses.
  • ## Scenarios Allianz’s business areas are exposed to climate change in different ways depending on their characteristics, e.g., different levels of exposure to physical or transition risks in different time periods. The scenarios used for the stress test therefore cover a broad spectrum of possible climatic and economic developments. This spectrum includes low-emission pathways, limiting global warming to 1.5°C by the end of the century, and high-emission pathways, where average global warming rises up to 4°C. Short, medium, and long term time horizons up to 2050 are considered, which are equally relevant for the processes in the individual business areas of Allianz, the implementation of important political and economic strategies in connection with the Paris Climate Agreement, and the onset of increasing global warming and its negative consequences. ## Scenarios Allianz’s business areas are exposed to climate change in different ways depending on their characteristics, e.g., different levels of exposure to physical or transition risks in different time periods. The scenarios used for the stress test therefore cover a broad spectrum of possible climatic and economic developments. This spectrum includes low-emission pathways, limiting global warming to 1.5°C by the end of the century, and high-emission pathways, where average global warming rises up to 4°C. Short, medium, and long term time horizons up to 2050 are considered, which are equally relevant for the processes in the individual business areas of Allianz, the implementation of important political and economic strategies in connection with the Paris Climate Agreement, and the onset of increasing global warming and its negative consequences.
  • # SUSTAINABILITY STATEMENT Sustainability Statement, which also fulfils the requirements for the Group non-financial statement prepared in accordance with sections § 315b to § 315c HGB # SUSTAINABILITY STATEMENT Sustainability Statement, which also fulfils the requirements for the Group non-financial statement prepared in accordance with sections § 315b to § 315c HGB

Oui, les objectifs de réduction d'Allianz sont alignés avec une trajectoire de réchauffement de 1,5°C conformément aux Accords de Paris. L'entreprise mentionne des objectifs intermédiaires pour 2030 qui sont sous-tendus par des actions vers l'atteinte de ces cibles. Ils sont alignés sur des scénarios climatiques crédibles et soutenus par la science, tels que ceux fournis par le 6ème Rapport d'évaluation du GIEC et le Modèle climatique One Earth, qui limitent le réchauffement global à 1,5°C d'ici 2100 avec un dépassement limité ou nul de cette température durant ce siècle (Context Num-4).

Concernant une trajectoire conforme aux objectifs SBTi, bien que les documents mentionnent l'alignement avec des scénarios scientifiques et les engagements de réduction des émissions, ils ne précisent pas explicitement une trajectoire conforme aux objectifs de l'initiative Science Based Targets (SBTi). Cependant, l'alignement avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris et la fixation d'objectifs à 2030 et 2050, avec des échelons intermédiaires, est mentionné (Context Num-6).

Il est important de noter que les objectifs de neutralité carbone d'Allianz s'inscrivent dans le cadre d'un engagement net-zéro, qui est en lien avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris, et que l'entreprise s'engage dans un dialogue actif avec les décideurs politiques pour soutenir une politique climatique mondiale efficace (Context Num-12).


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • In line with our net-zero commitment, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, which are further underpinned by actions toward achieving our targets. Our emission targets are aligned with credible, science-backed climate scenarios - such as those provided by the IPCC's 6th Assessment Report. Further scenarios used include the International Energy Agency (IEA)'s Net-Zero by 2050 and the One Earth Climate Model; these limit global warming in 2100 to 1.5 ℃ with only a limited or no overshoot of this temperature during this century. While the individual scenarios differ in their assumptions and narratives (including global future economic and public and private policy developments), they agree on a necessary emission reduction range for CO2 emissions of 36% to 69% from 2020 to 2030, with a median reduction of 48%. For GHG emissions, the range is 34% to 60%, with a median of 43%. All our existing sub-portfolio targets for our operations, proprietary investments, and Property-Casualty
  • ### Overarching GHG reduction target(s) In our Inaugural Net-Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year-end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50%, 65%, and 70% respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year-end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year-end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65% across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP.
  • ### Targets related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio We deem the framework of the NZAOA Target-Setting Protocol (TSP) as best practice for setting GHG emission reduction targets. The TSP was developed with a strong reference to IPCC's climate scenarios1, limiting temperature increase by the end of the century to 1.5℃ with no or limited overshoot during the century. The TSP was aligned with relevant stakeholders, including academia, and vetted in a public consultation. Thus, we generally follow its recommendations for our intermediate decarbonization targets. It should be noted that while the NZAOA TSP defines targets for engagements, sectors, and low- carbon solutions, we display these as actions in line with regulatory definitions in ESRS E1. When setting these targets, we considered potential future developments in large industries, especially the E.U. and the U.S., based on the latest climate laws and regulations.
  • # --- Page 40 --- ## C_ Group Management Report_ Sustainability Statement achieve the 2030 target, which is supported by ongoing or planned actions. The breakdown of our GHG emissions reduction target by Scopes is as follows. For Scope 1, Allianz Own Operations plans to reduce emissions per employee by 66% by 2030, and for Scope 2, we plan to reduce emissions per employee by 89% by 2030 compared to a 2019 baseline. Both targets are in line with the science-based-aligned minimum linear reduction rate for Scope 1 and 2 to limit global warming to 1.5℃. For Scope 3, our target is to reduce emissions per employee by 42% by 2030, compared to a 2019 baseline. The table below shows how each action contributes to the targets for the different scopes.
  • While the decision to define an intensity target allows us to reflect the expected growth of our portfolio by 2030 in a dynamic way, we have ensured that our targeted reduction is still within the scenario range to limit global warming to 1.5℃. Specifically, we have aimed to set an emission reduction target in the ranges of the IPCC net-zero scenarios by 2030. We also considered a growth in premium to simulate business growth while considering the resulting increase in insurance-associated emissions. In addition to factoring in expected portfolio growth, our target definition was also informed by the anticipated real economy decarbonization, which we modeled using authoritative scenarios such as the STEPS scenario of the IEA and publicly available and verified company commitments. The targets were developed with the support of dedicated teams at AGCS and finally approved by the Group Sustainability Board.
  • Our target setting is aligned with pathways to limit global warming to 1.5℃ and was informed by market decarbonization, modeled using scenarios from an external data partner. The pathways simulated developments in the motor market and ranged from an "as is" status to a "net-zero" status by 2050. We took a conservative view on potential emission reductions from continued real-world changes and focused on developing decarbonization levers to bridge the gap between market changes and the total required emission reduction to align with our 2030 targets. When setting the targets, we considered future developments such as: decarbonization of the real economy and implementation of government decarbonization commitments, as well as changes in customer behavior such as driving less or the increased use of public transport/e-mobility. When considering potential initiatives, we took into account future projections in the nine in-scope markets, including energy usage, vehicle usage, and vehicle
  • ### END TABLE 1_Coverage as per Transition Pathway Initiative universe and metrics. 2_As outlined in the inaugural transition plan, we have set a sector target for automobiles. However, this target covers Scope 3 (cat 11) emissions only and does therefore not directly contribute to our emission reduction target. Hence, we do not pursue this target further. 3_We have updated our 2030 target values to the 2028 Transition Pathway Initiative benchmark values, which are appropriate as they reflect the one year time lag in our emission data. Also, these targets build on the recommendations of the NZAOA TSP. They further incorporate potential and expected public and private policy developments which would close the gap towards the net-zero scenario. The targets trigger three types of actions: sector engagements, restrictions, and moving from climate laggards to climate leaders within the respective sectors.
  • We aim to finance the transition of companies in the hard-to- abate cement and steel sector that are aligned with a 1.5℃ path and have well-defined decarbonization strategies. We therefore created a separate emission bucket for new investments in those companies2 on our "steel and cement climate list," meaning that the financed emissions of these new investments are shown separately in the emissions table under "No target yet" and are not part of the 2030 corporate sub-portfolio emission target. Los años no están especificados en el contenido. 1. **ESRS S2-1** aborda el incumplimiento de los principios de los UNGPs sobre Empresas y Derechos Humanos y las directrices de la OCDE (párrafo 19), así como las políticas de diligencia debida relacionadas con los convenios fundamentales de la OIT (párrafo 19). Ambos son materiales y se relacionan con las políticas de ESRS y el modelo de negocio estratégico para los trabajadores en la cadena de valor. 2. **ESRS S2-4** trata temas de derechos humanos e incidentes en la cadena de valor (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos para remediar impactos negativos. 3. **ESRS S3-1** incluye compromisos de políticas de derechos humanos (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs, OIT u OCDE (párrafo 17), ambos materiales y vinculados al modelo de negocio estratégico para comunidades afectadas. 4. **ESRS S3-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos de interacción con comunidades afectadas. 5. **ESRS S4-1** sobre políticas relacionadas con consumidores y usuarios finales (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs y OCDE (párrafo 17) no son materiales. 6. **ESRS S4-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 35), considerado material, con enfoque en acciones. 7. **ESRS G1-1** sobre la Convención de las Naciones Unidas contra la Corrupción (párrafo 10 (b)) y la protección de denunciantes (párrafo 10 (d)) no son relevantes, ya que las políticas ya están implementadas. 8. **ESRS G1-4** sobre multas por violación de leyes anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (a)) y estándares anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (b)) son materiales, con enfoque en incidentes confirmados de corrupción o soborno. 9. Se menciona la aplicación de la cláusula de salvaguarda según ESRS 2.5(e) en relación con §§ 289e y 315c HGB para la brecha salarial de género en S1-16, sin más detalles.

Les objectifs de réduction fixés par l'entreprise sont alignés avec une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C, conformément aux Accords de Paris. Les contextes mentionnent que les objectifs sont basés sur des scénarios climatiques crédibles et soutenus par la science, comme ceux fournis par le 6e Rapport d'évaluation du GIEC (IPCC) et les scénarios de l'Agence internationale de l'énergie (IEA) visant à atteindre le Net-Zero d'ici 2050. Ces scénarios limitent le réchauffement climatique à 1,5°C d'ici 2100, avec un dépassement limité ou nul de cette température au cours du siècle.

L'entreprise vise également à réduire les émissions de GES par employé de 65% d'ici 2030 à travers les Scopes 1, 2 et certains Scopes 3, avec des cibles spécifiques de réduction pour les Scopes 1 et 2 alignées sur le taux de réduction linéaire minimum basé sur la science pour limiter le réchauffement à 1,5°C.

Cependant, il n'est pas mentionné explicitement si ces objectifs sont conformes aux objectifs de l'initiative Science Based Targets (SBTi). Néanmoins, l'engagement envers des scénarios de réduction des émissions basés sur la science et l'objectif de neutralité carbone indiquent un alignement général avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris.

Sources Azure :
  • to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Our targets are defined considering market -based scope 2 emis sions as well as SAF. Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations Overarching GHG reduction target(s) In our Inaugural Net -Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year -end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50 %, 65 %, and 70 % respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year -end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year -end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65 % across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations ). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP. to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65 % across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations ). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP.

Our engagement approach is further outlined in the subsequent sections below, and in the section Sustainability strategy and governance . Similarly, for our supply chain, we also expect 100 % of global framework vendors (i.e., vendors providing products and services under global master agreements with Allianz SE) to have made a public commitment to net-zero GHG emissions in line with a 1.5 °C path by 2025.   • For motor retail insurance, our target is to reduce the absolute carbon emissions within our in- scope portfolios by 30 % by 2030 compared to our 2022 baseline. The target covers nine key European markets, namely: Austria, Belgium, France, Italy, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland, and the U.K. For 2024, the in -scope portfolios within these markets represented 53 % of the motor retail premiums in the same year. These markets were chosen to focus on the most relevant and largest motor markets for Al lianz where adequate and reliable data was available. The in -scope portfolios were classified in line with the PCAF standard for personal motor. The target only covers CO 2 emissions, in line with the data which is currently available.   • 1.5 °C pathways We consider our impact on climate change to result from the GHG emissions generated from our business (Scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions). For Scope 3, category 15, our reporting boundaries are in line with GHG Protocol so that currently, assets under management owned by third parties and unit -linked funds are not part of the emissions reporting boundaries at Allianz Group . In line with our net -zero commitment, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, which are further underpinned by actions toward achieving our targets. Our emission targets are aligned with credible, science- backed climate scenarios – such as those provide d by the IPCC’s 6th Assessment Report. It should be noted that while the NZAOA TSP defines targets for engagements, sectors, and low - carbon solutions, we display these as actions in line with regulatory definitions in ESRS E1. When setting these targets, we considered potential future developments in large industries, especially the E.U. and the U.S., based on the latest climate laws and regulations.
  • for sectors1,2 Scopes covered 2024 2023 2030 target3 Oil & Gas Scope 1, 2 and 3 (cat 11) g CO 2e/MJ 70.6 n.a. 45.2 Utilities Scope 1 t CO 2e/MWh 0.2 n.a. 0.2 Steel Scope 1 and 2 t CO 2e/t steel 1.6 n.a. 1.2 1_Coverage as per Transition Pathway Initiative universe and metrics. 2_As outlined in the inaugural transition plan, we have set a sector target for automobiles. However, this target covers Scope 3 (cat 11) emissions only and does therefore not directly contribute to our emission reduction target. Hence, we do not pursue this target further. 3_We have updated our 2030 target values to the 2028 Transition Pathway Initiative benchmark values, which are appropriate as they reflect the one year time lag in our emission data. Also, these targets build on the recommendations of the NZAOA TSP. They further incorporate potential and expected public and private policy developments which would close the gap towards the net -zero scenario. for sectors1,2 Scopes covered 2024 2023 2030 target3 Oil & Gas Scope 1, 2 and 3 (cat 11) g CO 2e/MJ 70.6 n.a. 45.2 Utilities Scope 1 t CO 2e/MWh 0.2 n.a. 0.2 Steel Scope 1 and 2 t CO 2e/t steel 1.6 n.a. 1.2 1_Coverage as per Transition Pathway Initiative universe and metrics. 2_As outlined in the inaugural transition plan, we have set a sector target for automobiles. However, this target covers Scope 3 (cat 11) emissions only and does therefore not directly contribute to our emission reduction target. Hence, we do not pursue this target further. 3_We have updated our 2030 target values to the 2028 Transition Pathway Initiative benchmark values, which are appropriate as they reflect the one year time lag in our emission data. Also, these targets build on the recommendations of the NZAOA TSP. They further incorporate potential and expected public and private policy developments which would close the gap towards the net -zero scenario.
  • Standard. We will continue to enhance our carbon footprint disclosures and scope coverage as methodologies, data, and standards improve. For more information, please see section Methodology information for climate metrics . Our targets have not been separately validated by an external body. We regularly monitor and rep ort on progress toward our 2030 targets to the Group Sustainability Board. We also formally assess our performance at least annually in this context. Detailed information on these disclosures and targets is presented in the subsequent sections, which focus on our proprietary investments, insurance, and own o perations. In the past reporting year, we did not directly finance carbon removal. We also did not use carbon removal, allowances, and associated carbon credits when accounting for our GHG emissions and associated reduction targets or beyond our value chain. Our net -zero Standard. In the past reporting year, we did not directly finance carbon removal. We also did not use carbon removal, allowances, and associated carbon credits when accounting for our GHG emissions and associated reduction targets or beyond our value chain. Our net -zero
  • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management
  • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
  • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.
  • changes require widespread support. Our net -zero commitment and ability to implement decarbonization actions depend significantly on governments fulfilling the ambitious goals of the Paris Agreement through swi ft, stable, and reliable public policies, action plans, and regulations. This includes the need for adequate frameworks and market incentives to enable the transition of the global economy along 1.5 °C pathways. The private sector needs to play an important role in supporting actions toward this transition. In pursuit of this, we actively engage with policymakers and regulators to support sustainable financing and achieve the goals outlined in the Pari s Agreement. We are advocating for effective global climate policy which should achieve the following: − Embedding “net -zero by 2050” in short - and long -term governmental climate targets, climate strategies, and emissions changes require widespread support. Our net -zero commitment and ability to implement decarbonization actions depend significantly on governments fulfilling the ambitious goals of the Paris Agreement through swi ft, stable, and reliable public policies, action plans, and regulations. This includes the need for adequate frameworks and market incentives to enable the transition of the global economy along 1.5 °C pathways. The private sector needs to play an important role in supporting actions toward this transition. In pursuit of this, we actively engage with policymakers and regulators to support sustainable financing and achieve the goals outlined in the Pari s Agreement. We are advocating for effective global climate policy which should achieve the following: − Embedding “net -zero by 2050” in short - and long -term governmental climate targets, climate strategies, and emissions
E1-6

Quels sont les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de l'entreprise ?

Pour répondre à cette question, nous souhaitons avoir la liste ou les noms des actions menées, accompagnées d'une description simple. Si possible, afficher les objectifs de réduction pour chacune des actions, avec l'année cible et l'année de référence.

1. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction.
2. Métrique.
3. Périmètre des émissions (Scope 1, 2 ou 3).
4. Année de référence.
5. Objectif de réduction.
6. Année cible. Des informations moins primordiales, mais souhaitables pourraient être :

- La méthodologie utilisée ou l'initiative correspondante.
- Les objectifs intermédiaires (2030, 2035, 2040, 2045).

Je suis désolé, mais je ne peux pas répondre précisément à votre question car les informations détaillées concernant les méthodologies spécifiques, les années de référence, et les objectifs de réduction pour chaque action de décarbonation ne sont pas fournies dans les contextes disponibles. Cependant, je peux vous donner un aperçu des leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans les documents :

  1. Énergie Renouvelable

    • Action : Utilisation de l'électricité renouvelable.
    • Objectif de réduction : Variations attendues de (2.9) à 1.1 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales entre 2025 et 2029.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 2 et Scope 3.

  2. Efficacité Énergétique

    • Action : Réduction de la consommation d'énergie pour le chauffage et l'électricité.
    • Objectif de réduction : Attendus de 3.0 à 1.0 ktCO2e pour la consommation de chauffage, et de (1.2) à 2.9 ktCO2e pour la consommation d'électricité entre 2025 et 2029.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 1 pour le chauffage et non applicable pour l'électricité.

  3. Mobilité Verte

    • Action : Flotte verte et optimisation des voyages aériens.
    • Objectif de réduction : Attendus de (5.2) à 0.8 ktCO2e pour la flotte verte, et de (3.1) à 0.9 ktCO2e pour l'optimisation des voyages entre 2025 et 2029.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 1 et Scope 2.

  4. Autres Initiatives

    • Action : Ajustements liés à la consommation d'électricité des centres de données, à l'utilisation de véhicules de location, au papier, et au cloud.
    • Objectif de réduction : Attendus de (2.1) à 1.9 ktCO2e entre 2025 et 2029.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Non spécifié.

Ces leviers de décarbonation sont mis en place pour réduire les émissions de gaz à effet de serre dans les opérations de l'entreprise avec des objectifs de réduction spécifiques pour la période 2025-2029. Cependant, les années de référence précises pour chaque action, ainsi que les méthodologies utilisées, ne sont pas mentionnées dans les documents fournis.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau détaille les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les changements réalisés ou attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour les périodes 1.1.2024-31.12.2024 et 1.1.2025-31.12.2029, ainsi que les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les leviers incluent : "Start of period versus baseline", "Renewable energy", "Energy efficiency", "Green mobility" et "Other". - Les actions spécifiques comprennent : "Renewable energy", "Renewable electricity", "Reduction of heating energy consumption", "Reduction of electricity consumption", "Green fleet", "Air travel optimization¹", et diverses autres initiatives. - Les changements réalisés dans les émissions de GES pour la période 2024 incluent une réduction totale de 61.5 ktCO2e par rapport au début de la période. - Les changements attendus pour la période 2025-2029 varient selon les leviers et les portées : Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Par exemple, pour "Renewable electricity", les changements attendus sont de (2.9) à 1.1 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales, 1.1 ktCO2e pour Scope 2, et de (1.9) à 1.0 ktCO2e pour Scope 3. - Pour "Reduction of heating energy consumption", les changements attendus sont de 3.0 à 1.0 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales, et de (1.0) à 1.0 ktCO2e pour Scope 1 et Scope 3. - Les leviers "Green mobility" et "Air travel optimization¹" montrent également des réductions significatives, avec des variations selon les portées. - Les initiatives regroupées sous "Other" incluent des ajustements liés à la consommation d'électricité des centres de données, des véhicules de location, du papier, et du cloud, avec des réductions attendues de (2.1) à 1.9 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales. - À la fin de la période, une réduction totale de 65.0 ktCO2e est attendue par rapport au début de la période, avec des impacts spécifiques sur Scope 1 (5.2 ktCO2e), Scope 2 (40.1 ktCO2e), et Scope 3 (19.6 ktCO2e). and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les changements réalisés ou attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour différentes périodes et portées (Scope 1, Scope 2, Scope 3). - Les leviers incluent l'énergie renouvelable, l'efficacité énergétique, la mobilité verte et d'autres initiatives. - Les changements réalisés dans les émissions de GES pour la période 2024 sont détaillés, avec une réduction totale de 61.5 ktCO2e par rapport au début de la période. - Les changements attendus pour la période 2025-2029 sont estimés pour chaque levier, avec des variations dans les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les actions spécifiques incluent l'utilisation d'électricité renouvelable, la réduction de la consommation d'énergie pour le chauffage et l'électricité, l'optimisation des flottes et des voyages aériens, ainsi que des ajustements liés aux centres de données et autres activités.

Les actions incluent des engagements pour la transition vers le net zéro, des investissements dans des solutions bas carbone, des restrictions et des changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille. Les réductions réalisées pour 2024 totalisent (50.7), tandis que les réductions attendues pour 2025-2029 sont estimées à (61.3). Certaines actions, comme les engagements sur la transition net zéro, ne sont pas quantifiables. Les investissements dans des solutions bas carbone ont contribué à une réduction de (0.9) en 2024 et sont attendus pour varier entre 1.6 et 0.4 pour la période 2025-2029. Les changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille ont entraîné une réduction de (3.8) en 2024 et sont estimés entre 4.1 et (2.1) pour 2025-2029. and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonisation et les actions associées, ainsi que les changements réalisés et attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) pour deux périodes distinctes : 2024 et 2025-2029.
    - Début de la période par rapport à la base de référence : - Les engagements sur la transition vers le net zéro et la décarbonisation des clients ne sont pas quantifiables. - Les solutions bas carbone et les changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille ont permis une réduction de 3,3 MtCO2e en 2024.
    - Fin de la période par rapport à la base de référence : - Les solutions bas carbone devraient réduire les émissions de 22 à 18 MtCO2e entre 2025 et 2029. - Les changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille devraient réduire les émissions de 7 à 5 MtCO2e. - Une autre catégorie de changements dans le portefeuille pourrait varier entre une réduction de 1 MtCO2e et une augmentation de 1 MtCO2e. - La réduction totale attendue pour la période 2025-2029 est de 30 MtCO2e.

  • Le tableau présente les "Leviers de décarbonisation", les "Actions" associées, les "Réductions des émissions de GES réalisées du 1.1.2024 au 31.12.2024" et les "Changements attendus dans les réductions des émissions de GES du 1.1.2025 au 31.12.2029". Les leviers incluent la "Décarbonisation de l'économie réelle dans l'immobilier", la "Gestion de portefeuille dans l'économie réelle" et "Autres". Les actions spécifiques comprennent l'"Engagement des locataires", les "Améliorations de l'efficacité énergétique", l'"Énergie renouvelable", les "Rénovations profondes", les "Changements de portefeuille - Nouvelles acquisitions", les "Changements de portefeuille - Ventes" et "Autres". Pour 2024, les réductions réalisées incluent (1,2) pour l'efficacité énergétique, (1,4) pour l'énergie renouvelable, (4,0) pour les rénovations profondes, (0,5) pour les nouvelles acquisitions, (0,1) pour les ventes, et 0,5 pour "Autres". Certaines actions, comme l'"Engagement des locataires", ne sont pas quantifiables. Les réductions attendues pour 2025-2029 varient selon les actions, avec des plages spécifiques : par exemple, (35,0) à (29,0) pour "Locataires, partenaires commerciaux, réseau, etc.", (3,0) à (1,0) pour l'efficacité énergétique, et (8,0) à (6,0) pour les ventes. En fin de période, les réductions totales attendues par rapport à la ligne de base sont de (44) unités. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Real estate - Real economy decarbonization Tenant engagement - Not quantifiable

    Energy efficiency improvements (1.2) (3.0) to (1.0)

    Real economy - Portfolio steering Deep refurbishments² (4.0) (3.0) to (1.0)

    Portfolio changes - Sales (0.1) (8.0) to (6.0)

    End of period versus baseline (1.5) (44)

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonisation, les actions associées, les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) réalisées pour la période 2024, ainsi que les réductions attendues pour la période 2025-2029. Les leviers incluent la décarbonisation de l'économie réelle dans l'immobilier, la gestion de portefeuille dans l'économie réelle, et d'autres actions. Les réductions réalisées en 2024 totalisent 8,1 unités, tandis que les réductions attendues pour 2025-2029 s'élèvent à 44 unités. Certaines actions, comme l'engagement des locataires, ne sont pas quantifiables. Les réductions attendues varient selon les actions, avec des plages spécifiques indiquées pour chaque catégorie.

  • the decarbonization levers for our motor retail portfolio. Each lever is into specific actions, highlighting their respective broken down contributions to reducing CO2 emissions. The table tracks the percentage decrease in emissions compared to a baseline target value, covering the period from the beginning to the end of 2024. Additionally, it projects future developments and anticipated emission reductions through to the end of 2029, represented in ranges to account for potential variability. The lower ranges in the table reflect the maximum decarbonization effort and the upper ranges reflect the minimum decarbonization effort. the decarbonization levers for our motor retail portfolio. Each lever is into specific actions, highlighting their respective broken down contributions to reducing CO2 emissions. The table tracks the percentage decrease in emissions compared to a baseline target value, covering the period from the beginning to the end of 2024. Additionally, it projects future developments and anticipated emission reductions through to the end of 2029, represented in ranges to account for potential variability. The lower ranges in the table reflect the maximum decarbonization effort and the upper ranges reflect the minimum decarbonization effort.
  • Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for Allianz own operations There are three main decarbonization levers for our own operations: renewable energy, energy efficiency, and green mobility. Some emission sources are not covered by an action or target and thus a decarbonization lever, such as rental cars, rail travel, private car use for business purposes, and others. Each action is covered by a separate target, although some targets cover multiple actions at once. In addition, all actions are covered by the overall GHG emission reduction target for own operations. The travel target of a GHG emission reduction of 40 % per employee by year-end 2025 against a 2019 baseline as disclosed in the Allianz Annual Report 2023 was redefined into two targets: Green Fleet and Business Travel (excl. fleet). This reflects Allianz’s ambition to transition to a green fleet while separately addressing GHG emissions from business travel (excl. fleet). Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for Allianz own operations There are three main decarbonization levers for our own operations: renewable energy, energy efficiency, and green mobility. Some emission sources are not covered by an action or target and thus a decarbonization lever, such as rental cars, rail travel, private car use for business purposes, and others. Each action is covered by a separate target, although some targets cover multiple actions at once. In addition, all actions are covered by the overall GHG emission reduction target for own operations. The travel target of a GHG emission reduction of 40 % per employee by year-end 2025 against a 2019 baseline as disclosed in the Allianz Annual Report 2023 was redefined into two targets: Green Fleet and Business Travel (excl. fleet). This reflects Allianz’s ambition to transition to a green fleet while separately addressing GHG emissions from business travel (excl. fleet).
  • The main decarbonization levers in our own operations are renewable electricity, energy efficiency, and green mobility, with key actions comprising renewable electricity procurement, reduction of electricity and heat consumption, green fleet, and air travel decarbonization. The Allianz Group is not dependent on the allocation of resources because our specialized in-house teams drive the progress of our actions and the implementation of the transition plan, and these teams are implicitly incorporated into the financial plan. Experts must be deployed at a corporate level to ensure actions follow Allianz’s sustainability strategy, and at an operating entity level to ensure technical implementation. Further, Allianz’s ability to implement actions depends on data availability and collection, both in terms of its own operations and business activities. Climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio The main decarbonization levers in our own operations are renewable electricity, energy efficiency, and green mobility, with key actions comprising renewable electricity procurement, reduction of electricity and heat consumption, green fleet, and air travel decarbonization. The Allianz Group is not dependent on the allocation of resources because our specialized in-house teams drive the progress of our actions and the implementation of the transition plan, and these teams are implicitly incorporated into the financial plan. Experts must be deployed at a corporate level to ensure actions follow Allianz’s sustainability strategy, and at an operating entity level to ensure technical implementation. Further, Allianz’s ability to implement actions depends on data availability and collection, both in terms of its own operations and business activities. Climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio

Pour répondre à votre question concernant les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de l'entreprise, voici une liste des actions menées, accompagnées d'une description simple, ainsi que les objectifs de réduction pour chacune des actions :

  1. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction : Renewable energy

    • Métrique : Pourcentage de réduction des émissions grâce à l'électricité renouvelable.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 2
    • Année de référence : 2019
    • Objectif de réduction : Réduction de 2.3% en 2024, avec une projection de (2.9) à 1.1% d'ici 2029.

  2. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction : Energy efficiency

    • Métrique : Réduction de la consommation d'énergie (électricité).
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 2
    • Année de référence : 2019
    • Objectif de réduction : Réduction de (2.2)% en 2024, avec une projection de (1.2) à 2.9% d'ici 2029.

  3. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction : Green mobility

    • Métrique : Optimisation des déplacements aériens, flottes vertes.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 1 et 3
    • Année de référence : 2019
    • Objectif de réduction : Réduction de 1.6% en 2024 pour les flottes vertes, avec une projection de (5.2) à 0.8% d'ici 2029.

  4. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction : Portfolio steering

    • Métrique : Modification de la composition du portefeuille pour inclure des solutions à faible carbone.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 3
    • Année de référence : Non spécifiée
    • Objectif de réduction : Investissement de 20 milliards d'euros dans des solutions à faible carbone.

  5. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction : Engage high-emitting companies

    • Métrique : Engagement avec les entreprises à fortes émissions pour réduire les risques et augmenter l'impact positif.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 3
    • Année de référence : Non spécifiée
    • Objectif de réduction : Non spécifié, mais alignement avec le scénario IEA Net-Zero Emissions by 2050.

Ces actions s'inscrivent dans le cadre des objectifs de l'entreprise pour atteindre un engagement net zéro, avec des cibles intermédiaires fixées pour 2030.

Each lever is broken down into specific actions, highlighting their respective contributions to reducing GHG emissions. The table tracks the percentage decrease in emissions compared to a 2019 baseline. Additionally, it projects future developments and anticipated emission reductions through to 2030, represented in ranges to account for potential variability.   • # Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for Allianz own operations There are three main decarbonization levers for our own operations: renewable energy, energy efficiency, and green mobility. Some emission sources are not covered by an action or target and thus a decarbonization lever, such as rental cars, rail travel, private car use for business purposes, and others. Each action is covered by a separate target, although some targets cover multiple actions at once. In addition, all actions are covered by the overall GHG emission reduction target for our own operations. The overall target of a GHG emission reduction of 40% per employee by year-end 2025 against a 2019 baseline as disclosed in the Allianz Annual Report 2023 was redefined into two targets: Green Fleet and Business Travel (excl. fleet). This reflects Allianz's ambition to transition to a green fleet while separately addressing GHG emissions from business travel (excl. fleet). # Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for Allianz own operations There are three main decarbonization levers for our own operations: renewable energy, energy efficiency, and green mobility. Each action is covered by a separate target, although some targets cover multiple actions at once. In addition, all actions are covered by the overall GHG emission reduction target for our own operations. This reflects Allianz's ambition to transition to a green fleet while separately addressing GHG emissions from business travel (excl. fleet).

  • ### Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio For our portfolio targets, there are generally two levers for reducing GHG emissions: either the assets (i.e., our portfolio companies or our real estate investments) reduce their GHG emissions (investee company decarbonization), or we change the composition of our portfolio over time (portfolio steering). To this end, we have different actions in place to support emission reductions. #### Corporates For our corporate portfolio, we have set the following four targets on actions to pull the two decarbonization levers. These actions relate partially to addressing risks and opportunities, in addition to our inside-out impact: - Engage high-emitting companies in our portfolio to increase our positive impact and reduce risks; - Invest €20 bn in low-carbon solutions to increase our positive impact and seize opportunities; ### Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio For our portfolio targets, there are generally two levers for reducing GHG emissions: either the assets (i.e., our portfolio companies or our real estate investments) reduce their GHG emissions (investee company decarbonization), or we change the composition of our portfolio over time (portfolio steering). To this end, we have different actions in place to support emission reductions. #### Corporates For our corporate portfolio, we have set the following four targets on actions to pull the two decarbonization levers. These actions relate partially to addressing risks and opportunities, in addition to our inside-out impact: - Engage high-emitting companies in our portfolio to increase our positive impact and reduce risks; - Invest €20 bn in low-carbon solutions to increase our positive impact and seize opportunities;
