Les points de données matériels concernent principalement les politiques liées à la biodiversité, l'économie circulaire, la sécurité au travail, les droits humains, les mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, et les écarts de rémunération. Les points non matériels sont considérés comme non applicables.

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau détaille les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) réalisées ou attendues pour les périodes du 1er janvier 2024 au 31 décembre 2024 et du 1er janvier 2025 au 31 décembre 2029. - Les réductions des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base au début de la période sont de (16.6) en 2024 et de (11.7) en 2025-2029. - Pour les clients assurés, l'engagement vers une transition net zéro est non quantifiable, tandis que la décarbonation des clients contribue à une réduction de 0.7 en 2024 et entre (13.5) et (7.5) en 2025-2029. - Les actions de pilotage du portefeuille commercial incluent : - Les solutions bas carbone, avec des réductions de (0.1) en 2024 et entre (5.4) et (3.4) en 2025-2029. - Les restrictions, avec des réductions de (0.2) en 2024 et entre (7.3) et (5.3) en 2025-2029. - Les changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille, avec des réductions de 4.4 en 2024 et entre (13.0) et (11.0) en 2025-2029. - À la fin de la période, les réductions totales des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base sont de (11.7) en 2024 et de (45) en 2025-2029. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Decarbonization levers Actions Achieved GHG emissions reduction 1.1.2024-31.12.2024 Expected GHG emissions reduction 1.1.2025-31.12.2029
    Start of period versus baseline (16.6) (11.7)
    Commercial – Insured customers decarbonization Engagement on net-zero transition Not quantifiable Not quantifiable
    Customer decarbonization 0.7 (13.5) to (7.5)
    Commercial – Portfolio steering Low-carbon solutions (0.1) (5.4) to (3.4)
    Restrictions (0.2) (7.3) to (5.3)
    Further portfolio changes 4.4 (13.0) to (11.0)
    End of period versus baseline (11.7) (45)

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) réalisées ou attendues sur deux périodes : 2024 et 2025-2029. - Au début de la période, les réductions des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base sont de (16.6) pour 2024 et (11.7) pour 2025-2029. - Les actions liées à la décarbonation des clients assurés incluent l'engagement vers une transition net zéro (non quantifiable) et la décarbonation des clients, qui contribue à une réduction de 0.7 en 2024 et entre (13.5) et (7.5) en 2025-2029. - Les actions de pilotage du portefeuille commercial incluent des solutions bas carbone ((0.1) en 2024 et entre (5.4) et (3.4) en 2025-2029), des restrictions ((0.2) en 2024 et entre (7.3) et (5.3) en 2025-2029), et des changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille (4.4 en 2024 et entre (13.0) et (11.0) en 2025-2029). - À la fin de la période, les réductions totales des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base sont de (11.7) pour 2024 et (45) pour 2025-2029.

  • ### Résumé du contenu du tableau Le tableau présente les impacts, risques et opportunités liés aux questions de durabilité pour différents domaines d'activité d'Allianz : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres (y compris la chaîne d'approvisionnement). #### Impacts : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations dues aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires pour s'adapter au changement climatique. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Réduction des rendements des investissements en raison des risques physiques et de transition, affectant les actifs sous-jacents et les chaînes d'approvisionnement. - **Opérations propres** : Augmentation des perturbations opérationnelles et des coûts de conformité en raison des événements climatiques extrêmes et des réglementations liées à la décarbonisation. #### Risques : ### Résumé du contenu du tableau Le tableau présente les impacts, risques et opportunités liés aux questions de durabilité pour différents domaines d'activité d'Allianz : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres (y compris la chaîne d'approvisionnement). #### Impacts : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations dues aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires pour s'adapter au changement climatique. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Réduction des rendements des investissements en raison des risques physiques et de transition, affectant les actifs sous-jacents et les chaînes d'approvisionnement. - **Opérations propres** : Augmentation des perturbations opérationnelles et des coûts de conformité en raison des événements climatiques extrêmes et des réglementations liées à la décarbonisation. #### Risques :

Les mesures prises pour remédier au non-respect des procédures et des normes en matière de lutte contre la corruption chez Allianz incluent plusieurs actions et stratégies :

  1. Détection et Investigation :

    • Lorsqu'une enquête de conformité détecte une lacune dans un processus ou un contrôle commercial, la fonction de conformité peut recommander des mesures correctives à la fonction concernée (Context Num-1).

  2. Mesures Disciplinaires :

    • Si un employé ou un agent d'Allianz est trouvé en violation des lois externes ou du Code de Conduite du Groupe Allianz, des actions disciplinaires peuvent être envisagées. Celles-ci incluent un avertissement verbal, un avertissement écrit, une suspension, un licenciement ou une formation supplémentaire (Context Num-1).

  3. Formation Continue :

    • Une formation anti-corruption doit être dispensée au moins tous les trois ans à tous les employés. La formation est adaptée en fonction du risque et doit être complétée par ceux qui sont requis de le faire pendant la période de reporting (Context Num-3 et Num-6).

  4. Tolérance Zéro :

    • Allianz applique une politique de tolérance zéro à l'égard de la fraude, et prend des mesures promptes et appropriées contre les employés, les tiers agissant pour le compte d'Allianz, ou tout autre partie impliquée (Context Num-4).

  5. Politiques de Conformité :

    • Le système de gestion de la conformité, y compris les politiques de l'Allianz Group Compliance, les normes anti-criminalité financière, et le manuel de conformité, sont en place pour gérer l'impact de la corruption sur les activités et les relations d'Allianz (Context Num-5).

Ces mesures illustrent l'engagement d'Allianz à prévenir, détecter et remédier les incidents de corruption et de non-conformité dans le cadre de leurs opérations globales.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM2 :
  • ### Confirmed incidents of corruption or bribery If a Compliance Investigation detects a deficiency in the business process and control, the Compliance Function can recommend mitigating measures to the relevant affected function. The Compliance Function can also propose to management or the People and Culture functions to consider disciplinary actions if the investigation result shows that an Allianz employee and/or agent has violated external laws and/or the **Allianz Group Code of Conduct** or other internal Corporate Rules. Disciplinary actions may include verbal warning, written warning, suspension, termination, or additional training. The following table shows an overview of the convictions for anti-corruption/anti-bribery law. ### Confirmed incidents of corruption or bribery If a Compliance Investigation detects a deficiency in the business process and control, the Compliance Function can recommend mitigating measures to the relevant affected function. The Compliance Function can also propose to management or the People and Culture functions to consider disciplinary actions if the investigation result shows that an Allianz employee and/or agent has violated external laws and/or the **Allianz Group Code of Conduct** or other internal Corporate Rules. Disciplinary actions may include verbal warning, written warning, suspension, termination, or additional training. The following table shows an overview of the convictions for anti-corruption/anti-bribery law.
  • be positive. For further information about supplier management, refer to the section **Management of relationships with suppliers** and, for prevention of corruption and bribery, refer to the section **Corruption and bribery**. The effectiveness of our policies is tracked via the Corporate Rules Book process. For further details please refer to the section **Integrating sustainability via corporate rules and other ESRS policies**. be positive. The effectiveness of our policies is tracked via the Corporate Rules Book process. For further details please refer to the section **Integrating sustainability via corporate rules and other ESRS policies**.
  • Training can be provided through classroom training or by means of current IT-based training programs (e.g., web-based training), or documents with suitable content. The forms of training used, as well as its nature, scope, and timing, is decided on a risk-oriented basis. The following tables show the training coverage of anti-corruption, anti-bribery, and anti-money laundering training: It is calculated by the division of training sessions completed and functions-at-risk or Allianz SE Board members enrolled for the training. Enrolment in the training is dependent on the frequency of the training requirement. The Anti-corruption training must be completed at least every three years. Therefore, only these persons who are required to complete the training in the reporting period are considered as enrolled. For information provided to suppliers, please refer to the section Management of relationships with suppliers above. Training can be provided through classroom training or by means of current IT-based training programs (e.g., web-based training), or documents with suitable content. The forms of training used, as well as its nature, scope, and timing, is decided on a risk-oriented basis. The following tables show the training coverage of anti-corruption, anti-bribery, and anti-money laundering training: It is calculated by the division of training sessions completed and functions-at-risk or Allianz SE Board members enrolled for the training. Enrolment in the training is dependent on the frequency of the training requirement. The Anti-corruption training must be completed at least every three years. Therefore, only these persons who are required to complete the training in the reporting period are considered as enrolled. For information provided to suppliers, please refer to the section Management of relationships with suppliers above.
  • # Prevention and detection of corruption or bribery Allianz has zero tolerance for fraud. We are committed to complying with all applicable anti-fraud, anti-bribery, and anti-corruption laws and regulations in all jurisdictions in which we operate. - **Zero tolerance** applies irrespective of who benefits from the fraud – Allianz as a company, other Compliance/anti-corruption and bribery matter – internal parties (employees, tied agents, intermediaries), or third parties acting on behalf of Allianz. To protect against fraud, we will take prompt and appropriate action where necessary – against employees, others acting on behalf of Allianz, or third parties. # Prevention and detection of corruption or bribery Allianz has zero tolerance for fraud. We are committed to complying with all applicable anti-fraud, anti-bribery, and anti-corruption laws and regulations in all jurisdictions in which we operate. - **Zero tolerance** applies irrespective of who benefits from the fraud – Allianz as a company, other Compliance/anti-corruption and bribery matter – internal parties (employees, tied agents, intermediaries), or third parties acting on behalf of Allianz. To protect against fraud, we will take prompt and appropriate action where necessary – against employees, others acting on behalf of Allianz, or third parties.
  • ## Corruption and Bribery This section describes the impact of ethics, responsible business, and compliance matters on the Allianz Group's activities. Further, it describes the impact of the Allianz Group's activities and relationships on compliance. The concepts and achievements related to the management of these impacts are described with a focus on the compliance management system, anti-corruption, anti-bribery, and anti-money laundering. Additionally, subsidiaries maintain their own programs. The **Allianz Group Compliance Policy, Allianz Standard for Anti-Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Functional Rule for Anti-Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Compliance Manual**, and the **Allianz Group Code of Conduct** are policies which address the topics of corporate culture, whistleblower protection, and corruption and bribery on Group level. ## Corruption and Bribery This section describes the impact of ethics, responsible business, and compliance matters on the Allianz Group's activities. Further, it describes the impact of the Allianz Group's activities and relationships on compliance. The concepts and achievements related to the management of these impacts are described with a focus on the compliance management system, anti-corruption, anti-bribery, and anti-money laundering. Additionally, subsidiaries maintain their own programs. The **Allianz Group Compliance Policy, Allianz Standard for Anti-Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Functional Rule for Anti-Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Compliance Manual**, and the **Allianz Group Code of Conduct** are policies which address the topics of corporate culture, whistleblower protection, and corruption and bribery on Group level.
  • - **Anti-corruption training** must be provided at least every three years to all employees. The sole possible limit in relation to the obligation to provide such training applies in relation to employees who perform activities entirely connected to the tasks or services typical of the subsidiary's business. All other employees must complete at least a basic training. In a first step, subsidiaries are required to regularly (re)assess whether they are subject to AML-obliged entities under local law. The determination as to AML-Obliged entity status would normally be performed or managed in the subsidiary’s Legal Function in collaboration with the Compliance Function and must relate to each legal entity and branch of the subsidiary. 145 - **Anti-corruption training** must be provided at least every three years to all employees. Les mesures prises pour remédier au non-respect des procédures et des normes en matière de lutte contre la corruption chez Allianz comprennent plusieurs actions spécifiques.

  1. Détection et Investigation: Le système de gestion de la conformité d'Allianz est conçu pour garantir le respect des lois et réglementations internationalement reconnues, ce qui inclut la détection et le signalement des cas de fraude interne au comité d'intégrité du groupe. Les enquêtes de conformité permettent d'identifier toute déficience dans les processus et contrôles commerciaux.

  2. Mesures de Remédiation: Si une enquête de conformité détecte une déficience, la fonction de conformité peut recommander des mesures d'atténuation à la fonction concernée. Cela peut inclure des actions disciplinaires si un employé ou un agent d'Allianz a violé des lois externes ou le Code de conduite du groupe Allianz.

  3. Actions Disciplinaires: Les actions disciplinaires possibles incluent des avertissements verbaux ou écrits, la suspension, le licenciement ou une formation supplémentaire.

  4. Formation Continue: Allianz exige que la formation anti-corruption soit dispensée au moins tous les trois ans à tous les employés concernés, ce qui assure un engagement continu dans la lutte contre la corruption.

  5. Culture de l'Intégrité: Le système de gestion de la conformité d'Allianz promeut une culture d'intégrité pour protéger la réputation de l'entreprise et inclut des procédures anti-représailles pour protéger les lanceurs d'alerte.

Ces mesures sont mises en œuvre pour assurer que toute violation des normes anti-corruption soit traitée de manière efficace et pour promouvoir une culture de conformité et d'intégrité au sein de l'entreprise.

  • ### Confirmed incidents of corruption or bribery If a Compliance Investigation detects a deficiency in the business process and control, the Compliance Function can recommend mitigating measures to the relevant affected function. The Compliance Function can also propose to management or the People and Culture functions to consider disciplinary actions if the investigation result shows that an Allianz employee and/or agent has violated external laws and/or the Allianz Group Code of Conduct or other internal Corporate Rules. Disciplinary actions may include verbal warning, written warning, suspension, termination, or additional training. Enrolment in the training is dependent on the frequency of the training requirement. The Anti-corruption training must be completed at least every three years. Therefore, only these persons who are required to complete the training in the reporting period are considered as enrolled1.   • # --- Page 93 --- ## C_ Group Management Report_ Sustainability Statement Our Compliance Management System helps to ensure compliance with internationally recognized laws, rules, and regulations, and to promote a culture of integrity in order to safeguard the company's reputation. This includes, among others, rules and regulations against corruption and bribery, such as the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), the U.K. Bribery Act (UKBA), and the French Sapin II Law.

The effectiveness of our policies is tracked via the Corporate Rules Book process. For further details please refer to the section Integrating sustainability via corporate rules and other ESRS policies.
  • ### Prevention and detection of corruption or bribery Allianz has zero tolerance for fraud. We are committed to complying with all applicable anti-fraud, anti-bribery, and anti-corruption laws and regulations in all jurisdictions in which we operate. Zero tolerance applies irrespective of who benefits from the fraud - Allianz as a company, other Compliance/anti-corruption and bribery matter - internal parties (employees, tied agents, intermediaries), or any third parties acting on behalf of Allianz. To protect against fraud, we will take prompt and appropriate action where necessary - against employees, others acting on behalf of Allianz, or third parties.
  • ### Section summary This section details our commitment to maintaining high ethical standards and integrity in all of our business operations. Our policy emphasizes promoting transparency, preventing corruption and bribery, as well as having a resilient supplier management - all underpinned by our compliance with laws and regulations. The strategy involves setting guidelines for ethical behavior and fostering a culture of accountability. Key actions include implementing supplier due diligence, compliance training, and establishing clear reporting mechanisms for unethical conduct. This section further provides transparent information about our political influence and main lobbying activities.
  • ### Corruption and bribery This section describes the impact of ethics, responsible business, and compliance matters on the Allianz Group's activities. Further, it describes the impact of the Allianz Group's activities and relationships on compliance. The concepts and achievements related to the manage- ment of these impacts are described with a focus on the compliance management system, anti-corruption, anti-bribery, and anti-money laundering. Additionally, subsidiaries maintain their own programs. The Allianz Group Compliance Policy, Allianz Standard for Anti- Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Functional Rule for Anti- Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Compliance Manual, and the Allianz Group Code of Conduct are policies which address the topics of corporate culture, whistleblower protection, and corruption and bribery on Group level.
  • Anti-corruption training must be provided at least every three years to all employees. The sole possible limit in relation to the obligation to provide such training applies in relation to employees who perform activities entirely unconnected to the tasks or services typical of the subsidiary's business. All other employees must complete at least a basic training. In a first step, subsidiaries are required to regularly (re)assess whether they are subject to AML obligations under local law. The determination as to AML-Obliged entity status would normally be performed or managed in the subsidiary's Legal Function in collaboration with the Compliance Function and must relate to each legal entity and branch of the subsidiary.

Ambos son materiales y se relacionan con las políticas de ESRS y el modelo de negocio estratégico para los trabajadores en la cadena de valor. 2. **ESRS S2-4** trata temas de derechos humanos e incidentes en la cadena de valor (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos para remediar impactos negativos. 3. **ESRS S3-1** incluye compromisos de políticas de derechos humanos (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs, OIT u OCDE (párrafo 17), ambos materiales y vinculados al modelo de negocio estratégico para comunidades afectadas. 4. **ESRS S3-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos de interacción con comunidades afectadas. 5. **ESRS S4-1** sobre políticas relacionadas con consumidores y usuarios finales (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs y OCDE (párrafo 17) no son materiales. 6. **ESRS S4-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 35), considerado material, con enfoque en acciones. 7. **ESRS G1-1** sobre la Convención de las Naciones Unidas contra la Corrupción (párrafo 10 (b)) y la protección de denunciantes (párrafo 10 (d)) no son relevantes, ya que las políticas ya están implementadas. 8. **ESRS G1-4** sobre multas por violación de leyes anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (a)) y estándares anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (b)) son materiales, con enfoque en incidentes confirmados de corrupción o soborno. 9. Se menciona la aplicación de la cláusula de salvaguarda según ESRS 2.5(e) en relación con §§ 289e y 315c HGB para la brecha salarial de género en S1-16, sin más detalles.

Los indicadores incluyen: 1. **Reducción de emisiones propias en inversiones**: Emisiones absolutas financiadas de GHG en millones de toneladas de CO2e provenientes de corporaciones listadas, con un objetivo de **12.3 mn t CO2e**. 2. **Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)**: Porcentaje de líderes de lealtad en segmentos de negocio, con un objetivo de **50 %**. 3. **Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)**: Desarrollo contra el nivel de ambición general, con un objetivo de **77 %**. 4. **Plan de transición hacia compromisos de cero emisiones netas**: Incluye reducción de emisiones en el sector de motor retail y reducción de intensidad de emisiones en el sector comercial de Property-Casualty. 5. **Soluciones sostenibles en Property-Casualty**. 6. **Desarrollo del Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 7. **Desarrollo del Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 8. **Cumplimiento estricto de requisitos regulatorios y de gobernanza corporativa**, con enfoque en un sistema de gestión de riesgos adecuado y cultura de riesgos. 9. **Contribución de liderazgo**, con enfoque en atributos de personas de Allianz: Excelencia en clientes y mercado, liderazgo colaborativo, emprendimiento y confianza; evaluación multi-rater. ### END TABLE

Les mesures prises pour remédier au non-respect des procédures et des normes en matière de lutte contre la corruption incluent plusieurs actions et stratégies mises en place par Allianz :

  1. Détection et Enquête : La Fonction de Conformité mène des enquêtes pour détecter les déficiences dans les processus d'affaires et le contrôle. Si une violation des lois externes ou du Code de Conduite du Groupe Allianz est confirmée, des mesures correctrices sont recommandées.

  2. Mesures Correctrices : Ces mesures peuvent inclure des avertissements verbaux, des avertissements écrits, des suspensions, des licenciements ou des formations complémentaires pour les employés ou agents impliqués.

  3. Formation : Allianz impose une formation anti-corruption obligatoire pour tous les employés au moins tous les trois ans. Les formations couvrent également la lutte contre le blanchiment d'argent. Seuls les employés dont les activités sont directement liées aux risques de corruption sont tenus de suivre ces formations.

  4. Tolérance Zéro : Allianz applique une politique de tolérance zéro envers la fraude et la corruption, s'engageant à prendre des mesures rapides et appropriées contre les parties impliquées, qu'il s'agisse d'employés, d'agents liés ou de tiers agissant au nom de l'entreprise.

  5. Système de Gestion de Conformité : Un système de gestion de la conformité est en place pour s'assurer du respect des lois et règlements internationalement reconnus, renforçant une culture d'intégrité au sein de l'entreprise. Cela inclut des règles et des règlements contre la corruption et la subornation.

  6. Surveillance et Contrôle : L'efficacité des politiques est suivie via le processus du Corporate Rules Book, ce qui inclut la gestion des relations avec les fournisseurs et la prévention de la corruption et de la subornation.

Ces actions démontrent l'engagement continu d'Allianz à prévenir et à traiter le non-respect des normes anti-corruption.

Sources Azure :

  • for Anti -Financial Crime. Anti -corruption training must be provided at least every three years to all employees. The sole possible limit in relation to the obligation to provide such training applies in relation to employees who perform activities entirely unconnected to the tasks or services typical of the subsidiary’s business. All other employees must complete at least a basic training. In a first step, subsidiaries are required to regularly (re)assess whether they are subject to AML obligations under local law. The determination as to AML -Obliged entity status would normally be performed or managed in the subsidiary ’s Legal Function in collaboration with the Compliance Function and must relate to each legal entity and branch of the subsidiary . 1_“Functional at risk” refers to those individuals/persons deemed to be at risk of corruption, bribery, and/or for Anti -Financial Crime. Anti -corruption training must be provided at least every three years to all employees. The sole possible limit in relation to the obligation to provide such training applies in relation to employees who perform activities entirely unconnected to the tasks or services typical of the subsidiary’s business. All other employees must complete at least a basic training. In a first step, subsidiaries are required to regularly (re)assess whether they are subject to AML obligations under local law. The determination as to AML -Obliged entity status would normally be performed or managed in the subsidiary ’s Legal Function in collaboration with the Compliance Function and must relate to each legal entity and branch of the subsidiary . 1_“Functional at risk” refers to those individuals/persons deemed to be at risk of corruption, bribery, and/or
  • laundering . Additionally, subsidiaries maintain their own programs . The Allianz Group Compliance Policy, Allianz Standard for Anti - Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Functional Rule for Anti - Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Compliance Manual, and the Allianz Group Code of Conduct are policies which address the topics of corporate culture, whistleblower protection, and corruption and bribery on Group level. The Allianz Group Compliance Policy establishes the core principles and tasks of a Compliance Function within Allianz Group . It ensures that the organization and work of Allianz Group `s Compliance functions worldwide adhere to a consistent set of minimum rules. It defines also that the Compliance Function develops, implement s and oversees the compliance framework for the assigned compliance risk areas such as anti -bribery and corruption. The Allianz Group Standard for Anti -financial Crime Compliance laundering . Additionally, subsidiaries maintain their own programs . The Allianz Group Compliance Policy, Allianz Standard for Anti - Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Functional Rule for Anti - Financial Crime Compliance, Allianz Compliance Manual, and the Allianz Group Code of Conduct are policies which address the topics of corporate culture, whistleblower protection, and corruption and bribery on Group level. The Allianz Group Compliance Policy establishes the core principles and tasks of a Compliance Function within Allianz Group . It ensures that the organization and work of Allianz Group `s Compliance functions worldwide adhere to a consistent set of minimum rules. It defines also that the Compliance Function develops, implement s and oversees the compliance framework for the assigned compliance risk areas such as anti -bribery and corruption. The Allianz Group Standard for Anti -financial Crime Compliance
  • implemented in practice. The Allianz Compliance Manual (“Manual”) provides guidance on the execution of the principles and tasks of the local Compliance functions and departments. The aim of the Manual is to enhance organizational processes and operations through standardization and to ensure consistency in the implemen tation and operation of the requirements. This includes, among others, the anti -retaliation procedure. C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement Annual Report 2024 − Allianz Group 145 G1 Business Conduct Our Compliance Management System helps to ensure compliance with internationally recognized laws, rules, and regulations, and to promote a culture of integrity in order to safeguard the company’s reputation. This includes, among others, rules and regulations against corruption and bribery, such as the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), the U.K. Bribery Act (UKBA), and the French Sapin II Law. implemented in practice. This includes, among others, the anti -retaliation procedure. This includes, among others, rules and regulations against corruption and bribery, such as the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), the U.K. Bribery Act (UKBA), and the French Sapin II Law.
  • adequate and effective measures to address any confirmed incidents. We monitor our legal proceedings with our Litigation Proceedings Data Base and our Supervisory Proceedings Data Base. The Litigation Proceedings Data Base covers civil and administrative proceedings that pose reputational risks or exceed a financial thresh old and criminal cases against Allianz leaders or subsidiaries. The Supervisory Proceedings Data Base includes administrative fines and administrative proceedings which could lead to administrative fines each above a specified threshold, e.g., involving em ployees tied to their work or internally defined sensitive issues, as well as criminal proceedings against Allianz personnel that is related to their work or against subsidiaries of the Allianz Group without a threshold. The corresponding overall amount of material fines, penalties, and compensation for incidents connected to own workforce from proceedings adequate and effective measures to address any confirmed incidents. The Supervisory Proceedings Data Base includes administrative fines and administrative proceedings which could lead to administrative fines each above a specified threshold, e.g., involving em ployees tied to their work or internally defined sensitive issues, as well as criminal proceedings against Allianz personnel that is related to their work or against subsidiaries of the Allianz Group without a threshold. The corresponding overall amount of material fines, penalties, and compensation for incidents connected to own workforce from proceedings
  • The outcome of Compliance Investigations is shared first with the Group Chief Compliance Officer, who, on a quarterly basis, provides an update to the Group’s CFO based on the information provided to members of the Integrity Committee. Group Compliance is responsible for monitoring and reporting identified internal fraud cases to the Board of Management, Audit Committee, Statutory Auditor, and Group Integrity Committee. If a Compliance Investigation detects a deficiency in the business process and control, the Compliance Function can recommend mitigating measures to the relevant affected function. The Compliance Function can also propose to management or the People and Culture functions to consider disciplinary actions if the investigation result shows that an Allianz employee and/or agent has violated external laws and/or the Allianz Group Code of Conduct or other internal Corporate Rules. Disciplinary actions may include verbal warning, The outcome of Compliance Investigations is shared first with the Group Chief Compliance Officer, who, on a quarterly basis, provides an update to the Group’s CFO based on the information provided to members of the Integrity Committee.   • of the anti -financial crime compliance program of the subsidiaries and examples of indicators of financial crime, as well as information regarding new developments in financial crime trends and regulations. Training can be provided through classroom training or by means of current IT -based training programs (e.g., web -based training), or documents with suitable content. The forms of training used, as well as its nature, scope, and timing, is decided on a risk -oriented basis.   • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management
  • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
  • the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime

E1-124

Quelles sont les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées grâce à la méthode "location-based" ?

nan

Je suis désolé, mais les informations nécessaires pour calculer les émissions totales du Scope 2 selon la méthode "location-based" ne sont pas disponibles dans les documents fournis.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Résumé du tableau : - La **Catégorie** inclut les émissions de GES Scope 1, Scope 2, Scope 3, et les émissions totales de GES par employé. - Les **Émissions brutes de GES Scope 1** ont diminué de 22,4 % par rapport à la **Valeur de référence 2019** (297,7), avec un **Objectif 2030** de réduction de 66 %. - Les **Émissions brutes de GES Scope 2 (localisation)** ont baissé de 52,2 % par rapport à la **Valeur de référence 2019** (1 589,3), avec un **Objectif 2030** de réduction de 89 %. - Les **Émissions brutes de GES Scope 2 (marché)** ont diminué de 96,2 % par rapport à la **Valeur de référence 2019** (1 010,1). - Les **Émissions de GES Scope 3** incluent les catégories : **Biens et services achetés** (57,4 en 2024), **Activités liées au carburant et à l'énergie** (193,5 en 2024), **Voyages d'affaires** (356,7 en 2024), et **Déplacements des employés** (47,6 en 2024). Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles. - Les **Émissions totales de GES par employé pour les opérations propres (localisation)** ont baissé de 44,1 % par rapport à la **Valeur de référence 2019** (2 945,9), avec un **Objectif 2030** de réduction de 65 %. - Les **Émissions totales de GES par employé pour les opérations propres (marché)** ont diminué de 61 % par rapport à la **Valeur de référence 2019** (2 366,7). - Les **Émissions totales de GES par employé pour les opérations propres (marché, SAF inclus)** ont baissé de 61,5 % par rapport à la **Valeur de référence 2019** (2 366,7). - Les **Deltas en %** et les **Deltas objectif 2030 vs référence en %** sont indiqués pour chaque catégorie. and

    Résumé du tableau : - Les émissions de GES Scope 1 ont diminué de 22,4 % par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2019, avec un objectif de réduction de 66 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions de GES Scope 2 basées sur la localisation ont baissé de 52,2 % par rapport à 2019, avec un objectif de réduction de 89 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions de GES Scope 2 basées sur le marché ont diminué de 96,2 % par rapport à 2019. - Les émissions totales de GES par employé pour les opérations propres basées sur la localisation ont baissé de 44,1 % par rapport à 2019, avec un objectif de réduction de 65 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions totales de GES par employé pour les opérations propres basées sur le marché ont diminué de 61 % par rapport à 2019.

  • Le tableau présente les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) des investissements propriétaires pour les années 2024 et 2023, réparties selon les catégories et les Scopes 1, 2 et 3. Les émissions du Scope 1, provenant des actifs réels au bilan, ont diminué de 38,4 %, passant de 28,778.8 en 2023 à 17,723.7 en 2024. Les émissions du Scope 2 basées sur la localisation ont augmenté de 23,3 %, passant de 60,179.5 en 2023 à 74,180.8 en 2024, tandis que celles basées sur le marché ont augmenté de 38,7 %, passant de 38,062.9 en 2023 à 52,804.1 en 2024. Les émissions significatives du Scope 3 ont diminué de 15,1 %, passant de 57,359,001.7 en 2023 à 48,717,427 en 2024, principalement en raison de la baisse des émissions liées aux investissements (de 57,268,098.1 en 2023 à 48,626,453.1 en 2024). Les émissions des actifs loués en aval ont légèrement augmenté de 0,1 %, passant de 90,903.6 en 2023 à 90,974.1 en 2024. Les émissions totales des investissements propriétaires basées sur la localisation ont diminué de 15 %, passant de 57,447,960.0 en 2023 à 48,809,331.7 en 2024. De même, les émissions totales des investissements propriétaires basées sur le marché ont diminué de 15 %, passant de 57,425,843.4 en 2023 à 48,787,955.1 en 2024. and

    Catégorie 2024 2023 Variation en %

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour les années 2024 et 2023, réparties selon les Scopes 1, 2 et 3. Les émissions du Scope 1 ont diminué de 38,4 %, tandis que celles du Scope 2 ont augmenté, avec une hausse de 23,3 % pour les émissions basées sur la localisation et de 38,7 % pour celles basées sur le marché. Les émissions significatives du Scope 3 ont diminué de 15,1 %, principalement en raison de la baisse des émissions liées aux investissements. Les émissions totales des investissements propriétaires, qu'elles soient basées sur la localisation ou le marché, ont également diminué de 15 %.

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) sont réparties en trois catégories : Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les émissions Scope 1 ont augmenté de 13,8 % entre 2023 et 2024. - Les émissions Scope 2 basées sur la localisation ont augmenté de 6,0 %, tandis que celles basées sur le marché ont diminué de 25,0 %. - Les données pour les émissions Scope 3 incluent des catégories telles que les biens et services achetés, les activités liées au carburant et à l'énergie, les voyages d'affaires et les déplacements des employés. Cependant, les données de 2023 pour ces catégories ne sont pas disponibles. - Les émissions totales des opérations propres basées sur la localisation ont augmenté de 7,0 %, tandis que celles basées sur le marché ont augmenté de 6,1 %. Lorsque le SAF est inclus, l'augmentation est de 4,5 %.

  • Le tableau présente des données sur l'énergie de Scope 2 pour les années 2024 et 2023. En 2024, 40.5 unités d'énergie de Scope 2 sont couvertes par des instruments contractuels, dont 11.6 unités par des instruments contractuels non groupés et 28.9 unités par des instruments contractuels groupés. Par ailleurs, 59.5 unités d'énergie de Scope 2 ne sont pas liées à des instruments contractuels. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.).

  • ### Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) de différentes portées (Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3) pour Allianz, avec des données pour l'année de base, 2023, 2024, et des objectifs pour les années 2025, 2030 et 2050. Les informations incluent : - **Scope 1** : Les émissions brutes ont diminué de 11 % entre 2023 et 2024. Les émissions liées aux actifs réels ont augmenté de 13,8 %, tandis que celles provenant des systèmes d'échange de quotas d'émission ont diminué de 38,4 %. - **Scope 2 (location-based)** : Les émissions brutes ont augmenté de 12 % entre 2023 et 2024. Les émissions des opérations Allianz ont augmenté de 6 %, et celles des actifs réels ont augmenté de 23,3 %. - **Scope 2 (market-based)** : Les émissions brutes ont augmenté de 27,7 % entre 2023 et 2024. Les émissions des opérations Allianz ont diminué de 25 %, tandis que celles des actifs réels ont augmenté de 38,7 %. ### Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) de différentes portées (Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3) pour Allianz, avec des données pour l'année de base, 2023, 2024, et des objectifs pour les années 2025, 2030 et 2050. Les informations incluent : - **Scope 1** : Les émissions brutes ont diminué de 11 % entre 2023 et 2024. Les émissions liées aux actifs réels ont augmenté de 13,8 %, tandis que celles provenant des systèmes d'échange de quotas d'émission ont diminué de 38,4 %. - **Scope 2 (location-based)** : Les émissions brutes ont augmenté de 12 % entre 2023 et 2024. Les émissions des opérations Allianz ont augmenté de 6 %, et celles des actifs réels ont augmenté de 23,3 %. - **Scope 2 (market-based)** : Les émissions brutes ont augmenté de 27,7 % entre 2023 et 2024. Les émissions des opérations Allianz ont diminué de 25 %, tandis que celles des actifs réels ont augmenté de 38,7 %.
  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau détaille les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les changements réalisés ou attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour les périodes 1.1.2024-31.12.2024 et 1.1.2025-31.12.2029, ainsi que les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les leviers incluent : "Start of period versus baseline", "Renewable energy", "Energy efficiency", "Green mobility" et "Other". - Les actions spécifiques comprennent : "Renewable energy", "Renewable electricity", "Reduction of heating energy consumption", "Reduction of electricity consumption", "Green fleet", "Air travel optimization¹", et diverses autres initiatives. - Les changements réalisés dans les émissions de GES pour la période 2024 incluent une réduction totale de 61.5 ktCO2e par rapport au début de la période. - Les changements attendus pour la période 2025-2029 varient selon les leviers et les portées : Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Par exemple, pour "Renewable electricity", les changements attendus sont de (2.9) à 1.1 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales, 1.1 ktCO2e pour Scope 2, et de (1.9) à 1.0 ktCO2e pour Scope 3. - Pour "Reduction of heating energy consumption", les changements attendus sont de 3.0 à 1.0 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales, et de (1.0) à 1.0 ktCO2e pour Scope 1 et Scope 3. - Les leviers "Green mobility" et "Air travel optimization¹" montrent également des réductions significatives, avec des variations selon les portées. - Les initiatives regroupées sous "Other" incluent des ajustements liés à la consommation d'électricité des centres de données, des véhicules de location, du papier, et du cloud, avec des réductions attendues de (2.1) à 1.9 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales. - À la fin de la période, une réduction totale de 65.0 ktCO2e est attendue par rapport au début de la période, avec des impacts spécifiques sur Scope 1 (5.2 ktCO2e), Scope 2 (40.1 ktCO2e), et Scope 3 (19.6 ktCO2e). and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les changements réalisés ou attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour différentes périodes et portées (Scope 1, Scope 2, Scope 3). - Les leviers incluent l'énergie renouvelable, l'efficacité énergétique, la mobilité verte et d'autres initiatives. - Les changements réalisés dans les émissions de GES pour la période 2024 sont détaillés, avec une réduction totale de 61.5 ktCO2e par rapport au début de la période. - Les changements attendus pour la période 2025-2029 sont estimés pour chaque levier, avec des variations dans les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les actions spécifiques incluent l'utilisation d'électricité renouvelable, la réduction de la consommation d'énergie pour le chauffage et l'électricité, l'optimisation des flottes et des voyages aériens, ainsi que des ajustements liés aux centres de données et autres activités.

  • ### Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau détaille les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) d'Allianz pour les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 (localisation et marché) et Scope 3, avec des données pour l'année de base, 2023, 2024, et des objectifs pour 2025, 2030 et 2050. - **Scope 1** : Les émissions brutes ont diminué de 11 % entre 2023 (60,552.4) et 2024 (53,884.6). Les émissions des actifs réels ont augmenté de 13,8 %, passant de 31,773.7 en 2023 à 36,160.9 en 2024. - **Scope 2 (localisation)** : Les émissions brutes ont augmenté de 12 %, passant de 172,407.3 en 2023 à 193,109.3 en 2024. Les émissions des actifs réels ont augmenté de 23,3 %, atteignant 74,180.8 en 2024 contre 60,179.5 en 2023. - **Scope 2 (marché)** : Les émissions brutes ont augmenté de 27,7 %, passant de 45,992.1 en 2023 à 58,751.2 en 2024. Les émissions des actifs réels ont augmenté de 38,7 %, atteignant 52,804.1 en 2024 contre 38,062.9 en 2023. - **Scope 3** : Les émissions indirectes totales ont diminué de 15 %, passant de 57,455,746.8 en 2023 à 48,820,056.5 en 2024. - Des objectifs d'intensité sont en place pour 2025 et 2030, comme indiqué dans les sections et tableaux associés. - Les pourcentages des émissions Scope 1 provenant des systèmes d'échange de quotas d'émission ont diminué de 38,4 %, passant de 28,778.8 en 2023 à 17,723.7 en 2024. and

  • Methodology – Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions (tCO₂eq) are calculated as the sum of all categories of Scope 3 GHG emissions across our upstream and downstream value chain. Category 1 – Purchased goods and services This consists of paper and public cloud services. Paper use is monitored and reported for internal or external purposes, with the following environmental attributes: − Paper from certified sustainable sources – recycled or virgin fibers, and − Paper from non-certified sources. Methodology − Paper: Data is based on invoice amounts (where available) and estimations from entities. Methodology – Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions (tCO₂eq) are calculated as the sum of all categories of Scope 3 GHG emissions across our upstream and downstream value chain. Category 1 – Purchased goods and services This consists of paper and public cloud services. Paper use is monitored and reported for internal or external purposes, with the following environmental attributes: − Paper from certified sustainable sources – recycled or virgin fibers, and − Paper from non-certified sources. Methodology − Paper: Data is based on invoice amounts (where available) and estimations from entities.

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) pour différentes catégories et années, ainsi que les objectifs de réduction. Les données incluent les émissions basées sur la localisation et le marché, avec ou sans SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel). Les objectifs d'intensité pour 2025, 2030 et 2050 sont mentionnés, alignés sur les cibles de réduction des émissions de GHG d'Allianz.

Les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées grâce à la méthode "location-based", pour 2024 sont de 118,928.5 tonnes de CO₂e, et pour 2023, elles sont de 112,227.8 tonnes de CO₂e.

  • ## Scope 2 GHG Emissions ### Retrospective | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |--------------------------------------------------------------|-------|-------|------------| | Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions | 759.3 | 735.1 | 3.3 | | Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions1 | 38.0 | 51.9 | (26.9) | ## Scope 2 GHG Emissions ### Retrospective | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |--------------------------------------------------------------|-------|-------|------------| | Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions | 759.3 | 735.1 | 3.3 | | Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions1 | 38.0 | 51.9 | (26.9) |
  • ### Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions To fulfill the requirements of the “location-based” method for Scope 2 reporting, we also calculate and publish Scope 2 GHG emissions on the basis of grid-average emission factors (national, based on IEA, preliminary version, or state-level for U.S. assets based on EPA data) applied to Scope 2 energy consumed (which includes electricity from the grid). ### Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions To fulfill the requirements of the “location-based” method for Scope 2 reporting, we also calculate and publish Scope 2 GHG emissions on the basis of grid-average emission factors (national, based on IEA, preliminary version, or state-level for U.S. assets based on EPA data) applied to Scope 2 energy consumed (which includes electricity from the grid).
  • ## Gross Scopes 1, 2, 3, and Total GHG Emissions Metrics, Including Biogenic Emissions (E1-6) ### Scope 1 and 2 GHG Emissions Metrics #### Scope The scope for the Scope 1 and 2 GHG emission metrics is consistent with the scope of the energy metrics. #### Overarching Methodology For our own operations, as well as fully consolidated real estate assets and renewable energy assets, GHG emission calculations are based on input data such as: - Energy consumption data, including meter readings or invoice amounts, - Master (consisting of reporting boundary and buildings, headcount, building floor area, and CO₂e conversion factors) and financial data, - Input data and calculations from previous years. Where no primary energy activity data is available, estimation takes place in most cases to fill data gaps. The respective methods are described in more detail in the KPI descriptions below. ## Gross Scopes 1, 2, 3, and Total GHG Emissions Metrics, Including Biogenic Emissions (E1-6) ### Scope 1 and 2 GHG Emissions Metrics #### Scope The scope for the Scope 1 and 2 GHG emission metrics is consistent with the scope of the energy metrics. #### Overarching Methodology For our own operations, as well as fully consolidated real estate assets and renewable energy assets, GHG emission calculations are based on input data such as: - Energy consumption data, including meter readings or invoice amounts, - Master (consisting of reporting boundary and buildings, headcount, building floor area, and CO₂e conversion factors) and financial data, - Input data and calculations from previous years. Where no primary energy activity data is available, estimation takes place in most cases to fill data gaps. The respective methods are described in more detail in the KPI descriptions below.

  • The table below shows GHG emissions from our proprietary investment portfolio mapped to Scope 1, 2, and 3 according to ESRS requirements. Previously, the emissions from so-called on balance real assets held for proprietary investments, such as real estate and infrastructure, have been accounted for in category 15. These are now shown in Scope 1 and 2, as well as in Scope 3 category 13 for real estate. More details on the methodology, assumptions, and scope of these metrics can be found in the section [Methodology information for climate metrics](#). Previously, the emissions from so-called on balance real assets held for proprietary investments, such as real estate and infrastructure, have been accounted for in category 15. These are now shown in Scope 1 and 2, as well as in Scope 3 category 13 for real estate. More details on the methodology, assumptions, and scope of these metrics can be found in the section [Methodology information for climate metrics](#).
  • ## Additional climate-related metrics for the Allianz Group ### GHG emissions-related metrics The following table presents the Allianz Group GHG emissions broken down into Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected categories from Scope 3. Please note that, as part of the significance analysis performed in 2024, categories 1 and 7 were determined as not significant. For the 2024 disclosure, both categories are still included. Going forward, these will be excluded. Emissions from our fully consolidated real assets have been recategorized from Scope 3 category 15 to Scopes 1, 2 and Scope 3 category 13 as relevant, in line with the ESRS requirements. ## Additional climate-related metrics for the Allianz Group ### GHG emissions-related metrics The following table presents the Allianz Group GHG emissions broken down into Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected categories from Scope 3. Please note that, as part of the significance analysis performed in 2024, categories 1 and 7 were determined as not significant. For the 2024 disclosure, both categories are still included. Going forward, these will be excluded. Emissions from our fully consolidated real assets have been recategorized from Scope 3 category 15 to Scopes 1, 2 and Scope 3 category 13 as relevant, in line with the ESRS requirements.
  • # Total GHG emissions **Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market-based)** The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. **Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market-based)** Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. # Total GHG emissions **Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market-based)** The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. **Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market-based)** Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume.

Les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées selon la méthode "location-based", s'élèvent à 74,180.8 tonnes de CO₂e pour l'année 2024.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions To fulfil the requirements of the "location-based" method for Scope 2 reporting, we also calculate and publish Scope 2 GHG emissions on the basis of grid-average emission factors (national, based on IEA, preliminary version, or state-level for U.S. assets based on EPA data) applied to Scope 2 energy consumed (which includes electricity from the grid).
  • ### Methodology - Total GHG emissions (location- and market- based) The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO2eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO2eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3.
  • ### Methodology - Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions (tCO2eq) are calculated as the sum of all categories of Scope 3 GHG emissions across our upstream and downstream value chain.
  • The table below shows GHG emissions from our proprietary investment portfolio mapped to Scope 1, 2, and 3 according to ESRS requirements. Previously, the emissions from so-called on balance real assets held for proprietary investments, such as real estate and infrastructure, have been accounted for in category 15. These are now shown in Scope 1 and 2, as well as in Scope 3 category 13 for real estate. More details on the methodology, assumptions, and scope of these metrics can be found in the section Methodology information for climate metrics. Proprietary investments GHG emissions (Scope 1-3) - TOTAL t in CO2e
  • ### Introduction Scope 2 GHG emissions come from the consumption of purchased electricity, heat, or steam: - Electricity - Office buildings, real estate, and renewables assets, and data centers. - District heating and cooling - Office buildings, real estate, and renewables assets. In line with external requirements by the Greenhouse Gas Protocol for accounting for Scope 2 emissions, we use the dual reporting approach to calculate Scope 2 emissions.
  • ### Methodology - Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions are calculated in line with our existing carbon accounting approach; emission calculations are performed taking into account the contractual instruments (e.g., Energy Attribute Certificates, green tariffs). For our own operations, there are no Scope 2 market-based emissions associated with electricity consumption, because 100% of electricity used in our offices is covered by contractual instruments. The electricity mix for Allianz's renewable energy assets as well as the directly held real estate portfolio of Allianz Switzerland, by contrast, is not readily available, and as such, a conservative approach is taken by assuming market- based Scope 2 GHG emissions are the same as the location-based emissions.
  • - Issuer emissions: Total Scope 1 (direct) and Scope 2 (indirect) emissions of the company as per the GHG Protocol. For Scope 3 emissions we have included an estimate range for the magnitude of the Scope 3 of Scope 3 emissions. We will continue to monitor developments in this area, and develop our disclosures as more robust Scope 3 emissions disclosures become available. For listed equity investments, bonds from and loans to listed and not-listed privately owned corporates as well as corporates owned by sovereigns, sub-sovereigns, and municipals, when no emissions data are available, the issuer (i.e. corporates and corporate-like issuers) is assigned to a NACE sector, and sector average emissions based on the Allianz Group portfolio are calculated by dividing the sum of emissions by the sum of EVIC for companies in the same sector. The sector average is then used to estimate a company's emissions. Investors rely on investees disclosing carbon footprint information, which then needs to
  • ### Scope The scope for the Scope 1 and 2 GHG emission metrics is consistent with the scope of the energy metrics.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos sobre la intensidad de gases de efecto invernadero (GHG) y el volumen total de negocios de Allianz Group al 31 de diciembre de 2024 y 2023. - **Etiquetas de columnas**: "0", "1", "2", "3". - **Etiquetas de filas**: "As of 31 December", "Total business volume1", "Total GHG emissions (market-based)2", "GHG intensity (market-based)", "Total GHG emissions (location-based)2", "GHG intensity (location-based)". - **Años**: 2024 y 2023. **Datos clave**: 1. El volumen total de negocios ("Total business volume1") fue de **179,777.8 mn €** en 2024 y **161,700.0 mn €** en 2023. 2. Las emisiones totales de GHG basadas en el mercado ("Total GHG emissions (market-based)2") fueron de **48,932,692.3 t en CO2e** en 2024 y **57,562,291.4 t en CO2e** en 2023. 3. La intensidad de GHG basada en el mercado ("GHG intensity (market-based)") fue de **272.2 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2024 y **356.0 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2023. 4. Las emisiones totales de GHG basadas en la ubicación ("Total GHG emissions (location-based)2") fueron de **49,067,050.4 t en CO2e** en 2024 y **57,688,706.5 t en CO2e** en 2023. 5. La intensidad de GHG basada en la ubicación ("GHG intensity (location-based)") fue de **272.9 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2024 y **356.8 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2023. ### END TABLE
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre "Economic activities" y su alineación con la taxonomía en términos de "Turnover" para el año 2024. Las columnas incluyen "Amount and proportion (the information is to be presented in monetary amounts and as percentages)", desglosadas en "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila 1, las actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía según la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 2. En la fila 2, las actividades según la Sección 4.27 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 3. En la fila 3, las actividades según la Sección 4.28 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.4 (2.4% para CCM). 4. En la fila 4, las actividades según la Sección 4.29 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 5. En la fila 5, las actividades según la Sección 4.30 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.3 (0.3% para CCM). 6. En la fila 6, las actividades según la Sección 4.31 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 7. En la fila 7, otras actividades alineadas con la taxonomía no incluidas en las filas 1 a 6 reportan un "Turnover" de 15.5 (97.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA). 8. En la fila 8, el total de actividades alineadas con la taxonomía reporta un "Turnover" de 16.0 (100.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA).
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre "Economic activities" y su alineación con la taxonomía en el denominador del KPI aplicable para el año 2024. Las columnas incluyen "Turnover" con "Amount and proportion" expresados en montos monetarios y porcentajes, desglosados en "Climate change mitigation (CCM)" y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)". Las filas enumeran actividades económicas específicas referidas en las Secciones 4.26 a 4.31 de los Anexos I y II del Reglamento Delegado 2021/2139, así como otras actividades no incluidas en dichas secciones. 1. Las filas 1, 2, 4, 5 y 6 no tienen datos reportados, mostrando "-" en todas las columnas. 2. En la fila 3, la actividad económica de la Sección 4.28 reporta un monto de 0.4 y un porcentaje de 0.1% tanto para CCM como para el total, sin datos para CCA. 3. La fila 7, que incluye otras actividades no referidas en las filas anteriores, reporta un monto de 15.5 y un porcentaje de 2.1% para CCM, 15.4 y 2.0% para el total, y 0.1 sin porcentaje para CCA. 4. La fila 8, que resume el "Total applicable KPI", muestra un monto de 16.0 y un porcentaje de 2.1% para CCM, 15.9 y 2.1% para el total, y 0.1 sin porcentaje para CCA.

Les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées grâce à la méthode "location-based", sont de 49,067,050.4 tonnes de CO2e pour l'année 2024 et de 57,688,706.5 tonnes de CO2e pour l'année 2023.

  • 31 December 2024. Of that, 230.9 kg CO 2e results from Scope 1; 38.0 kg CO 2e from Scope 2; and 655.3 kg CO 2e from Scope 3. Scope 3 emissions include categories 1, 3, 6, and 7, covering fuel and energy - related emissions, business travel, remote working, public cloud, and paper use. Disclosure of significant categories of Scope 3 emissions may be adjusted from 2025 onwards based on the result s of the significance analysis. The current results of the Scope 3 significance analysis can be found in the table GHG Scope 3 inventory . Scop e 3 GHG financed emissions which fall under category 15 are covered under Proprietary Investment s and are therefore not within the scope of own operations. Total own operations GHG emissions per employee have slightly increased compared to 2023. This has been driven by increased business travel activities compared to previous years, as well as external effects (e.g. increased Scope 3 energy emission factors). 31 December 2024. Of that, 230.9 kg CO 2e results from Scope 1; 38.0 kg CO 2e from Scope 2; and 655.3 kg CO 2e from Scope 3. Scope 3 emissions include categories 1, 3, 6, and 7, covering fuel and energy - related emissions, business travel, remote working, public cloud, and paper use. Disclosure of significant categories of Scope 3 emissions may be adjusted from 2025 onwards based on the result s of the significance analysis. The current results of the Scope 3 significance analysis can be found in the table GHG Scope 3 inventory . Scop e 3 GHG financed emissions which fall under category 15 are covered under Proprietary Investment s and are therefore not within the scope of own operations. Total own operations GHG emissions per employee have slightly increased compared to 2023. This has been driven by increased business travel activities compared to previous years, as well as external effects (e.g. increased Scope 3 energy emission factors).

  • Scope Scope 3 GHG emissions consist of indirect emissions that occur in our company’s upstream and downstream value chain, and most significantly of the companies we insure and invest in, in line with the GHG Protocol. Methodology – Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions (tCO₂eq) are calculated as the sum of all categories of Scope 3 GHG emissions across our upstream and downstream value chain. Category 1 – Purchased goods and services This consists of paper and public cloud services. Paper use is monitored and reported for internal or external purposes, with the following environmental attributes: − Paper from certified sustainable sources – recycled or virgin fibers , and − Paper from non -certified sources. Methodology − Paper: Data is based on invoice amounts (where available) and estimations from entities. Scope Scope 3 GHG emissions consist of indirect emissions that occur in our company’s upstream and downstream value chain, and most significantly of the companies we insure and invest in, in line with the GHG Protocol. Methodology – Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions Total gross indirect Scope 3 GHG emissions (tCO₂eq) are calculated as the sum of all categories of Scope 3 GHG emissions across our upstream and downstream value chain. Category 1 – Purchased goods and services This consists of paper and public cloud services. Paper use is monitored and reported for internal or external purposes, with the following environmental attributes: − Paper from certified sustainable sources – recycled or virgin fibers , and − Paper from non -certified sources. Methodology − Paper: Data is based on invoice amounts (where available) and estimations from entities.
  • investments and own operations. The relatively low primary data quota is mainly attributed to emissions financed through sovereign debt. We have chosen to incorporate more recent data in calculations, and therefore use the PRIMAP database which includes data up to 2023, instead of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change ( UNFCCC ) database, which has data up to 2021. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC data base. The relatively low primary data quota is mainly attributed to emissions financed through sovereign debt. We have chosen to incorporate more recent data in calculations, and therefore use the PRIMAP database which includes data up to 2023, instead of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change ( UNFCCC ) database, which has data up to 2021. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC data base.   • Gross Scope 2 market -based + Gross Scope 3. − Total GHG emissions location -based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location -based + Gross Scope 3. Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market - based) Overa ll GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. The calculation is repeated twice, once using the market -based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group , and once using the location -based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group . The total absolute emissions used for these calculations do not include IAE or SAF. For both of the calculations, the total business volumes figure used is the same. Methodology – Percentage of Scope 3 GHG emissions calculated using primary data (%) For Scope 3 GHG emissions, we disclose the percentage of emissions Gross Scope 2 market -based + Gross Scope 3. − Total GHG emissions location -based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location -based + Gross Scope 3. The total absolute emissions used for these calculations do not include IAE or SAF. For both of the calculations, the total business volumes figure used is the same. The Allianz Group discloses GHG intensity with the following considerations for the numerator and denominator: − Net revenue: The Allianz Group does not report a net revenue figure so total business volume is used instead. − Total GHG emissions : The majority of emissions for an insurance company are concentrated in Scope 3, Category 15. We are constrained by the current development of methodologies and the availability of data. Consequently, we are not yet able to comprehensively cover emissions from all business activities contributing to the total business volume. 272.2 356.0 Total GHG emissions (location -based)2 t in CO 2e 49,067,050.4 57,6 88,706.5 GHG intensity (location -based) t in CO 2e/€ mn 272.9 356.8 1_As per the table "Business segment information – total business volume and reconciliation of operating profit (loss) to net income (loss) in the notes to the consolidated financia l statements." 2_Excluding insurance -associated emissions. We are constrained by the current development of methodologies and the availability of data. Consequently, we are not yet able to comprehensively cover emissions from all business activities contributing to the total business volume.

  • (IEA). For distance travelled, averages are based on national statistics or global sources like OECD -ITF and the International Council on Clean Transportation (ICCT). These averages result in varying data quality scores depending on granularity. For example, country -level data by vehicle type achieves a Score 2, while global averages lead to a Score 4. C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement Annual Report 2024 − Allianz Group 165 Methodology Information and Additional Tables Total GHG emissions Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market - based) The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group . This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market -based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location -based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. − Total GHG emissions market -based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market -based + Gross Scope 3. (IEA). For distance travelled, averages are based on national statistics or global sources like OECD -ITF and the International Council on Clean Transportation (ICCT). These averages result in varying data quality scores depending on granularity. For example, country -level data by vehicle type achieves a Score 2, while global averages lead to a Score 4. Emissions from our fully consolidated real assets have been recategorized from Scope 3 category 15 to Scopes 1, 2 and Scope 3 category 13 as relevant , in line with the ESRS requirements .
