  • ## Total Own Operations GHG Emissions per Employee (Location-based) | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |--------------------------------------|--------|--------|------------| | Total own operations GHG emissions | 1,645.4 | 1,577.0 | 4.3 | ## Total Own Operations GHG Emissions per Employee (Location-based) | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |--------------------------------------|--------|--------|------------| | Total own operations GHG emissions | 1,645.4 | 1,577.0 | 4.3 |
  • # Total GHG emissions **Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market-based)** The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. **Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market-based)** Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. # Total GHG emissions **Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market-based)** The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. **Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market-based)** Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume.
  • ## Total Own Operations GHG Emissions per Employee (Market-based) (SAF5 Included) | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |----------------------------------------------------|--------|-------|------------| | Total own operations GHG emissions (market-based) | 910.8 | 893.8 | 1.9 | ## Total Own Operations GHG Emissions per Employee (Market-based) (SAF5 Included) | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |----------------------------------------------------|--------|-------|------------| | Total own operations GHG emissions (market-based) | 910.8 | 893.8 | 1.9 |
  • ## Scope 1 GHG Emissions ### Retrospective | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |----------------------|-------|-------|------------| | Gross Scope 1 GHG emissions | 230.9 | 208.1 | 10.9 | ## Scope 1 GHG Emissions ### Retrospective | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |----------------------|-------|-------|------------| | Gross Scope 1 GHG emissions | 230.9 | 208.1 | 10.9 |
  • At the Allianz Group, we conduct due diligence and screening of our business transactions to identify adverse water and marine resource-related impacts, and risk management activities to monitor and mitigate the associated risks. These are outlined in the section [Sustainability integration](#). We will continue to develop our actions to better identify, manage, and mitigate negative impacts and risks associated with water and marine resource use.
    104 --- --- At the Allianz Group, we conduct due diligence and screening of our business transactions to identify adverse water and marine resource-related impacts, and risk management activities to monitor and mitigate the associated risks. These are outlined in the section [Sustainability integration](#). We will continue to develop our actions to better identify, manage, and mitigate negative impacts and risks associated with water and marine resource use.
    104 --- ---
  • ### Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI - **The percentage of derivatives relative to total assets covered by the KPI:** 3.0 - Value in monetary amounts of derivatives: 22.7 - **The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings not subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI:** - For non-financial undertakings : 29.2 - Monetary amount: 220.4 - For financial undertakings : 16.7 - Monetary amount: 126.3 - **The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings from non-EU countries not subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI:** - For non-financial undertakings : 22.8 - Monetary amount: 171.8 - For financial undertakings : 10.2 - Monetary amount: 76.9 ### Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI - **The percentage of derivatives relative to total assets covered by the KPI:** 3.0 - Value in monetary amounts of derivatives: 22.7 - **The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings not subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI:** - For non-financial undertakings : 29.2 - Monetary amount: 220.4 - For financial undertakings : 16.7 - Monetary amount: 126.3 - **The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings from non-EU countries not subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI:** - For non-financial undertakings : 22.8 - Monetary amount: 171.8 - For financial undertakings : 10.2 - Monetary amount: 76.9

  • ### END TABLE The table above shows the additionally divested equity related to the energy guidelines in 2024. As fixed-income investments of restricted companies are put into run-off, we show here for the first time the total outstanding amount in run-off. The 1 January 2025, milestone for the Group Oil and Gas restriction was largely anticipated already by the end of 2024, leading to a significant increase in the divestment of equities and the run-off of fixed-income assets related to oil and gas during 2024. ### END TABLE The table above shows the additionally divested equity related to the energy guidelines in 2024. As fixed-income investments of restricted companies are put into run-off, we show here for the first time the total outstanding amount in run-off. The 1 January 2025, milestone for the Group Oil and Gas restriction was largely anticipated already by the end of 2024, leading to a significant increase in the divestment of equities and the run-off of fixed-income assets related to oil and gas during 2024.

Je vais vous fournir un tableau présentant l'intensité des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour les années 2024 et 2023. L'intensité des émissions est calculée en divisant les émissions totales par le chiffre d'affaires, exprimée en tCO2e/€m.

Année Chiffre d'affaires total (mn €) Émissions totales (tCO2e) Intensité des émissions (tCO2e/€m)
2024 179,777.8 48,932,692.3 272.2
2023 161,700.0 57,562,291.4 356.0

Les données utilisées pour ce calcul proviennent des informations fournies dans les contextes. Le chiffre d'affaires total utilisé pour calculer l'intensité en GES est de 179,777.8 mn € pour 2024 et de 161,700.0 mn € pour 2023.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • Assuming a static portfolio in terms of 2024 business volume, our intensity target of 0.14 kt CO2e/mn € insurance premium would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 0.63 mn t CO2e for 2030. This figure is an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio. As our portfolio grows in business volume and data coverage increases, enabling us to report on more of the portfolio, we expect the associated absolute GHG emissions to grow as well.
  • ### Methodology - GHG emissions intensity (location- and market- based) Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. The calculation is repeated twice, once using the market-based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group, and once using the location-based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group. The total absolute emissions used for these calculations do not include IAE or SAF. For both of the calculations, the total business volumes figure used is the same.
  • ### END TABLE 1_As per the table "Business segment information - total business volume and reconciliation of operating profit (loss) to net income (loss) in the notes to the consolidated financial statements." 2_Excluding insurance-associated emissions. The Allianz Group discloses GHG intensity with the following considerations for the numerator and denominator: - Net revenue: The Allianz Group does not report a net revenue figure so total business volume is used instead. - Total GHG emissions: The majority of emissions for an insurance company are concentrated in Scope 3, Category 15. We are constrained by the current development of methodologies and the availability of data. Consequently, we are not yet able to comprehensively cover emissions from all business activities contributing to the total business volume.
  • Assuming a static headcount, our 2030 target would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 129.7 kt CO2e (2030 intensity target * estimated headcount). These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year; the current headcount was used as an estimate because we expect that new hires and leavers will broadly offset each other and therefore any net impact is not expected to be material.
  • ### END TABLE For the portfolio in scope of the emission reduction target for commercial insurance, the 2024 insurance associated emissions were 1.02 mn t CO2e1 and the insurance-associated emission intensity was 0.23 kt CO2e/€ mn Insurance Premium2. The IAE for a commercial insurance policy is equal to the GHG emissions (Scope 1 and 2) from the policyholder multiplied by the attribution factor provided by PCAF (insurance premium of the policy divided by the revenue of the customer). Additionally, specific assumptions for policies covering risks of assets linked to Renewables and Low-Carbon technologies are taken to discount the IAE linked to these policies. For commercial insurance, an emission intensity reduction has been achieved in 2024 compared to the baseline, decreasing from 0.26 kt CO2e/mn € Insurance Premium in 2022 to 0.23 ktvCO2e/mn € in 2024. This marks an 11.7% reduction from the 2022 baseline and a 6.4% increase compared to 2023.
  • Assuming a static portfolio and emission data coverage of non- listed investees increasing to reach 80 % by 2030, our intensity target for listed and non-listed corporates would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 19.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. For our real estate portfolio, our intensity target would correspond to associated absolute emissions of 0.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio. Analysis on the contribution of the different decarbonization levers for the Corporates and directly held Real Estate portfolios can be found in the respective tables below. Our progress toward target achievement will be monitored regularly and reported in the Sustainability Statement.
  • ### Proprietary investments GHG emissions - split per asset class (as of 31 December 2024 and 2023) The table compares GHG emissions metrics for proprietary investments across asset classes for the years 2024 and 2023. It includes the following labels: "Book value (€ bn)", "Absolute financed emissions (mn t CO2e)", "Carbon Intensity (t CO2e/€ mn invested)", and "Coverage (%)". The asset classes listed are "Corporates", "Public debt", "Real estate1,2", and "No methodology yet", with a "Total4" row summarizing all categories. - For "Corporates", the book value decreased from € 369.6 bn (2024) to € 294.2 bn (2023), while absolute financed emissions increased from 18.1 mn t CO2e to 20.1 mn t CO2e. Carbon intensity rose from 57.9 to 71.2, and coverage improved from 79.5% to 90.6%. - For "Public debt", the book value slightly decreased from € 165.2 bn (2024) to € 166.6 bn (2023). Absolute financed emissions increased from 29.8 mn t CO2e to 36.7 mn t CO2e, and carbon intensity rose from 163.8 to 205.0, with coverage remaining constant at 99.5%. - For "Real estate1,2", the book value decreased from € 125.4 bn (2024) to € 110.6 bn (2023). Absolute financed emissions dropped from 0.7 mn t CO2e to 0.3 mn t CO2e, while carbon intensity slightly decreased from 33.1 to 31.6. Coverage fell from 20.3% to 11.3%. - The "No methodology yet" category shows a book value increase from € 106.8 bn (2024) to € 165.4 bn (2023), with no emissions or intensity data provided. - The "Total4" row indicates a decrease in book value from € 767.0 bn (2024) to € 736.8 bn (2023). Absolute financed emissions rose from 48.6 mn t CO2e to 57.2 mn t CO2e, carbon intensity increased from 94.2 to 117.5, and coverage decreased from 64.3% to 60.4%.
  • Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emissions per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos sobre la intensidad de gases de efecto invernadero (GHG) y el volumen total de negocios de Allianz Group al 31 de diciembre de 2024 y 2023. - **Etiquetas de columnas**: "0", "1", "2", "3". - **Etiquetas de filas**: "As of 31 December", "Total business volume1", "Total GHG emissions (market-based)2", "GHG intensity (market-based)", "Total GHG emissions (location-based)2", "GHG intensity (location-based)". - **Años**: 2024 y 2023. **Datos clave**: 1. El volumen total de negocios ("Total business volume1") fue de **179,777.8 mn €** en 2024 y **161,700.0 mn €** en 2023. 2. La intensidad de GHG basada en el mercado ("GHG intensity (market-based)") fue de **272.2 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2024 y **356.0 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2023. 4. Las filas principales son: 1. **"Purchased goods and services"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 8,993.5, con objetivos de intensidad establecidos. 2. **"Fuel and energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or Scope 2)"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 30,305.1, con objetivos de intensidad establecidos. 3. **"Business traveling"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 55,873.8 y en 2023, 96,745.1. 4. **"Employee commuting"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 7,456.9, considerando solo trabajo remoto. 5. **"Downstream leased assets"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 90,974.1 y en 2023, 90,903.6, con un cambio del 0.1%. 6. **"Investments - Proprietary Investments"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 48,626,453.1 y en 2023, 57,268,098.1, con un cambio de (15.1)%. Se mencionan objetivos de reducción de emisiones para 2030 y 2050, con detalles adicionales en secciones específicas del informe.

  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos relacionados con los KPI de Taxonomía para las inversiones del Grupo Allianz en el año 2024. Los encabezados incluyen "Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI" y "Monetary amounts (€ bn)". Los porcentajes y proporciones se desglosan de la siguiente manera: 1. El porcentaje de derivados respecto al total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 3.0%. 2. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas financieras y no financieras no sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU sobre el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 29.2% para empresas no financieras y del 16.7% para empresas financieras. 3. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas financieras y no financieras de países fuera de la UE no sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU es del 22.8% para empresas no financieras y del 10.2% para empresas financieras. 4. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU es del 9.9% para empresas no financieras y del 28.5% para empresas financieras. 5. La proporción de exposiciones a otros contrapartes y activos sobre el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 12.6%. 6. La proporción de inversiones distintas de las mantenidas en contratos de seguros de vida donde el riesgo de inversión es asumido por los asegurados es del 81.4%. 7. El valor de las inversiones que financian actividades económicas no elegibles según la Taxonomía, en relación con el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI, es del 31.1% para el "Turnover" y del 30.5% para el "CAPEX". 8. El valor de las inversiones que financian actividades económicas elegibles según la Taxonomía, pero no alineadas, es del 17.8% para el "Turnover" y del 18.3% para el "CAPEX".

Je ne peux pas calculer l'intensité des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) du groupe Allianz pour l'année 2024 en utilisant le chiffre d'affaires, car le chiffre d'affaires n'est pas directement mentionné dans les contextes fournis. Cependant, on peut utiliser le volume total de l'activité comme un substitut pour le calcul de l'intensité en GES, car il est utilisé dans le contexte.

Voici les données disponibles pour l'intensité des émissions de GES, en utilisant le volume total de l'activité comme dénominateur pour les années 2024 et 2023 :

Année Volume total d'affaires (€ mn) Émissions totales de GES (market-based, tCO2e) Intensité des émissions de GES (tCO2e/€ mn)
2024 179,777.8 48,932,692.3 272.2
2023 161,700.0 57,562,291.4 356.0

Les données ci-dessus montrent que l'intensité des émissions de GES market-based a diminué de 2023 à 2024. Si vous avez besoin d'informations supplémentaires ou si vous avez une autre question, n'hésitez pas à demander !


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • investments and own operations. The relatively low primary data quota is mainly attributed to emissions financed through sovereign debt. We have chosen to incorporate more recent data in calculations, and therefore use the PRIMAP database which includes data up to 2023, instead of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change ( UNFCCC ) database, which has data up to 2021. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC data base. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC data base.   • Total 767.0 48.6 94.2 64.3 736.8 57.2 117.5 60.4 1_The emissions of these assets are not shown in this table under Scope 3 Cat 15 but in the table "Proprietary investme nts GHG emissions (Scope 1 -3) - TOTAL." These assets are also excluded from the calculation of coverage. 2023 figures are restated accordingly. 2_In 2024, the carbon intensity methodology was revised to align with the latest PCAF guidance. Previously, the methodology adhered to the calculation approach outlined in the SFDR RTS, published on 6 April 2022, where carbon intensity was determined by di viding absolute financed emissions by the total value of all investments. The updated methodology now calculates carbon intensity by dividing absolute financed emissio ns by the value of only those investments for which financed emissions are calculated. As a result, carbon intensities have increased significantly in asset classes with low emission data coverage. Targets related to climate change mitigation for Total 767.0 48.6 94.2 64.3 736.8 57.2 117.5 60.4 1_The emissions of these assets are not shown in this table under Scope 3 Cat 15 but in the table "Proprietary investme nts GHG emissions (Scope 1 -3) - TOTAL." These assets are also excluded from the calculation of coverage. 2023 figures are restated accordingly. 2_In 2024, the carbon intensity methodology was revised to align with the latest PCAF guidance. Previously, the methodology adhered to the calculation approach outlined in the SFDR RTS, published on 6 April 2022, where carbon intensity was determined by di viding absolute financed emissions by the total value of all investments. The updated methodology now calculates carbon intensity by dividing absolute financed emissio ns by the value of only those investments for which financed emissions are calculated. As a result, carbon intensities have increased significantly in asset classes with low emission data coverage. Targets related to climate change mitigation for
  • intensity target of 0.14 kt CO 2e/mn € insurance premium would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 0.63 mn t CO 2e for 2030. This figure is an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to ou r dynamic portfolio. As our portfolio grows in business volume and data coverage increases, enabling us to report on more of the portfolio, we expect the associated absolute GHG emissions to grow as well. 2_Insurance Premium is equal to Insurance Revenue minus external acquisition costs . While the decision to define an intensity target allows us to reflect the expected growth of our portfolio by 2030 in a dynamic way, we have ensured that our targeted reduction is still within the scenario range to limit global warming to 1.5 °C. Specifically, we have aimed to set an emission reduction target in the ranges of the IPCC net -zero scenarios by 2030. Specifically, we have aimed to set an emission reduction target in the ranges of the IPCC net -zero scenarios by 2030. We also considered a growth in premium to

  • total value of all investments. The updated methodology now calculates carbon intensity by dividing absolute financed emissio ns by the value of only those investments for which financed emissions are calculated. As a result, carbon intensities have increas ed significantly in asset classes with low emission data coverage. 4_Total 2024 coverage excluding "no methodology yet" would correspond to 75.1 % . 1_Switch from UNFCCC (last inventory year 2021) to PRIMAP database (last inventory year 2023) for emissions data. For Annex 1 countries, 2021 data were used for 2023 reporting, and 2023 data for 2024 reporting, reflecting a two -year change .   • 31 December 2024. Of that, 230.9 kg CO 2e results from Scope 1; 38.0 kg CO 2e from Scope 2; and 655.3 kg CO 2e from Scope 3. Scope 3 emissions include categories 1, 3, 6, and 7, covering fuel and energy - related emissions, business travel, remote working, public cloud, and paper use. Disclosure of significant categories of Scope 3 emissions may be adjusted from 2025 onwards based on the result s of the significance analysis. The current results of the Scope 3 significance analysis can be found in the table GHG Scope 3 inventory . Scop e 3 GHG financed emissions which fall under category 15 are covered under Proprietary Investment s and are therefore not within the scope of own operations. Total own operations GHG emissions per employee have slightly increased compared to 2023. This has been driven by increased business travel activities compared to previous years, as well as external effects (e.g. increased Scope 3 energy emission factors). 31 December 2024. Of that, 230.9 kg CO 2e results from Scope 1; 38.0 kg CO 2e from Scope 2; and 655.3 kg CO 2e from Scope 3. Scope 3 emissions include categories 1, 3, 6, and 7, covering fuel and energy - related emissions, business travel, remote working, public cloud, and paper use. Disclosure of significant categories of Scope 3 emissions may be adjusted from 2025 onwards based on the result s of the significance analysis. The current results of the Scope 3 significance analysis can be found in the table GHG Scope 3 inventory . Scop e 3 GHG financed emissions which fall under category 15 are covered under Proprietary Investment s and are therefore not within the scope of own operations. Total own operations GHG emissions per employee have slightly increased compared to 2023. This has been driven by increased business travel activities compared to previous years, as well as external effects (e.g. increased Scope 3 energy emission factors).

  • NatCat scenarios and global hazard maps. However, effecti ve adaptation to climate change not only requires adequate pricing of risks, but also individual measures by customers. We have therefore started considering preventative actions taken by the customer in our products and pricing models. Living up to our ro le as a climate risk manager, we are also integrating advisory services into our customer communication and we provide relevant information to customers, for example, on how to build stronger resilience to climate- related events. In addition, we are committed to offering comprehensive insurance products for low -carbon technologies – such as battery electric vehicles (BEV) and the related ecosystem – as well as for renewable energy technologies, to support the transition of our cust omers toward more environment -friendly solutions. For instance, Allianz entities offer BEV insurance products, which meet the specific NatCat scenarios and global hazard maps.   • Multinational Enterprises and the U.N. Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGP). Our due diligence in own operations and supply chains complies with the legal obligations of the German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (GSCA) and is covered by the Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement . Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report. At Allianz , sustainability is viewed as a journey across a dynamic and constantly evolving landscape. As such, we embrace the role of a learning organization. We acknowledge the ongoing enhancements of our impact, risk, and opportunity assessments as the maturity and availability of data, external credib le sources, and independent Multinational Enterprises and the U.N. We acknowledge the ongoing enhancements of our impact, risk, and opportunity assessments as the maturity and availability of data, external credib le sources, and independent
  • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. E1-133 partie 1

GHG Intensity location-based per net revenue (total GHG emissions per net revenue).

Je souhaite avoir la réponse en français.

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur l'intensité des GES basée sur la localisation par rapport au chiffre d'affaires net (total des émissions de GES par chiffre d'affaires net).


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • The relatively low primary data quota is mainly attributed to emissions financed through sovereign debt. We have chosen to incorporate more recent data in calculations, and therefore use the PRIMAP database which includes data up to 2023, instead of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) database, which has data up to 2021. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC database. GHG emissions intensity The table below presents the GHG intensity using both the location- based and market-based approaches: GHG intensity The relatively low primary data quota is mainly attributed to emissions financed through sovereign debt. We have chosen to incorporate more recent data in calculations, and therefore use the PRIMAP database which includes data up to 2023, instead of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) database, which has data up to 2021. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC database. GHG emissions intensity The table below presents the GHG intensity using both the location- based and market-based approaches: GHG intensity
  • Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emissions per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium. Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emissions per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium.

  • Assuming a static portfolio and emission data coverage of non- listed investees increasing to reach 80 % by 2030, our intensity target for listed and non-listed corporates would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 19.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. For our real estate portfolio, our intensity target would correspond to associated absolute emissions of 0.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio.   • Assuming a static headcount, our 2030 target would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 129.7 kt CO2e (2030 intensity target * estimated headcount). These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year; the current headcount was used as an estimate because we expect that new hires and leavers will broadly offset each other and therefore any net impact is not expected to be material. Assuming a static headcount, our 2030 target would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 129.7 kt CO2e (2030 intensity target * estimated headcount). These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year; the current headcount was used as an estimate because we expect that new hires and leavers will broadly offset each other and therefore any net impact is not expected to be material.
  • Assuming a static portfolio in terms of 2024 business volume, our intensity target of 0.14 kt CO2e/mn € insurance premium would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 0.63 mn t CO2e for 2030. This figure is an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio. As our portfolio grows in business volume and data coverage increases, enabling us to report on more of the portfolio, we expect the associated absolute GHG emissions to grow as well. Assuming a static portfolio in terms of 2024 business volume, our intensity target of 0.14 kt CO2e/mn € insurance premium would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 0.63 mn t CO2e for 2030. This figure is an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio. As our portfolio grows in business volume and data coverage increases, enabling us to report on more of the portfolio, we expect the associated absolute GHG emissions to grow as well.
  • Forum’s Clean Skies for Tomorrow guidance. We anticipate guidance on accounting of SAF to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Our targets are defined considering market-based Scope 2 emissions as well as SAF. For more information on the methodology used to calculate Allianz Own Operations GHG emissions, please refer to the section Methodology information for climate metrics. The total GHG emissions per employee arising from Allianz Own Operations were 924.1 kg CO2e for the twelve months ended 31 December 2024. Of that, 230.9 kg CO2e results from Scope 1; 38.0 kg CO2e from Scope 2; and 655.3 kg CO2e from Scope 3. Scope 3 Forum’s Clean Skies for Tomorrow guidance.   • ### END TABLE The Allianz Group discloses GHG considerations for the numerator and denominator: intensity with the following − Net revenue: The Allianz Group does not report a net revenue figure so total business volume is used instead. − Total GHG emissions: The majority of emissions for an insurance company are concentrated in Scope 3, Category 15. We are constrained by the current development of methodologies and the availability of data. Consequently, we are not yet able to comprehensively cover emissions from all business activities contributing to the total business volume. ### END TABLE The Allianz Group discloses GHG considerations for the numerator and denominator: intensity with the following − Net revenue: The Allianz Group does not report a net revenue figure so total business volume is used instead. − Total GHG emissions: The majority of emissions for an insurance company are concentrated in Scope 3, Category 15. We are constrained by the current development of methodologies and the availability of data. Consequently, we are not yet able to comprehensively cover emissions from all business activities contributing to the total business volume.
  • C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement Total GHG emissions Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market- based) The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. − Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. − Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market- based) Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement Total GHG emissions Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market- based) The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. − Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. − Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market- based) Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume.

Je ne dispose pas des informations nécessaires pour calculer l'intensité des émissions de GES basée sur l'emplacement par rapport au revenu net, car le Groupe Allianz utilise le volume total d'affaires au lieu du revenu net pour ces calculs. Par conséquent, je ne peux pas fournir une réponse précise à cette question.

  • # Total GHG emissions **Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market-based)** The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. **Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market-based)** Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. # Total GHG emissions **Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market-based)** The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. **Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market-based)** Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume.
  • ## Scope 2 GHG Emissions ### Retrospective | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |--------------------------------------------------------------|-------|-------|------------| | Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions | 759.3 | 735.1 | 3.3 | | Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions1 | 38.0 | 51.9 | (26.9) | ## Scope 2 GHG Emissions ### Retrospective | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |--------------------------------------------------------------|-------|-------|------------| | Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions | 759.3 | 735.1 | 3.3 | | Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions1 | 38.0 | 51.9 | (26.9) |
  • ### Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions To fulfill the requirements of the “location-based” method for Scope 2 reporting, we also calculate and publish Scope 2 GHG emissions on the basis of grid-average emission factors (national, based on IEA, preliminary version, or state-level for U.S. assets based on EPA data) applied to Scope 2 energy consumed (which includes electricity from the grid). ### Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions To fulfill the requirements of the “location-based” method for Scope 2 reporting, we also calculate and publish Scope 2 GHG emissions on the basis of grid-average emission factors (national, based on IEA, preliminary version, or state-level for U.S. assets based on EPA data) applied to Scope 2 energy consumed (which includes electricity from the grid).
  • ## Total Own Operations GHG Emissions per Employee (Location-based) | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |--------------------------------------|--------|--------|------------| | Total own operations GHG emissions | 1,645.4 | 1,577.0 | 4.3 | ## Total Own Operations GHG Emissions per Employee (Location-based) | | 2024 | 2023 | Delta in % | |--------------------------------------|--------|--------|------------| | Total own operations GHG emissions | 1,645.4 | 1,577.0 | 4.3 |
  • Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emission per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium. Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emission per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium.

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur l'intensité des GES basée sur l'emplacement par rapport au revenu net (émissions totales de GES par revenu net). Le Groupe Allianz utilise le volume total des affaires à la place du revenu net pour calculer l'intensité des GES.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### GHG emissions intensity The table below presents the GHG intensity using both the location- based and market-based approaches:
  • ### Methodology - GHG emissions intensity (location- and market- based) Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. The calculation is repeated twice, once using the market-based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group, and once using the location-based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group. The total absolute emissions used for these calculations do not include IAE or SAF. For both of the calculations, the total business volumes figure used is the same.
  • ### Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions To fulfil the requirements of the "location-based" method for Scope 2 reporting, we also calculate and publish Scope 2 GHG emissions on the basis of grid-average emission factors (national, based on IEA, preliminary version, or state-level for U.S. assets based on EPA data) applied to Scope 2 energy consumed (which includes electricity from the grid).
  • ### END TABLE 1_As per the table "Business segment information - total business volume and reconciliation of operating profit (loss) to net income (loss) in the notes to the consolidated financial statements." 2_Excluding insurance-associated emissions. The Allianz Group discloses GHG intensity with the following considerations for the numerator and denominator: - Net revenue: The Allianz Group does not report a net revenue figure so total business volume is used instead. - Total GHG emissions: The majority of emissions for an insurance company are concentrated in Scope 3, Category 15. We are constrained by the current development of methodologies and the availability of data. Consequently, we are not yet able to comprehensively cover emissions from all business activities contributing to the total business volume.
  • Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emissions per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium.
  • ### Methodology - Total GHG emissions (location- and market- based) The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO2eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO2eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3.
  • Assuming a static headcount, our 2030 target would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 129.7 kt CO2e (2030 intensity target * estimated headcount). These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year; the current headcount was used as an estimate because we expect that new hires and leavers will broadly offset each other and therefore any net impact is not expected to be material.
  • Assuming a static portfolio in terms of 2024 business volume, our intensity target of 0.14 kt CO2e/mn € insurance premium would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 0.63 mn t CO2e for 2030. This figure is an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio. As our portfolio grows in business volume and data coverage increases, enabling us to report on more of the portfolio, we expect the associated absolute GHG emissions to grow as well.

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas l'information spécifique sur l'intensité des GES basée sur la localisation par rapport au chiffre d'affaires net (total des émissions de GES par chiffre d'affaires net) pour le groupe Allianz. Le chiffre d'affaires net n'est pas utilisé dans les calculs d'intensité des GES, car le groupe Allianz utilise le volume total des affaires à la place du chiffre d'affaires net.

  • investments and own operations. The relatively low primary data quota is mainly attributed to emissions financed through sovereign debt. We have chosen to incorporate more recent data in calculations, and therefore use the PRIMAP database which includes data up to 2023, instead of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change ( UNFCCC ) database, which has data up to 2021. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC data base. Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market - based) Overa ll GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. The calculation is repeated twice, once using the market -based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group , and once using the location -based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group . The total absolute emissions used for these calculations do not include IAE or SAF. For both of the calculations, the total business volumes figure used is the same.   • (IEA). For distance travelled, averages are based on national statistics or global sources like OECD -ITF and the International Council on Clean Transportation (ICCT). These averages result in varying data quality scores depending on granularity. For example, country -level data by vehicle type achieves a Score 2, while global averages lead to a Score 4.   • to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Our targets are defined considering market -based scope 2 emis sions as well as SAF. Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations Overarching GHG reduction target(s) In our Inaugural Net -Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year -end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50 %, 65 %, and 70 % respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year -end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year -end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65 % across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations ). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP. to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Our targets are defined considering market -based scope 2 emis sions as well as SAF. Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations Overarching GHG reduction target(s) In our Inaugural Net -Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year -end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50 %, 65 %, and 70 % respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year -end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year -end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65 % across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations ). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP.
  • intensity target of 0.14 kt CO 2e/mn € insurance premium would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 0.63 mn t CO 2e for 2030. This figure is an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to ou r dynamic portfolio. As our portfolio grows in business volume and data coverage increases, enabling us to report on more of the portfolio, we expect the associated absolute GHG emissions to grow as well. 2_Insurance Premium is equal to Insurance Revenue minus external acquisition costs . While the decision to define an intensity target allows us to reflect the expected growth of our portfolio by 2030 in a dynamic way, we have ensured that our targeted reduction is still within the scenario range to limit global warming to 1.5 °C. Specifically, we have aimed to set an emission reduction target in the ranges of the IPCC net -zero scenarios by 2030. We also considered a growth in premium to intensity target of 0.14 kt CO 2e/mn € insurance premium would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 0.63 mn t CO 2e for 2030. Specifically, we have aimed to set an emission reduction target in the ranges of the IPCC net -zero scenarios by 2030. We also considered a growth in premium to
E1-133 partie 2

GHG Intensity, market-based per net revenue (total GHG emissions per net revenue).

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques concernant l'intensité des GES, basée sur le marché, par rapport au revenu net (émissions totales de GES par revenu net).


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emissions per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium. Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emissions per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium.
  • The relatively low primary data quota is mainly attributed to emissions financed through sovereign debt. We have chosen to incorporate more recent data in calculations, and therefore use the PRIMAP database which includes data up to 2023, instead of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) database, which has data up to 2021. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC database. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC database.   • Assuming a static portfolio and emission data coverage of non- listed investees increasing to reach 80 % by 2030, our intensity target for listed and non-listed corporates would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 19.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. For our real estate portfolio, our intensity target would correspond to associated absolute emissions of 0.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio. Assuming a static portfolio and emission data coverage of non- listed investees increasing to reach 80 % by 2030, our intensity target for listed and non-listed corporates would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 19.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. For our real estate portfolio, our intensity target would correspond to associated absolute emissions of 0.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio.
  • Assuming a static headcount, our 2030 target would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 129.7 kt CO2e (2030 intensity target * estimated headcount). These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year; the current headcount was used as an estimate because we expect that new hires and leavers will broadly offset each other and therefore any net impact is not expected to be material. Assuming a static headcount, our 2030 target would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 129.7 kt CO2e (2030 intensity target * estimated headcount). These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year; the current headcount was used as an estimate because we expect that new hires and leavers will broadly offset each other and therefore any net impact is not expected to be material.
  • For both our listed and non-listed corporate exposure, we have set a target to reduce our gross emission intensity by 50 % by 2030 compared to the 2019 baseline emission intensity (see table above). For non-listed corporates, we are still in the process of gathering emission data and we do not know beforehand how many of our portfolio companies and indirect investments via funds will deliver data in the coming years until 2030. As data coverage is uncertain and changing, we cannot set a reasonable absolute financed emission reduction target for our non-listed corporate portfolio yet. An intensity metric does not rely on coverage, as absolute emissions are divided by the respective covered portfolio exposure. For both our listed and non-listed corporate exposure, we have set a target to reduce our gross emission intensity by 50 % by 2030 compared to the 2019 baseline emission intensity (see table above). For non-listed corporates, we are still in the process of gathering emission data and we do not know beforehand how many of our portfolio companies and indirect investments via funds will deliver data in the coming years until 2030. As data coverage is uncertain and changing, we cannot set a reasonable absolute financed emission reduction target for our non-listed corporate portfolio yet. An intensity metric does not rely on coverage, as absolute emissions are divided by the respective covered portfolio exposure.
  • ### END TABLE Delta target 2030 vs baseline in % (66) (89) (42) (65) 1_The Allianz Group has only defined market-based Scope 2 GHG emission targets for own operations. 2_The breakdown of Scope 3 emissions by category was not reported for fiscal year 2023. 3_The category purchased goods and services includes only the emissions from paper and public cloud. 4_For air travel emissions, 2022 emission factors were applied to consider post-Covid air travel load factors and to ensure comparability. 5_The category employee commuting includes only the emissions from remote work. 6_As there is no guidance on accounting of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) in the GHG Protocol yet, we are disclosing our emissions following GHG Protocol requirements.   • ### END TABLE The Allianz Group discloses GHG considerations for the numerator and denominator: intensity with the following − Net revenue: The Allianz Group does not report a net revenue figure so total business volume is used instead. − Total GHG emissions: The majority of emissions for an insurance company are concentrated in Scope 3, Category 15. We are constrained by the current development of methodologies and the availability of data. Consequently, we are not yet able to comprehensively cover emissions from all business activities contributing to the total business volume. ### END TABLE The Allianz Group discloses GHG considerations for the numerator and denominator: intensity with the following − Net revenue: The Allianz Group does not report a net revenue figure so total business volume is used instead. − Total GHG emissions: The majority of emissions for an insurance company are concentrated in Scope 3, Category 15. We are constrained by the current development of methodologies and the availability of data. Consequently, we are not yet able to comprehensively cover emissions from all business activities contributing to the total business volume.
  • C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement Total GHG emissions Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market- based) The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. − Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. − Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market- based) Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement Total GHG emissions Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market- based) The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. − Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. − Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market- based) Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume.
  • Insurance-associated GHG emissions – Commercial insurance: Contribution to decarbonization per lever % (change in GHG emissions versus target baseline 2022) Insurance-associated GHG emissions – Commercial insurance: Contribution to decarbonization per lever % (change in GHG emissions versus target baseline 2022)

Je ne peux pas fournir une réponse précise à cette question car le Groupe Allianz n'utilise pas le chiffre d'affaires net pour calculer l'intensité des émissions de GES. À la place, ils utilisent le volume total des affaires. Par conséquent, l'intensité des GES, basée sur le marché, est exprimée en tonnes de CO₂e par million d'euros de volume total des affaires, et non par chiffre d'affaires net.

  • # Total GHG emissions **Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market-based)** The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3. **Methodology – GHG emissions intensity (location- and market-based)** Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. # Total GHG emissions **Methodology – Total GHG emissions (location- and market-based)** The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group.   • Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emission per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium. Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emission per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium.
  • ## Insurance-associated GHG emissions – Commercial insurance: Contribution to decarbonization per lever *% (change in GHG emissions versus target baseline 2022)* ## Insurance-associated GHG emissions – Commercial insurance: Contribution to decarbonization per lever *% (change in GHG emissions versus target baseline 2022)*

Je suis désolé, mais les informations concernant l'intensité des GES basée sur le marché par rapport au chiffre d'affaires net (émissions totales de GES par chiffre d'affaires net) ne sont pas disponibles dans les documents fournis. Les documents mentionnent que le Groupe Allianz utilise le volume total des affaires au lieu du chiffre d'affaires net pour calculer l'intensité des GES.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### GHG emissions intensity The table below presents the GHG intensity using both the location- based and market-based approaches:
  • ### Methodology - GHG emissions intensity (location- and market- based) Overall GHG emissions intensity for the Allianz Group is disclosed as an overarching figure representing GHG emissions per million euros of business volume. The calculation is repeated twice, once using the market-based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group, and once using the location-based total absolute emissions of the Allianz Group. The total absolute emissions used for these calculations do not include IAE or SAF. For both of the calculations, the total business volumes figure used is the same.
  • ### END TABLE 1_As per the table "Business segment information - total business volume and reconciliation of operating profit (loss) to net income (loss) in the notes to the consolidated financial statements." 2_Excluding insurance-associated emissions. The Allianz Group discloses GHG intensity with the following considerations for the numerator and denominator: - Net revenue: The Allianz Group does not report a net revenue figure so total business volume is used instead. - Total GHG emissions: The majority of emissions for an insurance company are concentrated in Scope 3, Category 15. We are constrained by the current development of methodologies and the availability of data. Consequently, we are not yet able to comprehensively cover emissions from all business activities contributing to the total business volume.
  • Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emissions per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium.
  • - Customer revenues: The total income generated from selling goods or services, sourced from Refinitiv (now LSEG). The portfolio's IAE are calculated annually. For customer revenues and GHG emissions, the most recent data from our external data providers (MSCI and Refinitiv) is used, going back up to four reporting years. The customer's insurance premium data is taken from internal data sources for the current reporting period. The portfolio emission intensity is calculated as IAE per volume of insurance premiums (in €). The intensity metric helps track portfolio decarbonization over time. We apply a 10% emission reduction factor to the IAE on insurance policies insuring technologies in line with the Allianz statement on renewable/low carbon energy. This methodology applies until more specific methodologies for renewable & low carbon solutions become available. This means that, for these policies (and the associated insurance premium), only 10% of IAE are considered.
  • ### Methodology - Total GHG emissions (location- and market- based) The total GHG emissions figure is the sum of the Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions of the Allianz Group. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. - Total GHG emissions market-based (t CO2eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market-based + Gross Scope 3. - Total GHG emissions location-based (t CO2eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 location-based + Gross Scope 3.
  • Assuming a static headcount, our 2030 target would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 129.7 kt CO2e (2030 intensity target * estimated headcount). These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year; the current headcount was used as an estimate because we expect that new hires and leavers will broadly offset each other and therefore any net impact is not expected to be material.
  • For both our listed and non-listed corporate exposure, we have set a target to reduce our gross emission intensity by 50% by 2030 compared to the 2019 baseline emission intensity (see table above). For non-listed corporates, we are still in the process of gathering emission data and we do not know beforehand how many of our portfolio companies and indirect investments via funds will deliver data in the coming years until 2030. As data coverage is uncertain and changing, we cannot set a reasonable absolute financed emission reduction target for our non-listed corporate portfolio yet. An intensity metric does not rely on coverage, as absolute emissions are divided by the respective covered portfolio exposure.
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table titled "Proprietary investments GHG emissions - Corporates target: Contribution to decarbonization per lever % (change in GHG emissions vs target baseline 2019)" outlines the following: 1. **Decarbonization Levers**: The rows include "Start of period versus baseline," "Corporates - Investee company decarbonization," "Corporates - Portfolio steering," and "End of period versus baseline." 2. **Actions**: Actions listed are "Engagements on net zero transition," "Investee decarbonization," "Low carbon solution investments," "Restrictions," and "Further Portfolio changes." 3. **Achieved GHG emissions reduction (1.1.2024-31.12.2024)**: Values include (43.9), Not quantifiable, (1.3), (0.9), (0.8), and (3.8). 4. **Expected change in GHG emissions reduction (1.1.2025-31.12.2029)**: Values include (50.7), Not quantifiable, (5.2), (1.6), (3.6), and (4.1). 5. **Additional Notes**: The "to" column provides further details, such as (3.2), 0.4, (1.6), and (2.1). 6. **End of period versus baseline**: Achieved reduction is (50.7), and expected reduction is (61.3). The table quantifies reductions achieved and expected across different actions and periods, with some values marked as "Not quantifiable."

Je suis désolé, mais je ne peux pas fournir une réponse concernant l'intensité des GES basée sur le marché par rapport au revenu net (émissions totales de GES par revenu net) car le revenu net n'est pas spécifiquement rapporté dans les documents fournis. Le Groupe Allianz utilise le volume total d'affaires à la place du revenu net pour calculer l'intensité des GES.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • investments and own operations. The relatively low primary data quota is mainly attributed to emissions financed through sovereign debt. We have chosen to incorporate more recent data in calculations, and therefore use the PRIMAP database which includes data up to 2023, instead of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change ( UNFCCC ) database, which has data up to 2021. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC data base. However, only the UNFCCC database is considered as a primary data source, and therefore the primary data quote is lower than if we were to use the UNFCCC data base.   • (IEA). For distance travelled, averages are based on national statistics or global sources like OECD -ITF and the International Council on Clean Transportation (ICCT). These averages result in varying data quality scores depending on granularity. For example, country -level data by vehicle type achieves a Score 2, while global averages lead to a Score 4. This figure is disclosed twice, once using the market -based Scope 2 GHG emissions and once using the location -based Scope 2 GHG emissions, according to the definitions below. − Total GHG emissions market -based (t CO₂eq) = Gross Scope 1 + Gross Scope 2 market -based + Gross Scope 3.

  • to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Our targets are defined considering market -based scope 2 emis sions as well as SAF. Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations Overarching GHG reduction target(s) In our Inaugural Net -Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year -end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50 %, 65 %, and 70 % respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year -end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year -end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65 % across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations ). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP. to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Our targets are defined considering market -based scope 2 emis sions as well as SAF. Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations Overarching GHG reduction target(s) In our Inaugural Net -Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year -end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50 %, 65 %, and 70 % respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year -end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year -end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65 % across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations ). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP.
  • customer’s insurance premium to their total revenues (attribution factor ) and is multiplied by their Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions (as defined by the GHG Protocol). Scope 3 GHG emissions are excluded for now due to data reliability but may be included later. The total portfolio IAE is the sum of all insurance policies’ IAE in the portfolio. Key inputs for the IAE calculation include: − Insurance premiums: Defined as Insurance Revenue , net of acquisition costs (brokerage, commissions). − Customer emissions: Based on Scope 1 and 2 emissions sourced from MSCI and Refinitiv, or parent company emissions if the subsidiary data is unavailable. − Customer revenues: The total income generated from selling goods or services, sourced from Refinitiv (now LSEG). The portfolio’s IAE are calculated annually. For customer revenues and GHG emissions, the most recent data from our external data providers (MSCI and Refinitiv) is used, going back up to four reporting years. The customer’s insurance premium to their total revenues (attribution factor ) and is multiplied by their Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions (as defined by the GHG Protocol). Scope 3 GHG emissions are excluded for now due to data reliability but may be included later. The total portfolio IAE is the sum of all insurance policies’ IAE in the portfolio. Key inputs for the IAE calculation include: − Insurance premiums: Defined as Insurance Revenue , net of acquisition costs (brokerage, commissions). − Customer emissions: Based on Scope 1 and 2 emissions sourced from MSCI and Refinitiv, or parent company emissions if the subsidiary data is unavailable. − Customer revenues: The total income generated from selling goods or services, sourced from Refinitiv (now LSEG). The portfolio’s IAE are calculated annually. For customer revenues and GHG emissions, the most recent data from our external data providers (MSCI and Refinitiv) is used, going back up to four reporting years. The

E1-64

Quelles sont les valeurs liées aux objectifs de réduction du plan de transition. Plusieurs types de réponses sont possibles :

La valeur brute de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES), séparée par Scope (1, 2 et 3).
Les cibles de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES), exprimées en pourcentage par rapport à une année de référence, séparées par Scope (1, 2 et 3).
Les cibles de réduction en intensité monétaire, séparées par Scope (1, 2 et 3).
Il est important de distinguer les cibles par secteur d'activité.
Si les objectifs concernent les émissions financées, il est important de préciser le périmètre concerné (Scope 1, 2 ou 3).


Si possible, préciser la méthodologie utilisée pour fixer l'objectif de référence.
Si possible, préciser si l'objectif est conforme à un scénario de réduction aligné avec l'Accord de Paris.
Merci de bien indiquer les années de référence ainsi que les années cibles pour chaque objectif présenté.

Je n'ai pas suffisamment d'informations pour répondre aux questions concernant la méthodologie utilisée pour fixer les objectifs de référence ou leur conformité avec un scénario de réduction aligné avec l'Accord de Paris. Cependant, je peux fournir les valeurs et cibles de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES) disponibles dans les contextes fournis :

  1. Valeurs brutes de réduction des GES par Scope :

    • Scope 1 :
      • Réductions attendues pour 2025-2029 : 5.2 ktCO2e (Context Num-5)
    • Scope 2 :
      • Réductions attendues pour 2025-2029 : 40.1 ktCO2e (Context Num-5)
    • Scope 3 :
      • Réductions attendues pour 2025-2029 : 19.6 ktCO2e (Context Num-5)

  2. Cibles de réduction des GES par rapport à une année de référence :

    • Scope 1 :
      • Réduction de 66 % d'ici 2030 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2019 (Context Num-2)
    • Scope 2 (localisation) :
      • Réduction de 89 % d'ici 2030 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2019 (Context Num-2)
    • Scope 2 (marché) :
      • Réduction de 96.2 % par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2019 (Context Num-2)
    • Scope 3 :
      • Réduction de 15 % des émissions indirectes totales entre 2023 et 2024 (Context Num-4)

  3. Cibles de réduction en intensité monétaire :

    • Émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros investi : réduction de 50 % d'ici 2030 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2019 (Context Num-9)

  4. Cibles par secteur d'activité :

    • Pétrole et gaz :
      • Objectif 2030 : 45.2 g CO₂e/MJ (Context Num-1)
    • Services publics :
      • Objectif 2030 : 0.2 t CO₂e/MWh (Context Num-1)
    • Acier :
      • Objectif 2030 : 1.2 t CO₂e/t acier (Context Num-1)

  5. Émissions financées :

    • Proprietary Investments :
      • Réduction de 50 % des émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros investi d'ici 2030 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2019 (Context Num-9)

Les années de référence et cibles sont mentionnées dans les contextes fournis, mais la méthodologie et l'alignement avec l'Accord de Paris ne sont pas spécifiés.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • - Le tableau présente les objectifs de réduction des émissions de CO₂ pour les secteurs "Pétrole et gaz", "Services publics" et "Acier" pour les années 2024, 2023 et l'objectif 2030. - Les portées couvertes sont : "Scope 1, 2 et 3 (catégorie 11)" pour le secteur "Pétrole et gaz", "Scope 1" pour "Services publics", et "Scope 1 et 2" pour "Acier". - Les unités de mesure sont : "g CO₂e/MJ" pour "Pétrole et gaz", "t CO₂e/MWh" pour "Services publics", et "t CO₂e/t acier" pour "Acier". - En 2024, les valeurs sont : 70.6 g CO₂e/MJ pour "Pétrole et gaz", 0.2 t CO₂e/MWh pour "Services publics", et 1.6 t CO₂e/t acier pour "Acier". - Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (indiquées par "n.a."). - Les objectifs pour 2030 sont : 45.2 g CO₂e/MJ pour "Pétrole et gaz", 0.2 t CO₂e/MWh pour "Services publics", et 1.2 t CO₂e/t acier pour "Acier". and
