    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les changements réalisés ou attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour différentes périodes et portées (Scope 1, Scope 2, Scope 3). - Les leviers incluent l'énergie renouvelable, l'efficacité énergétique, la mobilité verte et d'autres initiatives. - Les changements réalisés dans les émissions de GES pour la période 2024 sont détaillés, avec une réduction totale de 61.5 ktCO2e par rapport au début de la période. - Les changements attendus pour la période 2025-2029 sont estimés pour chaque levier, avec des variations dans les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les actions spécifiques incluent l'utilisation d'électricité renouvelable, la réduction de la consommation d'énergie pour le chauffage et l'électricité, l'optimisation des flottes et des voyages aériens, ainsi que des ajustements liés aux centres de données et autres activités.

  • - **Scope 3** : Les émissions indirectes totales ont diminué de 15 % entre 2023 et 2024. Des objectifs d'intensité sont en place pour 2025 et 2030, conformément aux stratégies de réduction des émissions de GES d'Allianz. - **Scope 3** : Les émissions indirectes totales ont diminué de 15 % entre 2023 et 2024. Des objectifs d'intensité sont en place pour 2025 et 2030, conformément aux stratégies de réduction des émissions de GES d'Allianz.
  • Le tableau présente des données sur les émissions de CO2 pour deux secteurs : **"Commercial"** et **"Motor retail"**, en comparant les valeurs rétrospectives pour les années **2023** et **2024**, les écarts en pourcentage par rapport à l'année de référence **FY2022**, ainsi que les objectifs fixés pour **2030** et les écarts en pourcentage par rapport à la valeur de référence. - **Commercial** : - En **2024**, les émissions sont de **0.23 kt CO2e/mn € Insurance Premium**, contre **0.22** en **2023**, soit une augmentation de **6.4 %**. - La valeur de référence pour **FY2022** est de **0.26**, ce qui représente une diminution de **11.7 %** en **2024**. - L'objectif pour **2030** est fixé à **0.14**, soit une réduction de **45 %** par rapport à la valeur de référence. - **Motor retail** : - En **2024**, les émissions sont de **1.95 mn t CO2**, contre **2.03** en **2023**, soit une diminution de **3.6 %**. - La valeur de référence pour **FY2022** est de **2.10**, ce qui représente une diminution de **6.8 %** en **2024**. - L'objectif pour **2030** est fixé à **1.47**, soit une réduction de **30 %** par rapport à la valeur de référence. and

    Le tableau présente des données sur les émissions de CO2 pour deux secteurs : "Commercial" et "Motor retail". Il compare les valeurs rétrospectives pour les années 2023 et 2024, les écarts en pourcentage par rapport à l'année de référence (FY2022), ainsi que les objectifs fixés pour 2030 et les écarts en pourcentage par rapport à la valeur de référence.
    - Commercial : - En 2024, les émissions sont de 0.23 kt CO2e/mn € Insurance Premium, contre 0.22 en 2023, soit une augmentation de 6.4 %. - La valeur de référence pour FY2022 est de 0.26, ce qui représente une diminution de 11.7 % en 2024. - L'objectif pour 2030 est fixé à 0.14, soit une réduction de 45 % par rapport à la valeur de référence.
    - Motor retail : - En 2024, les émissions sont de 1.95 mn t CO2, contre 2.03 en 2023, soit une diminution de 3.6 %. - La valeur de référence pour FY2022 est de 2.10, ce qui représente une diminution de 6.8 % en 2024. - L'objectif pour 2030 est fixé à 1.47, soit une réduction de 30 % par rapport à la valeur de référence.

  • Le tableau présente les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) liées aux voyages d'affaires, excluant la flotte. Les colonnes incluent les années 2024, 2023, et l'objectif pour 2030 ("2030 Target"). Les lignes sont intitulées "Business Travel GHG emissions reduction (excl. fleet)" et "Business Travel GHG emissions reduction (excl. fleet) SAF excluded". En 2024, la réduction prévue est de 47,8 % lorsque le carburant d'aviation durable (SAF) est inclus, et de 45,8 % lorsque le SAF est exclu. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles ("n.a."). L'objectif fixé pour 2030 est une réduction de 60 % dans les deux cas. and

    Le tableau présente les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) liées aux voyages d'affaires, excluant la flotte. En 2024, la réduction prévue est de 47,8 % lorsque le carburant d'aviation durable (SAF) est inclus, et de 45,8 % lorsque le SAF est exclu. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.). L'objectif fixé pour 2030 est une réduction de 60 % dans les deux cas.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations spécifiques concernant les cibles de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES) en intensité monétaire par unité monétaire (€) pour les Scopes 1, 2, et 3 ne sont pas fournies dans les documents disponibles. Les documents mentionnent des cibles de réduction en intensité à l'échelle globale, mais ne détaillent pas ces informations de manière monétaire ou spécifiquement par secteur d’activité. Si vous avez besoin d'informations supplémentaires, je vous recommande de consulter directement les rapports annuels ou les documents de durabilité de l'entreprise pour obtenir des détails plus précis.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM2 :
  • Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emission per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium. Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emission per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium.

  • Assuming a static portfolio and emission data coverage of non-listed investees increasing to reach 80 % by 2030, our intensity target for listed and non-listed corporates would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 192 m tCO₂e for year-end 2029. For our real estate portfolio, our intensity target would correspond to associated absolute emissions of 0.2 mn tCO₂e for year-end 2029. These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio. Analysis on the contribution of the different decarbonization levers for the Corporates and directly held Real Estate portfolios can be found in the respective tables below.   • ## Targets Related to Climate Change Mitigation for Allianz Own Operations ### Overarching GHG Reduction Target(s) In our inaugural Net-Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year-end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50%, 65%, and 70% respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year-end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year-end 2029). The 2030 target aims to cut our GHG emissions per employee by 65% across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations). The decarbonization and removal offsets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP. ## Targets Related to Climate Change Mitigation for Allianz Own Operations ### Overarching GHG Reduction Target(s) In our inaugural Net-Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year-end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50%, 65%, and 70% respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year-end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year-end 2029). The 2030 target aims to cut our GHG emissions per employee by 65% across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations). The decarbonization and removal offsets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP.
  • The combined GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% is anchored to and governed by the FRSO. The FRSO ensures the achievement of the Renewable Electricity, Energy Efficiency, Green Fleet, and the Business Travel (excl. fleet) targets. The GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% for 2030 versus 2019 baseline includes Allianz Own Operations' activities in Scope 1, 2, and selected Scope 3 activities as it is an overall reduction target. All the targets governed by the FRSO are Group targets, including data from all Allianz Group subsidiaries and global lines within the environmental reporting scope. The main stakeholders involved in setting the targets were the Allianz Group Centers, such as Group Sustainable Operations, Group Accounting & Reporting, and Global Sustainability, through the establishment of a working group to jointly design the targets, set our ambition level, and ensure compliance. The Group Sustainability Board advised on the targets. Delivery against the The combined GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% is anchored to and governed by the FRSO. The FRSO ensures the achievement of the Renewable Electricity, Energy Efficiency, Green Fleet, and the Business Travel (excl. fleet) targets. The GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% for 2030 versus 2019 baseline includes Allianz Own Operations' activities in Scope 1, 2, and selected Scope 3 activities as it is an overall reduction target. All the targets governed by the FRSO are Group targets, including data from all Allianz Group subsidiaries and global lines within the environmental reporting scope. The main stakeholders involved in setting the targets were the Allianz Group Centers, such as Group Sustainable Operations, Group Accounting & Reporting, and Global Sustainability, through the establishment of a working group to jointly design the targets, set our ambition level, and ensure compliance. The Group Sustainability Board advised on the targets. Delivery against the
  • For both our listed and non-listed corporate exposure, we have set a target to reduce our gross emission intensity by 50% by 2030 compared to the 2019 baseline emission intensity (see table above). For non-listed corporates, we are still in the process of gathering emission data and we do not know beforehand how many of our portfolio companies and indirect investments via funds will deliver data in the coming years until 2030. As data coverage is uncertain and changing, we cannot set a reasonable absolute financed emission reduction target for our non-listed corporate portfolio yet. An intensity metric does not rely on coverage, as absolute emissions are divided by the respective covered portfolio exposure. For both our listed and non-listed corporate exposure, we have set a target to reduce our gross emission intensity by 50% by 2030 compared to the 2019 baseline emission intensity (see table above). For non-listed corporates, we are still in the process of gathering emission data and we do not know beforehand how many of our portfolio companies and indirect investments via funds will deliver data in the coming years until 2030. As data coverage is uncertain and changing, we cannot set a reasonable absolute financed emission reduction target for our non-listed corporate portfolio yet. An intensity metric does not rely on coverage, as absolute emissions are divided by the respective covered portfolio exposure.
  • # Targets related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio We deem the framework of the NZOAI Target-Setting Protocol (TSP) as best practice for setting GHG emission reduction targets. The TSP was developed with a strong reference to IPCC’s climate scenarios, limiting temperature increase by the end of the century to 1.5°C with no or limited overshoot during the century. The TSP was aligned with relevant stakeholders, including academia, and vetted in a public consultation. Thus, we generally follow its recommendations for our intermediate decarbonization targets. It should be noted that while the NZOAI TSP defines targets for engagements, sectors, and low-carbon solutions, we display these as actions in line with regulatory definitions in EFRS E1. When setting these targets, we considered potential future developments in large industries, especially the E.U. and the U.S., based on the latest climate laws and regulations. # Targets related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio We deem the framework of the NZOAI Target-Setting Protocol (TSP) as best practice for setting GHG emission reduction targets. The TSP was developed with a strong reference to IPCC’s climate scenarios, limiting temperature increase by the end of the century to 1.5°C with no or limited overshoot during the century. The TSP was aligned with relevant stakeholders, including academia, and vetted in a public consultation. Thus, we generally follow its recommendations for our intermediate decarbonization targets. It should be noted that while the NZOAI TSP defines targets for engagements, sectors, and low-carbon solutions, we display these as actions in line with regulatory definitions in EFRS E1. When setting these targets, we considered potential future developments in large industries, especially the E.U. and the U.S., based on the latest climate laws and regulations.
  • In line with our net-zero commitment, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, which are further underpinned by actions toward achieving our targets. Our emission targets are aligned with credible, science-backed climate scenarios – such as those provided by the IPCC’s 6th Assessment Report. Further scenarios include the International Energy Agency (IEA)’s Net-Zero by 2050 and the One Earth Climate Model; these limit global warming in 2100 to 1.5°C with only a limited or no overshoot of this temperature during this century. While the individual scenarios differ in their assumptions and narratives (including global future economic and public and private policy developments), they agree on a necessary emission reduction range for CO₂ emissions of 36% to 69% from 2020 to 2030, with a median reduction of 48%. For GHG emissions, the range is 34% to 60%, with a median of 43%. All our existing sub-portfolio targets for our operations, proprietary investments, and Property-Casualty In line with our net-zero commitment, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, which are further underpinned by actions toward achieving our targets. Our emission targets are aligned with credible, science-backed climate scenarios – such as those provided by the IPCC’s 6th Assessment Report. Further scenarios include the International Energy Agency (IEA)’s Net-Zero by 2050 and the One Earth Climate Model; these limit global warming in 2100 to 1.5°C with only a limited or no overshoot of this temperature during this century. While the individual scenarios differ in their assumptions and narratives (including global future economic and public and private policy developments), they agree on a necessary emission reduction range for CO₂ emissions of 36% to 69% from 2020 to 2030, with a median reduction of 48%. For GHG emissions, the range is 34% to 60%, with a median of 43%. All our existing sub-portfolio targets for our operations, proprietary investments, and Property-Casualty
  • In the subsequent sections, we outline the integration of the transition plan into our business strategy and how we assess and address the impacts, risks, and opportunities of climate change mitigation. In the subsequent sections, we outline the integration of the transition plan into our business strategy and how we assess and address the impacts, risks, and opportunities of climate change mitigation.
  • Ultimate responsibility for all matters relating to sustainability resides with the Board of Management of Allianz SE as the Group’s parent company. This includes climate change and the net-zero transition plan, which has been approved by the Board of Management. Climate-related matters are typically part of all Group Sustainability Board meetings, which are held at least quarterly. The Supervisory Board is not required to formally approve the net-zero transition plan, however, the Supervisory Board is informed of the plan and provided with the level of transparency needed to execute their role of oversight. Ultimate responsibility for all matters relating to sustainability resides with the Board of Management of Allianz SE as the Group’s parent company. This includes climate change and the net-zero transition plan, which has been approved by the Board of Management. Climate-related matters are typically part of all Group Sustainability Board meetings, which are held at least quarterly. The Supervisory Board is not required to formally approve the net-zero transition plan, however, the Supervisory Board is informed of the plan and provided with the level of transparency needed to execute their role of oversight.
  • # Climate change mitigation ## Climate Change Strategy and Net-Zero Transition **Section summary** Allianz’s net-zero transition plan substantiates our long-term commitments to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions for proprietary investments, Property-Casualty insurance, and own operations. To deliver on our ambition, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, with key decarbonization actions encompassing restrictions on fossil fuels, strategically steering our portfolios, engaging with stakeholders (particularly our clients and investee companies), improving energy management across our operations, and scaling up support of renewable energy and low-carbon technologies. We are on track to achieving our targets. However, the transition will be complex, and we recognize that achieving our net-zero commitment will require significant collaboration with policymakers, regulators, and other key stakeholders to drive the transition. # Climate change mitigation ## Climate Change Strategy and Net-Zero Transition **Section summary** Allianz’s net-zero transition plan substantiates our long-term commitments to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions for proprietary investments, Property-Casualty insurance, and own operations. To deliver on our ambition, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, with key decarbonization actions encompassing restrictions on fossil fuels, strategically steering our portfolios, engaging with stakeholders (particularly our clients and investee companies), improving energy management across our operations, and scaling up support of renewable energy and low-carbon technologies. We are on track to achieving our targets. However, the transition will be complex, and we recognize that achieving our net-zero commitment will require significant collaboration with policymakers, regulators, and other key stakeholders to drive the transition.
  • ## Environmental ### Decarbonization - Ensure sustainable solutions in proprietary investments and products - **Achievement 2024**: Growth achieved in both sustainable investments and sustainable insurance solutions in Property-Casualty; Sustainable Life Savings product and offering framework - **More Details**: For further insights, please refer to the sections Integrating sustainability in insurance and Integrating sustainability in proprietary investments sections - Follow through on the transition plan to reach the net-zero commitments of our business and operations - **Achievement 2024**: GHG emissions from operations reduced (62%) - **More Details**: For further insights, please refer to section E1 Climate change ## Environmental ### Decarbonization - Ensure sustainable solutions in proprietary investments and products - **Achievement 2024**: Growth achieved in both sustainable investments and sustainable insurance solutions in Property-Casualty; Sustainable Life Savings product and offering framework - **More Details**: For further insights, please refer to the sections Integrating sustainability in insurance and Integrating sustainability in proprietary investments sections - Follow through on the transition plan to reach the net-zero commitments of our business and operations - **Achievement 2024**: GHG emissions from operations reduced (62%) - **More Details**: For further insights, please refer to section E1 Climate change

Je suis désolé, mais les informations fournies ne contiennent pas de données spécifiques sur les cibles de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES) en intensité monétaire dans le plan de transition. Les contextes fournis mentionnent divers aspects des objectifs de réduction des émissions, notamment les secteurs d'activité comme le pétrole et le gaz, les utilités, et l'acier, mais ils n'indiquent pas les réductions d'émissions en CO₂ équivalent par unité monétaire (€) ni ne distinguent ces cibles par Scope 1, 2 et 3. Si vous avez d'autres documents ou informations spécifiques, je pourrais essayer de vous aider davantage.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Overarching GHG reduction target(s) In our Inaugural Net-Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year-end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50%, 65%, and 70% respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year-end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year-end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65% across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP.
  • Our 2030 intermediate targets are both absolute and intensity GHG emission targets. Absolute GHG emissions refer to an absolute amount of GHG emissions associated with the respective business activity such as investing or insuring; absolute GHG emission targets seek to reduce the absolute amount of GHG emissions. Conversely, GHG intensity emission targets harmonize the GHG emissions through a denominator that relates to a business activity, such as GHG emissions per million euro invested, or per million euro of premium.
  • Based on the current emission intensity reduction progress, we believe we are on track to achieve the 45% reduction target by 2030.
  • The combined GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% is anchored to and governed by the FRSO. The FRSO ensures the achievement of the Renewable Electricity, Energy Efficiency, Green Fleet, and the Business Travel (excl. fleet) targets. The GHG emission intensity reduction target of 65% for 2030 versus 2019 baseline includes Allianz Own Operations' activities in Scope 1, 2, and selected Scope 3 activities as it is an overall reduction target. All the targets governed by the FRSO are Group targets, including data from all Allianz Group subsidiaries and global lines within the environmental reporting scope. The main stakeholders involved in setting the targets were the Allianz Group Centers, such as Group Sustainable Operations, Group Accounting & Reporting, and Global Sustainability, through the establishment of a working group to jointly design the targets, set our ambition level, and ensure compliance. The Group Sustainability Board advised on the targets. Delivery against the
  • Assuming a static portfolio and emission data coverage of non- listed investees increasing to reach 80 % by 2030, our intensity target for listed and non-listed corporates would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 19.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. For our real estate portfolio, our intensity target would correspond to associated absolute emissions of 0.2 mn tCO2e for year-end 2029. These figures are an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to our dynamic portfolio. Analysis on the contribution of the different decarbonization levers for the Corporates and directly held Real Estate portfolios can be found in the respective tables below. Our progress toward target achievement will be monitored regularly and reported in the Sustainability Statement.
  • For both our listed and non-listed corporate exposure, we have set a target to reduce our gross emission intensity by 50% by 2030 compared to the 2019 baseline emission intensity (see table above). For non-listed corporates, we are still in the process of gathering emission data and we do not know beforehand how many of our portfolio companies and indirect investments via funds will deliver data in the coming years until 2030. As data coverage is uncertain and changing, we cannot set a reasonable absolute financed emission reduction target for our non-listed corporate portfolio yet. An intensity metric does not rely on coverage, as absolute emissions are divided by the respective covered portfolio exposure.
  • ### Targets related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio We deem the framework of the NZAOA Target-Setting Protocol (TSP) as best practice for setting GHG emission reduction targets. The TSP was developed with a strong reference to IPCC's climate scenarios1, limiting temperature increase by the end of the century to 1.5℃ with no or limited overshoot during the century. The TSP was aligned with relevant stakeholders, including academia, and vetted in a public consultation. Thus, we generally follow its recommendations for our intermediate decarbonization targets. It should be noted that while the NZAOA TSP defines targets for engagements, sectors, and low- carbon solutions, we display these as actions in line with regulatory definitions in ESRS E1. When setting these targets, we considered potential future developments in large industries, especially the E.U. and the U.S., based on the latest climate laws and regulations.
  • The table below shows the contributions of the actions to the absolute GHG emission reductions in our listed corporate portfolio in 2024 as well as the further expected reductions from 2025 through to end of 2029. All figures are presented as percentages. Lower ranges in the table reflect expected maximum decarbonization and upper ranges correspond to minimum expected decarbonization. 1_This target previously referred to "Climate Solutions." We re-classified the eligible technologies which include the ones in our Statement on Renewable/Low-Carbon Energy as well as transport-related low- carbon technologies and others.   • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta los KPI/targets para el año 2025, con un objetivo del 100 %. Los indicadores incluyen: 1. **Reducción de emisiones propias en inversiones**: Emisiones absolutas financiadas de GHG en millones de toneladas de CO2e provenientes de corporaciones listadas, con un objetivo de **12.3 mn t CO2e**. 2. **Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)**: Porcentaje de líderes de lealtad en segmentos de negocio, con un objetivo de **50 %**. 3. **Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)**: Desarrollo contra el nivel de ambición general, con un objetivo de **77 %**. 4. **Plan de transición hacia compromisos de cero emisiones netas**: Incluye reducción de emisiones en el sector de motor retail y reducción de intensidad de emisiones en el sector comercial de Property-Casualty. 5. **Soluciones sostenibles en Property-Casualty**. 6. **Desarrollo del Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 7. **Desarrollo del Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 8. **Cumplimiento estricto de requisitos regulatorios y de gobernanza corporativa**, con enfoque en un sistema de gestión de riesgos adecuado y cultura de riesgos. 9. **Contribución de liderazgo**, con enfoque en atributos de personas de Allianz: Excelencia en clientes y mercado, liderazgo colaborativo, emprendimiento y confianza; evaluación multi-rater. ### END TABLE

Las emisiones totales de GHG basadas en el mercado ("Total GHG emissions (market-based)2") fueron de **48,932,692.3 t en CO2e** en 2024 y **57,562,291.4 t en CO2e** en 2023. 3. La intensidad de GHG basada en el mercado ("GHG intensity (market-based)") fue de **272.2 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2024 y **356.0 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2023. 4. Las emisiones totales de GHG basadas en la ubicación ("Total GHG emissions (location-based)2") fueron de **49,067,050.4 t en CO2e** en 2024 y **57,688,706.5 t en CO2e** en 2023. 5. Las etiquetas de las columnas incluyen: "Retrospective", "Base year", "2024", "2023", "Delta in %", "Milestones and target years" (2025, 2030, 2050), y "Annual % target / Base year". Las filas principales son: 1. **"Purchased goods and services"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 8,993.5, con objetivos de intensidad establecidos. 2. **"Fuel and energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or Scope 2)"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 30,305.1, con objetivos de intensidad establecidos. 3. **"Business traveling"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 55,873.8 y en 2023, 96,745.1. 4. **"Employee commuting"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 7,456.9, considerando solo trabajo remoto. 5. **"Downstream leased assets"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 90,974.1 y en 2023, 90,903.6, con un cambio del 0.1%. 6. **"Investments - Proprietary Investments"**: Emisiones en 2024 fueron 48,626,453.1 y en 2023, 57,268,098.1, con un cambio de (15.1)%. Totales de emisiones de GEI: - **"Total GHG emissions (location-based)"**: 49,067,050.4 en 2024 y 57,688,706.5 en 2023, con un cambio de (14.9)%. - **"Total GHG emissions (market-based)"**: 48,932,692.3 en 2024 y 57,562,291.4 en 2023, con un cambio de (15.0)%. - **"Total GHG emissions inc. insurance (location-based)"**: 52,034,326.8 en 2024 y 60,665,061.5 en 2023, con un cambio de (14.2)%. Se mencionan objetivos de reducción de emisiones para 2030 y 2050, con detalles adicionales en secciones específicas del informe.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations détaillées concernant les cibles de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES) en intensité monétaire par unité monétaire (€) pour chaque scope (1, 2 et 3) et par secteur d’activité ne sont pas disponibles dans les documents fournis. Il est mentionné que des objectifs d'intensité sont en place, mais les détails spécifiques ne sont pas fournis. Si vous avez besoin d'informations précises, je vous recommande de consulter les documents complets de l'entreprise ou de contacter directement Allianz pour obtenir des précisions.

  • investment portfolio For our portfolio targets, there are generally two levers for reducing GHG emissions: either the assets (i.e., our portfolio companies or our real estate investments) reduce their GHG emissions (investee company decarbonization), or we change the composition of our portfolio over time (portfolio steering). To this end, we have different actions in place to support emission reductions. Corporates For our corporate portfolio, we have set the following four targets on actions to pull the two decarbonization levers. These actions relate partially to addressing risks and opportunities, in addition to our inside -out impact: − Engage high -emitting companies in our portfolio to increase our positive impact and reduce risks; − Invest € 20 bn in low -carbon solutions to increase our positive impact and seize opportunities; − Align specific high -emitting sectors (oil and gas, utilities (coal), and steel 1) with IEA Net -Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario to reduce investment portfolio For our portfolio targets, there are generally two levers for reducing GHG emissions: either the assets (i.e., our portfolio companies or our real estate investments) reduce their GHG emissions (investee company decarbonization), or we change the composition of our portfolio over time (portfolio steering). To this end, we have different actions in place to support emission reductions. These actions relate partially to addressing risks and opportunities, in addition to our inside -out impact: − Engage high -emitting companies in our portfolio to increase our positive impact and reduce risks; − Invest € 20 bn in low -carbon solutions to increase our positive impact and seize opportunities; − Align specific high -emitting sectors (oil and gas, utilities (coal), and steel 1) with IEA Net -Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario to reduce
  • intensity target of 0.14 kt CO 2e/mn € insurance premium would correspond to associated absolute GHG emissions of 0.63 mn t CO 2e for 2030. This figure is an illustrative view rather than an accurate representation of the expected absolute emissions in the target year and will change due to ou r dynamic portfolio. As our portfolio grows in business volume and data coverage increases, enabling us to report on more of the portfolio, we expect the associated absolute GHG emissions to grow as well. 2_Insurance Premium is equal to Insurance Revenue minus external acquisition costs . While the decision to define an intensity target allows us to reflect the expected growth of our portfolio by 2030 in a dynamic way, we have ensured that our targeted reduction is still within the scenario range to limit global warming to 1.5 °C.   • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities.   • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
  • NatCat scenarios and global hazard maps. However, effecti ve adaptation to climate change not only requires adequate pricing of risks, but also individual measures by customers. We have therefore started considering preventative actions taken by the customer in our products and pricing models. Living up to our ro le as a climate risk manager, we are also integrating advisory services into our customer communication and we provide relevant information to customers, for example, on how to build stronger resilience to climate- related events. In addition, we are committed to offering comprehensive insurance products for low -carbon technologies – such as battery electric vehicles (BEV) and the related ecosystem – as well as for renewable energy technologies, to support the transition of our cust omers toward more environment -friendly solutions. For instance, Allianz entities offer BEV insurance products, which meet the specific NatCat scenarios and global hazard maps.   • investments in employees, external expertise, third party databases, IT systems and more. Together with an increase in operat ional compl exity, such new regulations may drive an increase in compliance or process failures and operational losses. Opportunities Insurance Opportunities are considered material for our insurance portfolio (Property -Casualty retail and commercial ) in that we are supporting our customers in their low -carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our Sustainable Solutions and low -carbon solutions. Proprietary investments Opportunities are considered material for our proprietary investments in that we are supporting our investees in their low -carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our low -carbon solutions. E1-122

Quelles sont les émissions de gaz à effet de serre liées à la Catégorie 15 du GHG Protocol : émissions financées ?



Pour répondre à cette question, veuillez :
Distinguer, si possible, les secteurs d'activité, emplacements géographiques ou le type d'actifs financés.
Indiquer les émissions financées provenant du portefeuille des investissements disponibles.
Distinguer le type de financement (investissement, prêt, etc.).
Veuillez noter que si l'entreprise étudiée n'a pas inclus cette catégorie dans son inventaire des émissions.
Dans ce cas, merci de préciser que cette information n'est pas disponible et la raison pour laquelle elle n'est pas disponible.

Les émissions de gaz à effet de serre liées à la Catégorie 15 du GHG Protocol, à savoir les émissions financées, sont calculées par le groupe Allianz pour les investissements dans les entreprises, la dette publique, et l'immobilier détenu sur le bilan. Cependant, elles excluent les produits de trésorerie et les produits titrisés en raison de l'absence de méthodologies pertinentes (Contexte Num-1).

En ce qui concerne les émissions financées du portefeuille d'investissements propriétaires, les émissions incluent principalement les émissions de Scope 1 et 2 des entreprises investies. Étant donné l'incertitude concernant les données du Scope 3 pour le portefeuille d'entreprises, les émissions financées sont estimées entre 87 millions et 161 millions de tonnes équivalent CO2, en raison d'une sous-déclaration actuelle des émissions de Scope 3 et des variations significatives dans les estimations par les fournisseurs de données (Contexte Num-4).

Le type de financement inclut les investissements propriétaires en actions et en immobilier, ainsi que les obligations publiques. Pour les obligations et prêts à des entités sous-souveraines et supranationales, Allianz a adapté la méthodologie utilisée pour les souverains (Contexte Num-5).

En résumé, les émissions financées de la Catégorie 15 incluent les investissements propriétaires, avec une estimation des émissions entre 87 mn et 161 mn t CO2e, tout en reconnaissant les limitations actuelles dues aux incertitudes des données du Scope 3.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Category 15 – Financed emissions Financed emissions – Proprietary Investments General statement The Allianz Group calculates financed emissions for corporates, public debt, and real estate held on the balance sheet, excluding cash and securitized products (like ABS/MBS and Covered Bonds) due to the absence of relevant methodologies. Our methodologies were defined in line with the SFDR Final Report on Draft Regulatory Technical Standards and the NZ AOA Target Setting Protocol. Allianz also the recommendations set out in the Global GHG Accounting & Reporting Standard for the Financial Industry (PCAF) to ensure robust climate- related financial reporting. Annual Report 2024 − Allianz Group 2 C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement Category 15 – Financed emissions Financed emissions – Proprietary Investments General statement The Allianz Group calculates financed emissions for corporates, public debt, and real estate held on the balance sheet, excluding cash and securitized products (like ABS/MBS and Covered Bonds) due to the absence of relevant methodologies. Our methodologies were defined in line with the SFDR Final Report on Draft Regulatory Technical Standards and the NZ AOA Target Setting Protocol. Allianz also the recommendations set out in the Global GHG Accounting & Reporting Standard for the Financial Industry (PCAF) to ensure robust climate- related financial reporting. Annual Report 2024 − Allianz Group 2 C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement
  • Le tableau présente les catégories du Scope 3 et leur statut d'inclusion ou d'exclusion. Les 15 catégories sont listées comme suit : 1. "Purchased goods and services" est exclue. 2. "Capital goods" est exclue. 3. "Fuel and energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or Scope 2)" est incluse. 4. "Upstream transportation and distribution" est exclue. 5. "Waste generated in operation" est exclue. 6. "Business traveling" est incluse. 7. "Employee commuting" est exclue. 8. "Upstream leased assets" est exclue. 9. "Downstream transportation" est exclue. 10. "Processing of sold products" est exclue. 11. "Use of sold products" est exclue. 12. "End-of-life treatment of sold products" est incluse. 13. "Downstream leased assets" est exclue. 14. "Franchises" est incluse. 15. "Investments" est incluse. En résumé, seules 5 catégories sont incluses : les activités liées au carburant et à l'énergie (non incluses dans les Scopes 1 et 2), les déplacements professionnels, le traitement en fin de vie des produits vendus, les franchises et les investissements. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Scope 3 categories Included/Excluded
    1 Purchased goods and services Excluded
    2 Capital goods Excluded
    3 Fuel and energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or Scope 2) Included
    4 Upstream transportation and distribution Excluded
    5 Waste generated in operation Excluded
    6 Business traveling Included
    7 Employee commuting Excluded
    8 Upstream leased assets Excluded
    9 Downstream transportation Excluded
    10 Processing of sold products Excluded
    11 Use of sold products Excluded
    12 End-of-life treatment of sold products Included
    13 Downstream leased assets Excluded
    14 Franchises Included
    15 Investments Included

    Résumé : Le tableau présente les catégories du Scope 3 et indique si elles sont incluses ou exclues. Parmi les 15 catégories, seules 5 sont incluses : les activités liées au carburant et à l'énergie (non incluses dans les Scopes 1 et 2), les déplacements professionnels, le traitement en fin de vie des produits vendus, les franchises et les investissements. Les autres catégories, telles que les biens achetés, les biens d'équipement, le transport en amont et en aval, ainsi que l'utilisation des produits vendus, sont exclues.

  • Category 13 – Downstream leased assets This refers to the operation of assets owned by an Allianz company (lessor) and leased to other entities in the reporting year. Emissions in this category are those not included in the Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions reported by the lessor, i.e., they are emissions from the lessee over the reporting period, and may also include emissions from sub- leased spaces if under control of the sub-lessee. Downstream leased assets therefore refers to tenant emissions. Where the Allianz Group fully consolidates a real estate investment, we allocate tenants' controlled emissions to Scope 3 category 13. Methodology Emissions are calculated using a similar approach to that described below in the section on category 15 on Directly Owned Real Estate (Not Fully Consolidated Assets). For fully consolidated downstream leased assets, Allianz recognizes 100 % of Scope 3 GHG emissions. Category 15 – Financed emissions Financed emissions – Proprietary Investments Category 13 – Downstream leased assets This refers to the operation of assets owned by an Allianz company (lessor) and leased to other entities in the reporting year. Emissions in this category are those not included in the Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions reported by the lessor, i.e., they are emissions from the lessee over the reporting period, and may also include emissions from sub- leased spaces if under control of the sub-lessee. Downstream leased assets therefore refers to tenant emissions. Where the Allianz Group fully consolidates a real estate investment, we allocate tenants' controlled emissions to Scope 3 category 13. Methodology Emissions are calculated using a similar approach to that described below in the section on category 15 on Directly Owned Real Estate (Not Fully Consolidated Assets). For fully consolidated downstream leased assets, Allianz recognizes 100 % of Scope 3 GHG emissions. Category 15 – Financed emissions Financed emissions – Proprietary Investments
  • Our Scope 3 category 15 emissions currently only include Scope 1 and 2 emissions from our corporate investees. Given the uncertainty about Scope 3 data for the corporates portfolio, we estimate that these financed emissions amount to between 87 mn and 161 mn t CO2e. This wide range is due to the current underreporting of Scope 3 emissions and significant variations in estimations by data providers. We are committed to closely monitoring this topic while further developing our reporting capability to enhance our disclosure. Proprietary investments GHG emissions - split per asset class Our Scope 3 category 15 emissions currently only include Scope 1 and 2 emissions from our corporate investees. Given the uncertainty about Scope 3 data for the corporates portfolio, we estimate that these financed emissions amount to between 87 mn and 161 mn t CO2e. This wide range is due to the current underreporting of Scope 3 emissions and significant variations in estimations by data providers. We are committed to closely monitoring this topic while further developing our reporting capability to enhance our disclosure. Proprietary investments GHG emissions - split per asset class
  • Since there is no guidance from PCAF or other carbon accounting standards for calculating financed emissions of bonds from and loans to sub-sovereign and supranationals, the Allianz Group has adapted the methodology used for sovereigns. Methodology – Financed emissions of real estate Financed emissions represent the share of a real estate investment’s GHG emissions that are attributed to the Allianz Group based on the proportion of financing provided by the Allianz Group, relative to the entity’s total value. These emissions are calculated annually. The key inputs to this metric are: − Investment value (€ Investment): − For public debt, issuer emissions consist of Scope 1 GHG emissions, which equal production emissions from within the country but exclude land use, land use change, and forestry (LULUCF), due to data uncertainty. − Directly Owned Real Estate Equity and Funds: Ownership share based on market value. Since there is no guidance from PCAF or other carbon accounting standards for calculating financed emissions of bonds from and loans to sub-sovereign and supranationals, the Allianz Group has adapted the methodology used for sovereigns. Methodology – Financed emissions of real estate Financed emissions represent the share of a real estate investment’s GHG emissions that are attributed to the Allianz Group based on the proportion of financing provided by the Allianz Group, relative to the entity’s total value. These emissions are calculated annually. The key inputs to this metric are: − Investment value (€ Investment): − For public debt, issuer emissions consist of Scope 1 GHG emissions, which equal production emissions from within the country but exclude land use, land use change, and forestry (LULUCF), due to data uncertainty. − Directly Owned Real Estate Equity and Funds: Ownership share based on market value.

  • The table below shows GHG emissions from our proprietary investment portfolio mapped to Scope 1, 2, and 3 according to ESRS requirements. Previously, the emissions from so-called on balance real assets held for proprietary investments, such as real estate and infrastructure, have been accounted for in category 15. These are now shown in Scope 1 and 2, as well as in Scope 3 category 13 for real estate. More details on the methodology, assumptions, and scope of these metrics can be found in the section Methodology information for climate metrics. The table below shows GHG emissions from our proprietary investment portfolio mapped to Scope 1, 2, and 3 according to ESRS requirements. Previously, the emissions from so-called on balance real assets held for proprietary investments, such as real estate and infrastructure, have been accounted for in category 15. These are now shown in Scope 1 and 2, as well as in Scope 3 category 13 for real estate. More details on the methodology, assumptions, and scope of these metrics can be found in the section Methodology information for climate metrics.
  • Le tableau présente les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) des investissements propriétaires pour les années 2024 et 2023, réparties selon les catégories et les Scopes 1, 2 et 3. Les émissions du Scope 1, provenant des actifs réels au bilan, ont diminué de 38,4 %, passant de 28,778.8 en 2023 à 17,723.7 en 2024. Les émissions du Scope 2 basées sur la localisation ont augmenté de 23,3 %, passant de 60,179.5 en 2023 à 74,180.8 en 2024, tandis que celles basées sur le marché ont augmenté de 38,7 %, passant de 38,062.9 en 2023 à 52,804.1 en 2024. Les émissions significatives du Scope 3 ont diminué de 15,1 %, passant de 57,359,001.7 en 2023 à 48,717,427 en 2024, principalement en raison de la baisse des émissions liées aux investissements (de 57,268,098.1 en 2023 à 48,626,453.1 en 2024). Les émissions des actifs loués en aval ont légèrement augmenté de 0,1 %, passant de 90,903.6 en 2023 à 90,974.1 en 2024. Les émissions totales des investissements propriétaires basées sur la localisation ont diminué de 15 %, passant de 57,447,960.0 en 2023 à 48,809,331.7 en 2024. De même, les émissions totales des investissements propriétaires basées sur le marché ont diminué de 15 %, passant de 57,425,843.4 en 2023 à 48,787,955.1 en 2024. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Catégorie 2024 2023 Variation en %

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour les années 2024 et 2023, réparties selon les Scopes 1, 2 et 3. Les émissions du Scope 1 ont diminué de 38,4 %, tandis que celles du Scope 2 ont augmenté, avec une hausse de 23,3 % pour les émissions basées sur la localisation et de 38,7 % pour celles basées sur le marché. Les émissions significatives du Scope 3 ont diminué de 15,1 %, principalement en raison de la baisse des émissions liées aux investissements. Les émissions totales des investissements propriétaires, qu'elles soient basées sur la localisation ou le marché, ont également diminué de 15 %.

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) au 31 décembre pour les années 2023 et 2024, réparties en trois catégories : Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les émissions **Scope 1 GHG** brutes sont passées de 31,773.7 en 2023 à 36,160.9 en 2024, soit une augmentation de 13,8 %. - Les émissions **Scope 2 GHG** brutes basées sur la localisation ont augmenté de 112,227.8 en 2023 à 118,928.5 en 2024 (+6,0 %), tandis que celles basées sur le marché ont diminué de 7,929.2 à 5,947.0 (-25,0 %). - Les données pour les émissions **Scope 3 GHG** en 2023 ne sont pas disponibles pour les catégories suivantes : biens et services achetés, activités liées au carburant et à l'énergie, voyages d'affaires et déplacements des employés. - Les émissions totales des opérations propres basées sur la localisation sont passées de 240,746.5 en 2023 à 257,718.7 en 2024 (+7,0 %). - Les émissions totales des opérations propres basées sur le marché ont augmenté de 136,447.9 en 2023 à 144,737.2 en 2024 (+6,1 %). - Lorsque le **SAF** (Sustainable Aviation Fuel) est inclus, les émissions totales basées sur le marché sont passées de 136,447.9 en 2023 à 142,648.5 en 2024 (+4,5 %). and

    As of 31 December 2024 2023 Delta in %
    Scope 1 GHG Emissions
    Gross Scope 1 GHG emissions 36,160.9 31,773.7 13.8
    Scope 2 GHG Emissions
    Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions 118,928.5 112,227.8 6.0

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) sont réparties en trois catégories : Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les émissions Scope 1 ont augmenté de 13,8 % entre 2023 et 2024. - Les émissions Scope 2 basées sur la localisation ont augmenté de 6,0 %, tandis que celles basées sur le marché ont diminué de 25,0 %. - Les données pour les émissions Scope 3 incluent des catégories telles que les biens et services achetés, les activités liées au carburant et à l'énergie, les voyages d'affaires et les déplacements des employés. Cependant, les données de 2023 pour ces catégories ne sont pas disponibles. - Les émissions totales des opérations propres basées sur la localisation ont augmenté de 7,0 %, tandis que celles basées sur le marché ont augmenté de 6,1 %. Lorsque le SAF est inclus, l'augmentation est de 4,5 %.

  • ### Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau détaille les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) d'Allianz pour les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 (localisation et marché) et Scope 3, avec des données pour l'année de base, 2023, 2024, et des objectifs pour 2025, 2030 et 2050. - **Scope 1** : Les émissions brutes ont diminué de 11 % entre 2023 (60,552.4) et 2024 (53,884.6). Les émissions des actifs réels ont augmenté de 13,8 %, passant de 31,773.7 en 2023 à 36,160.9 en 2024. - **Scope 2 (localisation)** : Les émissions brutes ont augmenté de 12 %, passant de 172,407.3 en 2023 à 193,109.3 en 2024. Les émissions des actifs réels ont augmenté de 23,3 %, atteignant 74,180.8 en 2024 contre 60,179.5 en 2023. - **Scope 2 (marché)** : Les émissions brutes ont augmenté de 27,7 %, passant de 45,992.1 en 2023 à 58,751.2 en 2024. Les émissions des actifs réels ont augmenté de 38,7 %, atteignant 52,804.1 en 2024 contre 38,062.9 en 2023. - **Scope 3** : Les émissions indirectes totales ont diminué de 15 %, passant de 57,455,746.8 en 2023 à 48,820,056.5 en 2024. - Des objectifs d'intensité sont en place pour 2025 et 2030, comme indiqué dans les sections et tableaux associés. - Les pourcentages des émissions Scope 1 provenant des systèmes d'échange de quotas d'émission ont diminué de 38,4 %, passant de 28,778.8 en 2023 à 17,723.7 en 2024. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    ```markdown

    Base year 2024 2023 Delta in % 2025 2030 2050 Annual % target / Base year
    Gross Scope 1 GHG emissions 53,884.6 60,552.4 (11.0) Intensity target in place – see section "Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations" Intensity target in place – see table "Allianz 2030 GHG emission reduction targets"
    thereof Allianz Operations
    thereof on balance real assets 36,160.9 31,773.7 13.8 Intensity target in place – see section "Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations" Intensity target in place – see table "Allianz 2030 GHG emission reduction targets"
    Percentage of Scope 1 GHG emissions from regulated emission trading schemes (%) 17,723.7 28,778.8 (38.4)
    Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions 193,109.3 172,407.3 12.0 Intensity target in place – see section "Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations" Intensity target in place – see table "Allianz 2030 GHG emission reduction targets"
    thereof Allianz Operations 118,928.5 112,227.8 6.0
    thereof on balance real assets 74,180.8 60,179.5 23.3
    Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions 58,751.2 45,992.1 27.7 Intensity target in place – see section "Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations" Intensity target in place – see table "Allianz 2030 GHG emission reduction targets"
    thereof Allianz Operations 5,947.0 7,929.2 (25.0)
    thereof on balance real assets 52,804.1 38,062.9 38.7
    Total Gross indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions 48,820,056.5 57,455,746.8 (15.0)

    ```

Les émissions de gaz à effet de serre liées à la Catégorie 15 du GHG Protocol, à savoir les émissions financées, sont incluses dans le portefeuille d'investissements de l'entreprise. Selon les informations disponibles, la Catégorie 15 inclut les émissions de Scope 1 et 2 de leurs entreprises investies. Cependant, il existe une incertitude concernant les données de Scope 3 pour le portefeuille d'entreprises, et les émissions financées sont estimées entre 87 millions et 161 millions de tonnes de CO₂e. Cette large fourchette est due à une sous-déclaration actuelle des émissions de Scope 3 et à des variations significatives dans les estimations des fournisseurs de données.

Concernant les secteurs d'activité et les types d'actifs financés, les émissions financées sont calculées pour les entreprises, les dettes publiques, et l'immobilier détenus au bilan, excluant les produits titrisés comme les ABS/MBS et les Covered Bonds en raison de l'absence de méthodologies pertinentes. Les financements incluent les actions cotées, les obligations d'entreprise, les prêts commerciaux, et les actions non cotées, entre autres.

En résumé, les émissions financées de la Catégorie 15 sont prises en compte dans le portefeuille d'investissements de l'entreprise, bien que des incertitudes demeurent quant aux données de Scope 3, limitant la précision de ces estimations.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM2 :
  • The table below shows GHG emissions from our proprietary investment portfolio mapped to Scope 1, 2, and 3 according to ESRS requirements. Previously, the emissions from so-called on balance real assets held for proprietary investments, such as real estate and infrastructure, have been accounted for in category 15. These are now shown in Scope 1 and 2, as well as in Scope 3 category 13 for real estate. More details on the methodology, assumptions, and scope of these metrics can be found in the section [Methodology information for climate metrics](#). These are now shown in Scope 1 and 2, as well as in Scope 3 category 13 for real estate. More details on the methodology, assumptions, and scope of these metrics can be found in the section [Methodology information for climate metrics](#).
  • Our Scope 3 category 15 emissions currently only include Scope 1 and 2 emissions from our corporate investees. Given the uncertainty about Scope 3 data for the corporates portfolio, we estimate that these financed emissions amount to between 87 mn and 161 mn t CO₂e. This wide range is due to the current underreporting of Scope 3 emissions and significant variations in estimations by data providers. We are committed to closely monitoring this topic while further developing our reporting capability to enhance our disclosure. Given the uncertainty about Scope 3 data for the corporates portfolio, we estimate that these financed emissions amount to between 87 mn and 161 mn t CO₂e. We are committed to closely monitoring this topic while further developing our reporting capability to enhance our disclosure. IFRS 9 asset classes.
  • ## Financed emissions – Proprietary Investments ### General statement The Allianz Group calculates financed emissions for corporates, public debt, and real estate held on the balance sheet, excluding cash and securitized products (like ABS/MBS and Covered Bonds) due to the absence of relevant methodologies. Our methodologies were defined in line with the SFDR Final Report on Draft Regulatory Technical Standards and the NZ AOA Target Setting Protocol. Allianz also strives to meet the recommendations set out in the Global GHG Accounting & Reporting Standard for the Financial Industry (PCAF) to ensure robust climate-related financial reporting. [161] --- --- C_Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement ## Financed emissions – Proprietary Investments ### General statement The Allianz Group calculates financed emissions for corporates, public debt, and real estate held on the balance sheet, excluding cash and securitized products (like ABS/MBS and Covered Bonds) due to the absence of relevant methodologies. Our methodologies were defined in line with the SFDR Final Report on Draft Regulatory Technical Standards and the NZ AOA Target Setting Protocol. Allianz also strives to meet the recommendations set out in the Global GHG Accounting & Reporting Standard for the Financial Industry (PCAF) to ensure robust climate-related financial reporting. [161] --- --- C_Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement
  • To date, we do not calculate financed emissions for covered bonds, ABS/MBS, and cash as there is no methodology available for these asset classes. These asset classes are therefore part of the “no methodology” group in the table “Proprietary investments GHG emissions – split per asset class.” We calculate three types of financed GHG emissions defined by the underlying investment: - **Corporates**, which includes all investees with a balance sheet, i.e. – in PCAF terminology – listed equity and corporate bonds, business loans and non-listed equity, project finance, as well as funds; and - **Real Estate**, which includes real estate equity investments, commercial real estate loans, and retail mortgages, as well as funds; and To date, we do not calculate financed emissions for covered bonds, ABS/MBS, and cash as there is no methodology available for these asset classes.   • ## Methodology – Financed emissions of real estate Financed emissions represent the share of a real estate investment’s GHG emissions that are attributed to the Allianz Group based on the proportion of financing provided by the Allianz Group, relative to the entity’s total value. These emissions are calculated annually. The key inputs to this metric are: - **Investment value (€ Investment):** - Directly Owned Real Estate Equity and Funds: Ownership share based on market value. - Commercial Real Estate Loans and Retail Mortgages: Outstanding loan amount. 162 --- --- ## Methodology – Financed emissions of real estate Financed emissions represent the share of a real estate investment’s GHG emissions that are attributed to the Allianz Group based on the proportion of financing provided by the Allianz Group, relative to the entity’s total value. These emissions are calculated annually. The key inputs to this metric are: - **Investment value (€ Investment):** - Directly Owned Real Estate Equity and Funds: Ownership share based on market value. - Commercial Real Estate Loans and Retail Mortgages: Outstanding loan amount. 162 --- ---
  • ## Scope We use three methodologies for calculating financed emissions, defined by the underlying investments. The table below shows the scope per asset class. Cash, derivatives, and unit-linked products[^1] are excluded from our financed emissions calculation. ## Scope We use three methodologies for calculating financed emissions, defined by the underlying investments. The table below shows the scope per asset class. Cash, derivatives, and unit-linked products[^1] are excluded from our financed emissions calculation.

  • - **Issuer emissions:** Total Scope 1 (direct) and Scope 2 (indirect) emissions of the company as per the GHG Protocol. For Scope 3 emissions we have included an estimate range for the magnitude of the Scope 3 of Scope 3 emissions. We will continue to monitor developments in this area, and develop our disclosures as more robust Scope 3 emissions disclosures become available. For listed equity investments, bonds from and loans to listed and not-listed privately owned corporates as well as corporates owned by sovereigns, sub-sovereigns, and municipals, when no emissions data are available, the issuer (i.e. corporates and corporate-like issuers) is assigned to a NACE sector, and sector average emissions based on the Allianz Group portfolio are calculated by dividing the sum of emissions by the sum of EVIC for companies in the same sector. The sector average is then used to estimate a company’s emissions. For Scope 3 emissions we have included an estimate range for the magnitude of the Scope 3 of Scope 3 emissions. We will continue to monitor developments in this area, and develop our disclosures as more robust Scope 3 emissions disclosures become available. The sector average is then used to estimate a company’s emissions. Investors rely on investees disclosing carbon footprint information, which then
  • ## Scope 3 Inventory When reporting Scope 3 GHG emissions, significance testing must be performed to identify the most significant GHG emission categories and prioritize accordingly for reporting. The following table lists the 15 Scope 3 categories as defined by the GHG Protocol and indicates for each category whether it is significant according to the significance testing conducted above. ## Scope 3 Inventory When reporting Scope 3 GHG emissions, significance testing must be performed to identify the most significant GHG emission categories and prioritize accordingly for reporting. The following table lists the 15 Scope 3 categories as defined by the GHG Protocol and indicates for each category whether it is significant according to the significance testing conducted above.
  • 5. The category employee commuting includes only the emissions from remote work. 6. As there is no guidance on accounting of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) in the GHG Protocol yet, we are disclosing our emissions following GHG Protocol requirements. In addition, we publish our emissions including SAF following a dual reporting approach and in accordance with the World Economic Forum’s Clean Skies for Tomorrow guidance. We anticipate guidance on accounting of SAF to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Our targets are defined considering market-based Scope 2 emissions as well as SAF. --- 5. The category employee commuting includes only the emissions from remote work. 6. In addition, we publish our emissions including SAF following a dual reporting approach and in accordance with the World Economic Forum’s Clean Skies for Tomorrow guidance. We anticipate guidance on accounting of SAF to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Our targets are defined considering market-based Scope 2 emissions as well as SAF. ---

  • ### Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI - **The percentage of derivatives relative to total assets covered by the KPI:** 3.0 - Value in monetary amounts of derivatives: 22.7 - **The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings not subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI:** - For non-financial undertakings : 29.2 - Monetary amount: 220.4 - For financial undertakings : 16.7 - Monetary amount: 126.3 - **The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings from non-EU countries not subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI:** - For non-financial undertakings : 22.8 - Monetary amount: 171.8 - For financial undertakings : 10.2 - Monetary amount: 76.9 ### Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI - **The percentage of derivatives relative to total assets covered by the KPI:** 3.0 - Value in monetary amounts of derivatives: 22.7 - **The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings not subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI:** - For non-financial undertakings : 29.2 - Monetary amount: 220.4 - For financial undertakings : 16.7 - Monetary amount: 126.3 - **The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings from non-EU countries not subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI:** - For non-financial undertakings : 22.8 - Monetary amount: 171.8 - For financial undertakings : 10.2 - Monetary amount: 76.9

Les émissions de gaz à effet de serre liées à la Catégorie 15 du GHG Protocol, qui concerne les émissions financées, sont le résultat des investissements financiers de l'Allianz Group. Voici un résumé des émissions financées selon les informations fournies :

  1. Secteurs d'activité et type d'actifs financés :

    • Corporates : Cela inclut les actions cotées, les obligations d'entreprises, les prêts commerciaux, les actions non cotées, le financement de projets, ainsi que les fonds investissant dans les dettes d'entreprises.
    • Immobilier : Cela inclut les investissements en actions immobilières détenues directement, les prêts immobiliers commerciaux, les hypothèques résidentielles, et les fonds investissant dans la dette immobilière.
    • Dette publique : Cela inclut la dette souveraine, sub-souveraine et supranationale.

  2. Emplacements géographiques :

    • Les informations géographiques précises ne sont pas mentionnées dans les contextes fournis, mais les méthodologies s'alignent sur les exigences de l'ESRS et du SFDR, qui sont généralement appliquées au niveau européen.

  3. Type de financement :

    • Les financements incluent des investissements directs, des prêts et des fonds investissant dans différents types d'actifs.

  4. Disponibilité des données et méthodologies :

    • Les émissions financées pour les actifs comme les obligations couvertes, les ABS/MBS et la trésorerie ne sont pas calculées en raison de l'absence de méthodologies appropriées.
    • Les émissions financées de la catégorie 15 incluent uniquement les émissions de Scope 1 et 2 de leurs portefeuilles d'entreprises, car les données de Scope 3 sont incertaines et sous-déclarées.

Les émissions financées de la catégorie 15 représentent la part des émissions de GES d'un investissement immobilier attribuée au groupe Allianz, basée sur la proportion de financement fourni par le groupe Allianz par rapport à la valeur totale de l'entité.

En résumé, les émissions de la catégorie 15 sont partiellement disponibles pour certains types d'actifs et sont estimées entre 87 et 161 millions de tonnes de CO2e pour le portefeuille des entreprises, en raison de l'incertitude actuelle des données de Scope 3.

Sources Pypdf :
  • The table below shows GHG emissions from our proprietary investment portfolio mapped to Scope 1, 2, and 3 according to ESRS requirements. Previously, the emissions from so-called on balance real assets held for proprietary investments, such as real estate and infrastructure, have been accounted for in category 15. These are now shown in Scope 1 and 2, as well as in Scope 3 category 13 for real estate. More details on the methodology, assumptions, and scope of these metrics can be found in the section Methodology information for climate metrics. Proprietary investments GHG emissions (Scope 1-3) - TOTAL t in CO2e
  • Our Scope 3 category 15 emissions currently only include Scope 1 and 2 emissions from our corporate investees. Given the uncertainty about Scope 3 data for the corporates portfolio, we estimate that these financed emissions amount to between 87 mn and 161 mn t CO2e. This wide range is due to the current underreporting of Scope 3 emissions and significant variations in estimations by data providers. We are committed to closely monitoring this topic while further developing our reporting capability to enhance our disclosure. The tables below show the book value, financed GHG emissions, and coverage (i.e., percentage of book value for which financed GHG emissions are available) in two different asset class splits, incl. IFRS 9 asset classes.

  • ### Methodology Emissions are calculated using a similar approach to that described below in the section on category 15 on Directly Owned Real Estate (Not Fully Consolidated Assets). For fully consolidated downstream leased assets, Allianz recognizes 100% of Scope 3 GHG emissions.
  • - Issuer emissions: Total Scope 1 (direct) and Scope 2 (indirect) emissions of the company as per the GHG Protocol. For Scope 3 emissions we have included an estimate range for the magnitude of the Scope 3 of Scope 3 emissions. We will continue to monitor developments in this area, and develop our disclosures as more robust Scope 3 emissions disclosures become available. For listed equity investments, bonds from and loans to listed and not-listed privately owned corporates as well as corporates owned by sovereigns, sub-sovereigns, and municipals, when no emissions data are available, the issuer (i.e. corporates and corporate-like issuers) is assigned to a NACE sector, and sector average emissions based on the Allianz Group portfolio are calculated by dividing the sum of emissions by the sum of EVIC for companies in the same sector.   • ### Category 13 - Downstream leased assets This refers to the operation of assets owned by an Allianz company (lessor) and leased to other entities in the reporting year. Emissions in this category are those not included in the Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions reported by the lessor, i.e., they are emissions from the lessee over the reporting period, and may also include emissions from sub- leased spaces if under control of the sub-lessee. Downstream leased assets therefore refers to tenant emissions. Where the Allianz Group fully consolidates a real estate investment, we allocate tenants' controlled emissions to Scope 3 category 13.
  • ### Scope We use three methodologies for calculating financed emissions, defined by the underlying investments. The table below shows the scope per asset class. Cash, derivatives, and unit-linked products1 are excluded from our financed emissions calculation.
  • ### Methodology - Financed emissions of real estate Financed emissions represent the share of a real estate investment's GHG emissions that are attributed to the Allianz Group based on the proportion of financing provided by the Allianz Group, relative to the entity's total value. These emissions are calculated annually. The key inputs to this metric are: - Investment value (€ Investment): - Directly Owned Real Estate Equity and Funds: Ownership share based on market value. - Commercial Real Estate Loans and Retail Mortgages: Outstanding loan amount. 1_Unit-linked describes a type of investment, usually offered by a life insurance company, which is essentially a combination of insurance and an investment vehicle.
