    ESRS S1-17 Non-respect of UNGPs on Business and Human Rights and OECD Guidelines, paragraph 104 (a) Material Human rights in own workforce
    ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S2 Significant risk of child labor or forced labor in the value chain, paragraph 11 (b) Material Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain
    ESRS S2-1 Human rights policy commitments, paragraph 18 Material Policies related to workers in the value chain

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité (matériel ou non matériel), ainsi que les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. Les points de données matériels concernent principalement les politiques liées à la biodiversité, l'économie circulaire, la sécurité au travail, les droits humains, les mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, et les écarts de rémunération. Les points non matériels sont considérés comme non applicables.

D'après les informations fournies, l'entreprise Allianz Group ne participe pas à la production ou à la commercialisation d'armes controversées, comme indiqué dans les contextes Num-1 et Num-7. Il n'y a pas d'information dans les extraits concernant une implication dans la culture ou la production de tabac. Concernant la conformité aux principes directeurs de l'OCDE ou aux principes du Pacte mondial des Nations Unies, les documents disponibles ne fournissent pas d'information à cet égard.

De plus, les contextes disponibles ne mentionnent pas spécifiquement que l'entreprise tire au moins 1% de son chiffre d'affaires des énergies fossiles. Cependant, il est mentionné que Allianz restreint les modèles d'affaires liés aux combustibles fossiles, ce qui pourrait indiquer une implication limitée dans ce secteur.

Compte tenu de ces éléments, il n'y a pas suffisamment d'informations pour affirmer que l'entreprise est concernée par les critères d'exclusion des indices de référence de l'Accord de Paris.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM2 :
  • # Restrictions In line with our guidelines on thermal coal, oil sands, and oil and gas, and as we see the future of these business models endangered, we restrict certain fossil fuel companies or projects (divestment for equity and run-off for debt investments). For more details, see section E1 Climate change. Allianz prohibits investments in controversial weapons as defined in the ASIS. Since 2023, we have placed further restrictions on companies not complying with the U.N. Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. --- --- 68 # Restrictions In line with our guidelines on thermal coal, oil sands, and oil and gas, and as we see the future of these business models endangered, we restrict certain fossil fuel companies or projects (divestment for equity and run-off for debt investments). For more details, see section E1 Climate change. Allianz prohibits investments in controversial weapons as defined in the ASIS. Since 2023, we have placed further restrictions on companies not complying with the U.N. Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. --- --- 68
  • ### Restrictions We are also applying the Allianz energy guidelines, which relate to discontinuing restricted business linked to coal assets or companies falling under restriction criteria for thermal coal, oil sands, oil & gas. For further information, please refer to the section *Policy inventory and governance related to Climate Change Mitigation.* ### Restrictions We are also applying the Allianz energy guidelines, which relate to discontinuing restricted business linked to coal assets or companies falling under restriction criteria for thermal coal, oil sands, oil & gas. For further information, please refer to the section *Policy inventory and governance related to Climate Change Mitigation.*
  • ## Restrictions Second, we restrict certain companies in line with our global energy-related guidelines for thermal coal, oil sands, and oil & gas. For further information, please refer to the section [Allianz ESRs policies](#). These restrictions also contribute to the implementation of our sector targets for oil & gas and utilities. All restricted companies are excluded in the Allianz Group Risk Global Restricted (GGRG) List and are shared with all asset managers on a regular basis. Asset managers are obliged to comply with these restrictions. ## Restrictions Second, we restrict certain companies in line with our global energy-related guidelines for thermal coal, oil sands, and oil & gas. For further information, please refer to the section [Allianz ESRs policies](#). These restrictions also contribute to the implementation of our sector targets for oil & gas and utilities. All restricted companies are excluded in the Allianz Group Risk Global Restricted (GGRG) List and are shared with all asset managers on a regular basis. Asset managers are obliged to comply with these restrictions.
  • The three fossil fuel guidelines define business practices and business models where we do not provide further services or investments along defined technical exclusion criteria. They typically differentiate between single-site restrictions – which apply to stand-alone Property-Casualty covers, as well as direct project investments – and restrictions on company-level exposures. To support renewable and low-carbon technologies, we allow ring-fenced coverages of and investments into projects of companies that are otherwise restricted due to the fossil-related energy guidelines. This is described in the Renewable/Low-Carbon Energy Guideline. The guidelines were introduced in 2015 (thermal coal), 2021 (oil sands), 2022 (oil & gas), and 2023 (renewable/low-carbon) respectively. The three fossil fuel guidelines define business practices and business models where we do not provide further services or investments along defined technical exclusion criteria. They typically differentiate between single-site restrictions – which apply to stand-alone Property-Casualty covers, as well as direct project investments – and restrictions on company-level exposures. To support renewable and low-carbon technologies, we allow ring-fenced coverages of and investments into projects of companies that are otherwise restricted due to the fossil-related energy guidelines. This is described in the Renewable/Low-Carbon Energy Guideline. The guidelines were introduced in 2015 (thermal coal), 2021 (oil sands), 2022 (oil & gas), and 2023 (renewable/low-carbon) respectively.
  • For Scope 3, our assessment of potential sources of locked-in emissions from significant categories of Scope 3 emissions is ongoing, and we will consider an approach to specify these over the coming years. Within our operational assets, we consider those which are incompatible with the transition to a climate-neutral economy to be those with locked-in emissions. In our proprietary investment and insurance portfolios, we monitor our exposure to entities which require significant efforts to transition or are incompatible with a climate-neutral economy, and we have implemented actions to manage these. See the sections _Climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio_ and _Climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio_ for more details. Allianz Group does not meet any exclusion criteria stated in Articles 12.1 (d) to (g) and 12.2 of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2020/1818 and is thus not excluded from EU. Paris-aligned benchmarks. Within our operational assets, we consider those which are incompatible with the transition to a climate-neutral economy to be those with locked-in emissions. In our proprietary investment and insurance portfolios, we monitor our exposure to entities which require significant efforts to transition or are incompatible with a climate-neutral economy, and we have implemented actions to manage these. See the sections _Climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio_ and _Climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio_ for more details. Allianz Group does not meet any exclusion criteria stated in Articles 12.1 (d) to (g) and 12.2 of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2020/1818 and is thus not excluded from EU. Paris-aligned benchmarks.
  • - Invest €20 bn in low-carbon solutions to increase our positive impact and seize opportunities; - Align specific high-emitting sectors (oil and gas, utilities (coal), and steel) with IEA Net-Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario to reduce negative impact and risks in our portfolio; - Restrict fossil fuel-related business models in a targeted manner to reduce our risk and negative impact. - Invest €20 bn in low-carbon solutions to increase our positive impact and seize opportunities; - Align specific high-emitting sectors (oil and gas, utilities (coal), and steel) with IEA Net-Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario to reduce negative impact and risks in our portfolio; - Restrict fossil fuel-related business models in a targeted manner to reduce our risk and negative impact.

The guidelines comprise criteria that assist all parties in screening transactions and identifying potential and/or actual sustainability issues.   • Third, of our top 100 portfolio emitters currently not already adequately engaged multilaterally or by our asset managers, we aim to engage bilaterally with 15. We will screen the financed GHG emissions of our portfolio companies to identify those qualifying for engagement, i.e., those with the highest financed GHG emissions that are not already engaged. As many of our high emitters in the portfolio can only decarbonize properly if the sector – including the value chain – has the right technology and economic incentives to do so, we are supportive of high-quality sector engagement initiatives. Sector engagements support our sector targets for 2030, particularly in the steel and oil & gas sectors, as described in the following paragraphs. The progress against our engagement targets can be found in the section **Sustainability integration** in the subsection **Active Engagements**. The progress against our engagement targets can be found in the section **Sustainability integration** in the subsection **Active Engagements**.
  • At the Allianz Group, we conduct due diligence and screening of our business transactions to identify adverse water and marine resource-related impacts, and risk management activities to monitor and mitigate the associated risks. These are outlined in the section [Sustainability integration](#). We will continue to develop our actions to better identify, manage, and mitigate negative impacts and risks associated with water and marine resource use.

  • ### Energy Production #### Scope The scope of energy production for the Allianz Group is consistent with the scope of energy consumption as outlined above. Energy production within the Allianz Group is largely driven by fully owned renewable energy assets within our proprietary investment portfolio (wind and solar parks). In addition to these, some of our offices and real estate assets produce renewable energy. However, the amount produced is not material compared to the energy generated by our renewable energy assets and, as such, will not be reported. #### Methodology Energy production consists of the electricity produced by Allianz’s renewable energy assets and is measured for each underlying wind and solar PV project after losses. As Allianz does not produce non-renewable energy, the total energy production is equal to the total renewable energy production. ### Energy Production #### Scope The scope of energy production for the Allianz Group is consistent with the scope of energy consumption as outlined above. Energy production within the Allianz Group is largely driven by fully owned renewable energy assets within our proprietary investment portfolio (wind and solar parks). In addition to these, some of our offices and real estate assets produce renewable energy. However, the amount produced is not material compared to the energy generated by our renewable energy assets and, as such, will not be reported. #### Methodology Energy production consists of the electricity produced by Allianz’s renewable energy assets and is measured for each underlying wind and solar PV project after losses. As Allianz does not produce non-renewable energy, the total energy production is equal to the total renewable energy production.
  • ## Energy production (E1-5) *mWh* ## Energy production (E1-5) *mWh*

Sur la base des informations fournies, Allianz est concernée par certains critères d'exclusion des indices de référence de l'Accord de Paris. Voici les détails :

  1. Production ou commercialisation d'armes controversées : Allianz interdit les investissements dans les armes controversées, ce qui signifie qu'elle ne participe pas à leur production ou commercialisation.

  2. Culture ou production de tabac : Il n'y a aucune information dans les documents fournis concernant l'implication d'Allianz dans la culture ou la production de tabac.

  3. Respect des principes directeurs de l'OCDE ou du Pacte mondial des Nations Unies : Les documents ne fournissent pas d'informations précises quant au non-respect par Allianz de ces principes.

  4. Chiffre d'affaires tiré des énergies fossiles : Allianz a des restrictions sur les investissements dans certains secteurs fossiles (comme le charbon thermique, le pétrole et le gaz), ce qui indique une certaine implication dans ces secteurs. Cependant, le pourcentage exact du chiffre d'affaires tiré des énergies fossiles n'est pas précisé, donc il est impossible de déterminer si cela représente au moins 1 % du chiffre d'affaires.

En conclusion, Allianz respecte certains critères d'exclusion (armes controversées) mais, en l'absence d'informations précises sur le chiffre d'affaires tiré des énergies fossiles, il est incertain de dire s'ils sont totalement concernés par les critères d'exclusion de l'indice de référence de l'Accord de Paris.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Restrictions In line with our guidelines on thermal coal, oil sands, and oil and gas, and as we see the future of these business models endangered, we restrict certain fossil fuel companies or projects (divestment for equity and run-off for debt investments). For more details, see section E1 Climate change. Allianz prohibits investments in controversial weapons as defined in the ASIS. Since 2023, we have placed further restrictions on companies not complying with the U.N. Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Annual Report 2024 - Allianz Group Sustainability Integration 67
  • ### Restrictions We are also applying the Allianz energy guidelines, which relate to discontinuing restricted business linked to coal assets or companies falling under restriction criteria for thermal coal, oil sands, oil & gas. For further information, please refer to the section Policy inventory and governance related to Climate Change Mitigation.
  • ### Corporates For our corporate portfolio, we have set the following four targets on actions to pull the two decarbonization levers. These actions relate partially to addressing risks and opportunities, in addition to our inside-out impact: - Engage high-emitting companies in our portfolio to increase our positive impact and reduce risks; - Invest € 20 bn in low-carbon solutions to increase our positive impact and seize opportunities; - Align specific high-emitting sectors (oil and gas, utilities (coal), and steel1) with IEA Net-Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario to reduce negative impact and risks in our portfolio; - Restrict fossil fuel-related business models in a targeted manner to reduce our risk and negative impact.
  • ### Restrictions Second, we restrict certain companies in line with our global energy- related guidelines for thermal coal, oil sands, and oil & gas. For further information, please refer to the section Allianz ESRS policies. These restrictions also contribute to the implementation of our sector targets for oil & gas and utilities. All restricted companies are included in the Allianz Group Risk Global Restricted (GRGR) List and are shared with all asset managers on a regular basis. Asset managers are obliged to comply with these restrictions.
  • The three fossil fuel guidelines define business practices and business models where we do not provide further services or investments along defined technical exclusion criteria. They typically differentiate between single-site restrictions - which apply to stand- alone Property-Casualty covers, as well as direct project investments - and restrictions on company-level exposures. To support renewable and low-carbon technologies, we allow ring-fenced coverages of and investments into projects of companies that are otherwise restricted due to the fossil-related energy guidelines. This is described in the Renewable/Low-Carbon Energy Guideline. The guidelines were introduced in 2015 (thermal coal), 2021 (oil sands), 2022 (oil & gas), and 2023 (renewable/ low-carbon) respectively.
  • For Scope 3, our assessment of potential sources of locked-in emissions from significant categories of Scope 3 emissions is ongoing, and we will consider an approach to specify these over the coming years. Within our operational assets, we consider those which are incompatible with the transition to a climate-neutral economy to be those with locked-in emissions. In our proprietary investment and insurance portfolios, we monitor our exposure to entities which require significant efforts to transition or are incompatible with a climate-neutral economy, and we have implemented actions to manage these. See the sections Climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio and Climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio for more details. Allianz Group does not meet any exclusion criteria stated in Articles 12.1 (d) to (g) and 12.2. of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2020/1818 and is thus not excluded from E.U. Paris-aligned benchmarks.

Se menciona la aplicación de la cláusula de salvaguarda según ESRS 2.5(e) en relación con §§ 289e y 315c HGB para la brecha salarial de género en S1-16, sin más detalles.

  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos relacionados con los KPI de Taxonomía para las inversiones del Grupo Allianz en el año 2024. Los encabezados incluyen "Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI" y "Monetary amounts (€ bn)". Los porcentajes y proporciones se desglosan de la siguiente manera: 1. El porcentaje de derivados respecto al total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 3.0%. 2. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas financieras y no financieras no sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU sobre el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 29.2% para empresas no financieras y del 16.7% para empresas financieras. 3. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas financieras y no financieras de países fuera de la UE no sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU es del 22.8% para empresas no financieras y del 10.2% para empresas financieras. 4. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU es del 9.9% para empresas no financieras y del 28.5% para empresas financieras. 5. La proporción de exposiciones a otros contrapartes y activos sobre el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 12.6%. 6. La proporción de inversiones distintas de las mantenidas en contratos de seguros de vida donde el riesgo de inversión es asumido por los asegurados es del 81.4%. 7. El valor de las inversiones que financian actividades económicas no elegibles según la Taxonomía, en relación con el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI, es del 31.1% para el "Turnover" y del 30.5% para el "CAPEX". 8. El valor de las inversiones que financian actividades económicas elegibles según la Taxonomía, pero no alineadas, es del 17.8% para el "Turnover" y del 18.3% para el "CAPEX".
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta los valores de las exposiciones alineadas con la Taxonomía para empresas financieras y no financieras, según los artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU. - **Para empresas no financieras**: - **Turnover**: 8.4 mil millones de euros. - **CAPEX**: 11.2 mil millones de euros. - **Para empresas financieras**: - **Turnover**: 1.2 mil millones de euros. - **CAPEX**: 1.5 mil millones de euros. - **Inversiones de empresas de seguros o reaseguros** (excluyendo contratos de seguros de vida donde el riesgo de inversión recae en los asegurados): - **Turnover**: 9.4 mil millones de euros. - **CAPEX**: 12.4 mil millones de euros. - **Exposiciones alineadas con la Taxonomía respecto a otros contrapartes y activos sobre el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI**: - **Turnover**: 6.4 mil millones de euros. - **CAPEX**: 4.4 mil millones de euros. ### END TABLE

Je ne peux pas déterminer si l'entreprise est concernée par les critères d'exclusion des indices de référence de l'Accord de Paris à partir des informations fournies. Les documents mentionnent certaines restrictions sur les investissements dans les armes controversées et les combustibles fossiles, mais ils ne fournissent pas suffisamment d'informations pour évaluer toutes les caractéristiques spécifiques mentionnées dans la question, telles que l'implication dans la production de tabac ou le respect des principes de l'OCDE et du Pacte mondial des Nations Unies.

  • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.

  • 1_Investments in non -listed asset classes include: real estate, infrastructure, renewable energy, private equity, private placements. human rights violations, and impacts to local communities (for further information, please refer to the Sustainability Integration Framework). The SCL identifies transactions in countries with systematic human rights violations, such as corruption and rule of law, requiring additional human rights due diligence. Criteria to determine sensitive countries are based on international human rights ass essments and indices. The SBA for Defense outlines Allianz ’s position on banned/controversial weapons. Allianz prohibits proprietary investments in and does not insure companies involved in the development, production, maintenance, and trading of certain types of controversial weapons. Banned or controversial weapons are those that fall under the scope of the following international conventions: 1_Investments in non -listed asset classes include: real estate, infrastructure, renewable energy, private equity, private placements. human rights violations, and impacts to local communities (for further information, please refer to the Sustainability Integration Framework). Banned or controversial weapons are those that fall under the scope of the following international conventions:
  • outlined in this section. The ASIS incorporates screening criteria to proactively identify, address, and mitigate business activities that may contribute to negative air, water, and soil (excluding GHG emissions and waste) pollution -related impacts, as part of the referral and due diligence process. Currently, our policy focuses on screening business transactions within the Sensitive Business Areas (SBAs) of Mining, Oil & Gas, Nuclear Energy, Hydro -Electric Power, Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, and Infrastructure. We focus on assessing pollution -related impacts from the inappropriate use of pesticides, fertilizer, insecticides, or other chemicals (e.g., neonicotinoids); the clearance by fire or location on sensitive soils or peatlands for palm oil; the use of cyanide or cyanide - related processes; and practices of riverine or submarine tailings disposal. In doing so, we can also identify the use of SOCs and SVHCs outlined in this section. The ASIS incorporates screening criteria to proactively identify, address, and mitigate business activities that may contribute to negative air, water, and soil (excluding GHG emissions and waste) pollution -related impacts, as part of the referral and due diligence process. Currently, our policy focuses on screening business transactions within the Sensitive Business Areas (SBAs) of Mining, Oil & Gas, Nuclear Energy, Hydro -Electric Power, Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, and Infrastructure. We focus on assessing pollution -related impacts from the inappropriate use of pesticides, fertilizer, insecticides, or other chemicals (e.g., neonicotinoids); the clearance by fire or location on sensitive soils or peatlands for palm oil; the use of cyanide or cyanide - related processes; and practices of riverine or submarine tailings disposal. In doing so, we can also identify the use of SOCs and SVHCs
  • and external stakeholders (NGOs). For each of the twelve SBAs, across “Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry”, “Agricultural Commodities investments”, “Animal Welfare”, “Betting and Gambling”, “Clinical Trials”, “Animal Testing”, “Defense” (which outlines Allianz ’s restrictions for banned/controversial weapons), “Hydro -electric Power”, “Infrastructure”, “Mining”, “Nuclear Energy”, “Oil and Gas”, and “Sex industry”, SBGs were developed based on internationally recognized standards and best practices, such as the International Finance Corporation’s Environmental & Social Performance Standards, International Hydropower Association Sustainability Protocol, and the core ILO conventions. The Guidelines comprise crit eria that assist all parties in screening transactions and identifying potential and/or actual sustainability issues. Examples of screening criteria include impacts to protected areas, deforestation, pollution such as oil spills, and external stakeholders (NGOs).   • are further detailed in the section Allianz ESRS policies ). Within ASIS, Allianz has four energy -related guidelin es in place: thermal coal, oil sands, oil & gas, and renewable/low- carbon energy. The guidelines are owned by Global Sustainability and authorized by the Allianz SE Board of Management. They apply to proprietary investments and commercial P roperty -Casualty insurance, including facultative reinsurance. Their common goals are to contribute to the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy technologies, to manage sustainability and reputational risks, an d to contribute to emission reduction targets for the GHG -intensive parts of our portfolios. The three fossil fuel guidelines define business practices and business models where we do not provide further services or investments along defined technical exclusion criteria. They typically differentiate between single- site restrictions – which apply t o stand- are further detailed in the section Allianz ESRS policies ). Within ASIS, Allianz has four energy -related guidelin es in place: thermal coal, oil sands, oil & gas, and renewable/low- carbon energy. The guidelines are owned by Global Sustainability and authorized by the Allianz SE Board of Management. They apply to proprietary investments and commercial P roperty -Casualty insurance, including facultative reinsurance. Their common goals are to contribute to the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy technologies, to manage sustainability and reputational risks, an d to contribute to emission reduction targets for the GHG -intensive parts of our portfolios. The three fossil fuel guidelines define business practices and business models where we do not provide further services or investments along defined technical exclusion criteria. They typically differentiate between single- site restrictions – which apply t o stand-
  • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management
  • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
  • boundaries reflect minimum decarbonization effort. In 2023, the insurance -associated emission intensity decreased by 16.6 % against the 2022 baseline. This was mainly driven by the customer decarbonization lever. Since our portfolio consists of corporate companies, many of which have seen revenue increases as a downstream effect of increased energy prices and inflation, this effect also contributed to ou r insurance -associated emission intensity decrease. The restrictions based on Allianz ’s energy guidelines further reduced the emissions intensity of the por tfolio by lowering the exposure to high -emitting companies. The emission intensity reduction over 2023 was higher than the expected reductions in subsequent years. E1-16

Décrivez la manière dont le plan de transition pour l'atténuation des risques climatiques est intégré dans la stratégie commerciale globale la planification financière de l'entreprise.

nan

Je suis désolé, mais les informations disponibles ne fournissent pas de détails spécifiques sur la manière dont le plan de transition pour l'atténuation des risques climatiques est intégré dans la stratégie commerciale globale et la planification financière de l'entreprise. Les documents mentionnent diverses actions de décarbonation, des engagements pour la transition vers le net zéro et des stratégies liées au changement climatique, mais ils ne décrivent pas exactement comment ces éléments s'intègrent dans la stratégie commerciale globale ou la planification financière.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau détaille les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) réalisées ou attendues pour les périodes du 1er janvier 2024 au 31 décembre 2024 et du 1er janvier 2025 au 31 décembre 2029. - Les réductions des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base au début de la période sont de (16.6) en 2024 et de (11.7) en 2025-2029. - Pour les clients assurés, l'engagement vers une transition net zéro est non quantifiable, tandis que la décarbonation des clients contribue à une réduction de 0.7 en 2024 et entre (13.5) et (7.5) en 2025-2029. - Les actions de pilotage du portefeuille commercial incluent : - Les solutions bas carbone, avec des réductions de (0.1) en 2024 et entre (5.4) et (3.4) en 2025-2029. - Les restrictions, avec des réductions de (0.2) en 2024 et entre (7.3) et (5.3) en 2025-2029. - Les changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille, avec des réductions de 4.4 en 2024 et entre (13.0) et (11.0) en 2025-2029. - À la fin de la période, les réductions totales des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base sont de (11.7) en 2024 et de (45) en 2025-2029. and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) réalisées ou attendues sur deux périodes : 2024 et 2025-2029. - Au début de la période, les réductions des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base sont de (16.6) pour 2024 et (11.7) pour 2025-2029. - Les actions liées à la décarbonation des clients assurés incluent l'engagement vers une transition net zéro (non quantifiable) et la décarbonation des clients, qui contribue à une réduction de 0.7 en 2024 et entre (13.5) et (7.5) en 2025-2029. - Les actions de pilotage du portefeuille commercial incluent des solutions bas carbone ((0.1) en 2024 et entre (5.4) et (3.4) en 2025-2029), des restrictions ((0.2) en 2024 et entre (7.3) et (5.3) en 2025-2029), et des changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille (4.4 en 2024 et entre (13.0) et (11.0) en 2025-2029). - À la fin de la période, les réductions totales des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base sont de (11.7) pour 2024 et (45) pour 2025-2029.

  • #### Risques : - **Assurance** : Litiges liés au changement climatique, dommages réputationnels, volatilité des ratios de pertes, et défis dans la tarification des risques. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Dégradations des modèles économiques des investees dues aux changements climatiques, réglementaires et comportementaux. - **Opérations propres** : Complexité accrue des opérations et augmentation des coûts de conformité. #### Opportunités : - **Assurance** : Soutien aux clients dans leur transition vers une économie bas carbone via des solutions durables. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Soutien aux investees dans leur transition bas carbone conformément aux objectifs de durabilité d'Allianz. #### Risques : - **Assurance** : Litiges liés au changement climatique, dommages réputationnels, volatilité des ratios de pertes, et défis dans la tarification des risques. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Dégradations des modèles économiques des investees dues aux changements climatiques, réglementaires et comportementaux. - **Opérations propres** : Complexité accrue des opérations et augmentation des coûts de conformité. #### Opportunités : - **Assurance** : Soutien aux clients dans leur transition vers une économie bas carbone via des solutions durables. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Soutien aux investees dans leur transition bas carbone conformément aux objectifs de durabilité d'Allianz.
  • ### Résumé du contenu du tableau Le tableau présente les impacts, risques et opportunités liés aux questions de durabilité pour différents domaines d'activité d'Allianz : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres (y compris la chaîne d'approvisionnement). #### Impacts : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations dues aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires pour s'adapter au changement climatique. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Réduction des rendements des investissements en raison des risques physiques et de transition, affectant les actifs sous-jacents et les chaînes d'approvisionnement. - **Opérations propres** : Augmentation des perturbations opérationnelles et des coûts de conformité en raison des événements climatiques extrêmes et des réglementations liées à la décarbonisation. #### Risques : ### Résumé du contenu du tableau Le tableau présente les impacts, risques et opportunités liés aux questions de durabilité pour différents domaines d'activité d'Allianz : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres (y compris la chaîne d'approvisionnement). #### Impacts : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations dues aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires pour s'adapter au changement climatique. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Réduction des rendements des investissements en raison des risques physiques et de transition, affectant les actifs sous-jacents et les chaînes d'approvisionnement. - **Opérations propres** : Augmentation des perturbations opérationnelles et des coûts de conformité en raison des événements climatiques extrêmes et des réglementations liées à la décarbonisation. #### Risques :
  • Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonisation et les actions associées, ainsi que les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) réalisées et attendues pour deux périodes distinctes : du 1er janvier 2024 au 31 décembre 2024, et du 1er janvier 2025 au 31 décembre 2029. Les colonnes incluent les catégories suivantes : "Decarbonization Levers", "Actions", "Achieved GHG emissions reduction 1.1.2024-31.12.2024", et "Expected change in GHG emissions reduction 1.1.2025-31.12.2029". Les lignes incluent les catégories "Start of period versus baseline", "Corporates - Investee company", "decarbonization", "Corporates - Portfolio steering", et "End of period versus baseline". Les actions incluent des engagements pour la transition vers le net zéro, des investissements dans des solutions bas carbone, des restrictions et des changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille. Les réductions réalisées pour 2024 totalisent (50.7), tandis que les réductions attendues pour 2025-2029 sont estimées à (61.3). Certaines actions, comme les engagements sur la transition net zéro, ne sont pas quantifiables. Les investissements dans des solutions bas carbone ont contribué à une réduction de (0.9) en 2024 et sont attendus pour varier entre 1.6 et 0.4 pour la période 2025-2029. Les changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille ont entraîné une réduction de (3.8) en 2024 et sont estimés entre 4.1 et (2.1) pour 2025-2029. and

    1. La décarbonisation des entreprises investies est incluse au niveau des actions pour garantir l'exhaustivité, car elle contribue à atteindre les objectifs de réduction des émissions. Cependant, elle ne peut pas être attribuée directement au groupe Allianz. 2. Cela inclut tous les autres changements de portefeuille et l'effet des modifications dans l'EVIC des entreprises investies, entraînant une variation de (1.6) %. 3. Les actions incluent des engagements pour la transition vers le net zéro, des investissements dans des solutions bas carbone, des restrictions et des changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille. Les réductions réalisées pour 2024 totalisent (50.7), tandis que les réductions attendues pour 2025-2029 sont estimées à (61.3). Certaines actions, comme les engagements sur la transition net zéro, ne sont pas quantifiables.

  • Le tableau analyse les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés au changement climatique (E1 Climate change) dans quatre domaines d'activité : **Insurance**, **Proprietary investments**, **Asset management** et **Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)**. Résumé : - **Impacts** : Tous les domaines sont marqués comme "Material" avec un impact négatif (-). - **Risques** : Les risques sont considérés comme "Material" pour **Insurance**, **Proprietary investments** et **Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)**, mais "Not material" pour **Asset management**. - **Opportunités** : Les opportunités sont "Material" avec un impact positif (+) pour **Insurance** et **Proprietary investments**, mais elles ne sont pas mentionnées pour **Asset management** ni **Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)**. and

    Le tableau analyse les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés au changement climatique (E1 Climate change) dans différents domaines d'activité : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres d'Allianz (incluant la chaîne d'approvisionnement).
    Résumé : - Impacts : Tous les domaines sont marqués comme "Material" avec un impact négatif (-). - Risques : Les risques sont considérés comme "Material" pour l'assurance, les investissements propriétaires et les opérations propres d'Allianz, mais "Not material" pour la gestion d'actifs. - Opportunités : Les opportunités sont "Material" avec un impact positif (+) pour l'assurance et les investissements propriétaires, mais elles ne sont pas mentionnées pour la gestion d'actifs ni les opérations propres d'Allianz.

  • Le tableau détaille les **questions de durabilité** pour quatre domaines : **assurance**, **investissements propriétaires**, **gestion d'actifs** et **opérations propres (et chaîne d'approvisionnement)**, en distinguant les **impacts**, **risques** et **opportunités**. 1. **Impacts** : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations liée aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires (nouvelles technologies, changements juridiques, comportements clients). - **Investissements propriétaires** : Baisse des rendements due aux risques physiques (événements climatiques) et de transition (changements technologiques, réglementaires, juridiques, comportementaux). - **Opérations propres** : Hausse des perturbations opérationnelles dues aux événements climatiques extrêmes et aux coûts de conformité réglementaire liés à la décarbonisation. 2. **Risques** : - **Assurance** : Volatilité des ratios de pertes, litiges climatiques, dommages réputationnels, et défis liés à l'abordabilité des primes. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Dévalorisation des actifs due aux risques climatiques physiques et aux perturbations de transition. - **Opérations propres** : Complexité accrue et coûts de conformité réglementaire. 3. **Opportunités** : - **Assurance** et **investissements propriétaires** : Soutien à la transition bas-carbone des clients et des investis dans le cadre de la stratégie de durabilité d'Allianz. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    ```markdown

    Sustainability matters Insurance Proprietary investments Asset management Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)
    Impacts Impacts Impacts Impacts
    Risks For our retail and commercial Property-Casualty business, climate change is expected to drive an increase in the frequency and severity of claims. These may be derived from both an increase in policyholders’ exposure to the physical risks of climate change as well as the consequences of transitory measures intended to mitigate or adapt to climate change, such as adopting new technologies, materials or processes with a poorly understood (insured) risk profile, legal developments, or changes in customer behavior. Especially within our Commercial business, insured parties may be subject to climate change-related litigation due to alleged greenwashing incidents, responsibility for damages due to their historical greenhouse gas emissions and other potential issues. For our Retail business, customers may require new products or coverages in response to decarbonization-related lifestyle changes; Allianz may also suffer reputational damage if our own decarbonization efforts fall short of stakeholder expectations. Some risks may be offset with premium increases, but tangential issues such as insurance affordability for customers, difficulty in pricing risks with limited historical risk data, and increased loss-ratio volatility may present challenges. Our proprietary investments may be impacted by adverse developments in investment returns due to physical and transition risks. On the physical side, decreases in investment valuations may be triggered by acute and chronic weather events; both directly in the form of damage to underlying real assets as well as indirectly in the form of disruptions to business continuity, supply chains or resource availability. Decreases in valuation may also occur solely due to an increase in investees’ exposure to physical climate change risks. On the transition side, a combination of climate change-driven changes in technological, regulatory, legal and consumer behavior may adversely impact investment performance insofar as these materially disrupt the business model of investees. This includes, for example, transition-related disruptions to the cost, quality, and availability of inputs an investee relies on to run their business; a significant increase in investees’ regulatory compliance costs or legal losses; or a decrease in customer demand for the investees’ products or services. For our own operations, an increase in extreme weather events may increase the likelihood of operational disruptions, both directly and indirectly. Decarbonization efforts are also acting as a catalyst for broad regulatory changes, including regulations impacting the insurance industry. The design and implementation of processes needed to comply will require investments in employees, external expertise, third party databases, IT systems and more. Together with an increase in operational complexity, such new regulations may drive an increase in compliance costs, business failures and operational losses.
    Opportunities Opportunities are considered material for our insurance portfolio (Property-Casualty retail and commercial) in that we are supporting our customers in their low-carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our Sustainable Solutions and low-carbon solutions. Opportunities are considered material for our proprietary investments in that we are supporting our investees in their low-carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our low-carbon solutions.

    ```

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau détaille les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les changements réalisés ou attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour les périodes 1.1.2024-31.12.2024 et 1.1.2025-31.12.2029, ainsi que les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les leviers incluent : "Start of period versus baseline", "Renewable energy", "Energy efficiency", "Green mobility" et "Other". - Les actions spécifiques comprennent : "Renewable energy", "Renewable electricity", "Reduction of heating energy consumption", "Reduction of electricity consumption", "Green fleet", "Air travel optimization¹", et diverses autres initiatives. - Les changements réalisés dans les émissions de GES pour la période 2024 incluent une réduction totale de 61.5 ktCO2e par rapport au début de la période. - Les changements attendus pour la période 2025-2029 varient selon les leviers et les portées : Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Par exemple, pour "Renewable electricity", les changements attendus sont de (2.9) à 1.1 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales, 1.1 ktCO2e pour Scope 2, et de (1.9) à 1.0 ktCO2e pour Scope 3. - Pour "Reduction of heating energy consumption", les changements attendus sont de 3.0 à 1.0 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales, et de (1.0) à 1.0 ktCO2e pour Scope 1 et Scope 3. - Les leviers "Green mobility" et "Air travel optimization¹" montrent également des réductions significatives, avec des variations selon les portées. - Les initiatives regroupées sous "Other" incluent des ajustements liés à la consommation d'électricité des centres de données, des véhicules de location, du papier, et du cloud, avec des réductions attendues de (2.1) à 1.9 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales. - À la fin de la période, une réduction totale de 65.0 ktCO2e est attendue par rapport au début de la période, avec des impacts spécifiques sur Scope 1 (5.2 ktCO2e), Scope 2 (40.1 ktCO2e), et Scope 3 (19.6 ktCO2e). and

    Renewable energy Renewable electricity 2.3 (2.9) to 1.1 Not applicable 1.1 (1.9) to 1.0
    Energy efficiency Reduction of heating energy consumption (0.4) 3.0 to 1.0 (1.0) to 1.0 Not applicable (1.0) to 1.0
    Reduction of electricity consumption (2.2) (1.2) to 2.9 Not applicable (0.9) to 1.1
    Green mobility Green fleet 1.6 (5.2) to 0.8 (3.4) to (1.4) (1.6) to 0.4

    Other Data center electricity consumption, PCU, rail, rental cars, green fleet adjustments, paper, cloud (0.6) (2.1) to 1.9 Not applicable (0.9) to 1.1
    End of period versus baseline (61.5) (65.0) (5.2) (40.1) (19.6)

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les changements réalisés ou attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour différentes périodes et portées (Scope 1, Scope 2, Scope 3). - Les leviers incluent l'énergie renouvelable, l'efficacité énergétique, la mobilité verte et d'autres initiatives. - Les changements réalisés dans les émissions de GES pour la période 2024 sont détaillés, avec une réduction totale de 61.5 ktCO2e par rapport au début de la période. - Les changements attendus pour la période 2025-2029 sont estimés pour chaque levier, avec des variations dans les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les actions spécifiques incluent l'utilisation d'électricité renouvelable, la réduction de la consommation d'énergie pour le chauffage et l'électricité, l'optimisation des flottes et des voyages aériens, ainsi que des ajustements liés aux centres de données et autres activités.

  • Le tableau présente les impacts cumulés à long terme (5-20 ans) sur les fonds propres selon différents scénarios climatiques. Les scénarios incluent "Net Zero 2050", "Below 2°C", "Delayed Transition", "Nationally Determined Contributions", "Current Policies" et "Fragmented World". 1. Le scénario "Net Zero 2050" prévoit des impacts positifs à moyen et long terme grâce à des politiques climatiques agressives et des progrès technologiques rapides, bien que des pertes mineures soient attendues d'ici 2050. 2. Le scénario "Below 2°C" montre des pertes cumulées relativement faibles dues aux risques de transition, mais des pertes plus importantes liées aux risques physiques à long terme. 3. Le scénario "Delayed Transition" implique des impacts faibles au début, suivis de pertes élevées après 2030 en raison d'une transition retardée et d'une reprise économique lente jusqu'en 2050. 4. Le scénario "Nationally Determined Contributions" présente des impacts similaires à court terme au scénario "Below 2°C", mais des risques physiques plus élevés à long terme en raison de l'absence de mesures politiques supplémentaires. 5. Le scénario "Current Policies" montre des impacts modérés, avec des risques physiques qui augmentent progressivement dans la seconde moitié de la période. 6. Le scénario "Fragmented World" entraîne des impacts élevés après 2030, mais moins prononcés que dans le scénario "Delayed Transition", tout en échouant à limiter efficacement le réchauffement climatique, ce qui entraîne des pertes modérées à importantes à long terme. Les scénarios "Fragmented World", "Current Policies" et "Nationally Determined Contributions" prévoient des pertes croissantes dues aux risques physiques après 2050. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Scenario Long-term 5-20 years Observations
    Net Zero 2050 0.6 The aggressive assumptions in the “Net-Zero 2050” scenario regarding the implementation of climate policies and the pace of technological progress to limit global warming to 1.5 °C result in an initial period of strong economic pressure followed by a rapid economic recovery. Positive cumulative medium- to long-term stress impacts relative to the baseline due to lower energy prices and higher energy efficiency revert to minor losses by 2050.
    Below 2°C (2.4) The orderly implementation of the policy ambition of limiting global warming to below 2 °C is associated with comparatively low cumulative losses from transition risk compared to the “Net-Zero 2050” scenario. This comes at the cost of higher losses from physical risks in the long-term due to higher global warming. In particular, an overall negative trend is predicted for the second half of the century compared to the “Net-Zero 2050” scenario.
    Delayed Transition (12.6) Very slow stress impacts materialize in initial years, followed by high cumulative own funds impacts after 2030 with the start of the delayed transition. This scenario is less ambitious than the “Below 2 °C” scenario. The stress impacts decline only slowly until 2050 due to the sluggish economic recovery in this scenario.
    Nationally Determined Contributions (3.3) In the short term, decarbonization efforts in the “Nationally Determined Contributions” scenario are similar to those in the “Below 2 °C” scenario, leading to comparable impacts from transition risks. However, the absence of additional long-term policy measures implies that global warming cannot be limited to 2 °C, leading to a comparatively larger increase in physical risks.
    Current Policies (5.4) In the absence of stringent climate policy implementation, stress impacts are relatively muted, similar to the “Delayed Transition” scenario, until the second half of the time horizon where stress impacts from physical risk phase in bringing about moderate cumulative own funds impacts by 2050.
    Fragmented World (9.1) High-stress impacts materialize after 2030 in the “Fragmented World” scenario, but somewhat less pronounced than in the “Delayed Transition” scenario due to less aggressive climate policy targets on this stage. However, this scenario fails to effectively limit global warming, resulting in moderate losses from physical risks by 2050. Beyond this period, the “Fragmented World”, “Current Policies” and the “Nationally Determined Contributions” scenarios are expected to entail even more material losses as impacts from physical risks increase and outweigh transition risk impacts.

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente différents scénarios climatiques et leurs impacts cumulés à long terme (5-20 ans) sur les fonds propres. Les scénarios varient en fonction de l'ambition des politiques climatiques et des progrès technologiques. Le scénario "Net Zero 2050" montre des impacts positifs à long terme grâce à une transition rapide et efficace, tandis que les scénarios "Below 2°C" et "Delayed Transition" impliquent des pertes plus importantes dues à des transitions moins ambitieuses ou retardées. Les scénarios "Nationally Determined Contributions", "Current Policies" et "Fragmented World" montrent des impacts croissants liés aux risques physiques, avec des pertes modérées à importantes à long terme.

  • Le tableau présente les thèmes de durabilité, les exigences de divulgation, les sections et les sous-sections associées. Les thèmes principaux incluent le changement climatique (E1), la pollution (E2) et les ressources en eau et marines (E3). Chaque thème est subdivisé en plusieurs sous-sections qui couvrent des aspects tels que les stratégies, les politiques, les actions, les cibles et les métriques liées à la durabilité. Pour le thème E1 – Changement climatique, les sous-sections incluent des stratégies de transition vers le net zéro, des politiques et actions de décarbonisation, des cibles de réduction des émissions de GES, et des métriques climatiques pour le groupe Allianz. Le thème E2 – Pollution aborde les politiques, actions et cibles spécifiques à la pollution. Le thème E3 – Ressources en eau et marines traite des politiques, actions et cibles liées à ces ressources. De plus, les processus d'identification et d'évaluation des impacts matériels, des risques et des opportunités sont mentionnés dans les sous-sections de matérialité (E1 – IRO-1, E2 – IRO-1, E3 – IRO-1). Les informations sont organisées par exigences de divulgation et par sections pour chaque thème. and

Chaque sujet est divisé en plusieurs catégories, telles que la stratégie, la matérialité, les politiques, les actions, les objectifs, et les métriques, afin de fournir une vue complète des impacts, des risques et des opportunités liés à ces domaines.

  • Le tableau présente des données sur la part des véhicules électriques à batterie (BEVs) dans le portefeuille du groupe Allianz et dans ses marchés subsidiaires, ainsi que le ratio entre ces deux parts pour les années 2024, 2023 et l'objectif pour 2030. - En 2024, la **"Share of BEVs in Allianz Group portfolio (%)"** est de 3,2 %, tandis que la **"Share of BEVs in subsidiary markets (%)"** est de 3,0 %. Le **"Ratio (targeting >1) (number)"** est de 1,1. - En 2023, la **"Share of BEVs in Allianz Group portfolio (%)"** est de 2,6 %, contre 1,4 % pour la **"Share of BEVs in subsidiary markets (%)"**. Le **"Ratio (targeting >1) (number)"** est de 1,9. - L'objectif pour 2030 est d'avoir un **"Ratio (targeting >1) (number)"** supérieur à 1. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    2024 2023 2030 target
    Share of BEVs in Allianz Group portfolio (%) 3.2 2.6 -
    Share of BEVs in subsidiary markets (%) 3.0 1.4 -

    Le tableau présente des données sur la part des véhicules électriques à batterie (BEVs) dans le portefeuille du groupe Allianz et dans ses marchés subsidiaires, ainsi que le ratio entre ces deux parts.
    - En 2024, la part des BEVs dans le portefeuille du groupe Allianz est de 3,2 %, tandis que dans les marchés subsidiaires, elle est de 3,0 %. Le ratio est de 1,1. - En 2023, la part des BEVs dans le portefeuille du groupe Allianz est de 2,6 %, contre 1,4 % dans les marchés subsidiaires. Le ratio est de 1,9. - L'objectif pour 2030 est d'avoir un ratio supérieur à 1.

Le plan de transition pour l'atténuation des risques climatiques est intégré dans la stratégie commerciale globale et la planification financière de l'entreprise à travers plusieurs actions stratégiques. Allianz s'engage à atteindre des émissions nettes nulles de gaz à effet de serre pour ses investissements, ses assurances de biens et de responsabilité civile, ainsi que ses propres opérations, comme indiqué dans le contexte 5. Pour concrétiser cette ambition, des objectifs intermédiaires ont été fixés pour 2030, impliquant des actions clés de décarbonisation telles que des restrictions sur les combustibles fossiles, le pilotage stratégique de leurs portefeuilles, l'engagement avec les parties prenantes, l'amélioration de la gestion de l'énergie dans leurs opérations, et le soutien accru aux énergies renouvelables et aux technologies à faible émission de carbone. Le suivi et le rapport réguliers des progrès permettent de s'assurer que l'entreprise reste sur la bonne voie pour atteindre ses objectifs ambitieux, comme noté dans le contexte 6.

  • In the subsequent sections, we outline the integration of the transition plan into our business strategy and how we assess and address the impacts, risks, and opportunities of climate change mitigation. In the subsequent sections, we outline the integration of the transition plan into our business strategy and how we assess and address the impacts, risks, and opportunities of climate change mitigation.
  • We expect climate change will have significant impact on global economies and our business. The risks and opportunities we see emerging today from the transition to a low-carbon economy will transform and increase over the mid to long term, driven through technological progress, changes in consumer sentiment, increasing costs from regulatory compliance on disclosing physical climate risks or operational disruptions caused by more extreme weather events and ecosystem degradation. ¹ Our climate change strategy guides our response to impacts, risks and opportunities to drive decarbonization and climate resilience across our operations and insurance and proprietary investment businesses. Through our resources, partnerships, expertise, and influence, we aim to be a trusted partner for our clients and investee companies across different sectors in their transition toward net-zero. We expect climate change will have significant impact on global economies and our business. The risks and opportunities we see emerging today from the transition to a low-carbon economy will transform and increase over the mid to long term, driven through technological progress, changes in consumer sentiment, increasing costs from regulatory compliance on disclosing physical climate risks or operational disruptions caused by more extreme weather events and ecosystem degradation. ¹ Our climate change strategy guides our response to impacts, risks and opportunities to drive decarbonization and climate resilience across our operations and insurance and proprietary investment businesses. Through our resources, partnerships, expertise, and influence, we aim to be a trusted partner for our clients and investee companies across different sectors in their transition toward net-zero.
  • ## Targets related to climate change adaptation for our insurance portfolio Anticipating and adapting to climate change risks is a strategic focus for Allianz and it is embedded into our strategy and everyday processes. We embed climate change risk and opportunity management into our insurance business by developing and adjusting products and services, updating policies and processes, setting targets and limits, and engaging with internal and external stakeholders. ## Targets related to climate change adaptation for our insurance portfolio Anticipating and adapting to climate change risks is a strategic focus for Allianz and it is embedded into our strategy and everyday processes. We embed climate change risk and opportunity management into our insurance business by developing and adjusting products and services, updating policies and processes, setting targets and limits, and engaging with internal and external stakeholders.

For medium- to long-term risks, mitigation measures can be projects and initiatives that specifically address emerging environmental, social, and governance issues, such as the Green Building Initiative in property insurance. The broad diversification of Allianz’s business model, risk management, and capitalization – combined with the business functions’ assessment of the materiality of sustainability risks and the processes to manage them – confirm the resilience of our strategy and business model in terms of its ability to manage its material sustainability risks.   • # Climate change mitigation ## Climate Change Strategy and Net-Zero Transition **Section summary** Allianz’s net-zero transition plan substantiates our long-term commitments to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions for proprietary investments, Property-Casualty insurance, and own operations. To deliver on our ambition, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, with key decarbonization actions encompassing restrictions on fossil fuels, strategically steering our portfolios, engaging with stakeholders (particularly our clients and investee companies), improving energy management across our operations, and scaling up support of renewable energy and low-carbon technologies. We are on track to achieving our targets. However, the transition will be complex, and we recognize that achieving our net-zero commitment will require significant collaboration with policymakers, regulators, and other key stakeholders to drive the transition. # Climate change mitigation ## Climate Change Strategy and Net-Zero Transition **Section summary** Allianz’s net-zero transition plan substantiates our long-term commitments to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions for proprietary investments, Property-Casualty insurance, and own operations. To deliver on our ambition, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, with key decarbonization actions encompassing restrictions on fossil fuels, strategically steering our portfolios, engaging with stakeholders (particularly our clients and investee companies), improving energy management across our operations, and scaling up support of renewable energy and low-carbon technologies. We are on track to achieving our targets. However, the transition will be complex, and we recognize that achieving our net-zero commitment will require significant collaboration with policymakers, regulators, and other key stakeholders to drive the transition.
  • Strategic actions include supporting and engaging with customers on their decarbonization plans, steering the decarbonization of our portfolios and developing insurance offerings for low-carbon solutions. Progress is regularly monitored and reported, ensuring we remain on track to meet our ambitious targets. Strategic actions include supporting and engaging with customers on their decarbonization plans, steering the decarbonization of our portfolios and developing insurance offerings for low-carbon solutions. Progress is regularly monitored and reported, ensuring we remain on track to meet our ambitious targets.
  • # Climate Change Adaptation ## Climate change adaptation for our insurance portfolio ### Section summary Our strategy on climate change adaptation is guided by our objective to build resilience internally and for our customers. Governed by the ASU, our approach involves identifying, assessing, managing, and monitoring climate risks and opportunities within our insurance portfolio. Although we do not have specific quantifiable targets for climate change adaptation, we leverage our technical excellence using tools such as our Natural Catastrophe Modeling and SPHERE to understand and manage risk exposure. # Climate Change Adaptation ## Climate change adaptation for our insurance portfolio ### Section summary Our strategy on climate change adaptation is guided by our objective to build resilience internally and for our customers. Governed by the ASU, our approach involves identifying, assessing, managing, and monitoring climate risks and opportunities within our insurance portfolio. Although we do not have specific quantifiable targets for climate change adaptation, we leverage our technical excellence using tools such as our Natural Catastrophe Modeling and SPHERE to understand and manage risk exposure.
  • Our ambition is to transition our global proprietary investment portfolio to net-zero by 2050, with the management of climate change risks firmly integrated into our investment processes. For example, we have conducted climate stress testing to understand the physical and transition risks posed to our proprietary investment portfolio; please see the Climate-related risks section for more detail. We consider certain nature-related topics material to our portfolio and are developing a systematic approach for these areas. We implement best practices across all of our asset classes, guided by recommendations from NZAOA, PRI, and the Institutional Investors Group on Climate Change (IIGCC). Described below are the key processes in place to manage sustainability risks, impacts, and opportunities. These are set out in the FRSI described in the section [Allianz Functional Rule for Sustainability in Investments (FRSI)](#). Our ambition is to transition our global proprietary investment portfolio to net-zero by 2050, with the management of climate change risks firmly integrated into our investment processes. For example, we have conducted climate stress testing to understand the physical and transition risks posed to our proprietary investment portfolio; please see the Climate-related risks section for more detail.
