    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques éligibles à la taxonomie mais non alignées avec celle-ci, selon différentes sections des annexes I et II du règlement délégué 2021/2139. - Les colonnes incluent les montants et proportions pour l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM) et l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA). - La plupart des lignes indiquent des montants et proportions nuls, sauf pour la ligne 5 où un montant de 0.1 est mentionné. - La ligne 8 résume les totaux, avec un montant de 137.7 et une proportion de 18.3 pour CCM + CCA.

  • ### Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les ratios et les montants monétaires relatifs aux actifs couverts par les indicateurs clés de performance (KPI) du groupe Allianz, conformément à la réglementation sur la taxonomie. Les informations incluent : - Les ratios pour le chiffre d'affaires (2.1%) et les dépenses d'investissement (CAPEX, 2.3%). - La valeur monétaire totale des actifs couverts par le KPI (71.5%). - Les montants monétaires des dérivés (3.0%). - Les proportions des expositions à des entreprises financières et non financières, classées selon leur conformité ou non aux articles 19a et 29a de la directive 2013/34/EU, ainsi que leur origine (UE ou hors UE). - Les expositions à d'autres contreparties et actifs (12.6%). - Les investissements dans des activités économiques non éligibles à la taxonomie (31.1% pour le chiffre d'affaires et 30.5% pour le CAPEX). ### Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les ratios et les montants monétaires relatifs aux actifs couverts par les indicateurs clés de performance (KPI) du groupe Allianz, conformément à la réglementation sur la taxonomie. Les informations incluent : - Les ratios pour le chiffre d'affaires (2.1%) et les dépenses d'investissement (CAPEX, 2.3%). - La valeur monétaire totale des actifs couverts par le KPI (71.5%). - Les montants monétaires des dérivés (3.0%). - Les proportions des expositions à des entreprises financières et non financières, classées selon leur conformité ou non aux articles 19a et 29a de la directive 2013/34/EU, ainsi que leur origine (UE ou hors UE). - Les expositions à d'autres contreparties et actifs (12.6%). - Les investissements dans des activités économiques non éligibles à la taxonomie (31.1% pour le chiffre d'affaires et 30.5% pour le CAPEX).
  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques éligibles à la taxonomie mais non alignées à celle-ci, selon différentes sections des annexes I et II du règlement délégué 2021/2139. - Les colonnes incluent : "CAPEX", "CCM + CCA Amount", "CCM + CCA %", "Climate change mitigation (CCM) Amount", "Climate change mitigation (CCM) %", "Climate change adaptation (CCA) Amount", et "Climate change adaptation (CCA) %". - Les lignes 1, 2, 3, 5, 6 et 7 indiquent des montants et proportions nuls ("-") pour les activités économiques éligibles. - La ligne 4 mentionne un montant de 0.1 et une proportion de 0.01 pour les activités liées à l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM). - La ligne 8 résume le total des montants et proportions des activités éligibles mais non alignées, avec un montant total de 114.7 et une proportion de 15.46 %. - Les données pour "CCM" et "CCA" dans la ligne 8 sont marquées comme "n.a." (non disponibles). - Le tableau est basé sur le modèle "Template 4 2023" et concerne les activités économiques éligibles mais non alignées à la taxonomie. - Les informations sont liées au rapport annuel 2024 du groupe Allianz. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Row Economic activities CAPEX CCM + CCA Amount CCM + CCA % Climate change mitigation (CCM) Amount Climate change mitigation (CCM) % Climate change adaptation (CCA) Amount Climate change adaptation (CCA) %
    1 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.26 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI - - - - - - -
    2 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.27 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI - - - - - - -
    3 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.28 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI - - - - - - -
    4 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.29 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI 0.1 0.01 0.1 0.01 - -
    5 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.30 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI - - - - - - -

    8 Total amount and proportion of taxonomy eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activities in the denominator of the applicable KPI 114.7 15.46 n.a. n.a. n.a. n.a.

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques éligibles à la taxonomie mais non alignées à celle-ci, selon différentes sections des annexes I et II du règlement délégué 2021/2139. - La majorité des lignes indiquent des montants et proportions nuls pour les activités économiques éligibles. - Une seule ligne (ligne 4) mentionne un montant de 0.1 et une proportion de 0.01 pour les activités liées à l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM). - La ligne 8 résume le total des montants et proportions des activités éligibles mais non alignées, avec un montant total de 114.7 et une proportion de 15.46 %. Les données pour CCM et CCA ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.).

  • Le tableau présente les objectifs de réduction des émissions de CO₂ d'Allianz pour ses propres opérations, ses investissements propriétaires et ses activités d'assurance, avec des valeurs de référence, des performances pour 2023 et 2024, ainsi que des écarts en pourcentage par rapport aux valeurs de référence. Les objectifs pour 2030 et les écarts prévus par rapport aux valeurs de référence sont également inclus. - **Allianz Own Operations** : Les émissions de CO₂ par employé (kg CO₂e/employee) ont diminué de 61,5 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2,366.7, avec un objectif de 828.3 kg CO₂e/employee en 2030, soit une réduction de 65 %. - **Proprietary Investments** : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros investi (t CO₂e/mn € invested) ont baissé de 46,5 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 108.1, avec un objectif de 54.0 en 2030, soit une réduction de 50 %. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ des entreprises cotées (mn t CO₂) ont diminué de 50,7 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 24.9, avec un objectif de 12.5 en 2030, soit une réduction de 50 %. - Les émissions de CO₂ par m² pour l'immobilier (kg CO₂e/m²) sont de 33.5 en 2023, avec un objectif d'environ 20 kg CO₂e/m² en 2030. - **Insurance** : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros de primes d'assurance commerciale (kt CO₂e/mn € Insurance Premium) ont baissé de 11,7 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 0.26, avec un objectif de 0.14 en 2030, soit une réduction de 45 %. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ pour le secteur automobile de détail (mn t CO₂) ont diminué de 6,8 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2.10, avec un objectif de 1.47 en 2030, soit une réduction de 30 %. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Target unit Baseline value 2024 2023 Delta current year vs baseline in % 2030 target Delta 2030 target vs baseline in %
    Allianz Own Operations
    Allianz Own Operations kg CO₂e/employee 2,366.7 924.1 893.8 (61.5) 828.3 (65)
    Proprietary Investments
    Corporates¹ t CO₂e/mn € invested 108.1 57.8 71.2 (46.5) 54.0 (50)
    Listed Corporates¹ mn t CO₂ 24.9 12.3 14.0 (50.7) 12.5 (50)
    Real Estate²,³,⁴ kg CO₂e/m² 21.0 33.5 ca. 20
    Insurance
    Commercial kt CO₂e/mn € Insurance Premium 0.26 0.23 0.22 (11.7) 0.14 (45)
    Motor Retail mn t CO₂ 2.10 1.95 2.03 (6.8) 1.47 (30)

    Le tableau présente les progrès réalisés par Allianz en vue d'atteindre ses objectifs intermédiaires pour 2030 dans différents domaines, notamment ses propres opérations, ses investissements propriétaires et ses activités d'assurance. Les données incluent les valeurs de référence, les performances pour 2023 et 2024, ainsi que les écarts par rapport aux valeurs de référence en pourcentage. Les objectifs pour 2030 sont également indiqués, accompagnés des écarts prévus par rapport aux valeurs de référence.
    - Allianz Own Operations : Les émissions de CO₂ par employé ont diminué de 61,5 % par rapport à la valeur de référence, avec un objectif de réduction de 65 % d'ici 2030. - Proprietary Investments : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros investi ont baissé de 46,5 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 50 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ des entreprises cotées ont diminué de 50,7 %, avec un objectif similaire pour 2030. - Les émissions de CO₂ par m² pour l'immobilier sont en cours de suivi, avec un objectif d'environ 20 kg CO₂e/m² d'ici 2030. - Insurance : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros de primes d'assurance commerciale ont baissé de 11,7 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 45 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ pour le secteur automobile de détail ont diminué de 6,8 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 30 % d'ici 2030.

Je ne sais pas. Les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur les plans de dépenses de l'entreprise visant à augmenter ses activités alignées à la Taxonomie européenne, notamment en ce qui concerne les dépenses d'investissement (CAPEX) et les dépenses opérationnelles (OPEX) pour développer ses activités durables.

  • ### Template 2023: The proportion of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking's investments that are directed at funding, or are associated with, Taxonomy-aligned economic activities in relation to total investments – part I #### Allianz Group reporting under the Taxonomy Regulation ###### Ratios (relative to total assets covered by the KPI) in % #### Beginning of Table - **Turnover**: 1.49 - **CAPEX**: 2.02 - **Monetary amounts (€ bn)** - Turnover: 11.0 - CAPEX: 15.0 #### Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI - The weighted average value of all the investments of insurance or reinsurance undertakings that are directed at funding, or are associated with Taxonomy-aligned economic activities relative to the value of total assets covered by the KPI, with following weights for investments in undertakings per below: - **Turnover** - **CAPEX** ### Template 2023: The proportion of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking's investments that are directed at funding, or are associated with, Taxonomy-aligned economic activities in relation to total investments – part I #### Allianz Group reporting under the Taxonomy Regulation ###### Ratios (relative to total assets covered by the KPI) in % #### Beginning of Table - **Turnover**: 1.49 - **CAPEX**: 2.02 - **Monetary amounts (€ bn)** - Turnover: 11.0 - CAPEX: 15.0 #### Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI - The weighted average value of all the investments of insurance or reinsurance undertakings that are directed at funding, or are associated with Taxonomy-aligned economic activities relative to the value of total assets covered by the KPI, with following weights for investments in undertakings per below: - **Turnover** - **CAPEX**
  • - Action plans are defined to address medium and high risks, incl. process tracking. There are processes in place to ensure monitoring of these components across the Allianz Group, which are outlined in more detail in the section Human rights in own workforce. Moreover, most Allianz subsidiaries have implemented local OHS management systems to effectively address OHS matters. These systems include OHS risk and hazard assessments, dedicated action plans to mitigate these risks, and protocols for emergency actions. Internal inspections are conducted and progress in reducing and preventing health issues and risks is evaluated against set targets. This encompasses procedures for investigating work-related injuries, ill health, diseases, and incidents, and regular workforce training to enhance awareness and reduce operational health and safety incidents. - Action plans are defined to address medium and high risks, incl. process tracking. There are processes in place to ensure monitoring of these components across the Allianz Group, which are outlined in more detail in the section Human rights in own workforce. Moreover, most Allianz subsidiaries have implemented local OHS management systems to effectively address OHS matters. These systems include OHS risk and hazard assessments, dedicated action plans to mitigate these risks, and protocols for emergency actions. Internal inspections are conducted and progress in reducing and preventing health issues and risks is evaluated against set targets. This encompasses procedures for investigating work-related injuries, ill health, diseases, and incidents, and regular workforce training to enhance awareness and reduce operational health and safety incidents.
  • The required target will vary from year to year as progress will be tracked against the percentage of BEVs in the respective markets, which is a variable factor. We have partnered with a reliable external data provider to obtain data on the in-scope markets and ensure consistency in data collection across markets and across years. The targets have been discussed in collaboration with subsidiaries and Mobility Initiative Steering Committee members. As part of the initiative, subsidiaries have provided action plans which aim to ensure they embed initiatives which improve Allianz’s reputation in mobility insurance within their respective markets. These mobility action plans are aligned with the more comprehensive decarbonization roadmaps, which detail all actions planned to reach our 2030 targets. The Group has again used established reporting processes to track progress against these planned initiatives. The required target will vary from year to year as progress will be tracked against the percentage of BEVs in the respective markets, which is a variable factor. We have partnered with a reliable external data provider to obtain data on the in-scope markets and ensure consistency in data collection across markets and across years. The targets have been discussed in collaboration with subsidiaries and Mobility Initiative Steering Committee members. As part of the initiative, subsidiaries have provided action plans which aim to ensure they embed initiatives which improve Allianz’s reputation in mobility insurance within their respective markets. These mobility action plans are aligned with the more comprehensive decarbonization roadmaps, which detail all actions planned to reach our 2030 targets. The Group has again used established reporting processes to track progress against these planned initiatives.
  • ## Main lobbying activities Our lobbying activities in 2024 included the following main topics: - **Solvency II** is the prudential regime for insurance undertakings in the E.U. With regard to the recently adopted amendments to the Solvency II Directive (“Solvency II review”), Allianz generally shares the positions of the German Insurance Association (GDV) and Insurance Europe. Particularly, the accurate calibration of risk parameters is of importance. - **The Insurance Recovery and Resolution Directive (IRRD)** introduces the obligation to draw up recovery and resolution plans for the insurance sector. With regard to the structure of the plans, Allianz generally shares the positions of the GDV and Insurance Europe. From Allianz’s point of view, legal certainty regarding the requirements for the preparation of (Group) recovery plans and a practical design for the intervention rights of the resolution authorities are of particular importance. ## Main lobbying activities Our lobbying activities in 2024 included the following main topics: - **Solvency II** is the prudential regime for insurance undertakings in the E.U. With regard to the recently adopted amendments to the Solvency II Directive (“Solvency II review”), Allianz generally shares the positions of the German Insurance Association (GDV) and Insurance Europe. Particularly, the accurate calibration of risk parameters is of importance. - **The Insurance Recovery and Resolution Directive (IRRD)** introduces the obligation to draw up recovery and resolution plans for the insurance sector. With regard to the structure of the plans, Allianz generally shares the positions of the GDV and Insurance Europe. From Allianz’s point of view, legal certainty regarding the requirements for the preparation of (Group) recovery plans and a practical design for the intervention rights of the resolution authorities are of particular importance.
  • Recognizing the importance of addressing the avoidance, control, and limitation of emergency situations, the **ASIS** also screens business activities in Oil & Gas to identify the lack of spill management, response, and remediation plans in line with industry best practices such as the IPIECA Oil & Gas Industry Guidance on Voluntary Sustainable Reporting and the Extractive Industry Transparency Initiative. For more information on the **ASIS**, the referral process, and how we measure and track the effectiveness of our policies, please refer to section [Sustainability integration](#). Recognizing the importance of addressing the avoidance, control, and limitation of emergency situations, the **ASIS** also screens business activities in Oil & Gas to identify the lack of spill management, response, and remediation plans in line with industry best practices such as the IPIECA Oil & Gas Industry Guidance on Voluntary Sustainable Reporting and the Extractive Industry Transparency Initiative. For more information on the **ASIS**, the referral process, and how we measure and track the effectiveness of our policies, please refer to section [Sustainability integration](#).

Je ne sais pas. Les documents fournis ne mentionnent pas spécifiquement les plans de dépenses de l'entreprise visant à augmenter ses activités alignées à la Taxonomie européenne, ni les détails sur les dépenses d'investissement (CAPEX) et les dépenses opérationnelles (OPEX) pour développer ses activités durables.

  • ### Summary of the Table: The table titled "Template 3 2024: Taxonomy-aligned economic activities (numerator) - CAPEX" presents data on economic activities aligned with the E.U. Taxonomy for the year 2024. It includes the following labels: "Economic activities," "CAPEX," "Amount and proportion (the information is to be presented in monetary amounts and as percentages)," "CCM + CCA," "Climate change mitigation (CCM)," and "Climate change adaptation (CCA)." The rows are numbered from 1 to 8, with an additional row for totals. 1. **Row 1**: No data is provided for taxonomy-aligned activities under Section 4.26. 2. **Row 2**: Activities under Section 4.27 show an amount of 0.1 (monetary) and 0.5% for both CCM and CCA. 3. **Row 3**: Activities under Section 4.28 show an amount of 0.3 (monetary) and 1.6% for both CCM and CCA. 4. **Row 4**: Activities under Section 4.29 show no monetary amount for CCM and 0.1% proportion. 5. **Row 5**: Activities under Section 4.30 show no monetary amount for CCM and 0.1% proportion. 6. **Row 6**: Activities under Section 4.31 show an amount of 0.1 (monetary) and 0.6% for both CCM and CCA. 7. **Row 7**: Other taxonomy-aligned activities not listed in rows 1–6 show an amount of 16.6 (monetary) and 97.2% for CCM, and 0.1 (monetary) and 100.0% for CCA. 8. **Row 8**: The total amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned activities are 17.1 (monetary) and 100.0% for CCM, and 17.0 (monetary) and 100.0% for CCA, with 0.1 (monetary) and 100.0% for CCA. The table provides a comprehensive breakdown of CAPEX amounts and proportions for taxonomy-aligned activities in 2024.

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos sobre la intensidad de gases de efecto invernadero (GHG) y el volumen total de negocios de Allianz Group al 31 de diciembre de 2024 y 2023. - **Etiquetas de columnas**: "0", "1", "2", "3". - **Etiquetas de filas**: "As of 31 December", "Total business volume1", "Total GHG emissions (market-based)2", "GHG intensity (market-based)", "Total GHG emissions (location-based)2", "GHG intensity (location-based)". - **Años**: 2024 y 2023. **Datos clave**: 1. El volumen total de negocios ("Total business volume1") fue de **179,777.8 mn €** en 2024 y **161,700.0 mn €** en 2023. 2. Las emisiones totales de GHG basadas en el mercado ("Total GHG emissions (market-based)2") fueron de **48,932,692.3 t en CO2e** en 2024 y **57,562,291.4 t en CO2e** en 2023. 3. La intensidad de GHG basada en el mercado ("GHG intensity (market-based)") fue de **272.2 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2024 y **356.0 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2023. 4. Las emisiones totales de GHG basadas en la ubicación ("Total GHG emissions (location-based)2") fueron de **49,067,050.4 t en CO2e** en 2024 y **57,688,706.5 t en CO2e** en 2023. 5. La intensidad de GHG basada en la ubicación ("GHG intensity (location-based)") fue de **272.9 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2024 y **356.8 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2023. ### END TABLE
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre "Economic activities" y su alineación con la taxonomía en términos de "Turnover" para el año 2024. Las columnas incluyen "Amount and proportion (the information is to be presented in monetary amounts and as percentages)", desglosadas en "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila 1, las actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía según la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 2. En la fila 2, las actividades según la Sección 4.27 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 3. En la fila 3, las actividades según la Sección 4.28 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.4 (2.4% para CCM). 4. En la fila 4, las actividades según la Sección 4.29 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 5. En la fila 5, las actividades según la Sección 4.30 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.3 (0.3% para CCM). 6. En la fila 6, las actividades según la Sección 4.31 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 7. En la fila 7, otras actividades alineadas con la taxonomía no incluidas en las filas 1 a 6 reportan un "Turnover" de 15.5 (97.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA). 8. En la fila 8, el total de actividades alineadas con la taxonomía reporta un "Turnover" de 16.0 (100.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA).
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta actividades relacionadas con la energía nuclear y el gas fósil en el año 2023. **Etiquetas y columnas:** - **Columnas:** "0", "1", "2". - **Filas:** "Row", "Nuclear energy related activities", "Fossil gas related activities". **Actividades relacionadas con la energía nuclear:** 1. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en investigación, desarrollo, demostración y despliegue de instalaciones innovadoras de generación de electricidad que producen energía a partir de procesos nucleares con residuos mínimos del ciclo de combustible. **Estado:** NO. 2. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción y operación segura de nuevas instalaciones nucleares para producir electricidad o calor de proceso, incluyendo calefacción distrital, procesos industriales como la producción de hidrógeno, y mejoras de seguridad utilizando las mejores tecnologías disponibles. 3. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la operación segura de instalaciones nucleares existentes que producen electricidad o calor de proceso, incluyendo calefacción distrital, procesos industriales como la producción de hidrógeno a partir de energía nuclear, y mejoras de seguridad. **Actividades relacionadas con el gas fósil:** 4. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción u operación de instalaciones de generación de electricidad que producen electricidad utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. 5. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción, renovación y operación de instalaciones de generación combinada de calor/frío y electricidad utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. 6. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción, renovación y operación de instalaciones de generación de calor/frío utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. ### END TABLE
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre "Economic activities" y "CAPEX" en el contexto de actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía para el año 2023. Los datos están organizados en las siguientes columnas: "Row", "Economic activities", "CAPEX", "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila "1.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos disponibles ("-"). 2. En la fila "2.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.27 muestran un "Amount" de 0.0 y un porcentaje de 0.01% tanto para CCM como para CCA. 3. En la fila "3.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.28 tienen un "Amount" de 0.3 y un porcentaje de 0.04% tanto para CCM como para CCA. 4. Las filas "4.", "5." y "6." (Secciones 4.29, 4.30 y 4.31) no tienen datos disponibles ("-"). 5. En la fila "7.", las actividades alineadas no incluidas en las filas anteriores tienen un "Amount" de 14.7 (1.98%), con 13.5 (1.82%) para CCM y 0.8 (0.11%) para CCA. 6. En la fila "8.", el "Total applicable KPI" es de 741.9, pero no hay datos disponibles ("n.a.") para CCM y CCA. Notas adicionales: "n.a." indica información no disponible, y no se asignaron cuotas de alineación a objetivos climáticos o actividades nucleares/gas debido a limitaciones de datos.

Je ne sais pas. Les documents fournis ne mentionnent pas de détails spécifiques sur les plans de l'entreprise concernant l'augmentation de ses activités alignées sur la Taxonomie européenne en termes de dépenses d'investissement (CAPEX) et de dépenses opérationnelles (OPEX).

  • C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement 184 Annual Report 2024 − Allianz Group E.U.   • For 2024, Allianz has followed the disclosure guidance for insurer investment KPIs detailed in Annex IX/X of the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/ 2178 ( Disclosure Delegated Act). As mentioned earlier, the main changes regarding the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/1214 are the introduction of alignment KPIs (by turnover and CAPEX) and the separate tables required for nuclear/gas exposures. For Taxonomy reporting in 2024, there were some changes to how Allianz presents its numbers. The first change relates to the exclusion of investments which do not meet the IFRS definition of cash and cash equivalents (mainly cash deposits with a maturity between 3 months and one year or cash collaterals received on securities borrowing) but are co nsidered as cash equivalents by Allianz as these investments will never deploy a Taxonomy -aligned activity. After reassessing the E.U. Taxonomy Regulation, Allianz has determined that cash and cash equivalents For 2024, Allianz has followed the disclosure guidance for insurer investment KPIs detailed in Annex IX/X of the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/ 2178 ( Disclosure Delegated Act). As mentioned earlier, the main changes regarding the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/1214 are the introduction of alignment KPIs (by turnover and CAPEX) and the separate tables required for nuclear/gas exposures. For Taxonomy reporting in 2024, there were some changes to how Allianz presents its numbers. The first change relates to the exclusion of investments which do not meet the IFRS definition of cash and cash equivalents (mainly cash deposits with a maturity between 3 months and one year or cash collaterals received on securities borrowing) but are co nsidered as cash equivalents by Allianz as these investments will never deploy a Taxonomy -aligned activity. After reassessing the E.U. Taxonomy Regulation, Allianz has determined that cash and cash equivalents
  • the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime

The target is s et in line with the CRREM pathways, therefore the basis for th e target setting is the pathways and not a baseline value. Proprietary Investments Corporates1 t CO 2e/mn € invested 108.1 57.8 71.2 (46.5) 54.0 (50) Listed Corporates1 mn t CO 2e 24.9 12.3 14.0 (50.7) 12.5 (50) Real Estate2,3,4 kg CO 2e/m2 21.0 33.5 ca. 20 Insurance Commercial kt CO 2e/mn € Insurance Premium 0.26 0.23 0.22 (11.7) 0.14 (45) Motor Retail mn t CO 2 2.10 1.95 2.03 (6.8) 1.47 (30) 1_Both corporate targets exclude investments which qualify for the Allianz Steel and Cement Climate List. 2_ Including our portfolio managed by PIMCO Prime Real Estate (PPRE) and the direct portfolio of Allianz Switzerland. The target is s et in line with the CRREM pathways, therefore the basis for th e target setting is the pathways and not a baseline value.
  • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.
  • system, established in 2024, is built along the following components for applicable subsidiaries : − Dedicated GSCA Risk Experts, responsible for OHS are identified. − Health & Safety risk assessments are conducted at least annually, covering physical safety, workplace safety, and mental health. − Action plans are defined to address medium and high risks, incl. process tracking. There are processes in place to ensure monitoring of these components across the Allianz Group , which are outlined in more detail in the section Human rights in own workforce. M oreover, most Allianz subsidiaries have implemented local OHS management systems to effectively address OHS matters. These systems include OHS risk and hazards assessments, dedicated action plans to mitigate these risks, and protocols for emergency actions. Internal inspections are conduct ed and progress in reducing and preventing health issues system, established in 2024, is built along the following components for applicable subsidiaries : − Dedicated GSCA Risk Experts, responsible for OHS are identified. − Health & Safety risk assessments are conducted at least annually, covering physical safety, workplace safety, and mental health. − Action plans are defined to address medium and high risks, incl. process tracking. There are processes in place to ensure monitoring of these components across the Allianz Group , which are outlined in more detail in the section Human rights in own workforce. M oreover, most Allianz subsidiaries have implemented local OHS management systems to effectively address OHS matters. These systems include OHS risk and hazards assessments, dedicated action plans to mitigate these risks, and protocols for emergency actions. Internal inspections are conduct ed and progress in reducing and preventing health issues
E1-185

Quelle est la proportion d'actifs exposés à un risque physique important avant prise en compte des mesures d'adaptation au changement climatique ?

nan

Je ne sais pas. Les informations sur la proportion d'actifs exposés à un risque physique important avant prise en compte des mesures d'adaptation au changement climatique ne sont pas disponibles dans les documents fournis.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Le tableau présente les impacts cumulés à long terme (5-20 ans) sur les fonds propres selon différents scénarios climatiques. Les scénarios incluent "Net Zero 2050", "Below 2°C", "Delayed Transition", "Nationally Determined Contributions", "Current Policies" et "Fragmented World". 1. Le scénario "Net Zero 2050" prévoit des impacts positifs à moyen et long terme grâce à des politiques climatiques agressives et des progrès technologiques rapides, bien que des pertes mineures soient attendues d'ici 2050. 2. Le scénario "Below 2°C" montre des pertes cumulées relativement faibles dues aux risques de transition, mais des pertes plus importantes liées aux risques physiques à long terme. 3. Le scénario "Delayed Transition" implique des impacts faibles au début, suivis de pertes élevées après 2030 en raison d'une transition retardée et d'une reprise économique lente jusqu'en 2050. 4. Le scénario "Nationally Determined Contributions" présente des impacts similaires à court terme au scénario "Below 2°C", mais des risques physiques plus élevés à long terme en raison de l'absence de mesures politiques supplémentaires. 5. Le scénario "Current Policies" montre des impacts modérés, avec des risques physiques qui augmentent progressivement dans la seconde moitié de la période. 6. Le scénario "Fragmented World" entraîne des impacts élevés après 2030, mais moins prononcés que dans le scénario "Delayed Transition", tout en échouant à limiter efficacement le réchauffement climatique, ce qui entraîne des pertes modérées à importantes à long terme. Les scénarios "Fragmented World", "Current Policies" et "Nationally Determined Contributions" prévoient des pertes croissantes dues aux risques physiques après 2050. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Scenario Long-term 5-20 years Observations
    Net Zero 2050 0.6 The aggressive assumptions in the “Net-Zero 2050” scenario regarding the implementation of climate policies and the pace of technological progress to limit global warming to 1.5 °C result in an initial period of strong economic pressure followed by a rapid economic recovery. Positive cumulative medium- to long-term stress impacts relative to the baseline due to lower energy prices and higher energy efficiency revert to minor losses by 2050.
    Below 2°C (2.4) The orderly implementation of the policy ambition of limiting global warming to below 2 °C is associated with comparatively low cumulative losses from transition risk compared to the “Net-Zero 2050” scenario. This comes at the cost of higher losses from physical risks in the long-term due to higher global warming. In particular, an overall negative trend is predicted for the second half of the century compared to the “Net-Zero 2050” scenario.
    Delayed Transition (12.6) Very slow stress impacts materialize in initial years, followed by high cumulative own funds impacts after 2030 with the start of the delayed transition. This scenario is less ambitious than the “Below 2 °C” scenario. The stress impacts decline only slowly until 2050 due to the sluggish economic recovery in this scenario.
    Nationally Determined Contributions (3.3) In the short term, decarbonization efforts in the “Nationally Determined Contributions” scenario are similar to those in the “Below 2 °C” scenario, leading to comparable impacts from transition risks. However, the absence of additional long-term policy measures implies that global warming cannot be limited to 2 °C, leading to a comparatively larger increase in physical risks.
    Current Policies (5.4) In the absence of stringent climate policy implementation, stress impacts are relatively muted, similar to the “Delayed Transition” scenario, until the second half of the time horizon where stress impacts from physical risk phase in bringing about moderate cumulative own funds impacts by 2050.
    Fragmented World (9.1) High-stress impacts materialize after 2030 in the “Fragmented World” scenario, but somewhat less pronounced than in the “Delayed Transition” scenario due to less aggressive climate policy targets on this stage. However, this scenario fails to effectively limit global warming, resulting in moderate losses from physical risks by 2050. Beyond this period, the “Fragmented World”, “Current Policies” and the “Nationally Determined Contributions” scenarios are expected to entail even more material losses as impacts from physical risks increase and outweigh transition risk impacts.

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente différents scénarios climatiques et leurs impacts cumulés à long terme (5-20 ans) sur les fonds propres. Les scénarios varient en fonction de l'ambition des politiques climatiques et des progrès technologiques. Le scénario "Net Zero 2050" montre des impacts positifs à long terme grâce à une transition rapide et efficace, tandis que les scénarios "Below 2°C" et "Delayed Transition" impliquent des pertes plus importantes dues à des transitions moins ambitieuses ou retardées. Les scénarios "Nationally Determined Contributions", "Current Policies" et "Fragmented World" montrent des impacts croissants liés aux risques physiques, avec des pertes modérées à importantes à long terme.

  • ### Résumé du contenu du tableau Le tableau présente les impacts, risques et opportunités liés aux questions de durabilité pour différents domaines d'activité d'Allianz : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres (y compris la chaîne d'approvisionnement). #### Impacts : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations dues aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires pour s'adapter au changement climatique. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Réduction des rendements des investissements en raison des risques physiques et de transition, affectant les actifs sous-jacents et les chaînes d'approvisionnement. - **Opérations propres** : Augmentation des perturbations opérationnelles et des coûts de conformité en raison des événements climatiques extrêmes et des réglementations liées à la décarbonisation. #### Risques : ### Résumé du contenu du tableau Le tableau présente les impacts, risques et opportunités liés aux questions de durabilité pour différents domaines d'activité d'Allianz : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres (y compris la chaîne d'approvisionnement). #### Impacts : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations dues aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires pour s'adapter au changement climatique. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Réduction des rendements des investissements en raison des risques physiques et de transition, affectant les actifs sous-jacents et les chaînes d'approvisionnement. - **Opérations propres** : Augmentation des perturbations opérationnelles et des coûts de conformité en raison des événements climatiques extrêmes et des réglementations liées à la décarbonisation. #### Risques :
  • Le tableau analyse les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés au changement climatique (E1 Climate change) dans quatre domaines d'activité : **Insurance**, **Proprietary investments**, **Asset management** et **Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)**. Résumé : - **Impacts** : Tous les domaines sont marqués comme "Material" avec un impact négatif (-). - **Risques** : Les risques sont considérés comme "Material" pour **Insurance**, **Proprietary investments** et **Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)**, mais "Not material" pour **Asset management**. - **Opportunités** : Les opportunités sont "Material" avec un impact positif (+) pour **Insurance** et **Proprietary investments**, mais elles ne sont pas mentionnées pour **Asset management** ni **Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)**. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Sustainability matters Insurance Proprietary investments Asset management Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)
    E1 Climate change
    Impacts Material (-) Material (-) Material (-) Material (-)
    Risks Material Material Not material Material
    Opportunities Material (+) Material (+)

    Le tableau analyse les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés au changement climatique (E1 Climate change) dans différents domaines d'activité : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres d'Allianz (incluant la chaîne d'approvisionnement).
    Résumé : - Impacts : Tous les domaines sont marqués comme "Material" avec un impact négatif (-). - Risques : Les risques sont considérés comme "Material" pour l'assurance, les investissements propriétaires et les opérations propres d'Allianz, mais "Not material" pour la gestion d'actifs. - Opportunités : Les opportunités sont "Material" avec un impact positif (+) pour l'assurance et les investissements propriétaires, mais elles ne sont pas mentionnées pour la gestion d'actifs ni les opérations propres d'Allianz.

  • Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques alignées sur la taxonomie, conformément aux sections spécifiques des Annexes I et II du Règlement délégué 2021/2139. Les données sont exprimées en montants monétaires et en pourcentages pour l'année 2024, réparties entre l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM) et l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA). - Les activités des lignes 1, 4 et 5 n'ont pas de montants ou proportions associés. - Les activités des lignes 2, 3 et 6 ont des montants faibles (0.1 à 0.3) et des proportions allant de 0.5% à 1.6%. - La ligne 7 représente la majorité des montants et proportions, avec 16.6 (97.2%). - La ligne 8 totalise les montants et proportions, avec 17.1 (100%), répartis entre CCM (17.0, 100%) et CCA (0.1, 100%). and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Row Economic activities CAPEX CCM + CCA Climate change mitigation (CCM) Climate change adaptation (CCA)
    Amount and proportion (the information is to be presented in monetary amounts and as percentages) Amount % Amount % Amount %
    1 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.26 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the numerator of the applicable KPI - - - - -
    2 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.27 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the numerator of the applicable KPI 0.1 0.5 0.1 0.5 - - -
    3 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.28 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the numerator of the applicable KPI 0.3 1.6 0.3 1.6 - - -
    4 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.29 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the numerator of the applicable KPI - - 0.1 - - - -
    5 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.30 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the numerator of the applicable KPI - - - - - - -
    6 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.31 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the numerator of the applicable KPI 0.1 0.6 0.1 0.6 - - -
    7 Amount and proportion of other taxonomy-aligned economic activities not referred to in rows 1 to 6 above in the numerator of the applicable KPI 16.6 97.2 16.6 97.2 - - -
    8 Total amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activities in the numerator of the applicable KPI 17.1 100.0 17.0 100.0 0.1 100.0 100.0

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques alignées sur la taxonomie, conformément aux sections spécifiques des Annexes I et II du Règlement délégué 2021/2139. Les données sont exprimées en montants monétaires et en pourcentages pour l'année 2024, réparties entre l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM) et l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA).
    - Les activités des lignes 1, 4 et 5 n'ont pas de montants ou proportions associés. - Les activités des lignes 2, 3 et 6 ont des montants faibles (0.1 à 0.3) et des proportions allant de 0.5% à 1.6%. - La ligne 7 représente la majorité des montants et proportions, avec 16.6 (97.2%). - La ligne 8 totalise les montants et proportions, avec 17.1 (100%), répartis entre CCM (17.0, 100%) et CCA (0.1, 100%).

  • Le tableau détaille les **questions de durabilité** pour quatre domaines : **assurance**, **investissements propriétaires**, **gestion d'actifs** et **opérations propres (et chaîne d'approvisionnement)**, en distinguant les **impacts**, **risques** et **opportunités**. 1. **Impacts** : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations liée aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires (nouvelles technologies, changements juridiques, comportements clients). - **Investissements propriétaires** : Baisse des rendements due aux risques physiques (événements climatiques) et de transition (changements technologiques, réglementaires, juridiques, comportementaux). - **Opérations propres** : Hausse des perturbations opérationnelles dues aux événements climatiques extrêmes et aux coûts de conformité réglementaire liés à la décarbonisation. 2. **Risques** : - **Assurance** : Volatilité des ratios de pertes, litiges climatiques, dommages réputationnels, et défis liés à l'abordabilité des primes. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Dévalorisation des actifs due aux risques climatiques physiques et aux perturbations de transition. - **Opérations propres** : Complexité accrue et coûts de conformité réglementaire. 3. **Opportunités** : - **Assurance** et **investissements propriétaires** : Soutien à la transition bas-carbone des clients et des investis dans le cadre de la stratégie de durabilité d'Allianz. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    ```markdown

    Sustainability matters Insurance Proprietary investments Asset management Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)
    Impacts Impacts Impacts Impacts
    Risks For our retail and commercial Property-Casualty business, climate change is expected to drive an increase in the frequency and severity of claims. These may be derived from both an increase in policyholders’ exposure to the physical risks of climate change as well as the consequences of transitory measures intended to mitigate or adapt to climate change, such as adopting new technologies, materials or processes with a poorly understood (insured) risk profile, legal developments, or changes in customer behavior. Especially within our Commercial business, insured parties may be subject to climate change-related litigation due to alleged greenwashing incidents, responsibility for damages due to their historical greenhouse gas emissions and other potential issues. For our Retail business, customers may require new products or coverages in response to decarbonization-related lifestyle changes; Allianz may also suffer reputational damage if our own decarbonization efforts fall short of stakeholder expectations. Some risks may be offset with premium increases, but tangential issues such as insurance affordability for customers, difficulty in pricing risks with limited historical risk data, and increased loss-ratio volatility may present challenges. Our proprietary investments may be impacted by adverse developments in investment returns due to physical and transition risks. On the physical side, decreases in investment valuations may be triggered by acute and chronic weather events; both directly in the form of damage to underlying real assets as well as indirectly in the form of disruptions to business continuity, supply chains or resource availability. Decreases in valuation may also occur solely due to an increase in investees’ exposure to physical climate change risks. On the transition side, a combination of climate change-driven changes in technological, regulatory, legal and consumer behavior may adversely impact investment performance insofar as these materially disrupt the business model of investees. This includes, for example, transition-related disruptions to the cost, quality, and availability of inputs an investee relies on to run their business; a significant increase in investees’ regulatory compliance costs or legal losses; or a decrease in customer demand for the investees’ products or services. For our own operations, an increase in extreme weather events may increase the likelihood of operational disruptions, both directly and indirectly. Decarbonization efforts are also acting as a catalyst for broad regulatory changes, including regulations impacting the insurance industry. The design and implementation of processes needed to comply will require investments in employees, external expertise, third party databases, IT systems and more. Together with an increase in operational complexity, such new regulations may drive an increase in compliance costs, business failures and operational losses.
    Opportunities Opportunities are considered material for our insurance portfolio (Property-Casualty retail and commercial) in that we are supporting our customers in their low-carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our Sustainable Solutions and low-carbon solutions. Opportunities are considered material for our proprietary investments in that we are supporting our investees in their low-carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our low-carbon solutions.

    ```

  • #### Risques : - **Assurance** : Litiges liés au changement climatique, dommages réputationnels, volatilité des ratios de pertes, et défis dans la tarification des risques. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Dégradations des modèles économiques des investees dues aux changements climatiques, réglementaires et comportementaux. - **Opérations propres** : Complexité accrue des opérations et augmentation des coûts de conformité. #### Opportunités : - **Assurance** : Soutien aux clients dans leur transition vers une économie bas carbone via des solutions durables. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Soutien aux investees dans leur transition bas carbone conformément aux objectifs de durabilité d'Allianz. #### Risques : - **Assurance** : Litiges liés au changement climatique, dommages réputationnels, volatilité des ratios de pertes, et défis dans la tarification des risques. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Dégradations des modèles économiques des investees dues aux changements climatiques, réglementaires et comportementaux. - **Opérations propres** : Complexité accrue des opérations et augmentation des coûts de conformité. #### Opportunités : - **Assurance** : Soutien aux clients dans leur transition vers une économie bas carbone via des solutions durables. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Soutien aux investees dans leur transition bas carbone conformément aux objectifs de durabilité d'Allianz.

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) réalisées ou attendues sur deux périodes : 2024 et 2025-2029. - Au début de la période, les réductions des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base sont de (16.6) pour 2024 et (11.7) pour 2025-2029. - Les actions liées à la décarbonation des clients assurés incluent l'engagement vers une transition net zéro (non quantifiable) et la décarbonation des clients, qui contribue à une réduction de 0.7 en 2024 et entre (13.5) et (7.5) en 2025-2029. - Les actions de pilotage du portefeuille commercial incluent des solutions bas carbone ((0.1) en 2024 et entre (5.4) et (3.4) en 2025-2029), des restrictions ((0.2) en 2024 et entre (7.3) et (5.3) en 2025-2029), et des changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille (4.4 en 2024 et entre (13.0) et (11.0) en 2025-2029). - À la fin de la période, les réductions totales des émissions par rapport à la ligne de base sont de (11.7) pour 2024 et (45) pour 2025-2029.

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques alignées sur la taxonomie, ainsi que leur contribution au CAPEX pour l'année 2024. - Les activités économiques sont classées selon les sections des Annexes I et II du Règlement Délégué 2021/2139. - Les montants sont exprimés en unités monétaires, tandis que les proportions sont exprimées en pourcentage. - Les colonnes distinguent les contributions totales (CCM + CCA), celles liées à l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM), et celles liées à l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA). - La majorité des montants provient des activités économiques non spécifiées dans les sections 4.26 à 4.31, avec un total de 16.6 pour CCM + CCA. - Le total applicable KPI pour 2024 est de 17.1, avec une proportion de 2.3 %.

Je ne sais pas. Les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur la proportion d'actifs exposés à un risque physique important avant la prise en compte des mesures d'adaptation au changement climatique.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM2 :
  • ### Maximum adverse cumulative own funds impacts in NGFS/IPCC scenarios relative to a baseline scenario without climate change #### % | Scenario | Long-term 5-20 years | Observations | ### Maximum adverse cumulative own funds impacts in NGFS/IPCC scenarios relative to a baseline scenario without climate change #### % | Scenario | Long-term 5-20 years | Observations |
  • | Below 2°C | (2.4) | The orderly implementation of the policy ambition of limiting global warming to below 2 °C is associated with comparatively low cumulative losses from transition risk compared to the "Net-Zero 2050" scenario. This comes at the cost of higher losses from physical risks in the long-term due to higher global warming. In particular, an overall negative trend is predicted for the second half of the century compared to the "Net-Zero 2050" scenario. | | Below 2°C | (2.4) | The orderly implementation of the policy ambition of limiting global warming to below 2 °C is associated with comparatively low cumulative losses from transition risk compared to the "Net-Zero 2050" scenario. This comes at the cost of higher losses from physical risks in the long-term due to higher global warming. In particular, an overall negative trend is predicted for the second half of the century compared to the "Net-Zero 2050" scenario. |
  • | Delayed Transition | (12.6) | Very low stress impacts materialize in initial years, followed by relatively high cumulative own funds impacts after 2030 with the start of the delayed but rapid implementation of a policy ambition that is comparable to that in the "Below 2 °C" scenario. The stress impacts decline only slowly until 2050 due to the sluggish economic recovery in this scenario. | | Nationally Determined Contributions | (3.3) | In the short term, decarbonization efforts in the "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenario are similar to those in the "Below 2°C" scenario, leading to comparable impacts from transition risks. However, the absence of additional long-term policy measures implies that global warming cannot be limited to 2°C, leading to a comparatively larger increase in physical risks. | | Delayed Transition | (12.6) | Very low stress impacts materialize in initial years, followed by relatively high cumulative own funds impacts after 2030 with the start of the delayed but rapid implementation of a policy ambition that is comparable to that in the "Below 2 °C" scenario. The stress impacts decline only slowly until 2050 due to the sluggish economic recovery in this scenario. | | Nationally Determined Contributions | (3.3) | In the short term, decarbonization efforts in the "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenario are similar to those in the "Below 2°C" scenario, leading to comparable impacts from transition risks. However, the absence of additional long-term policy measures implies that global warming cannot be limited to 2°C, leading to a comparatively larger increase in physical risks. |
  • # Quantitative assessment of climate change risks ## Approach Complementary to the qualitative approach, we quantify the impact of climate change on Allianz’s balance sheet in a range of high- and low-emissions scenarios. In particular, we apply an integrated climate change stress test considering a limited set of risks and risk transmission channels. Results are shown in the section *Climate-related risks*. The stress test covers both sides of the balance sheet by measuring asset- or liability-specific stress impacts, as well as their dependencies for a static baseline sheet. Impacts are assessed for market and credit stresses, as well as Property-Casualty and Life/Health underwriting stresses, using NGFS/IPCC1 scenario-based data. All entities contributing to Allianz Group’s Solvency II model are in scope for the assessment. The main focus is to provide the best estimate for own funds’ impacts. # Quantitative assessment of climate change risks ## Approach Complementary to the qualitative approach, we quantify the impact of climate change on Allianz’s balance sheet in a range of high- and low-emissions scenarios. In particular, we apply an integrated climate change stress test considering a limited set of risks and risk transmission channels. Results are shown in the section *Climate-related risks*. The stress test covers both sides of the balance sheet by measuring asset- or liability-specific stress impacts, as well as their dependencies for a static baseline sheet. Impacts are assessed for market and credit stresses, as well as Property-Casualty and Life/Health underwriting stresses, using NGFS/IPCC1 scenario-based data. All entities contributing to Allianz Group’s Solvency II model are in scope for the assessment. The main focus is to provide the best estimate for own funds’ impacts.
  • | Current Policies | (5.4) | In the absence of stringent climate policy implementations, stress impacts are relatively muted, similar to the "Delayed Transition" scenario, until the second half of the time horizon where stress impacts from physical risk phase in bringing about moderate cumulative own funds impacts by 2050. | | Fragmented World | (9.1) | High-stress impacts materialize after 2030 in the "Fragmented World" scenario, but somewhat less pronounced than in the "Delayed Transition" scenario due to less aggressive climate policy targets on average. However, this scenario fails to effectively limit global warming, resulting in moderate losses from physical risks by 2050. | | Current Policies | (5.4) | In the absence of stringent climate policy implementations, stress impacts are relatively muted, similar to the "Delayed Transition" scenario, until the second half of the time horizon where stress impacts from physical risk phase in bringing about moderate cumulative own funds impacts by 2050. | | Fragmented World | (9.1) | High-stress impacts materialize after 2030 in the "Fragmented World" scenario, but somewhat less pronounced than in the "Delayed Transition" scenario due to less aggressive climate policy targets on average. However, this scenario fails to effectively limit global warming, resulting in moderate losses from physical risks by 2050. |
  • # Climate-related risks ### Section summary The Allianz Group is exposed to risks that are affected by climate change in a multitude of ways. To assess and manage climate change-related risks, we use both qualitative and quantitative strategies for climate stress testing and scenario analysis. Key risks identified for the Allianz Group include those related to proprietary investments and Property-Casualty underwriting. Stress test results based on currently available scenarios indicate that transition risks will dominate over the next 5 – 10 years, while physical risks will gradually increase. We consider the stress buffers and management actions in place to be sufficient to manage these risks. # Climate-related risks ### Section summary The Allianz Group is exposed to risks that are affected by climate change in a multitude of ways. To assess and manage climate change-related risks, we use both qualitative and quantitative strategies for climate stress testing and scenario analysis. Key risks identified for the Allianz Group include those related to proprietary investments and Property-Casualty underwriting. Stress test results based on currently available scenarios indicate that transition risks will dominate over the next 5 – 10 years, while physical risks will gradually increase. We consider the stress buffers and management actions in place to be sufficient to manage these risks.
  • ## Scenarios Allianz’s business areas are exposed to climate change in different ways depending on their characteristics, e.g., different levels of exposure to physical or transition risks in different time periods. The scenarios used for the stress test therefore cover a broad spectrum of possible climatic and economic developments. This spectrum includes low-emission pathways, limiting global warming to 1.5°C by the end of the century, and high-emission pathways, where average global warming rises up to 4°C. Short, medium, and long term time horizons up to 2050 are considered, which are equally relevant for the processes in the individual business areas of Allianz, the implementation of important political and economic strategies in connection with the Paris Climate Agreement, and the onset of increasing global warming and its negative consequences. ## Scenarios Allianz’s business areas are exposed to climate change in different ways depending on their characteristics, e.g., different levels of exposure to physical or transition risks in different time periods. The scenarios used for the stress test therefore cover a broad spectrum of possible climatic and economic developments. This spectrum includes low-emission pathways, limiting global warming to 1.5°C by the end of the century, and high-emission pathways, where average global warming rises up to 4°C. Short, medium, and long term time horizons up to 2050 are considered, which are equally relevant for the processes in the individual business areas of Allianz, the implementation of important political and economic strategies in connection with the Paris Climate Agreement, and the onset of increasing global warming and its negative consequences.
  • - **Risks:** Our proprietary investments may be impacted by adverse developments in investment returns due to physical and transition risks. On the physical side, decreases in investment valuations may be triggered by acute and chronic weather events; both directly in the form of damage to underlying physical assets as well as indirectly in the form of disruptions to business continuity, supply chains or resource availability. Decreases in valuation may also occur solely due to an increase in investees’ exposure to physical and climate risks. On the transition side, a combination of climate change-driven changes in technological, regulatory, legal and consumer behavior may adversely impact investment performance insofar as these materially disrupt the business model of investees. This includes, for example, transition-related disruptions to the cost, quality, and availability of outputs an investee relies on to run their business; a significant increase in investees’ regulatory - **Risks:** Our proprietary investments may be impacted by adverse developments in investment returns due to physical and transition risks. On the physical side, decreases in investment valuations may be triggered by acute and chronic weather events; both directly in the form of damage to underlying physical assets as well as indirectly in the form of disruptions to business continuity, supply chains or resource availability. Decreases in valuation may also occur solely due to an increase in investees’ exposure to physical and climate risks. On the transition side, a combination of climate change-driven changes in technological, regulatory, legal and consumer behavior may adversely impact investment performance insofar as these materially disrupt the business model of investees. This includes, for example, transition-related disruptions to the cost, quality, and availability of outputs an investee relies on to run their business; a significant increase in investees’ regulatory
  • # C_Group Management Report – Sustainability Statement ## Template 2 2023: Taxonomy-aligned economic activities (denominator) – Turnover ### BEGIN TABLE | Row | Economic activities | |-----|---------------------| | 1. | Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.26 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI | | 2. | Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.27 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI | | 3. | Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.28 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI | | 4. | Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.29 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI | | 5. | Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.30 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI | | 6. | Amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.31 of Annexes I and II to Delegated Regulation 2021/2139 in the denominator of the applicable KPI | | 7. | Amount and proportion of other taxonomy-aligned economic activities not referred to in rows 1 to 6 above in the denominator of the applicable KPI | | 8. | **Total applicable KPI** | # C_Group Management Report – Sustainability Statement ##
