Je ne sais pas. Les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'information spécifique sur la proportion d'actifs exposés à un risque physique important avant prise en compte des mesures d'adaptation au changement climatique.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Maximum adverse cumulative own funds impacts in NGFS/IPCC scenarios relative to a baseline scenario without climate change1 %
  • ### Maximum adverse cumulative own funds impacts in NGFS/IPCC scenarios relative to a baseline scenario without climate change The table compares the "Scenario," "Long-term 5-20 years" impacts, and "Observations" across six climate scenarios from NGFS/IPCC. In the "Net Zero 2050" scenario, a 0.6% impact is observed, with initial economic pressure followed by recovery due to lower energy prices and higher efficiency, leading to minor losses by 2050. The "Below 2℃" scenario shows a (2.4%) impact, with lower transition risk losses but higher physical risk losses in the long term. The "Delayed Transition" scenario has a (12.6%) impact, with low initial stress impacts followed by high cumulative impacts after 2030 due to delayed policy implementation and slow recovery. The "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenario shows a (3.3%) impact, with short-term impacts similar to "Below 2℃" but higher physical risks due to insufficient long-term policies. The "Current Policies" scenario has a (5.4%) impact, with muted stress impacts initially but moderate cumulative impacts from physical risks by 2050. The "Fragmented World" scenario shows a (9.1%) impact, with high stress impacts after 2030 and moderate physical risk losses by 2050, with increasing material losses beyond this period.
  • # --- Page 101 --- ## C_ Group Management Report_ Sustainability Statement The (4) "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenario includes all pledged climate policies, even if not yet implemented. However, these policies are insufficient to limit global warming to below 2℃, leading to increasing physical risks. Accounting only for climate policies that were in place before 2022, the (5) "Current Policies" scenario is characterized by limited transition risks and high physical risks, becoming more visible over the second half of the projection period.
  • ### Section summary The Allianz Group is exposed to risks that are affected by climate change in a multitude of ways. To assess and manage climate change- related risks, we use both qualitative and quantitative strategies for climate stress testing and scenario analysis. Key risks identified for the Allianz Group include those related to proprietary investments and Property-Casualty underwriting. Stress test results based on currently available scenarios indicate that transition risks will dominate over the next 5- 10 years, while physical risks will gradually increase. We consider the stress buffers and management actions in place to be sufficient to manage these risks.
  • ### Approach Complementary to the qualitative approach, we quantify the impact of climate change on Allianz's balance sheet in a range of high- and low-emissions scenarios. In particular, we apply an integrated climate change stress test considering a limited set of risks and risk transmission channels. Results are shown in the section Climate- related risks. The stress test covers both sides of the balance sheet by measuring asset- or liability-specific stress impacts, as well as their dependencies for a static balance sheet. Impacts are assessed for market and credit stresses, as well as Property-Casualty and Life/Health underwriting stresses, using NGFS/IPCC1 scenario-based data. All entities contributing to Allianz Group's Solvency Il model are in scope for the assessment. The main focus is to provide the best estimate for own funds2 impacts.
  • ### Scenarios Allianz's business areas are exposed to climate change in different ways depending on their characteristics, e.g., different levels of exposure to physical or transition risks in different time periods. The scenarios used for the stress test therefore cover a broad spectrum of possible climatic and economic developments. This spectrum includes low-emission pathways, limiting global warming to 1.5℃ by the end of the century, and high-emission pathways, where average global warming rises up to 4℃. Short, medium, and long term time horizons up to 2050 are considered, which are equally relevant for the processes in the individual business areas of Allianz, the implementation of important political and economic strategies in connection with the Paris Climate Agreement, and the onset of increasing global warming and its negative consequences.
  • The (1) "Net-Zero 2050" scenario is determined by an orderly transition to net-zero emissions by 2050, aiming to limit global warming to 1.5℃ through stringent climate policies, causing high economic strain initially. The (2) "Below 2℃" scenario assumes an early and orderly transition to a low-carbon economy, with a less ambitious policy target to limit global warming to below 2℃ by the end of the century, with limited impact on economic growth. In the (3) "Delayed Transition" scenario, GHG emissions remain high until 2030, when strong policy measures limit warming to below 2℃. Physical risks are relatively small in the "Net-Zero 2050," "Below 2℃," and "Delayed Transition" scenarios over the 2050 time horizon. 1_IPCC: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. 152 Methodology Information and Additional Tables 2_For the purpose of the integrated climate change stress test, we estimate the own funds impacts based on the stressed MVBS excess assets over liabilities.
  • An excerpt from the aggregated stress test results is shown in table Maximum adverse cumulative own funds impacts in NGFS/IPCC scenarios relative to a baseline scenario without climate change,1 alongside observations at the individual scenario level2. The complete analysis covers the period from now until 2050. We show here the estimated maximum adverse impacts over the 5 - 20 year period, noting that the current NGFS scenarios are primarily aimed at modeling medium- to long-term climate-economic relationships.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre "Economic activities" y su alineación con la taxonomía en términos de "Turnover" para el año 2024. Las columnas incluyen "Amount and proportion (the information is to be presented in monetary amounts and as percentages)", desglosadas en "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila 1, las actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía según la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 2. En la fila 2, las actividades según la Sección 4.27 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 3. En la fila 3, las actividades según la Sección 4.28 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.4 (2.4% para CCM). 4. En la fila 4, las actividades según la Sección 4.29 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 5. En la fila 5, las actividades según la Sección 4.30 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.3 (0.3% para CCM). 6. En la fila 6, las actividades según la Sección 4.31 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 7. En la fila 7, otras actividades alineadas con la taxonomía no incluidas en las filas 1 a 6 reportan un "Turnover" de 15.5 (97.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA). 8. En la fila 8, el total de actividades alineadas con la taxonomía reporta un "Turnover" de 16.0 (100.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA).
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre "Economic activities" y su alineación con la taxonomía en el denominador del KPI aplicable para el año 2024. Las columnas incluyen "Turnover" con "Amount and proportion" expresados en montos monetarios y porcentajes, desglosados en "Climate change mitigation (CCM)" y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)". Las filas enumeran actividades económicas específicas referidas en las Secciones 4.26 a 4.31 de los Anexos I y II del Reglamento Delegado 2021/2139, así como otras actividades no incluidas en dichas secciones. 1. Las filas 1, 2, 4, 5 y 6 no tienen datos reportados, mostrando "-" en todas las columnas. 2. En la fila 3, la actividad económica de la Sección 4.28 reporta un monto de 0.4 y un porcentaje de 0.1% tanto para CCM como para el total, sin datos para CCA. 3. La fila 7, que incluye otras actividades no referidas en las filas anteriores, reporta un monto de 15.5 y un porcentaje de 2.1% para CCM, 15.4 y 2.0% para el total, y 0.1 sin porcentaje para CCA. 4. La fila 8, que resume el "Total applicable KPI", muestra un monto de 16.0 y un porcentaje de 2.1% para CCM, 15.9 y 2.1% para el total, y 0.1 sin porcentaje para CCA.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre "Economic activities" y "CAPEX" en el contexto de actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía para el año 2023. Los datos están organizados en las siguientes columnas: "Row", "Economic activities", "CAPEX", "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila "1.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos disponibles ("-"). 2. En la fila "2.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.27 muestran un "Amount" de 0.0 y un porcentaje de 0.01% tanto para CCM como para CCA. 3. En la fila "3.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.28 tienen un "Amount" de 0.3 y un porcentaje de 0.04% tanto para CCM como para CCA. 4. Las filas "4.", "5." y "6." (Secciones 4.29, 4.30 y 4.31) no tienen datos disponibles ("-"). 5. En la fila "7.", las actividades alineadas no incluidas en las filas anteriores tienen un "Amount" de 14.7 (1.98%), con 13.5 (1.82%) para CCM y 0.8 (0.11%) para CCA. 6. En la fila "8.", el "Total applicable KPI" es de 741.9, pero no hay datos disponibles ("n.a.") para CCM y CCA. Notas adicionales: "n.a." indica información no disponible, y no se asignaron cuotas de alineación a objetivos climáticos o actividades nucleares/gas debido a limitaciones de datos.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre "Economic activities" y "CAPEX" en el contexto de actividades económicas elegibles según la taxonomía, pero no alineadas con ella, para el año 2024. Los datos están organizados en las siguientes columnas: "Row", "Economic activities", "Amount", "%", "Amount (Climate change mitigation - CCM)", "%", "Amount (Climate change adaptation - CCA)", "%". 1. Las filas 1 a 3 y 5 a 6, que corresponden a actividades específicas referidas en las Secciones 4.26, 4.27, 4.28, 4.30 y 4.31 de los Anexos I y II del Reglamento Delegado 2021/2139, no tienen valores reportados ("-"). 2. En la fila 4, correspondiente a la Sección 4.29, se reporta un "Amount" de 0.1 para "CAPEX" y "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", sin porcentaje asociado. 3. La fila 7, que incluye otras actividades elegibles no alineadas no mencionadas en las filas anteriores, reporta un "Amount" de 137.7 y un porcentaje de 18.3% tanto para "CAPEX" como para "Climate change mitigation (CCM)". 4. La fila 8, que resume el total de actividades elegibles pero no alineadas, reporta un "Amount" de 137.9 y un porcentaje de 18.3% para "CAPEX". No se reportan valores para "Climate change adaptation (CCA)" en ninguna fila.

Je ne sais pas. Les informations fournies ne précisent pas la proportion d'actifs exposés à un risque physique important avant prise en compte des mesures d'adaptation au changement climatique.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • stakeholders to drive the transition. 1_For further information, please refer to the Allianz Risk Barometer on the Allianz company website . Human- made climate change has already caused significant adverse impacts for nature and people. The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5 °C above pre -industrial levels by the end of the century. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), to restrict warming to 1.5 °C, emissions need to be almost halved every decade and reach net -zero emissions by the middle of the century to maintain a reasonable chance of achieving this goal. However, if current emission trends p ersist, climate scientists estimate the greenhouse gas ( GHG ) budget will be exceeded before 2030, which necessitates urgent climate mitigation efforts from policymakers and businesses. We expect climate change will have significant impact on global stakeholders to drive the transition. 1_For further information, please refer to the Allianz Risk Barometer on the Allianz company website . Human- made climate change has already caused significant adverse impacts for nature and people. The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5 °C above pre -industrial levels by the end of the century. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), to restrict warming to 1.5 °C, emissions need to be almost halved every decade and reach net -zero emissions by the middle of the century to maintain a reasonable chance of achieving this goal. However, if current emission trends p ersist, climate scientists estimate the greenhouse gas ( GHG ) budget will be exceeded before 2030, which necessitates urgent climate mitigation efforts from policymakers and businesses. We expect climate change will have significant impact on global
  • the absence of additional long -term policy meas ures implies that global warming cannot be limited to 2°C, leading to a comparatively larger increase in physical risks. Current Policies (5.4) In the absence of stringent climate policy implementation, stress impacts are relatively muted, similar to the "Delayed Transition" scenario, until the second half of the time horizon where stress impacts from physical risk phase in bringing about moderate cumulative own funds impacts by 2050. Fragmented World (9.1) High -stress impacts materialize after 2030 in the "Fragmented World" scenario, but somewhat less pronounced than in the "Delayed T ransition" scenario due to less aggressive climate policy targets on average. However, this scenario fails to effectively limi t global warming, resulting in moderate losses from physical risks by 2050. the absence of additional long -term policy meas ures implies that global warming cannot be limited to 2°C, leading to a comparatively larger increase in physical risks. Current Policies (5.4) In the absence of stringent climate policy implementation, stress impacts are relatively muted, similar to the "Delayed Transition" scenario, until the second half of the time horizon where stress impacts from physical risk phase in bringing about moderate cumulative own funds impacts by 2050. Fragmented World (9.1) High -stress impacts materialize after 2030 in the "Fragmented World" scenario, but somewhat less pronounced than in the "Delayed T ransition" scenario due to less aggressive climate policy targets on average. However, this scenario fails to effectively limi t global warming, resulting in moderate losses from physical risks by 2050.
  • Beyond this period, the "Fragmented World", "Current Policies" and the "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenarios are ex pected to entail even more material losses as impacts from physical risks increase and outweigh transition risk impacts. 1_The metric “maximum adverse cumulative impact on own funds” represents the worst -case cumulative stress impact that could materialize in a given scenario in the period between 5 and 20 years from today. Conclusion From the quantitative perspective, the overall cumulative own funds impacts derived from the integrated climate change stress test are considered to be within Allianz ’s risk tolerance, considering both the magnitude of the estimated losses and the time horizon over which they materialize, further underpinning the conclusion of the qualitative resilience analysis. This is particularly evident over the three- year Beyond this period, the "Fragmented World", "Current Policies" and the "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenarios are ex pected to entail even more material losses as impacts from physical risks increase and outweigh transition risk impacts. 1_The metric “maximum adverse cumulative impact on own funds” represents the worst -case cumulative stress impact that could materialize in a given scenario in the period between 5 and 20 years from today. Conclusion From the quantitative perspective, the overall cumulative own funds impacts derived from the integrated climate change stress test are considered to be within Allianz ’s risk tolerance, considering both the magnitude of the estimated losses and the time horizon over which they materialize, further underpinning the conclusion of the qualitative resilience analysis. This is particularly evident over the three- year
  • physical risk arising from the impact of temperature changes on labor productivity. Scenario variables are expanded using internal approaches to adjust regional coverage for Allianz ’s main markets and consider selected sector -specific developments. Market and credit stresses are applied to market values of assets and liabilities of in -scope entities, using a simplified approach to assess mitigation of stress impacts due to policyholder profit sharing. Scenario variables in the Property -Casualty and Life/Health underwriting stress modules are derived from hazard models based on RCPs 2.6, 4.5, 6.0, and 8.5 of the IPCC. The Property - Casualty underwriting stress module relies on projections for Average Annual Loss for a selection of the most climate change- relevant country and peril combinations. Property -Casualty underwriting stress variables are aggregated from location -specific data and applied at a country level. Property -Casualty underwriting stresses are applied to physical risk arising from the impact of temperature changes on labor productivity.   • Accounting only for climate policies that were in place before 2022, the (5) “Current Policies” scenario is characterized by limited transition risks and high physical risks, becoming more visible over the second half of the projection period. In the (6) “Fragmented World” scenario, the tightening of climate policy is also delayed until after 2030, as in the “Delayed Transition” scenario. However, it is fragmented globally; countries with net -zero targets may only partially achieve them, while o thers maintain current policies. Overall, action is too little, too late, and global warming rises to 2.3 °C. Both physical and transition risks are high in this scenario. The “Fragmented World”, “Current Policies”, and “Nationally Determined Contributions ” scenarios are projected to entail even higher physical risks after 2050, outweighing transition risks.   • climate change risks for the Allianz Group relate to proprietary investments and Property -Casualty underwriting. Risks related to own operations and Life/Health underwriting are also present, albeit to a lesser extent. The following section presents the results of the integrated climate change stress test as of the fourth quarter 2024. The main focus of the stress test is to provide the best estimate for own funds impacts in Network for Greening the Financial System ( NGFS )/ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ( IPCC ) scenarios for a static balance sheet. A detailed description of the methodology is given in the sub section Quantitative assessment of climate change risks of the section Financial materiality – Risk perspective. The climate climate change risks for the Allianz Group relate to proprietary investments and Property -Casualty underwriting. Risks related to own operations and Life/Health underwriting are also present, albeit to a lesser extent. The following section presents the results of the integrated climate change stress test as of the fourth quarter 2024. The main focus of the stress test is to provide the best estimate for own funds impacts in Network for Greening the Financial System ( NGFS )/ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ( IPCC ) scenarios for a static balance sheet. A detailed description of the methodology is given in the sub section Quantitative assessment of climate change risks of the section Financial materiality – Risk perspective. The climate
  • stresses on the static fourth quarter 2024 balance sheet, without adaptation or mitigation actions from Allianz and its business partners. Impact estimates from different stress test modules are integrated based on matching global mean temperatures for 2050 between NGFS and IPCC scenarios and considering overall scenario characteristics. No diversification between market, credit, and underwriting stresses is assumed for the aggregation. The estimates of the effects of the integrated climate stress test are based on scientific research findings and scenario data that are currently available and considered relevant. They are subject to considerable uncertainties associated with long -term pr ojections in general and climate change modeling in particular. These include, for example, scientific uncertainties in the projection of hazard distributions and macroeconomic impacts in the climate change scenarios used. They are also subject to more fun damental stresses on the static fourth quarter 2024 balance sheet, without adaptation or mitigation actions from Allianz and its business partners. No diversification between market, credit, and underwriting stresses is assumed for the aggregation.   • noting that the current NGFS scenarios are primarily aimed at modeling medium - to long -term climate -economic relationships.   • the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime
  • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.
  • °C trajectories, ideally aligned internationally. − Sustainable finance regulation that provides a defined, science - based, and reliable framework via a common taxonomy of sustainability, clarification of asset managers’ duties related to sustainability, inclusion of sustainability in prudential regulation, and enhanced transparency of corporate reporting. Climate engagement and partnerships Since the net -zero transition is a systemic issue, it requires a whole -of- society response. Therefore, we are also seeking to join forces with other stakeholders. Our approach on the proprietary investment side builds on the work of the UN -convened Net -Zero Asset Owner Alliance, which Allianz co-founded and chaired from its inception to year -end 2024. Furthermore, we encourage companies to implement net -zero strategies via initiatives such as the Institutional Investors Group on Climate Change , Climate Acti on 100+, and the PRI .   • alone. True to our name “ Allianz ” – signifying alliance – we act as a trusted partner and collaborate with public and private sectors and civil society, contributing to systemic change toward a more sustainable future. By pooling resources, expertise, and innovation, we address these glo bal challenges together. Our involvement in the UN - convened Net -Zero Asset Owner Alliance (NZAOA) exemplifies our commitment to bridging public and private sector action to address climate change. We recognize the importance of human rights as both a value -based topic and a business issue, and we are committed to supporting and respecting the protection of human rights, in addition to ensuring that Allianz is not complicit in human rights abuses. The human rights that Allianz is committed to respecting are those agreed by governments in: SUSTAINABILITY STRATEGY AND GOVERNANCE C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement alone. True to our name “ Allianz ” – signifying alliance – we act as a trusted partner and collaborate with public and private sectors and civil society, contributing to systemic change toward a more sustainable future. By pooling resources, expertise, and innovation, we address these glo bal challenges together. Our involvement in the UN - convened Net -Zero Asset Owner Alliance (NZAOA) exemplifies our commitment to bridging public and private sector action to address climate change. We recognize the importance of human rights as both a value -based topic and a business issue, and we are committed to supporting and respecting the protection of human rights, in addition to ensuring that Allianz is not complicit in human rights abuses. The human rights that Allianz is committed to respecting are those agreed by governments in: SUSTAINABILITY STRATEGY AND GOVERNANCE C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement
S1-17

Quels sont les principaux engagements de l'entreprise en matière de respect des droits de l'Homme de ses employés ?

nan

L'entreprise s'engage principalement à respecter les droits de l'Homme de ses employés à travers plusieurs axes clés :

  1. Traitement Égalitaire : Assurer un traitement égal pour tous les employés, indépendamment de leur origine nationale ou ethnique, statut social, santé, handicap, orientation sexuelle, âge, sexe, croyances religieuses ou toute autre caractéristique protégée.

  2. Conditions de Travail Adéquates : Mettre en place des pratiques garantissant des conditions de travail adéquates, notamment par l'engagement des employés, la formation, l'apprentissage, et le développement personnel.

  3. Santé et Sécurité au Travail : Accorder une attention particulière à la santé et au bien-être des employés, incluant la flexibilité du temps de travail, des salaires compétitifs, et la promotion de la liberté d'association et du dialogue avec les employés.

  4. Liberté d'Association et Négociation Collective : Soutenir la liberté d'association et le droit à la négociation collective.

  5. Mécanismes de Plaintes : Fournir des mécanismes officiels, tels que SpeakUp@Allianz, pour que les employés puissent signaler des préoccupations, y compris les risques et violations des droits de l'Homme.

  6. Politique de Tolérance Zéro envers la Discrimination : Mettre en œuvre une politique de tolérance zéro envers la discrimination, incluse dans le Code de Conduite du Groupe Allianz.

  7. Diligence Raisonnable en Droits Humains : Appliquer des règles fonctionnelles pour la diligence raisonnable en droits humains dans ses propres opérations.

Ces engagements sont soutenus par des processus de diligence raisonnable conformes aux exigences du GSCA et alignés avec les Principes directeurs des Nations Unies relatifs aux entreprises et aux droits de l'homme (UNGPs).


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS: On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety.   • In addition to the zero-tolerance policy toward discrimination included in the Allianz Group Code of Conduct, the Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social origin, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with the general principles. We support and respect international human rights as outlined in the International Bill of Human Rights and the core International Labor In addition to the zero-tolerance policy toward discrimination included in the Allianz Group Code of Conduct, the Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social origin, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with the general principles. We support and respect international human rights as outlined in the International Bill of Human Rights and the core International Labor
  • Le tableau présente des données sur les droits humains et la main-d'œuvre propre pour les années 2024 et 2023. Les colonnes incluent "Description", "Unité", "2024" et "2023". Les lignes sont : "Nombre de plaintes déposées par les employés via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz", "Nombre de plaintes déposées auprès des Points de Contact Nationaux pour les Entreprises Multinationales de l'OCDE", "Nombre d'incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement", "Nombre d'incidents graves relatifs aux droits humains concernant la main-d'œuvre propre", et "Montant des amendes matérielles, pénalités et compensations pour incidents liés à la main-d'œuvre propre". En 2024, 388 plaintes ont été déposées via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz, et 31 incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement, ont été signalés. Aucun incident grave relatif aux droits humains ou montant d'amendes n'a été enregistré pour cette année. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.). and

Aucun incident grave relatif aux droits humains ou montant d'amendes n'a été enregistré pour cette année. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.).

  • C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement — — the International Bill of Human Rights, comprising the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and its two Optional Protocols, in addition to the core International Labor Organization (ILO) Conventions, comprising the prohibition of child labor and forced labor, freedom of association and the right to collective bargaining, occupational health and safety, and the elimination of discrimination in respect of employment and occupation. C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement — — the International Bill of Human Rights, comprising the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and its two Optional Protocols, in addition to the core International Labor Organization (ILO) Conventions, comprising the prohibition of child labor and forced labor, freedom of association and the right to collective bargaining, occupational health and safety, and the elimination of discrimination in respect of employment and occupation.
  • Le tableau présente une liste de sujets de durabilité, des exigences de divulgation associées, des sections correspondantes et des sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections détaillant les aspects spécifiques à traiter. Les sujets incluent "E4 Biodiversity and ecosystems", "E5 Resource use and circular economy" et "S1 Own workforce". Pour "E4 Biodiversity and ecosystems", les sous-sections couvrent la stratégie et le modèle d'affaires, la matérialité, les politiques, les actions et les objectifs liés à la biodiversité et aux écosystèmes. Pour "E5 Resource use and circular economy", les sous-sections incluent la matérialité, les politiques, les actions, les objectifs et les métriques, telles que l'influx de ressources et les déchets électroniques. Concernant "S1 Own workforce", les sous-sections abordent la stratégie "Group People and Culture", la matérialité, les politiques, l'engagement, les processus pour soulever des préoccupations, les actions, les objectifs, les caractéristiques des employés, la négociation collective, le genre, les générations, les salaires adéquats, la protection sociale, les personnes handicapées, l'apprentissage et le développement, la santé et la sécurité, l'équilibre travail-vie personnelle, l'écart de rémunération entre les sexes et les droits humains. Chaque sujet est structuré pour analyser les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés à ces domaines. and

    Le tableau présente une liste de sujets de durabilité, des exigences de divulgation associées, des sections correspondantes et des sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections détaillant les aspects spécifiques à traiter. Les sujets abordés incluent la biodiversité et les écosystèmes, l'utilisation des ressources et l'économie circulaire, ainsi que la gestion de la main-d'œuvre propre. Chaque sujet est divisé en plusieurs catégories, telles que la stratégie, la matérialité, les politiques, les actions, les objectifs, et les métriques, afin de fournir une vue complète des impacts, des risques et des opportunités liés à ces domaines.

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, classés par leur matérialité ("matériel", "non matériel" ou "non pertinent") et leurs sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections. Les exigences matérielles incluent : 1. **ESRS S2-1** : Non-respect des principes des UNGPs et des lignes directrices de l'OCDE (paragraphe 19) et politiques de diligence raisonnable liées aux conventions fondamentales de l'OIT (1 à 8, paragraphe 19), dans les sous-sections "politiques Allianz ESRS" et "stratégie et modèle d'affaires liés aux travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur". 2. **ESRS S2-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains dans la chaîne de valeur (paragraphe 36), avec des cibles, actions et processus pour remédier aux impacts négatifs. 3. **ESRS S3-1** : Engagements politiques en matière de droits humains (paragraphe 16) et non-respect des principes des UNGPs, de l'OIT ou de l'OCDE (paragraphe 17), dans le cadre de la stratégie et du modèle d'affaires liés aux communautés affectées. 4. **ESRS S3-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains (paragraphe 36), avec des actions et processus d'engagement avec les communautés affectées. 5. **ESRS S4-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains (paragraphe 35), avec des actions. 6. **ESRS G1-4** : Incidents confirmés de corruption ou de pots-de-vin (paragraphes 24 (a) et (b)). Les points non matériels ou non pertinents incluent : - **ESRS S4-1** : Politiques liées aux consommateurs et utilisateurs finaux (paragraphes 16 et 17), jugées non applicables. - **ESRS G1-1** : Convention des Nations Unies contre la corruption (paragraphe 10 (b)) et protection des lanceurs d'alerte (paragraphe 10 (d)), avec des politiques déjà en place. and

    ESRS S4-1 Policies related to consumers and end-users, paragraph 16 Not material Not applicable, since not material

    ESRS G1-1 United Nations Convention against Corruption, paragraph 10 (b) Not relevant Policy(ies) are already in place
    ESRS G1-1 Protection of whistle-blowers, paragraph 10 (d) Not relevant Policy(ies) are already in place

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation liées à divers aspects des droits humains, de la corruption et des politiques de diligence raisonnable. Il indique si ces exigences sont considérées comme "matérielles", "non matérielles" ou "non pertinentes", et précise les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections associées. Les points matériels incluent des politiques et des actions liées aux droits humains, aux travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur, aux communautés affectées, ainsi qu'aux incidents confirmés de corruption ou de pots-de-vin. Les points non matériels ou non pertinents concernent principalement les politiques déjà en place ou les aspects jugés non applicables.

  • Positive impacts in our own operations are created through Allianz practices ensuring adequate working conditions, particularly by means of employee engagement, training, learning, and personal development. We have a strong focus on equal treatment and opportunities for all; this encompasses diversity, inclusion, and talent acquisition and retention. The health and well-being of our employees continues to be an area of focus – our practices typically include offering flexibility in working time, paying competitive wages, and fostering freedom of association and dialogue with our employees. Furthermore, securing the confidentiality of employee data is key for us. By implementing these and further practices – including annual risk assessments, as applicable, regarding the protection of human/employee rights in accordance with the GSCA – we continue to work to ensure (potential/actual) adverse impacts are prevented and reduced. All the people in Allianz own workforce are in scope of the Positive impacts in our own operations are created through Allianz practices ensuring adequate working conditions, particularly by means of employee engagement, training, learning, and personal development. We have a strong focus on equal treatment and opportunities for all; this encompasses diversity, inclusion, and talent acquisition and retention. The health and well-being of our employees continues to be an area of focus – our practices typically include offering flexibility in working time, paying competitive wages, and fostering freedom of association and dialogue with our employees. Furthermore, securing the confidentiality of employee data is key for us. By implementing these and further practices – including annual risk assessments, as applicable, regarding the protection of human/employee rights in accordance with the GSCA – we continue to work to ensure (potential/actual) adverse impacts are prevented and reduced. All the people in Allianz own workforce are in scope of the
  • human rights as outlined in the International Bill of Human Rights and the core International Labor Organization Convention. Our due diligence processes in own operations comply with the requirements of the GSCA, aligned with the UNGPs.   • Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau détaille les "exigences de divulgation et points de données associés", leur "matérialité" (matériel ou non matériel), et les "sous-sections/sous-sous-sections" correspondantes. Les points matériels incluent : 1. **ESRS E4-2** : Politiques sur les océans/mer et la déforestation, liées à la biodiversité et aux écosystèmes. 2. **ESRS E5-5** : Déchets non recyclés et dangereux, liés à l'économie circulaire et à l'utilisation des ressources. 3. **ESRS S1-1** : Engagements en matière de droits humains, politiques de diligence raisonnable, prévention des accidents, et mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, liés à la main-d'œuvre propre. 4. **ESRS S1-14** : Santé et sécurité, incluant les accidents et jours perdus. 5. **ESRS S1-16** : Écarts de rémunération entre genres et ratios de rémunération. 6. **ESRS S1-17** : Incidents de discrimination et non-respect des principes directeurs de l'ONU et des lignes directrices de l'OCDE, liés aux droits humains dans la main-d'œuvre propre. 7. **ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S2** : Risques significatifs de travail des enfants ou forcé dans la chaîne de valeur. 8. **ESRS S2-1** : Engagements en matière de droits humains pour les travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur. Les points non matériels incluent les risques d'incidents de travail forcé ou des enfants (ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S1) et les mesures contre la traite humaine (ESRS S1-1). and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité (matériel ou non matériel), ainsi que les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. Les points de données matériels concernent principalement les politiques liées à la biodiversité, l'économie circulaire, la sécurité au travail, les droits humains, les mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, et les écarts de rémunération. Les points non matériels sont considérés comme non applicables.

  • Le tableau présente des objectifs liés à la gestion d'actifs et aux engagements multilatéraux pour les années 2023, 2024 et la cible pour 2030. Les colonnes incluent "2024", "2023" et "Cible 2030", tandis que les lignes sont intitulées : "Collaborer avec tous les gestionnaires d'actifs externes 'en dessous des attentes' basé sur une évaluation systématique en %¹", "Diriger ou soutenir 30 engagements multilatéraux", "Dont 15 axés sur le climat", et "Engager 15 parmi les 100 principaux émetteurs de portefeuille non engagés". En 2024, 95,2 % des gestionnaires d'actifs externes "en dessous des attentes" seront engagés, avec une cible de 100 % pour 2030. 15 engagements multilatéraux seront dirigés ou soutenus en 2024, dont 10 axés sur le climat, avec une cible respective de 30 et 15 pour 2030. Enfin, 5 des 100 principaux émetteurs de portefeuille non engagés seront ciblés en 2024, avec une cible de 15 pour 2030. Le tableau précise que l'évaluation des gestionnaires d'actifs évolue dans le temps et n'est pas une cible fixe. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Objectif 2024 2023 Cible 2030
    Collaborer avec tous les gestionnaires d'actifs externes "en dessous des attentes" basé sur une évaluation systématique en %¹ 95.2 n.a. 100.0
    Diriger ou soutenir 30 engagements multilatéraux 15 8 30
    Dont 15 axés sur le climat 10 7 15
    Engager 15 parmi les 100 principaux émetteurs de portefeuille non engagés 5 5 15

    ¹ Comme nous évaluons continuellement les gestionnaires d'actifs, ce chiffre n'est pas une cible fixe et évolue dans le temps.
    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente des objectifs liés à la gestion d'actifs et aux engagements multilatéraux pour les années 2023, 2024 et la cible pour 2030. En 2024, 95,2 % des gestionnaires d'actifs externes "en dessous des attentes" seront engagés, avec une cible de 100 % pour 2030. 15 engagements multilatéraux seront dirigés ou soutenus en 2024, dont 10 axés sur le climat, avec une cible respective de 30 et 15 pour 2030. Enfin, 5 des 100 principaux émetteurs de portefeuille non engagés seront ciblés en 2024, avec une cible de 15 pour 2030.

Les principaux engagements de l'entreprise Allianz en matière de respect des droits de l'Homme de ses employés incluent :

  1. Respect des Droits de l'Homme : Allianz considère le respect des droits de l'Homme comme un standard minimum pour un traitement responsable de ses employés.

  2. Évaluation et Gestion des Risques : L'entreprise effectue des évaluations annuelles et ponctuelles des risques liés aux droits des employés selon les normes GSCA. En cas de risques identifiés, Allianz prend des mesures préventives et, en cas de violations, elle intervient rapidement pour les corriger.

  3. Politiques de Non-Discrimination : Allianz a une politique de tolérance zéro envers la discrimination, assurant un traitement égal des employés, indépendamment de leur origine, statut de santé, orientation sexuelle, âge, genre, croyances religieuses, ou toute autre caractéristique protégée.

  4. Mécanismes de Plaintes : Le mécanisme global de plaintes SpeakUp@Allianz permet aux employés de soulever des préoccupations, y compris celles liées aux risques et violations des droits de l'Homme.

  5. Entraînement et Sensibilisation : Allianz offre des formations sur les questions liées à la durabilité, y compris le traitement égal et la santé et sécurité au travail.

  6. Engagement International : Allianz soutient et respecte les droits de l'Homme tels que définis dans la Déclaration Internationale des Droits de l'Homme et les Conventions Fondamentales de l'Organisation Internationale du Travail (OIT).

Ces engagements visent à assurer un environnement de travail sûr, équitable et respectueux pour tous les employés de l'entreprise.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM2 :
  • # Integrating Sustainability in Own Operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad-hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promptly and effectively (see our [Policy Statement on Human Rights](URL)). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: - The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. - Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. - Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well-being. - Training in sustainability-related issues, including equal treatment and occupational health & safety, at Group and subsidiary levels. # Integrating Sustainability in Own Operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad-hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promptly and effectively (see our [Policy Statement on Human Rights](URL)). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: - The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. - Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. - Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well-being. - Training in sustainability-related issues, including equal treatment and occupational health & safety, at Group and subsidiary levels.
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS: On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS:
  • In addition to the zero-tolerance policy toward discrimination included in the Allianz Group Code of Conduct, the Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social origin, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with these general principles. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social origin, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with these general principles.   • ### Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain Allianz is committed to supporting and respecting the protection of international human rights, as well as ensuring it is not complicit in the abuse of human rights, as outlined in the International Bill of Rights and the ILO Core Conventions. This commitment also applies to our value chain. Allianz's due diligence approach to identify, prevent, and mitigate adverse human rights impacts linked to business activities has been guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UNGPs. As a multinational insurance and asset management company, our value chain encompasses workers at: - Allianz suppliers, - companies insured by Allianz, - companies that Allianz invests in as part of its proprietary investments, and - our tied agents responsible for distributing our products. ### Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain Allianz is committed to supporting and respecting the protection of international human rights, as well as ensuring it is not complicit in the abuse of human rights, as outlined in the International Bill of Rights and the ILO Core Conventions. This commitment also applies to our value chain. Allianz's due diligence approach to identify, prevent, and mitigate adverse human rights impacts linked to business activities has been guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UNGPs. As a multinational insurance and asset management company, our value chain encompasses workers at: - Allianz suppliers, - companies insured by Allianz, - companies that Allianz invests in as part of its proprietary investments, and - our tied agents responsible for distributing our products.
  • # Human Rights in Own Workforce Allianz recognizes the importance of human rights as both a value-based and a business issue. We see respect for human rights as a minimum standard for responsible business, both within and beyond our direct operations. For further information on our human rights commitment see our Human Rights Policy Statement. # Human Rights in Own Workforce Allianz recognizes the importance of human rights as both a value-based and a business issue. We see respect for human rights as a minimum standard for responsible business, both within and beyond our direct operations. For further information on our human rights commitment see our Human Rights Policy Statement.

  • ## Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report. At Allianz, sustainability is viewed as a journey across a dynamic and constantly evolving landscape. As such, we embrace the role of a learning organization. We acknowledge the ongoing enhancements of our impact, risk, and opportunity assessments as the maturity and availability of data, external credible sources, and independent standards continue to evolve, enabling us to effectively address the challenges of sustainability. ## Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report. At Allianz, sustainability is viewed as a journey across a dynamic and constantly evolving landscape. As such, we embrace the role of a learning organization. We acknowledge the ongoing enhancements of our impact, risk, and opportunity assessments as the maturity and availability of data, external credible sources, and independent standards continue to evolve, enabling us to effectively address the challenges of sustainability.
  • ### END TABLE Engagements conducted in 2024 include engaging with customers via online platforms, social media, newsletters, and various marketing campaigns. Although engagements were taking place prior to this, the reporting process was not in place and therefore the number is not reported. In 2024, six of the nine markets in-scope reported engagements. Of the three markets which did not report engagements in 2024, there was a focus on creating credible roadmaps for future engagements. It is therefore expected that all nine markets will report engagements in 2025. ### END TABLE Engagements conducted in 2024 include engaging with customers via online platforms, social media, newsletters, and various marketing campaigns. Although engagements were taking place prior to this, the reporting process was not in place and therefore the number is not reported. In 2024, six of the nine markets in-scope reported engagements. Of the three markets which did not report engagements in 2024, there was a focus on creating credible roadmaps for future engagements. It is therefore expected that all nine markets will report engagements in 2025.

L'entreprise s'engage à respecter les droits de l'Homme de ses employés à travers plusieurs mesures clés. Elle considère les droits de l'Homme comme un minimum pour le traitement de ses employés et réalise des évaluations annuelles et ponctuelles des risques liés aux droits des employés. Les principaux engagements incluent :

  1. Égalité de traitement et opportunités pour tous : Cela englobe la diversité, l'inclusion, et l'acquisition et la rétention des talents.

  2. Des salaires adéquats et compétitifs : L'entreprise veille à ce que les salaires soient équitables et compétitifs.

  3. Liberté d'association et de négociation collective : L'entreprise soutient la liberté d'association et le dialogue avec ses employés.

  4. Santé et sécurité au travail : L'entreprise met en place des mesures pour assurer la sécurité physique et améliorer la santé et le bien-être des employés.

  5. Mécanisme de plainte : Le mécanisme "SpeakUp@ Allianz" permet aux employés de signaler des préoccupations, y compris les risques et violations des droits de l'Homme.

Ces engagements sont intégrés dans les règles d'entreprise et reflètent les obligations de l'entreprise en matière de diligence raisonnable en droits de l'Homme.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Integrating sustainability in own operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad-hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promptly and effectively (see our Policy Statement on Human Rights). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: - The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. - Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. - Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well-being. - Training in sustainability-related issues, including equal treatment and occupational health & safety, at Group and subsidiary levels.
  • Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social origin, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with the general principles. We support and respect international human rights as outlined in the International Bill of Human Rights and the core International Labor Organization Convention. Our due diligence processes in own operations comply with the requirements of the GSCA, aligned with the UNGPs.
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS:
  • # --- Page 79 --- ## C_ Group Management Report_ Sustainability Statement ### Human rights in own workforce Allianz recognizes the importance of human rights as both a value- based and a business issue. We see respect for human rights as a minimum standard for responsible business, both within and beyond our direct operations. For further information on our human rights commitment see our Human Rights Policy Statement.
  • ### Section summary The section describes how Allianz's commitment to human rights applies to the human rights and labor standards of workers in our value chain. For us, value chain workers encompass those at our suppliers, at the companies we insure and invest in, and at Allianz tied agents. For each of these stages of our value chain we have dedicated policies and actions, which are described below. They all aim to identify, assess, and mitigate risks to human rights as well as to stop and remediate human rights violations. Our complaints mechanism, NGO dialogue, and other channels allow us to engage with affected value chain workers.
  • ### Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain Allianz is committed to supporting and respecting the protection of international human rights, as well as ensuring it is not complicit in the abuse of human rights, as outlined in the International Bill of Rights and the ILO Core Conventions. This commitment also applies to our value chain. Allianz's due diligence approach to identify, prevent, and mitigate adverse human rights impacts linked to business activities has been guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UNGPs. As a multinational insurance and asset management company, our value chain encompasses workers at: - Allianz suppliers, - companies insured by Allianz, - companies that Allianz invests in as part of its proprietary investments, and - our tied agents responsible for distributing our products.
  • ### Section summary Our strategy details how we manage and support our workforce with the ambition of being the top employer in the financial services industry globally. Our policies emphasize fair treatment, diversity and inclusion, and lifelong learning, all aimed at fostering an environment where every employee feels valued and respected. Our strategy involves setting clear targets for employee engagement, development, and gender and generational diversity as further outlined below. Key actions include conducting regular employee engagement surveys, offering various training programs, establishing multiple exchange forums, networks, and partnerships to promote inclusivity, and enhancing an Occupational Health and Safety Management system, as further outlined below.
  • During the supplier onboarding process, suppliers registered in our standard tool for procurement are asked to comply with the VCoC or to submit a comparable code of conduct. For suppliers over a defined threshold, we apply additional checks, including questions on their human rights due diligence. This mitigates the risk of engaging with suppliers who do not uphold human rights standards. Additional actions and processes are based on voluntary commitments as well as the requirements of the GSCA. If risks related to violations of human rights of supply chain workers are identified, we take appropriate preventive measures, including, for example, engaging with the companies in question or adding human rights- related contractual clauses to the supplier agreement. If we identify human rights violations in our supply chain, we seek to take remedial action, in line with our ability to influence suppliers. We will sever the supplier relationship as a last resort.

Los indicadores incluyen: 1. **Reducción de emisiones propias en inversiones**: Emisiones absolutas financiadas de GHG en millones de toneladas de CO2e provenientes de corporaciones listadas, con un objetivo de **12.3 mn t CO2e**. 2. **Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)**: Porcentaje de líderes de lealtad en segmentos de negocio, con un objetivo de **50 %**. 3. **Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)**: Desarrollo contra el nivel de ambición general, con un objetivo de **77 %**. 4. **Plan de transición hacia compromisos de cero emisiones netas**: Incluye reducción de emisiones en el sector de motor retail y reducción de intensidad de emisiones en el sector comercial de Property-Casualty. 5. **Soluciones sostenibles en Property-Casualty**. 6. **Desarrollo del Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 7. **Desarrollo del Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 8. **Cumplimiento estricto de requisitos regulatorios y de gobernanza corporativa**, con enfoque en un sistema de gestión de riesgos adecuado y cultura de riesgos. 9. **Contribución de liderazgo**, con enfoque en atributos de personas de Allianz: Excelencia en clientes y mercado, liderazgo colaborativo, emprendimiento y confianza; evaluación multi-rater. ### END TABLE
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos sobre la intensidad de gases de efecto invernadero (GHG) y el volumen total de negocios de Allianz Group al 31 de diciembre de 2024 y 2023. - **Etiquetas de columnas**: "0", "1", "2", "3". - **Etiquetas de filas**: "As of 31 December", "Total business volume1", "Total GHG emissions (market-based)2", "GHG intensity (market-based)", "Total GHG emissions (location-based)2", "GHG intensity (location-based)". - **Años**: 2024 y 2023. **Datos clave**: 1. La intensidad de GHG basada en el mercado ("GHG intensity (market-based)") fue de **272.2 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2024 y **356.0 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2023. 4. Las emisiones totales de GHG basadas en la ubicación ("Total GHG emissions (location-based)2") fueron de **49,067,050.4 t en CO2e** en 2024 y **57,688,706.5 t en CO2e** en 2023. 5. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en investigación, desarrollo, demostración y despliegue de instalaciones innovadoras de generación de electricidad que producen energía a partir de procesos nucleares con residuos mínimos del ciclo de combustible. **Estado:** NO. 2. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción y operación segura de nuevas instalaciones nucleares para producir electricidad o calor de proceso, incluyendo calefacción distrital, procesos industriales como la producción de hidrógeno, y mejoras de seguridad utilizando las mejores tecnologías disponibles. 3. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la operación segura de instalaciones nucleares existentes que producen electricidad o calor de proceso, incluyendo calefacción distrital, procesos industriales como la producción de hidrógeno a partir de energía nuclear, y mejoras de seguridad. **Actividades relacionadas con el gas fósil:** 4. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción u operación de instalaciones de generación de electricidad que producen electricidad utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. 5. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción, renovación y operación de instalaciones de generación combinada de calor/frío y electricidad utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. 6. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción, renovación y operación de instalaciones de generación de calor/frío utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. ### END TABLE

L'entreprise s'engage fortement en matière de respect des droits de l'Homme de ses employés. Voici les principaux engagements :

  1. Égalité de traitement : Tous les employés sont traités de manière égale, indépendamment de leur origine nationale ou ethnique, origine sociale, état de santé, handicap, orientation sexuelle, âge, sexe, croyances religieuses, ou toute autre caractéristique protégée.

  2. Santé et sécurité au travail : L'entreprise met en place des mesures étendues pour assurer la sécurité physique et améliorer la santé et le bien-être des employés.

  3. Liberté d'association et de négociation collective : Elle respecte et soutient les droits des employés à s'associer librement et à participer à des négociations collectives.

  4. Salaires décents : Elle s'engage à garantir des salaires qui permettent un niveau de vie adéquat.

  5. Interdiction du travail des enfants et du travail forcé : L'entreprise interdit strictement toute forme de travail des enfants et de travail forcé.

  6. Mécanismes de feedback et de plainte : Des outils de feedback anonymes et des mécanismes de plainte, tels que SpeakUp@Allianz, permettent aux employés de signaler des préoccupations ou des violations des droits de l'Homme.

  7. Formation et sensibilisation : Des formations sur les questions liées à la durabilité, y compris le traitement équitable et la santé et la sécurité au travail, sont proposées à tous les niveaux de l'organisation.

Ces engagements sont alignés avec les normes internationales, telles que la Déclaration universelle des droits de l'Homme et les conventions fondamentales de l'Organisation internationale du travail (OIT).

  • development. We have a strong focus on equal treatment and opportunities for all; this encompasses diversity, inclusion, and talent acquisition and retention. The health and well -being of our employees continues to be an area of focus – our practices typically include offering flexibility in working time, paying competitive wages, and fostering freedom of association and dialogue with our employees. Furthermore, securing the confidentiality of employee data is key for us.   • public human rights commitment, see the Allianz Human Rights Policy Statement and the Sustainability Integration Framework . While Allianz has not adopted a dedicated process to engage with value chain workers, human rights issues can be addressed through existing engagement channels. Everyone inside and outside Allianz can report issues related to the human rights of workers in our value chain through our independent complaints mechanism, SpeakUp@ Allianz , which is further detailed in the section G1 Business conduct . In 2024, no severe human rights violations of value chain workers were reported through SpeakUp@Alllianz. Adverse media screenings of potentially high -risk suppliers did not produce any information on human rights violations in our supply chain in 2024. For our insurance and proprietary investment, the ASIS process is designed to prevent Allianz from insuring or investing in public human rights commitment, see the Allianz Human Rights Policy Statement and the Sustainability Integration Framework .   • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities.   • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
