Thereof with a focus on Climate Change 72 n.a. 1_Many engagements have multiple topics, sometimes also multiple topics falling into one
  • potential customers, individual targets have been provided to each in - scope operating entity, based on their current number of customers and potential customers noted within plan figures, excluding all customers who currently drive BEVs. This enables engagements with customers who own higher -emitting vehicles and are yet to make the transition to more sustainable mobility options. The indiv idual targets have been set in collaboration with su bsidiaries . Subsidiaries have provided their planned year -on-year customer engagements to enable progress to be tracked. When combined, they meet the Group target of 20 million engagements by 2030. The Group uses established reporting processes to track progress against these planned engagements . Targets on engagement for motor retail insurance number of engagements (in mn) 2024 2023 2030 target Engagements on transition to BEVs >4.5 n.a. 20 Engagements conducted in 2024 include engaging with customers via potential customers, individual targets have been provided to each in - scope operating entity, based on their current number of customers and potential customers noted within plan figures, excluding all customers who currently drive BEVs. This enables engagements with customers who own higher -emitting vehicles and are yet to make the transition to more sustainable mobility options. The indiv idual targets have been set in collaboration with su bsidiaries . Subsidiaries have provided their planned year -on-year customer engagements to enable progress to be tracked. When combined, they meet the Group target of 20 million engagements by 2030. The Group uses established reporting processes to track progress against these planned engagements . Targets on engagement for motor retail insurance number of engagements (in mn) 2024 2023 2030 target Engagements on transition to BEVs >4.5 n.a. 20 Engagements conducted in 2024 include engaging with customers via
S1-18

Peux-tu me donner des détails sur l'approche générale de l'entreprise en matière de respect des droits de l'homme, y compris les droits du travail, pour ses propres employés ?

nan

L'approche de l'entreprise en matière de respect des droits de l'homme, y compris les droits du travail pour ses propres employés, est centrée sur plusieurs aspects clés :

  1. Politiques et Engagements : L'entreprise s'engage à identifier, prévenir, atténuer ou remédier aux impacts négatifs sur les droits de l'homme liés à ses activités commerciales et opérations, y compris sa chaîne d'approvisionnement. Cet engagement est guidé par les Principes directeurs des Nations Unies sur les entreprises et les droits de l'homme (UNGP) et les Lignes directrices de l'Organisation de coopération et de développement économiques (OCDE) pour les entreprises multinationales.

  2. Diligence Raisonnable : L'entreprise met en œuvre des politiques de diligence raisonnable, notamment en conformité avec la loi allemande sur la diligence raisonnable dans les chaînes d'approvisionnement (GSCA). Ces politiques couvrent les opérations internes et les chaînes d'approvisionnement, et sont détaillées dans la déclaration de politique sur les droits de l'homme d'Allianz SE.

  3. Mécanismes de Plaintes : Un mécanisme global de plaintes, nommé SpeakUp@Allianz, est en place pour permettre aux employés de soulever des préoccupations, y compris les risques et violations des droits de l'homme. Ce mécanisme est largement promu au sein de l'entreprise et fait partie de la formation mondiale sur la déclaration des violations.

  4. Principaux Droits Reconnus : Les droits humains les plus pertinents pour la main-d'œuvre de l'entreprise incluent le traitement équitable, des salaires adéquats, la liberté d'association et de négociation collective, ainsi que la santé et la sécurité au travail.

  5. Diversité, Équité et Inclusion (DEI) : L'entreprise accorde une attention particulière à la diversité, l'équité et l'inclusion, reconnaissant que des équipes diverses obtiennent de meilleurs résultats, montrent une plus grande résilience et stimulent l'innovation et la productivité.

Pour plus de détails, il est recommandé de se référer aux sections spécifiques sur la main-d'œuvre propre et les droits humains dans les rapports de l'entreprise.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Le tableau présente une liste de sujets de durabilité, des exigences de divulgation associées, des sections correspondantes et des sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections détaillant les aspects spécifiques à traiter. Les sujets incluent "E4 Biodiversity and ecosystems", "E5 Resource use and circular economy" et "S1 Own workforce". Pour "E4 Biodiversity and ecosystems", les sous-sections couvrent la stratégie et le modèle d'affaires, la matérialité, les politiques, les actions et les objectifs liés à la biodiversité et aux écosystèmes. Pour "E5 Resource use and circular economy", les sous-sections incluent la matérialité, les politiques, les actions, les objectifs et les métriques, telles que l'influx de ressources et les déchets électroniques. Concernant "S1 Own workforce", les sous-sections abordent la stratégie "Group People and Culture", la matérialité, les politiques, l'engagement, les processus pour soulever des préoccupations, les actions, les objectifs, les caractéristiques des employés, la négociation collective, le genre, les générations, les salaires adéquats, la protection sociale, les personnes handicapées, l'apprentissage et le développement, la santé et la sécurité, l'équilibre travail-vie personnelle, l'écart de rémunération entre les sexes et les droits humains. Chaque sujet est structuré pour analyser les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés à ces domaines. and

    Le tableau présente une liste de sujets de durabilité, des exigences de divulgation associées, des sections correspondantes et des sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections détaillant les aspects spécifiques à traiter. Les sujets abordés incluent la biodiversité et les écosystèmes, l'utilisation des ressources et l'économie circulaire, ainsi que la gestion de la main-d'œuvre propre. Chaque sujet est divisé en plusieurs catégories, telles que la stratégie, la matérialité, les politiques, les actions, les objectifs, et les métriques, afin de fournir une vue complète des impacts, des risques et des opportunités liés à ces domaines.

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, classés par leur matérialité ("matériel", "non matériel" ou "non pertinent") et leurs sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections. Les exigences matérielles incluent : 1. **ESRS S2-1** : Non-respect des principes des UNGPs et des lignes directrices de l'OCDE (paragraphe 19) et politiques de diligence raisonnable liées aux conventions fondamentales de l'OIT (1 à 8, paragraphe 19), dans les sous-sections "politiques Allianz ESRS" et "stratégie et modèle d'affaires liés aux travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur". 2. **ESRS S2-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains dans la chaîne de valeur (paragraphe 36), avec des cibles, actions et processus pour remédier aux impacts négatifs. 3. **ESRS S3-1** : Engagements politiques en matière de droits humains (paragraphe 16) et non-respect des principes des UNGPs, de l'OIT ou de l'OCDE (paragraphe 17), dans le cadre de la stratégie et du modèle d'affaires liés aux communautés affectées. 4. **ESRS S3-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains (paragraphe 36), avec des actions et processus d'engagement avec les communautés affectées. 5. **ESRS S4-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains (paragraphe 35), avec des actions. 6. **ESRS G1-4** : Incidents confirmés de corruption ou de pots-de-vin (paragraphes 24 (a) et (b)). Les points non matériels ou non pertinents incluent : - **ESRS S4-1** : Politiques liées aux consommateurs et utilisateurs finaux (paragraphes 16 et 17), jugées non applicables. - **ESRS G1-1** : Convention des Nations Unies contre la corruption (paragraphe 10 (b)) et protection des lanceurs d'alerte (paragraphe 10 (d)), avec des politiques déjà en place. and

Les points non matériels ou non pertinents concernent principalement les politiques déjà en place ou les aspects jugés non applicables.

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation liées à différents aspects de la durabilité, classées par matière de durabilité, section et sous-section. Les principales catégories incluent les travailleurs dans la chaîne de valeur, les communautés affectées, les consommateurs et utilisateurs finaux, la stratégie et gouvernance de durabilité, la matérialité, et la conduite des affaires. Chaque catégorie est associée à des sous-sections spécifiques, telles que les politiques, les objectifs, les actions, les processus pour soulever des préoccupations, et les modèles stratégiques. Les informations couvrent des sujets variés, allant de la gestion des relations avec les fournisseurs à la prévention de la corruption et des activités de lobbying.

  • Le tableau présente des données sur les droits humains et la main-d'œuvre propre pour les années 2024 et 2023. Les colonnes incluent "Description", "Unité", "2024" et "2023". Les lignes sont : "Nombre de plaintes déposées par les employés via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz", "Nombre de plaintes déposées auprès des Points de Contact Nationaux pour les Entreprises Multinationales de l'OCDE", "Nombre d'incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement", "Nombre d'incidents graves relatifs aux droits humains concernant la main-d'œuvre propre", et "Montant des amendes matérielles, pénalités et compensations pour incidents liés à la main-d'œuvre propre". En 2024, 388 plaintes ont été déposées via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz, et 31 incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement, ont été signalés. Aucun incident grave relatif aux droits humains ou montant d'amendes n'a été enregistré pour cette année. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.). and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente des données sur les plaintes, incidents et amendes liés aux droits humains et à la main-d'œuvre propre pour les années 2024 et 2023. En 2024, 388 plaintes ont été déposées via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz, et 31 incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement, ont été signalés. Aucun incident grave relatif aux droits humains ou montant d'amendes n'a été enregistré pour cette année. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.).

  • For information on our global complaints mechanism to allow our employees to raise concerns, please refer to the section Human rights in own workforce. DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) This section includes disclosures relevant to our DEI strategy, including the strategic sub-sections Gender, Generations as well as Persons with disabilities and disclosures relevant to the ESRS S1 Own workforce sustainability matter “Equal treatment and opportunity for all”. DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) DEI is a core element in helping our business to fulfill and meet the needs of our equally diverse customer base. We also know that diverse teams yield better results, show higher resilience, and drive innovation and productivity. Central to achieving this is creating an inclusive culture where all our employees can be themselves and unique views are appreciated and respected. For information on our global complaints mechanism to allow our employees to raise concerns, please refer to the section Human rights in own workforce. DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) This section includes disclosures relevant to our DEI strategy, including the strategic sub-sections Gender, Generations as well as Persons with disabilities and disclosures relevant to the ESRS S1 Own workforce sustainability matter “Equal treatment and opportunity for all”. DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) DEI is a core element in helping our business to fulfill and meet the needs of our equally diverse customer base. We also know that diverse teams yield better results, show higher resilience, and drive innovation and productivity. Central to achieving this is creating an inclusive culture where all our employees can be themselves and unique views are appreciated and respected.
  • Allianz aims to identify, prevent, mitigate or remediate adverse human rights impacts linked to its business activities and operations, including our supply chain. Our approach is guided by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the U.N. Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGP). Our due diligence in own operations and supply chains complies with the German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (GSCA) and is covered by the Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement. Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report. Allianz aims to identify, prevent, mitigate or remediate adverse human rights impacts linked to its business activities and operations, including our supply chain. Our approach is guided by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the U.N. Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGP). Our due diligence in own operations and supply chains complies with the German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (GSCA) and is covered by the Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement. Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report.
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS: On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA.   • Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau détaille les "exigences de divulgation et points de données associés", leur "matérialité" (matériel ou non matériel), et les "sous-sections/sous-sous-sections" correspondantes. Les points matériels incluent : 1. **ESRS E4-2** : Politiques sur les océans/mer et la déforestation, liées à la biodiversité et aux écosystèmes. 2. **ESRS E5-5** : Déchets non recyclés et dangereux, liés à l'économie circulaire et à l'utilisation des ressources. 3. **ESRS S1-1** : Engagements en matière de droits humains, politiques de diligence raisonnable, prévention des accidents, et mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, liés à la main-d'œuvre propre. 4. **ESRS S1-14** : Santé et sécurité, incluant les accidents et jours perdus. 5. **ESRS S1-16** : Écarts de rémunération entre genres et ratios de rémunération. 6. **ESRS S1-17** : Incidents de discrimination et non-respect des principes directeurs de l'ONU et des lignes directrices de l'OCDE, liés aux droits humains dans la main-d'œuvre propre. 7. **ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S2** : Risques significatifs de travail des enfants ou forcé dans la chaîne de valeur. 8. **ESRS S2-1** : Engagements en matière de droits humains pour les travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur. Les points non matériels incluent les risques d'incidents de travail forcé ou des enfants (ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S1) et les mesures contre la traite humaine (ESRS S1-1). and

    ESRS S1-16 Unadjusted gender pay gap, paragraph 97 (a) Material - not disclosed Gender pay gap and remuneration ratio
    ESRS S1-16 Excessive CEO pay ratio, paragraph 97 (b) Material Gender pay gap and remuneration ratio
    ESRS S1-17 Incidents of discrimination, paragraph 103 (a) Material Human rights in own workforce
    ESRS S1-17 Non-respect of UNGPs on Business and Human Rights and OECD Guidelines, paragraph 104 (a) Material Human rights in own workforce
    ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S2 Significant risk of child labor or forced labor in the value chain, paragraph 11 (b) Material Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain
    ESRS S2-1 Human rights policy commitments, paragraph 18 Material Policies related to workers in the value chain

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité (matériel ou non matériel), ainsi que les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. Les points de données matériels concernent principalement les politiques liées à la biodiversité, l'économie circulaire, la sécurité au travail, les droits humains, les mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, et les écarts de rémunération. Les points non matériels sont considérés comme non applicables.

  • Le tableau présente deux catégories d'activités : **activités liées à l'énergie nucléaire** et **activités liées au gaz fossile**, avec une colonne "YES/NO" indiquant si l'entreprise mène, finance ou est exposée à ces activités. Pour les **activités nucléaires** : 1. Les activités de recherche, développement, démonstration et déploiement d'installations innovantes produisant de l'énergie nucléaire avec des déchets minimaux sont marquées "NO". 2. Les activités de construction et d'exploitation sécurisée de nouvelles installations nucléaires pour produire de l'électricité ou de la chaleur, y compris pour le chauffage urbain ou des processus industriels comme la production d'hydrogène, sont marquées "YES". 3. Les activités d'exploitation sécurisée des installations nucléaires existantes pour produire de l'électricité ou de la chaleur, y compris pour le chauffage urbain ou des processus industriels comme la production d'hydrogène, sont également marquées "YES". Pour les **activités liées au gaz fossile** : 4. La construction ou l'exploitation d'installations de production d'électricité utilisant des combustibles gazeux fossiles est marquée "YES". 5. La construction, rénovation et exploitation d'installations de cogénération de chaleur/refroidissement et d'électricité utilisant des combustibles gazeux fossiles sont marquées "YES". 6. La construction, rénovation et exploitation d'installations de production de chaleur/refroidissement utilisant des combustibles gazeux fossiles sont également marquées "YES". and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Row Nuclear energy related activities YES/NO
    1 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to research, development, demonstration and deployment of innovative electricity generation facilities that produce energy from nuclear processes with minimal waste from the fuel cycle. NO
    2 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to construction and safe operation of new nuclear installations to produce electricity or process heat, including for the purposes of district heating or industrial processes such as hydrogen production, as well as their safety upgrades, using best available technologies. YES
    3 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to safe operation of existing nuclear installations that produce electricity or process heat, including for the purposes of district heating or industrial processes such as hydrogen production from nuclear energy, as well as their safety upgrades. YES
    ----- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------
    Row Fossil gas related activities YES/NO
    4 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to construction or operation of electricity generation facilities that produce electricity using fossil gaseous fuels. YES
    5 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to construction, refurbishment, and operation of combined heat/cool and power generation facilities using fossil gaseous fuels. YES
    6 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to construction, refurbishment and operation of heat generation facilities that produce heat/cool using fossil gaseous fuels. YES

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente deux catégories d'activités : celles liées à l'énergie nucléaire et celles liées au gaz fossile. Pour les activités nucléaires, seules les activités de construction et d'exploitation sécurisée des installations nucléaires, qu'elles soient nouvelles ou existantes, sont marquées comme "YES". Les activités de recherche et développement pour des installations innovantes produisant de l'énergie nucléaire avec des déchets minimaux sont marquées "NO". En ce qui concerne les activités liées au gaz fossile, toutes les activités mentionnées, qu'il s'agisse de la construction, de la rénovation ou de l'exploitation d'installations de production d'électricité, de chaleur ou de refroidissement utilisant des combustibles gazeux fossiles, sont marquées "YES".

L'entreprise intègre le respect des droits de l'homme comme un standard minimum pour le traitement de ses employés. Elle réalise des évaluations annuelles et ponctuelles des risques liés aux droits des employés conformément au Global Social Compliance Audit (GSCA). En cas de risques identifiés, elle prend des mesures préventives, et en cas de violations, elle veille à les corriger rapidement et efficacement. Les droits de l'homme sont inscrits dans les règles d'entreprise, en tenant compte des lois locales. Des outils de feedback anonymes et des enquêtes permettent aux employés d'évaluer des aspects tels que la charge de travail, les salaires et la diversité. Des mesures étendues sont mises en place pour garantir la sécurité physique et améliorer la santé et le bien-être des employés. La formation sur les questions liées à la durabilité, y compris le traitement équitable et la santé et sécurité au travail, est dispensée au niveau du groupe et des filiales. L'entreprise soutient également les principes des conventions fondamentales de l'OIT sur la liberté d'association et la négociation collective, respectant les lois locales en matière de syndicats et de représentation des employés là où ces principes sont inscrits dans la loi.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM2 :
  • # Integrating Sustainability in Own Operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad-hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promptly and effectively (see our [Policy Statement on Human Rights](URL)). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: - The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. - Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. - Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well-being. - Training in sustainability-related issues, including equal treatment and occupational health & safety, at Group and subsidiary levels. # Integrating Sustainability in Own Operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad-hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promptly and effectively (see our [Policy Statement on Human Rights](URL)). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: - The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. - Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. - Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well-being. - Training in sustainability-related issues, including equal treatment and occupational health & safety, at Group and subsidiary levels.
  • ## Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report. At Allianz, sustainability is viewed as a journey across a dynamic and constantly evolving landscape. As such, we embrace the role of a learning organization. We acknowledge the ongoing enhancements of our impact, risk, and opportunity assessments as the maturity and availability of data, external credible sources, and independent standards continue to evolve, enabling us to effectively address the challenges of sustainability. ## Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report. At Allianz, sustainability is viewed as a journey across a dynamic and constantly evolving landscape. As such, we embrace the role of a learning organization. We acknowledge the ongoing enhancements of our impact, risk, and opportunity assessments as the maturity and availability of data, external credible sources, and independent standards continue to evolve, enabling us to effectively address the challenges of sustainability.
  • ### Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain Allianz is committed to supporting and respecting the protection of international human rights, as well as ensuring it is not complicit in the abuse of human rights, as outlined in the International Bill of Rights and the ILO Core Conventions. This commitment also applies to our value chain. Allianz's due diligence approach to identify, prevent, and mitigate adverse human rights impacts linked to business activities has been guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UNGPs. As a multinational insurance and asset management company, our value chain encompasses workers at: - Allianz suppliers, - companies insured by Allianz, - companies that Allianz invests in as part of its proprietary investments, and - our tied agents responsible for distributing our products. ### Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain Allianz is committed to supporting and respecting the protection of international human rights, as well as ensuring it is not complicit in the abuse of human rights, as outlined in the International Bill of Rights and the ILO Core Conventions. This commitment also applies to our value chain. Allianz's due diligence approach to identify, prevent, and mitigate adverse human rights impacts linked to business activities has been guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UNGPs. As a multinational insurance and asset management company, our value chain encompasses workers at: - Allianz suppliers, - companies insured by Allianz, - companies that Allianz invests in as part of its proprietary investments, and - our tied agents responsible for distributing our products.
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS: On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety.   • ## Taking Action on Material Impacts, Risks, and Opportunities We implement specific actions, managed by dedicated Group People and Culture functions, to act on material impacts, mitigate material risks, and pursue material opportunities (see the section [Group People and Culture strategy - Related impacts, risks, and opportunities](#)). These actions are outlined in the remaining sections: - Characteristics of our employees, - Processes for engaging with our own workforce, - DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion), - Learning and development and performance management, - Fair remuneration, - Human rights in own workforce, - Social protection and health and safety. The structure of the sections in the remainder of “S1 Own workforce” generally adheres to the Policies – Actions – Targets logic. ## Taking Action on Material Impacts, Risks, and Opportunities We implement specific actions, managed by dedicated Group People and Culture functions, to act on material impacts, mitigate material risks, and pursue material opportunities (see the section [Group People and Culture strategy - Related impacts, risks, and opportunities](#)). These actions are outlined in the remaining sections: - Characteristics of our employees, - Processes for engaging with our own workforce, - DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion), - Learning and development and performance management, - Fair remuneration, - Human rights in own workforce, - Social protection and health and safety. The structure of the sections in the remainder of “S1 Own workforce” generally adheres to the Policies – Actions – Targets logic.
  • During the supplier onboarding process, suppliers registered in our standard tool for procurement are asked to comply with the VCoC or to submit a comparable code of conduct. For suppliers over a defined threshold, we apply additional checks, including questions on their human rights due diligence. This mitigates the risk of engaging with suppliers who do not uphold human rights standards. Additional actions and processes are based on voluntary commitments as well as the requirements of the _GSCA_. If risks related to violations of human rights of supply chain workers are identified, we take appropriate preventive measures, including, for example, engaging with the companies in question or adding human rights-related contractual clauses to the supplier agreement. If we identify human rights violations in our supply chain, we seek to take remedial action, in line with our ability to influence suppliers. We will sever the supplier relationship as a last resort. During the supplier onboarding process, suppliers registered in our standard tool for procurement are asked to comply with the VCoC or to submit a comparable code of conduct. For suppliers over a defined threshold, we apply additional checks, including questions on their human rights due diligence. This mitigates the risk of engaging with suppliers who do not uphold human rights standards. Additional actions and processes are based on voluntary commitments as well as the requirements of the _GSCA_. If risks related to violations of human rights of supply chain workers are identified, we take appropriate preventive measures, including, for example, engaging with the companies in question or adding human rights-related contractual clauses to the supplier agreement. If we identify human rights violations in our supply chain, we seek to take remedial action, in line with our ability to influence suppliers. We will sever the supplier relationship as a last resort.
  • ### Risks **Section summary** The section describes how Allianz's commitment to human rights applies to the human rights and labor standards of workers in our value chain. For us, value chain workers encompass those at our suppliers, at the companies we insure and invest in, and at Allianz tied agents. For each of these stages of our value chain we have dedicated policies and actions, which are described below. They all aim to identify, assess, and mitigate risks to human rights as well as to stop and remediate human rights violations. Our complaints mechanism, NGO dialogue, and other channels allow us to engage with affected value chain workers. ### Risks **Section summary** The section describes how Allianz's commitment to human rights applies to the human rights and labor standards of workers in our value chain. For us, value chain workers encompass those at our suppliers, at the companies we insure and invest in, and at Allianz tied agents. For each of these stages of our value chain we have dedicated policies and actions, which are described below. They all aim to identify, assess, and mitigate risks to human rights as well as to stop and remediate human rights violations. Our complaints mechanism, NGO dialogue, and other channels allow us to engage with affected value chain workers.
  • ## Determination of (retro-)ceded premium share For natural catastrophe events, Allianz Group subsidiaries transfer a portion of their business and associated risks to Allianz SE Reinsurance through internal reinsurance agreements. Allianz SE Reinsurance pools this business and, along with the net retained business of these local entities, manages the risk using external reinsurance purchased centrally on behalf of Allianz SE. 115 --- --- #### The underwriting KPI for non-life insurance and reinsurance undertakings ### BEGIN TABLE | Economic activities | Substantial contribution to climate change adaptation | DNSH (Do Not Significant Harm) | |-------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------| | | Absolute premiums 2024 (c mn) | Proportion of premiums 2024 (%) | Proportion of premiums 2023 (%) | Climate change mitigation (Y/N) | Water and marine resources (Y/N) | Circular economy (Y/N) | Pollution (Y/N) | Biodiversity and ecosystems (Y/N) | Minimum safeguards (Y/N) | | A.1.   • ## Minimum Safeguards Taxonomy-aligned activities need to be carried out in compliance with Minimum Safeguards with respect to the value chain (i.e., with respect to policyholders in the insurance context). Minimum Safeguards require a due diligence process. Our approach is guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the U.N. Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. This is ensured by our Sustainability referral process governed by the Allianz Standard for Integration of Sustainability, which applies to insurance transactions following a risk-based approach. For more information on the Sustainability referral process, please refer to the Allianz Sustainability Integration Framework, version 6.0 on the Allianz company website. ## Minimum Safeguards Taxonomy-aligned activities need to be carried out in compliance with Minimum Safeguards with respect to the value chain (i.e., with respect to policyholders in the insurance context). Minimum Safeguards require a due diligence process. Our approach is guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the U.N. Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. This is ensured by our Sustainability referral process governed by the Allianz Standard for Integration of Sustainability, which applies to insurance transactions following a risk-based approach. For more information on the Sustainability referral process, please refer to the Allianz Sustainability Integration Framework, version 6.0 on the Allianz company website.
  • We support the principles included in the ILO core conventions on freedom of association and collective bargaining as outlined in the **Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations**. In countries where those principles have been enshrined in local law, we fully respect and implement local rules on trade unions and employee representation. In countries that have not ratified the relevant ILO conventions, we respect the primacy of local laws and look for ways to allow our employees to organize and voice their interests to the management. In compliance with the GSCA, each subsidiary in scope conducts an annual risk assessment for the rights to freedom of association and collective bargaining. For details, please refer to the section **Human rights in own workforce**. We support the principles included in the ILO core conventions on freedom of association and collective bargaining as outlined in the **Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations**. In countries where those principles have been enshrined in local law, we fully respect and implement local rules on trade unions and employee representation. In countries that have not ratified the relevant ILO conventions, we respect the primacy of local laws and look for ways to allow our employees to organize and voice their interests to the management. In compliance with the GSCA, each subsidiary in scope conducts an annual risk assessment for the rights to freedom of association and collective bargaining. For details, please refer to the section **Human rights in own workforce**.
  • - **22.66** For non-financial undertakings: 168.1 - **10.15** For financial undertakings: 75.3 ##### The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI: - **8.96** For non-financial undertakings: 66.5 - **33.59** For financial undertakings: 249.2 ##### The proportion of exposures to other counterparties and assets over total assets covered by the KPI: - **12.13** Value of exposures to other counterparties and assets: 90.0 The proportion of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking's investments other than investments held in respect of life insurance contracts where the investment risk is borne by the policy holders: - **85.62** Value of insurance or reinsurance undertaking's investments other than investments held in respect of life insurance contracts where the investment risk is borne by the policy holders: 635.2 - **22.66** For non-financial undertakings: 168.1 - **10.15** For financial undertakings: 75.3 ##### The proportion of exposures to financial and non-financial undertakings subject to Articles 19a and 29a of Directive 2013/34/EU over total assets covered by the KPI: - **8.96** For non-financial undertakings: 66.5 - **33.59** For financial undertakings: 249.2 ##### The proportion of exposures to other counterparties and assets over total assets covered by the KPI: - **12.13** Value of exposures to other counterparties and assets: 90.0 The proportion of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking's investments other than investments held in respect of life insurance contracts where the investment risk is borne by the policy holders: - **85.62** Value of insurance or reinsurance undertaking's investments other than investments held in respect of life insurance contracts where the investment risk is borne by the policy holders: 635.2

L'approche générale de l'entreprise en matière de respect des droits de l'homme, y compris les droits du travail, pour ses propres employés, est centrée sur plusieurs aspects clés :

  1. Protection des droits de l'homme : L'entreprise considère les droits de l'homme comme une norme minimale pour le traitement de ses employés. Elle a intégré la protection des droits de l'homme dans ses règles d'entreprise, en fonction des lois et exigences locales (Context Num-1).

  2. Évaluations des risques : Des évaluations annuelles et ponctuelles des risques pour les droits des employés sont effectuées conformément au GSCA. Si des risques ou des violations sont identifiés, des mesures préventives ou correctives sont mises en place rapidement et efficacement (Context Num-1).

  3. Conditions de travail et égalité de traitement : L'entreprise met l'accent sur l'égalité de traitement et les opportunités pour tous, englobant la diversité, l'inclusion et la rétention des talents. Des pratiques telles que la flexibilité du temps de travail, des salaires compétitifs et la promotion de la liberté d'association sont en place pour favoriser un environnement de travail équitable (Context Num-4).

  4. Mécanisme de plainte : Un mécanisme de plainte global, SpeakUp@ Allianz, est mis à disposition pour permettre à tous, y compris les employés, de signaler des préoccupations ou des violations des droits de l'homme. Ce mécanisme est largement promu au sein de l'entreprise (Context Num-3).

  5. Normes européennes : L'entreprise applique des normes à l'échelle européenne pour protéger les droits des employés, incluant la représentation effective de sa propre main-d'œuvre au niveau européen (Context Num-6).

  6. Diligence raisonnable : Des processus de diligence raisonnable en matière de droits de l'homme sont en place pour gérer les risques pour les droits des employés, en mettant l'accent sur l'égalité de traitement, la sécurité et la santé au travail, la liberté d'association et des salaires décents (Context Num-8).

En résumé, l'entreprise s'engage activement à protéger et promouvoir les droits de l'homme et du travail au sein de ses opérations, en adoptant des pratiques qui visent à prévenir et réduire les impacts négatifs potentiels sur ses employés.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Integrating sustainability in own operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad-hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promptly and effectively (see our Policy Statement on Human Rights). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: - The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. - Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. - Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well-being. - Training in sustainability-related issues, including equal treatment and occupational health & safety, at Group and subsidiary levels.
  • ### Section summary Our strategy details how we manage and support our workforce with the ambition of being the top employer in the financial services industry globally. Our policies emphasize fair treatment, diversity and inclusion, and lifelong learning, all aimed at fostering an environment where every employee feels valued and respected. Our strategy involves setting clear targets for employee engagement, development, and gender and generational diversity as further outlined below. Key actions include conducting regular employee engagement surveys, offering various training programs, establishing multiple exchange forums, networks, and partnerships to promote inclusivity, and enhancing an Occupational Health and Safety Management system, as further outlined below.
  • ### Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain Allianz is committed to supporting and respecting the protection of international human rights, as well as ensuring it is not complicit in the abuse of human rights, as outlined in the International Bill of Rights and the ILO Core Conventions. This commitment also applies to our value chain. Allianz's due diligence approach to identify, prevent, and mitigate adverse human rights impacts linked to business activities has been guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UNGPs. As a multinational insurance and asset management company, our value chain encompasses workers at: - Allianz suppliers, - companies insured by Allianz, - companies that Allianz invests in as part of its proprietary investments, and - our tied agents responsible for distributing our products.
  • Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social origin, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with the general principles. We support and respect international human rights as outlined in the International Bill of Human Rights and the core International Labor Organization Convention. Our due diligence processes in own operations comply with the requirements of the GSCA, aligned with the UNGPs.
  • ### Section summary The section describes how Allianz's commitment to human rights applies to the human rights and labor standards of workers in our value chain. For us, value chain workers encompass those at our suppliers, at the companies we insure and invest in, and at Allianz tied agents. For each of these stages of our value chain we have dedicated policies and actions, which are described below. They all aim to identify, assess, and mitigate risks to human rights as well as to stop and remediate human rights violations. Our complaints mechanism, NGO dialogue, and other channels allow us to engage with affected value chain workers.
  • # --- Page 79 --- ## C_ Group Management Report_ Sustainability Statement ### Human rights in own workforce Allianz recognizes the importance of human rights as both a value- based and a business issue. We see respect for human rights as a minimum standard for responsible business, both within and beyond our direct operations. For further information on our human rights commitment see our Human Rights Policy Statement.
  • Allianz aims to identify, prevent, mitigate or remediate adverse human rights impacts linked to its business activities and operations, including our supply chain. Our approach is guided by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the U.N. Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGP). Our due diligence in own operations and supply chains complies with the legal obligations of the German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (GSCA) and is covered by the Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement. Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report.
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS:
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos sobre la intensidad de gases de efecto invernadero (GHG) y el volumen total de negocios de Allianz Group al 31 de diciembre de 2024 y 2023. - **Etiquetas de columnas**: "0", "1", "2", "3". - **Etiquetas de filas**: "As of 31 December", "Total business volume1", "Total GHG emissions (market-based)2", "GHG intensity (market-based)", "Total GHG emissions (location-based)2", "GHG intensity (location-based)". - **Años**: 2024 y 2023. **Datos clave**: 1. El volumen total de negocios ("Total business volume1") fue de **179,777.8 mn €** en 2024 y **161,700.0 mn €** en 2023. 2. Las emisiones totales de GHG basadas en el mercado ("Total GHG emissions (market-based)2") fueron de **48,932,692.3 t en CO2e** en 2024 y **57,562,291.4 t en CO2e** en 2023. 3. La intensidad de GHG basada en el mercado ("GHG intensity (market-based)") fue de **272.2 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2024 y **356.0 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2023. 4. Las emisiones totales de GHG basadas en la ubicación ("Total GHG emissions (location-based)2") fueron de **49,067,050.4 t en CO2e** en 2024 y **57,688,706.5 t en CO2e** en 2023. 5. La intensidad de GHG basada en la ubicación ("GHG intensity (location-based)") fue de **272.9 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2024 y **356.8 t en CO2e/€ mn** en 2023. ### END TABLE

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta los KPI/targets para el año 2025, con un objetivo del 100 %. Los indicadores incluyen: 1. **Reducción de emisiones propias en inversiones**: Emisiones absolutas financiadas de GHG en millones de toneladas de CO2e provenientes de corporaciones listadas, con un objetivo de **12.3 mn t CO2e**. 2. **Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)**: Porcentaje de líderes de lealtad en segmentos de negocio, con un objetivo de **50 %**. 3. **Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)**: Desarrollo contra el nivel de ambición general, con un objetivo de **77 %**. 4. **Plan de transición hacia compromisos de cero emisiones netas**: Incluye reducción de emisiones en el sector de motor retail y reducción de intensidad de emisiones en el sector comercial de Property-Casualty. 5. **Soluciones sostenibles en Property-Casualty**. 6. **Desarrollo del Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 7. **Desarrollo del Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 8. **Cumplimiento estricto de requisitos regulatorios y de gobernanza corporativa**, con enfoque en un sistema de gestión de riesgos adecuado y cultura de riesgos. 9. **Contribución de liderazgo**, con enfoque en atributos de personas de Allianz: Excelencia en clientes y mercado, liderazgo colaborativo, emprendimiento y confianza; evaluación multi-rater. ### END TABLE
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta los requisitos de divulgación y puntos de datos relacionados, clasificados por "Materiality" y "Sub-section/sub-sub-section". Los años no están especificados en el contenido. 1. **ESRS S2-1** aborda el incumplimiento de los principios de los UNGPs sobre Empresas y Derechos Humanos y las directrices de la OCDE (párrafo 19), así como las políticas de diligencia debida relacionadas con los convenios fundamentales de la OIT (párrafo 19). Ambos son materiales y se relacionan con las políticas de ESRS y el modelo de negocio estratégico para los trabajadores en la cadena de valor. 2. **ESRS S2-4** trata temas de derechos humanos e incidentes en la cadena de valor (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos para remediar impactos negativos. 3. **ESRS S3-1** incluye compromisos de políticas de derechos humanos (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs, OIT u OCDE (párrafo 17), ambos materiales y vinculados al modelo de negocio estratégico para comunidades afectadas. 4. **ESRS S3-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos de interacción con comunidades afectadas. 5. **ESRS S4-1** sobre políticas relacionadas con consumidores y usuarios finales (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs y OCDE (párrafo 17) no son materiales. 6. **ESRS S4-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 35), considerado material, con enfoque en acciones. 7. **ESRS G1-1** sobre la Convención de las Naciones Unidas contra la Corrupción (párrafo 10 (b)) y la protección de denunciantes (párrafo 10 (d)) no son relevantes, ya que las políticas ya están implementadas. 8. **ESRS G1-4** sobre multas por violación de leyes anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (a)) y estándares anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (b)) son materiales, con enfoque en incidentes confirmados de corrupción o soborno. 9. Se menciona la aplicación de la cláusula de salvaguarda según ESRS 2.5(e) en relación con §§ 289e y 315c HGB para la brecha salarial de género en S1-16, sin más detalles.

L'entreprise met en place une approche rigoureuse pour respecter les droits de l'homme et les droits du travail pour ses propres employés. Les éléments clés de cette approche incluent :

  1. Respect des Droits de l'Homme : L'entreprise considère le respect des droits de l'homme comme une norme minimale pour le traitement de ses employés. Cela est intégré dans ses règles d'entreprise, adaptées aux lois et exigences locales (Context Num-1).

  2. Évaluations et Mesures Préventives : Des évaluations annuelles et ponctuelles des risques liés aux droits des employés sont effectuées conformément au GSCA. En cas de risques identifiés, des mesures préventives sont prises, et en cas de violations, des remèdes sont appliqués rapidement et efficacement (Context Num-1).

  3. Inclusion et Diversité : Les politiques de l'entreprise mettent l'accent sur le traitement équitable, la diversité et l'inclusion, ainsi que l'apprentissage tout au long de la vie pour favoriser un environnement où chaque employé se sent valorisé (Context Num-2).

  4. Conditions de Travail : L'entreprise s'engage à assurer un traitement égal pour tous les employés, indépendamment de leur origine nationale ou ethnique, santé, handicap, orientation sexuelle, âge, sexe, croyances religieuses, ou toute autre caractéristique protégée. Elle garantit également la sécurité physique et améliore la santé et le bien-être au travail (Context Num-4).

  5. Mécanismes de Plaintes : Un mécanisme de plaintes global, SpeakUp@Allianz, est disponible pour permettre aux employés et à d'autres parties de soulever des préoccupations, y compris les risques et violations des droits de l'homme (Context Num-8).

  6. Formation et Sensibilisation : La formation sur les questions liées à la durabilité, y compris le traitement égal et la santé et sécurité au travail, est dispensée à l'échelle du groupe et des filiales (Context Num-1).

Dans l'ensemble, l'entreprise démontre un engagement fort envers le respect des droits de l'homme et des normes du travail à travers des politiques claires, des évaluations régulières, et des mécanismes de remédiation efficaces.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • follow their respective definitions and do not aim to meet the definitions of any regulation, including but not limited to Sustainable Finance regulation. Integrating sustainability in own operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad- hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promp tly and effectively (see our Policy Statement on Human Rights). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: − The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. − Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. − Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well -being. follow their respective definitions and do not aim to meet the definitions of any regulation, including but not limited to Sustainable Finance regulation.   • cover topics such as working conditions, equal treatment and opportunities for all, other work -related rights, and child labor and forced labor, including human trafficking. During the supplier onboarding process, suppliers registered in our standard tool for procurement are asked to comply with the VCoC or to submit a comparable code of conduct. For suppliers over a defined threshold, we apply additional checks, including questions on their human rights due diligence. This mitigates the risk of engaging with suppliers who do not uphold human rights standa rds. Additional actions and processes are based on voluntary commitments as well as the requirements of the GSCA . If risks related to violations of human rights of supply chain workers are identified, we take appropriate preventive measures, including, for example, engaging with the companies in question or adding human rights - related contractual clauses to the supplier agreement.   • development. We have a strong focus on equal treatment and opportunities for all; this encompasses diversity, inclusion, and talent acquisition and retention. The health and well -being of our employees continues to be an area of focus – our practices typically include offering flexibility in working time, paying competitive wages, and fostering freedom of association and dialogue with our employees. Furthermore, securing the confidentiality of employee data is key for us. By implementing these and further practices – including annual risk assessments, as applicable, regarding the protection of human/emplo yee rights in accordance with the GSCA – we continue to work to ensure (potential/actual) adverse impacts are prevented and reduced. In addition to the zero -tolerance policy toward discrimination included in the Allianz Group Code of Conduct , the Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor.   • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities.   • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
  • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.

S1-19

Peux-tu me décrire l'approche générale de l'entreprise en matière d'engagement avec ses propres employés ?

nan

L'approche générale de l'entreprise Allianz en matière d'engagement avec ses propres employés met l'accent sur l'écoute et la réponse aux opinions, idées et préoccupations des employés. Cela façonne la stratégie, les valeurs et le lieu de travail, tout en permettant à Allianz de générer une valeur à long terme. Les moyens d'engagement incluent l'Allianz Engagement Survey (AES), le feedback à 360 degrés, les conseils de travailleurs, les dialogues, les réseaux, et les programmes de volontariat. Ces initiatives visent à créer un environnement de travail inclusif et participatif, favorisant l'engagement et le développement des employés.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les groupes de parties prenantes clés d'Allianz, les raisons pour lesquelles leur engagement est important, et les moyens par lesquels Allianz interagit avec eux. Les groupes identifiés sont : **Employés**, **Investisseurs**, **Clients**, **Investis et gestionnaires d'actifs**, **Société, Gouvernements et Régulateurs**, et **Tous**. - **Employés** : Leur engagement façonne la stratégie, les valeurs et le lieu de travail d'Allianz, tout en générant une valeur à long terme. Moyens : Enquête Allianz Engagement Survey (AES), feedback à 360 degrés, conseils de travailleurs, dialogues, réseaux, et programmes de volontariat. - **Investisseurs** : L'engagement permet de communiquer la stratégie de durabilité et de comprendre leurs attentes. Moyens : Assemblée générale annuelle, site web, déclarations de durabilité, présentations d'analystes, dialogues et roadshows. - **Clients** : Leurs retours améliorent les produits, services et processus. Moyens : Notations ESG, recherche et développement, score Net Promoter digital (dNPS), enquêtes clients. - **Investis et gestionnaires d'actifs** : L'alignement des intérêts à long terme est essentiel. Moyens : Revue des développements du secteur financier, engagements bilatéraux, initiatives d'investisseurs. - **Société, Gouvernements et Régulateurs** : L'engagement favorise le changement positif et des partenariats efficaces. Moyens : Partenariats civiques, fondations, dons, leadership intellectuel, discussions et tables rondes. - **Tous** : Opportunité de signaler des inconduites liées aux activités d'Allianz. Moyen : Mécanisme mondial de plaintes SpeakUp@Allianz. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Key stakeholder groups Why engagement is important How we engage
    Employees Listening and responding to our employees’ views, ideas, and concerns shapes our strategy, values, and workplace while enabling Allianz to generate long-term value. - The Allianz Engagement Survey (AES)
    - 360-degree feedback (“Multi-Rater”)
    - Employee representation and workers’ councils
    - Employee dialogues and networks
    - Corporate volunteering programs
    Investors We engage with investors to communicate our sustainability strategy and performance, to enable them to make informed decisions about their investments, and to understand their expectations of our business. - Annual General Meeting
    - Website, Sustainability Statement
    - Analyst presentations
    - Events for employees (e.g., Employee Investor Day)
    - Dialogues and roadshows
    Customers Feedback from customers helps improve our products, services, and processes and ensures we offer easy and adaptable solutions. - Ratings (e.g., MSCI ESG, DJSI) and benchmarks
    - Research and development to support product innovations
    - Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)
    - Customer surveys, learning from and sharing customer insights
    Investees and asset managers Aligning our long-term interest with portfolio actors through active engagements (for details, please refer to the section “Integrating Sustainability in proprietary investments”). - Review of financial services sector developments
    - Asset Manager engagements
    - Bilateral engagements
    - Investor initiatives
    Society, Governments, and Regulators Engaging with civil society, governments, regulators, and institutions helps us drive positive change and contribute to effective regulation and multi-stakeholder partnerships. - Partnerships for civic engagement
    - Foundations, donations, and volunteering
    - Thought leadership on global issues
    - Panel discussions and roundtables
    All Providing Allianz employees, the employees of our suppliers, and other people whose rights might be impacted by Allianz’s operations and business activities with the opportunity to report (alleged) misconduct, such as fraud, mis-selling, or violations of human rights or environmental protection, in relation to Allianz’s operations and business activities. - SpeakUp@Allianz worldwide complaints mechanism

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les groupes de parties prenantes clés d'Allianz, les raisons pour lesquelles leur engagement est important, et les moyens par lesquels Allianz interagit avec eux. Les employés, investisseurs, clients, gestionnaires d'actifs, la société civile, les gouvernements et les régulateurs sont identifiés comme des parties prenantes essentielles. L'engagement vise à améliorer la stratégie, les produits, les services, et à promouvoir des pratiques durables et responsables. Les méthodes d'engagement incluent des enquêtes, des dialogues, des initiatives de volontariat, des présentations, des collaborations, et des mécanismes de signalement.

  • Le tableau présente une liste de sujets de durabilité, des exigences de divulgation associées, des sections correspondantes et des sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections détaillant les aspects spécifiques à traiter. Les sujets incluent "E4 Biodiversity and ecosystems", "E5 Resource use and circular economy" et "S1 Own workforce". Pour "E4 Biodiversity and ecosystems", les sous-sections couvrent la stratégie et le modèle d'affaires, la matérialité, les politiques, les actions et les objectifs liés à la biodiversité et aux écosystèmes. Pour "E5 Resource use and circular economy", les sous-sections incluent la matérialité, les politiques, les actions, les objectifs et les métriques, telles que l'influx de ressources et les déchets électroniques. Concernant "S1 Own workforce", les sous-sections abordent la stratégie "Group People and Culture", la matérialité, les politiques, l'engagement, les processus pour soulever des préoccupations, les actions, les objectifs, les caractéristiques des employés, la négociation collective, le genre, les générations, les salaires adéquats, la protection sociale, les personnes handicapées, l'apprentissage et le développement, la santé et la sécurité, l'équilibre travail-vie personnelle, l'écart de rémunération entre les sexes et les droits humains. Chaque sujet est structuré pour analyser les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés à ces domaines. and

    Le tableau présente une liste de sujets de durabilité, des exigences de divulgation associées, des sections correspondantes et des sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections détaillant les aspects spécifiques à traiter. Les sujets abordés incluent la biodiversité et les écosystèmes, l'utilisation des ressources et l'économie circulaire, ainsi que la gestion de la main-d'œuvre propre. Chaque sujet est divisé en plusieurs catégories, telles que la stratégie, la matérialité, les politiques, les actions, les objectifs, et les métriques, afin de fournir une vue complète des impacts, des risques et des opportunités liés à ces domaines.

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau détaille les exigences de divulgation pour diverses matières de durabilité, organisées par "Sustainability matter", "Disclosure requirements", "Section" et "Sub-section/sub-sub-section". Les principales catégories incluent : 1. **Workers in the value chain** : Exigences S2 SBM-2 à S2-5, couvrant la stratégie, la matérialité, les politiques, les objectifs, les actions, et les processus pour remédier aux impacts négatifs sur les travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur. 2. **Affected communities** : Exigences S3 SBM-2 à S3-5, abordant la stratégie, la matérialité, les politiques, les objectifs, et les processus pour engager les communautés affectées. 3. **Consumers and end-users** : Exigences S4 SBM-2 à S4-5, incluant la stratégie, la matérialité, les politiques, l'engagement, les actions, et les objectifs liés aux consommateurs et utilisateurs finaux. 4. **Sustainability Strategy and Governance** : Exigence G1 GOV-1, portant sur le rôle des organes administratifs, de gestion et de supervision. 5. **Materiality** : Exigence G1 IRO-1, décrivant le processus d'identification et d'évaluation des impacts et opportunités matériels. 6. **Business conduct** : Exigences G1-1 à G1-5, couvrant la culture d'entreprise, la gestion des relations avec les fournisseurs, la prévention et détection de la corruption, les incidents confirmés de corruption, et les activités d'influence politique et de lobbying. Chaque catégorie est associée à des sous-sections spécifiques, mettant en avant les politiques, objectifs, actions, et processus pertinents. and
