Oui, Allianz dispose d'un système de traitement des plaintes pour les salariés. Ce système est inclus dans le mécanisme de plaintes global de l'entreprise, appelé SpeakUp@Allianz. Il est accessible aux employés d'Allianz, ainsi qu'à toute personne potentiellement impactée par les activités économiques d'Allianz. Ce mécanisme permet de signaler des risques environnementaux et de droits de l'homme, ainsi que des violations associées. Les experts en conformité d'Allianz qui traitent ces rapports sont indépendants et respectent les règles de confidentialité. Le système assure également qu'aucune mesure de représailles n'est prise contre les lanceurs d'alerte, garantissant ainsi un environnement de travail sûr pour ceux qui souhaitent exprimer leurs préoccupations.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • - Allianz does not tolerate any reprisals or any disadvantages for reporting persons related to their complaint. - The Allianz complaints mechanism consists of several channels, including email, postal letter, and an online reporting tool that allows the creation of anonymous mailboxes allowing the reporting person to communicate with the responsible compliance experts. The tool is available in all countries in which Allianz operates. The tool is available in German, English, and 19 additional languages. - The rules of procedure for the Allianz complaints mechanism have been published in text form. They contain clear and comprehensible information on the process of reporting, the communication between the compliance experts and the reporting person, as well as the investigation of incidents raised by the reporting person.
  • The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to enable a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR functions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules.
  • ### Processes and channels to raise concerns For further information, please refer to the sections Human rights in own workforce and Corruption and bribery.
  • We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS: - A complaint is any expression of dissatisfaction about a person or group. Customer complaints that are not related to potential misconduct are excluded. For further information, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. - An incident is a predicated and confirmed event or occurrence that is contrary to the rules as set out in Allianz's internal rules and/or legal regulations. - A severe human rights incident/violation is defined as follows: - Every case of child labor. - Every case of forced labor and modern slavery, including human trafficking. - Every case of severe (sexual) harassment or other severe human rights violations.
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS:
  • While Allianz has not adopted a dedicated process to engage with value chain workers, human rights issues can be addressed through existing engagement channels. Everyone inside and outside Allianz can report issues related to the human rights of workers in our value chain through our independent complaints mechanism, SpeakUp@Allianz, which is further detailed in the section G1 Business conduct. In 2024, no severe human rights violations of value chain workers were reported through SpeakUp@Alllianz. Adverse media screenings of potentially high-risk suppliers did not produce any information on human rights violations in our supply chain in 2024. For our insurance and proprietary investment, the ASIS process is designed to prevent Allianz from insuring or investing in companies that cause severe human rights violations. We continuously monitor our portfolios to be able to address violations should they occur.
  • ### Processes and channels to raise concerns Under the Allianz Standard for Customer Protection, subsidiaries must provide continuous support throughout the retail product lifecycle. This support includes managing sold products and services and assisting customers, especially with service requests, claims, or complaints. An effective external complaint management process builds trust, maintains customer relationships, ensures long-term retention, and safeguards Allianz's reputation. Subsidiaries must comply with laws, regulations, and corporate rules concerning complaints management. Each subsidiary must have a standardized process to handle complaints and ensure fair treatment of customers.
  • Employees are encouraged to report concerns about any possible illegal or other misconduct that might violate the Allianz Group Code of Conduct, any laws, regulations, order of regulators, or any internal corporate rules. Employees have multiple channels for doing so. These include via management, speaking directly with Group Compliance, by e-mail, or anonymously via a third-party solution provided by EQS Group GmbH and accessible via the intranet. The same tool is also accessible to external parties on the Allianz company website. Some subsidiaries provide employees with the option to report via an 1_"Functional at risk" refers to those individuals/persons deemed to be at risk of corruption, bribery, and/or money laundering as a result of their tasks and responsibilities. 145 G1 Business Conduct Annual Report 2024 - Allianz Group
  • ### Zusammenfassung der Tabelle Die Tabelle enthält drei Spalten mit den Labels: "Disclosure Requirement", "Reference" und "Annotation". Die Zeilen umfassen Informationen über die Erfahrung der Mitglieder des Vorstands und des Aufsichtsrats, die für Sektoren, Produkte und geografische Standorte des Unternehmens relevant sind. Die erste Zeile beschreibt die Anforderungen an die Mitglieder des Vorstands gemäß dem deutschen Versicherungsaufsichtsgesetz (VAG) und der BaFin-Rundschreiben 9/2023 (VA) sowie Art. 273 der delegierten Verordnung (EU) 2015/35. Es wird betont, dass die Mitglieder des Vorstands über ausreichende theoretische und praktische Kenntnisse in den Bereichen Versicherungs- und Finanzmärkte, Geschäftsstrategie, Governance-System, Finanz- und versicherungsmathematische Analyse sowie regulatorische Anforderungen verfügen müssen. Die zweite Zeile beschreibt die Anforderungen an die Mitglieder des Aufsichtsrats gemäß dem VAG und BaFin-Rundschreiben 10/2023 (VA). Es wird hervorgehoben, dass die Mitglieder des Aufsichtsrats über ausreichende Kenntnisse in den Bereichen Rechnungswesen, versicherungsmathematische Praxis, Investmentmanagement, Prüfung und internes Modell verfügen müssen. Beide Gremien müssen ihre Eignung und Zuverlässigkeit jährlich durch Selbstbewertungen und BaFin-Bestätigungen nachweisen. Zusätzliche Informationen zu den relevanten Erfahrungen der Mitglieder sind in deren Lebensläufen auf der Allianz-Website verfügbar.
  • ### Insurance-associated GHG emissions - Commercial insurance: Contribution to decarbonization per lever % (change in GHG emissions versus target baseline 2022) La tabla presenta las "Decarbonization levers" y las "Actions" asociadas, junto con las reducciones de emisiones de GHG logradas y esperadas en los períodos "1.1.2024-31.12.2024" y "1.1.2025-31.12.2029". En "Start of period versus baseline", se indica una reducción lograda de (16.6) y una esperada de (11.7). Para "Commercial - Insured customers decarbonization", las acciones incluyen "Engagement on net-zero transition", cuyos impactos no son cuantificables, y "Customer decarbonization", con reducciones logradas de 0.7 y esperadas entre (13.5) y (7.5). En "Commercial - Portfolio steering", las acciones incluyen "Low-carbon solutions" con reducciones logradas de (0.1) y esperadas entre (5.4) y (3.4), "Restrictions" con reducciones logradas de (0.2) y esperadas entre (7.3) y (5.3), y "Further portfolio changes" con reducciones logradas de 4.4 y esperadas entre (13.0) y (11.0). Finalmente, en "End of period versus baseline", se indica una reducción lograda de (11.7) y una esperada de (45).
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta los requisitos de divulgación y puntos de datos relacionados, clasificados por "Materiality" y "Sub-section/sub-sub-section". Los años no están especificados en el contenido. 1. **ESRS S2-1** aborda el incumplimiento de los principios de los UNGPs sobre Empresas y Derechos Humanos y las directrices de la OCDE (párrafo 19), así como las políticas de diligencia debida relacionadas con los convenios fundamentales de la OIT (párrafo 19). Ambos son materiales y se relacionan con las políticas de ESRS y el modelo de negocio estratégico para los trabajadores en la cadena de valor. 2. **ESRS S2-4** trata temas de derechos humanos e incidentes en la cadena de valor (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos para remediar impactos negativos. 3. **ESRS S3-1** incluye compromisos de políticas de derechos humanos (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs, OIT u OCDE (párrafo 17), ambos materiales y vinculados al modelo de negocio estratégico para comunidades afectadas. 4. **ESRS S3-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos de interacción con comunidades afectadas. 5. **ESRS S4-1** sobre políticas relacionadas con consumidores y usuarios finales (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs y OCDE (párrafo 17) no son materiales. 6. **ESRS S4-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 35), considerado material, con enfoque en acciones. 7. **ESRS G1-1** sobre la Convención de las Naciones Unidas contra la Corrupción (párrafo 10 (b)) y la protección de denunciantes (párrafo 10 (d)) no son relevantes, ya que las políticas ya están implementadas. 8. **ESRS G1-4** sobre multas por violación de leyes anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (a)) y estándares anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (b)) son materiales, con enfoque en incidentes confirmados de corrupción o soborno. 9. Se menciona la aplicación de la cláusula de salvaguarda según ESRS 2.5(e) en relación con §§ 289e y 315c HGB para la brecha salarial de género en S1-16, sin más detalles.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos relacionados con los KPI de Taxonomía para las inversiones del Grupo Allianz en el año 2024. Los encabezados incluyen "Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI" y "Monetary amounts (€ bn)". Los porcentajes y proporciones se desglosan de la siguiente manera: 1. El porcentaje de derivados respecto al total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 3.0%. 2. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas financieras y no financieras no sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU sobre el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 29.2% para empresas no financieras y del 16.7% para empresas financieras. 3. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas financieras y no financieras de países fuera de la UE no sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU es del 22.8% para empresas no financieras y del 10.2% para empresas financieras. 4. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU es del 9.9% para empresas no financieras y del 28.5% para empresas financieras. 5. La proporción de exposiciones a otros contrapartes y activos sobre el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 12.6%. 6. La proporción de inversiones distintas de las mantenidas en contratos de seguros de vida donde el riesgo de inversión es asumido por los asegurados es del 81.4%. 7. El valor de las inversiones que financian actividades económicas no elegibles según la Taxonomía, en relación con el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI, es del 31.1% para el "Turnover" y del 30.5% para el "CAPEX". 8. El valor de las inversiones que financian actividades económicas elegibles según la Taxonomía, pero no alineadas, es del 17.8% para el "Turnover" y del 18.3% para el "CAPEX".

Oui, Allianz dispose d'un mécanisme de traitement des plaintes pour les salariés. Ce système, appelé SpeakUp@Allianz, permet aux employés, ainsi qu'à d'autres parties, de soulever des préoccupations, y compris des risques et des violations des droits de l'homme. Le mécanisme de plaintes est largement promu via l'intranet d'Allianz et d'autres canaux. Il est conçu pour garantir la confidentialité des cas signalés et s'assurer qu'aucune mesure de représailles n'est prise contre les lanceurs d'alerte. Les employés peuvent signaler leurs préoccupations par divers canaux, y compris via la direction, directement avec le Group Compliance, par e-mail ou de manière anonyme via un outil tiers fourni par EQS Group GmbH, accessible via l'intranet et le site Web d'Allianz.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • reports submitted through SpeakUp@ Allianz are independent and observe confidentiality rules. − Allianz does not tolerate any reprisals or any disadvantages for reporting persons related to their complaint. − The Allianz complaints mechanism consists of several channels, including email, postal letter, and an online reporting tool that allows the creation of anonymous mailboxes allowing the reporting person to communicate with the responsible compliance experts. The tool is available in all countries in which Allianz operates. The tool is available in German, English, and 19 additional languages. − The rules of procedure for the Allianz complaints mechanism have been published in text form. They contain clear and comprehensible information on the process of reporting, the communication between the compliance experts and the reporting person, as well as the investigation of incidents rais ed by the reporting person. reports submitted through SpeakUp@ Allianz are independent and observe confidentiality rules. − Allianz does not tolerate any reprisals or any disadvantages for reporting persons related to their complaint. − The Allianz complaints mechanism consists of several channels, including email, postal letter, and an online reporting tool that allows the creation of anonymous mailboxes allowing the reporting person to communicate with the responsible compliance experts. They contain clear and comprehensible information on the process of reporting, the communication between the compliance experts and the reporting person, as well as the investigation of incidents rais ed by the reporting person.
  • safeguards Allianz ’s reputation. Subsidiaries must comply with laws, regulations, and corporate rules concerning complaints management. Each subsidiary must have a standardized process to handle complaints and ensure fair treatment of customers. Additionally, Allianz has engagement channels, such as SpeakUp@ Allianz , that are open to all people, inside and outside Allianz , who feel that they have been impacted by Allianz ’s business or by a business in the Allianz value chain. For more details, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery . Additionally, retail customers have the opportunity to engage with Allianz via the Voice of the Customer program. By asking the customers for their satisfaction rating along five key Customer Journeys, they have the opportunity to provide any (negative) feedback. In this way, VoC identifies dissatisfied retail customers (3 stars or fewer). As stated in the Customer Experience Functional Rule , safeguards Allianz ’s reputation.   • the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime the reporting person. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime
  • Human Rights Policy Statement . On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occu pational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website . Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@ Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery . Human Rights Policy Statement . On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occu pational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website . Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@ Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery .
  • C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement Annual Report 2024 − Allianz Group 146 G1 Business Conduct external channel. Group Compliance runs an annual global awareness campaign to remind employees of the avenues available for reporting. Under the headline SpeakUp@Allianz , our worldwide complaints mechanism has the following features: − It is accessible to Allianz employees, to the employees of Allianz ’s direct and indirect suppliers, and to anyone else who might be impacted by the economic activities of Allianz . − It enables people to draw attention to human rights and environmental risks, as well as violations of human rights or environmental obligations, that have arisen as a result of the economic activities of Allianz or of direct or indirect suppliers. − The Allianz compliance experts responsible for handling the reports submitted through SpeakUp@ Allianz are independent and observe confidentiality rules. While Allianz has not adopted a dedicated process to engage with value chain workers, human rights issues can be addressed through existing engagement channels. Everyone inside and outside Allianz can report issues related to the human rights of workers in our value chain through our independent complaints mechanism, SpeakUp@ Allianz , which is further detailed in the section G1 Business conduct . In 2024, no severe human rights violations of value chain workers were reported through SpeakUp@Alllianz.   • We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS: − A complaint is any expression of dissatisfaction about a person or group. Customer complaints that are not related to potential misconduct are excluded. For further information, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery . − An incident is a predicated and confirmed event or occurrence that is contrary to the rules as set out in Allianz ´s internal rules and/or legal regulations. − A severe human rights incident/violation is defined as follows: − Every case of child labor. − Every case of forced labor and modern slavery, including human trafficking. − Every case of severe (sexual) harassment or other severe human rights violations. Indications for a severe violation can be the number of people affected, the length of the violation, and the severity of the damage inflicted, including its reversibility. Customer complaints that are not related to potential misconduct are excluded. Indications for a severe violation can be the number of people affected, the length of the violation, and the severity of the damage inflicted, including its reversibility. Taxonomy for proprietary investments For investments, the E.U. Taxonomy Regulation currently limits the scope of financial investments that can be considered as “Taxonomy - eligible” to exposures to undertakings that are obliged to publish non - financial information pursuant to Article 19a or 29 a of Directive 2013/34/EU. This means that, for Taxonomy reporting as an investor in other undertakings, the Allianz Group can only consider reported data of economic activities of investees in scope of the NFRD that are reinsurance activities 59.7 0.1 - Y Y Y Y Y Y A.1.2.1 Of which reinsured (retrocession) 3.3 - - Y Y Y Y Y Y A.2 Non -life insurance and reinsurance underwriting Taxonomy- eligible but not environmentally sustainable activities (not Taxonomy -aligned activities) 65,719.0 76.6 76.3 B. Taxonomy for proprietary investments For investments, the E.U. Taxonomy Regulation currently limits the scope of financial investments that can be considered as “Taxonomy - eligible” to exposures to undertakings that are obliged to publish non - financial information pursuant to Article 19a or 29 a of Directive 2013/34/EU.   • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.

  • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
S1-120

Quelle est la répartition par sexe du personnel dans l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise ?

nan

La répartition par sexe dans l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise varie en fonction des différents niveaux de direction :

  • Dans les postes de direction (top management), en 2024, 60.9 % sont des hommes et 39.1 % sont des femmes. En 2023, ces chiffres étaient de 65.7 % pour les hommes et 34.3 % pour les femmes.
  • Pour les postes Allianz Global Executive (AGE), en 2024, 3.2 % sont des hommes et 70.0 % sont des femmes, avec un pourcentage d'autres genres de 30.0 %. En 2023, ces pourcentages étaient de 3.5 % pour les hommes, 74.0 % pour les femmes, et 26.0 % pour d'autres genres.
  • Dans les postes Allianz Senior Executive (ASE), en 2024, 11.9 % sont des hommes, 68.0 % sont des femmes, et 32.0 % appartiennent à d'autres genres. En 2023, ces chiffres étaient de 11.8 % pour les hommes, 72.1 % pour les femmes, et 27.9 % pour d'autres genres.
  • Enfin, pour les postes Allianz Executive (AE), en 2024, 84.9 % sont des hommes, 59.5 % sont des femmes, et 40.5 % appartiennent à d'autres genres. En 2023, ces pourcentages étaient de 84.7 % pour les hommes, 64.5 % pour les femmes, et 35.5 % pour d'autres genres.

Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - La répartition par genre dans les postes de direction (top management) montre une diminution du pourcentage d'hommes (de 65.7% en 2023 à 60.9% en 2024) et une augmentation du pourcentage de femmes (de 34.3% en 2023 à 39.1% en 2024). - Dans les postes Allianz Global Executive (AGE), le pourcentage de femmes a diminué (de 74.0% en 2023 à 70.0% en 2024), tandis que celui des hommes a légèrement baissé (de 3.5% en 2023 à 3.2% en 2024). Le pourcentage d'autres genres a augmenté (de 26.0% en 2023 à 30.0% en 2024). - Pour les postes Allianz Senior Executive (ASE), le pourcentage d'hommes est resté stable (11.8% en 2023 contre 11.9% en 2024). Le pourcentage de femmes a diminué (de 72.1% en 2023 à 68.0% en 2024), tandis que celui des autres genres a augmenté (de 27.9% en 2023 à 32.0% en 2024). - Dans les postes Allianz Executive (AE), le pourcentage d'hommes est resté stable (84.7% en 2023 contre 84.9% en 2024). Le pourcentage de femmes a diminué (de 64.5% en 2023 à 59.5% en 2024), tandis que celui des autres genres a augmenté (de 35.5% en 2023 à 40.5% en 2024). - Les catégories "Other³" et "Not reported³" sont mentionnées mais ne contiennent pas de données pour certains postes. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    ```markdown

    As of 31 December 2024 2023
    # % # %
    Gender distribution
    in Executive positions (top management)²
    Male 6,677 60.9 6,788 65.7
    Female 4,064 39.1 4,461 34.3
    Other³ - - - -
    Not reported³ - - - -
    in Allianz Global Executive (AGE) positions

    Female 149 70.0 174 74.0

    Not reported³ - - - -
    in Allianz Senior Executive (ASE) positions⁴

    in Allianz Executive (AE) positions⁴

    Female 3,376 59.5 3,708 64.5
    Other³ 2,295 40.5 2,042 35.5
    Not reported³ - - - -

    ```
    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - La répartition par genre dans les postes de direction (top management) montre une légère diminution du pourcentage d'hommes (de 65.7% en 2023 à 60.9% en 2024) et une augmentation du pourcentage de femmes (de 34.3% en 2023 à 39.1% en 2024). - Dans les postes Allianz Global Executive (AGE), le pourcentage de femmes a diminué (de 74.0% en 2023 à 70.0% en 2024), tandis que celui des hommes a légèrement baissé (de 3.5% en 2023 à 3.2% en 2024). Le pourcentage d'autres genres a augmenté (de 26.0% en 2023 à 30.0% en 2024). - Pour les postes Allianz Senior Executive (ASE), le pourcentage d'hommes est resté stable (11.8% en 2023 contre 11.9% en 2024). Le pourcentage de femmes a diminué (de 72.1% en 2023 à 68.0% en 2024), tandis que celui des autres genres a augmenté (de 27.9% en 2023 à 32.0% en 2024). - Dans les postes Allianz Executive (AE), le pourcentage d'hommes est resté stable (84.7% en 2023 contre 84.9% en 2024). Le pourcentage de femmes a diminué (de 64.5% en 2023 à 59.5% en 2024), tandis que celui des autres genres a augmenté (de 35.5% en 2023 à 40.5% en 2024).

  • Le tableau présente des informations sur la diversité de genre et l'indépendance des membres des conseils d'administration et de surveillance d'Allianz SE. - Le conseil d'administration d'Allianz SE est composé de 80 % d'hommes et 20 % de femmes, soit 4 femmes et 5 hommes. - Le conseil de surveillance d'Allianz SE est composé de 71,4 % d'hommes et 28,6 % de femmes, soit 5 femmes et 7 hommes. - Tous les représentants des actionnaires au sein du conseil de surveillance sont indépendants conformément aux critères du DCGK, soit 100 %. and

    Gender Diversity Supervisory Board of Allianz SE Annual Report – Information in accordance with the German Act on the Equal Participation of Women and Men in Executive Positions in the Private and the Public Sectors ratio female to male: 71.4 % (5 female and 7 male members)

    Le tableau présente des informations sur la diversité de genre et l'indépendance des membres des conseils d'administration et de surveillance d'Allianz SE.
    - Le conseil d'administration d'Allianz SE est composé de 80 % d'hommes et 20 % de femmes, soit 4 femmes et 5 hommes. - Le conseil de surveillance d'Allianz SE est composé de 71,4 % d'hommes et 28,6 % de femmes, soit 5 femmes et 7 hommes. - Tous les représentants des actionnaires au sein du conseil de surveillance sont indépendants conformément aux critères du DCGK, soit 100 %.

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - En 2024, 74 % des non-exécutifs d'Allianz ont un PDP (Plan de Développement Personnel), avec des taux similaires pour les hommes (73.4 %) et les femmes (74.5 %). Les autres non-exécutifs atteignent un taux de 100 %, tandis que les non-exécutifs non reportés sont à 64.3 %. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.). - Pour les exécutifs et niveaux supérieurs (AE+) en 2024, 90.8 % ont un PDP, avec des taux légèrement plus élevés pour les hommes (91.4 %) que pour les femmes (89.9 %). En 2023, ces taux étaient respectivement de 83.9 %, 83.3 % et 84.9 %. - Les données pour les autres exécutifs et les exécutifs non reportés ne sont pas disponibles pour les deux années. and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - En 2024, 74 % des non-exécutifs d'Allianz ont un PDP (Plan de Développement Personnel), avec des taux similaires pour les hommes (73.4 %) et les femmes (74.5 %). Les autres non-exécutifs atteignent un taux de 100 %, tandis que les non-exécutifs non reportés sont à 64.3 %. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.). - Pour les exécutifs et niveaux supérieurs (AE+) en 2024, 90.8 % ont un PDP, avec des taux légèrement plus élevés pour les hommes (91.4 %) que pour les femmes (89.9 %). En 2023, ces taux étaient respectivement de 83.9 %, 83.3 % et 84.9 %. Les données pour les autres exécutifs et les exécutifs non reportés ne sont pas disponibles pour les deux années.

  • Le tableau fournit des informations sur les "Exigences de divulgation" concernant la composition et la diversité des membres des organes administratifs, de gestion et de supervision. Il mentionne que les références incluent le "Rapport Annuel – Déclaration sur le gouvernement d’entreprise" dans les sections "Conseil de Direction" et "Conseil de Surveillance". Le tableau indique que le "Nombre de membres exécutifs" est de 9, tandis que le "Nombre de membres non exécutifs" est de 12, selon la section "Composition et fonctionnement du Conseil de Direction" et "Composition et fonctionnement du Conseil de Surveillance". Concernant la "Représentation des employés et autres travailleurs", le Conseil de Surveillance est composé de 12 membres, répartis également entre 6 représentants des actionnaires (nommés par l'Assemblée Générale) et 6 représentants des employés (nommés par le Comité d’Entreprise SE). Parmi les représentants des employés, il y a quatre membres d'Allemagne (dont un représentant syndical), ainsi qu’un membre de France et un d’Italie. De plus, un membre du Conseil Exécutif est désigné pour superviser les "Affaires sociales et du travail", avec l'approbation du Conseil de Surveillance. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Disclosure Requirement Reference Annotation
    Information about composition and diversity of members of administrative, management, and supervisory bodies Annual Report – Corporate Governance Statement – Parts "Board of Management" and "Supervisory Board"
    Number of executive members Annual Report – Corporate Governance Statement "Composition and operations of the Board of Management" 9
    Number of non-executive members Annual Report – Corporate Governance Statement "Composition and operations of the Supervisory Board" 12
    Information about representation of employees and other workers Annual Report – Corporate Governance Statement – Parts "Composition and operations of the Supervisory Board" and "Composition and operations of the Board of Management" The Supervisory Board comprises twelve members. The six shareholder representatives are appointed by the General Meeting, and the six employee representatives by the SE Works Council. The Supervisory Board currently in office includes four employee representatives from Germany – including one trade union representative – and one each from France and Italy. Moreover, the Board of Management appoints a member of the Executive Board who is responsible for the area of “Labor and Social Affairs”. The appointment requires the approval of the Supervisory Board.

    Le tableau fournit des informations sur les exigences de divulgation concernant la composition et la diversité des membres des organes administratifs, de gestion et de supervision. Il précise également le nombre de membres exécutifs (9) et non exécutifs (12). En outre, il détaille la représentation des employés et autres travailleurs au sein du Conseil de Surveillance, qui est composé de douze membres, répartis entre représentants des actionnaires et des employés. Les représentants des employés incluent quatre membres d'Allemagne (dont un représentant syndical) et un membre chacun de France et d'Italie. Enfin, un membre du Conseil Exécutif est nommé pour superviser les affaires sociales et du travail, avec l'approbation du Conseil de Surveillance.

  • Le tableau présente une répartition des employés par genre pour les années 2024 et 2023. En 2024, le nombre total d'employés est de **154,346**, contre **154,862** en 2023, ce qui représente une diminution de **516 employés**. La catégorie "Male" compte **72,644** employés en 2024, contre **73,884** en 2023, soit une baisse de **1,240 employés**. La catégorie "Female" affiche une augmentation, passant de **80,949** employés en 2023 à **81,661** en 2024, soit une hausse de **712 employés**. La catégorie "Other²" montre une augmentation notable, passant de **7** employés en 2023 à **18** en 2024, soit une hausse de **11 employés**. La catégorie "Not reported²" reste relativement stable, avec **22** employés en 2023 et **23** en 2024. Les catégories "Other²" et "Not reported²" restent marginales par rapport aux catégories principales "Male" et "Female". and

    BEGIN TABLE

    As of 31 December 2024 2023
    Male 72,644 73,884
    Female 81,661 80,949
    Other² 18 7
    Not reported² 23 22
    Total Employees 154,346 154,862

    Le tableau présente une répartition des employés par genre pour les années 2024 et 2023. En 2024, le nombre total d'employés est légèrement inférieur à celui de 2023, avec une diminution de 516 employés. Les hommes et les femmes constituent la majorité des employés, avec une légère baisse du nombre d'hommes (-1,240) et une augmentation du nombre de femmes (+712) en 2024 par rapport à 2023. Les catégories "Other" et "Not reported" restent marginales, bien que le nombre d'employés dans la catégorie "Other" ait augmenté de manière notable (+11).

  • Le tableau présente la répartition des employés par tranche d'âge pour les années 2024 et 2023, en nombre absolu (#) et en pourcentage (%). - En 2024, la proportion d'employés de moins de 30 ans est légèrement inférieure à celle de 2023 (18.6% contre 19.1%). - La part des employés âgés de 30 à 50 ans reste stable, représentant environ 55% pour les deux années. - La proportion d'employés de plus de 50 ans augmente légèrement en 2024 (26.4% contre 25.9% en 2023). - La part des employés de moins de 35 ans diminue également en 2024, passant de 34.3% en 2023 à 33.6%. and

  • Le tableau présente des données sur la part des véhicules électriques à batterie (BEVs) dans le portefeuille du groupe Allianz et dans ses marchés subsidiaires, ainsi que le ratio entre ces deux parts pour les années 2024, 2023 et l'objectif pour 2030. - En 2024, la **"Share of BEVs in Allianz Group portfolio (%)"** est de 3,2 %, tandis que la **"Share of BEVs in subsidiary markets (%)"** est de 3,0 %. Le **"Ratio (targeting >1) (number)"** est de 1,1. - En 2023, la **"Share of BEVs in Allianz Group portfolio (%)"** est de 2,6 %, contre 1,4 % pour la **"Share of BEVs in subsidiary markets (%)"**. Le **"Ratio (targeting >1) (number)"** est de 1,9. - L'objectif pour 2030 est d'avoir un **"Ratio (targeting >1) (number)"** supérieur à 1. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    2024 2023 2030 target
    Share of BEVs in Allianz Group portfolio (%) 3.2 2.6 -
    Share of BEVs in subsidiary markets (%) 3.0 1.4 -

    Le tableau présente des données sur la part des véhicules électriques à batterie (BEVs) dans le portefeuille du groupe Allianz et dans ses marchés subsidiaires, ainsi que le ratio entre ces deux parts.
    - En 2024, la part des BEVs dans le portefeuille du groupe Allianz est de 3,2 %, tandis que dans les marchés subsidiaires, elle est de 3,0 %. Le ratio est de 1,1. - En 2023, la part des BEVs dans le portefeuille du groupe Allianz est de 2,6 %, contre 1,4 % dans les marchés subsidiaires. Le ratio est de 1,9. - L'objectif pour 2030 est d'avoir un ratio supérieur à 1.

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les données de couverture (%) au 31 décembre pour différentes catégories d'investissements. - La couverture totale est de 60,4 %. - Les investissements en dette à la juste valeur par le biais d'autres éléments du résultat global ont une couverture de 71,8 %. - Les investissements en actions désignés à la juste valeur par le biais d'autres éléments du résultat global affichent une couverture de 85,3 %. - Les parts dans des entreprises affiliées et associées ont une couverture de 60,9 %. - Les biens immobiliers détenus pour investissement ne présentent pas de données de couverture dans ce tableau. - Les fonds d'investissement à la juste valeur par le biais du compte de résultat ont une couverture très faible, à 0,9 %. - Les autres catégories (valeur comptable < 20 milliards d'euros et liquidités) ont une couverture de 36,7 %. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    As of 31 December 2024 2023
    Book value (€ bn) Absolute financed emissions (mn t CO₂e) Carbon Intensity (t CO₂e/€ mn invested) Coverage (%) Book value (€ bn) Absolute financed emissions (mn t CO₂e) Carbon Intensity (t CO₂e/€ mn invested) Coverage (%)
    Debt investments at fair value through other comprehensive income 545.4 45.1 101.2 74.1 534.7 53.9 129.2 71.1
    Equity investments designated at fair value through other comprehensive income 26.3 0.8 36.7 86.2 26.9 1.1 53.6 85.5

    Real estate held for investment 22.5 - - - 23.9 - - 0.0
    Investment funds at fair value through profit and loss 82.5 1.1 62.2 21.1 73.6 1.6 10.3 36.6
    Other (book value < € 20 bn and cash) 68.0 1.3 68.4 27.8 56.5 1.6 83.4 36.6
    Total 767.0 48.6 94.2 64.3 736.8 57.2 117.5 60.0

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau compare les données financières et environnementales pour les années 2024 et 2023, en se concentrant sur la valeur comptable, les émissions financées absolues, l'intensité carbone et la couverture. - En 2024, la valeur comptable totale est de 767,0 milliards d'euros, avec des émissions financées absolues de 48,6 millions de tonnes de CO₂e et une intensité carbone de 94,2 t CO₂e/€ mn investi. La couverture est de 64,3 %. - En 2023, la valeur comptable totale est légèrement inférieure, à 736,8 milliards d'euros, avec des émissions financées absolues plus élevées (57,2 millions de tonnes de CO₂e) et une intensité carbone plus importante (117,5 t CO₂e/€ mn investi). La couverture est de 60,0 %. - Les investissements en dette représentent la majorité de la valeur comptable et des émissions financées absolues pour les deux années. - Les investissements en actions et les parts dans des entreprises affiliées montrent une intensité carbone plus faible mais une couverture élevée. - Les biens immobiliers détenus pour investissement n'ont pas de données sur les émissions ou l'intensité carbone pour les deux années. - Les fonds d'investissement et les autres catégories montrent des variations significatives dans l'intensité carbone et la couverture entre les deux années.

  • Le tableau présente les données de consommation énergétique au 31 décembre pour l'année 2024, avec une répartition en pourcentage par rapport à la consommation totale. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (indiquées par "n.a."). - La consommation totale d'énergie fossile en 2024 est de 348,703.4 unités, représentant 32.7 % de la consommation totale. - La consommation provenant de sources nucléaires est de 7,595.3 unités, soit 0.7 % de la consommation totale. - La consommation totale d'énergie non renouvelable atteint 356,298.7 unités, correspondant à 33.4 % de la consommation totale. - La consommation d'énergie renouvelable se divise en deux catégories : 587,554.0 unités pour l'électricité, la chaleur, la vapeur et le refroidissement achetés ou acquis, représentant 55.2 %, et 121,599.6 unités pour l'énergie renouvelable auto-produite sans combustible, représentant 11.4 %. - La consommation totale d'énergie renouvelable s'élève à 709,153.6 unités, soit 66.6 % de la consommation totale. - La consommation énergétique globale pour 2024 est de 1,065,452.4 unités, avec une répartition de 100 % entre les différentes sources. and

    Le tableau présente les données de consommation énergétique au 31 décembre pour l'année 2024, avec une répartition en pourcentage par rapport à la consommation totale. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (indiquées par "n.a.").
    - La consommation totale d'énergie fossile en 2024 est de 348,703.4 unités, représentant 32.7 % de la consommation totale. - La consommation provenant de sources nucléaires est de 7,595.3 unités, soit 0.7 % de la consommation totale. - La consommation totale d'énergie non renouvelable atteint 356,298.7 unités, correspondant à 33.4 % de la consommation totale. - La consommation d'énergie renouvelable se divise en deux catégories : 587,554.0 unités pour l'électricité, la chaleur, la vapeur et le refroidissement achetés ou acquis, représentant 55.2 %, et 121,599.6 unités pour l'énergie renouvelable auto-produite sans combustible, représentant 11.4 %. - La consommation totale d'énergie renouvelable s'élève à 709,153.6 unités, soit 66.6 % de la consommation totale. - La consommation énergétique globale pour 2024 est de 1,065,452.4 unités, avec une répartition de 100 % entre les différentes sources.

La répartition par sexe du personnel dans l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise Allianz pour l'année 2024 est la suivante :

  • Dans les postes de direction exécutive globale d'Allianz (AGE) :

    • Hommes : 70.0%
    • Femmes : 30.0%

  • Dans les postes de direction exécutive senior d'Allianz (ASE) :

    • Hommes : 68.0%
    • Femmes : 32.0%

  • Dans les postes de direction exécutive d'Allianz (AE) :

    • Hommes : 59.5%
    • Femmes : 40.5%

Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM2 :
  • We regularly monitor and report the percentage of our female executives to the Allianz SE Board of Management. Our 2024 targets are to have 30% women in Allianz Global Executive positions, 30% women in Allianz Senior Executive positions, and 40% women in Allianz Executive positions. The targets are set and calibrated every three years. The levels of female representation achieved in our executive clusters for 2024 are detailed in table S1-9.1. We regularly monitor and report the percentage of our female executives to the Allianz SE Board of Management. Our 2024 targets are to have 30% women in Allianz Global Executive positions, 30% women in Allianz Senior Executive positions, and 40% women in Allianz Executive positions. The targets are set and calibrated every three years. The levels of female representation achieved in our executive clusters for 2024 are detailed in table S1-9.1.

  • ### Gender pay gap and remuneration ratio We strive for equitable and fair remuneration across the organization, as defined in our **Allianz Group Code of Conduct** and **Group Remuneration Policy**. In 2024, the entity-specific unadjusted gender pay gap is 25.2%.[^1] It is defined as the difference of average pay levels between female and male employees, expressed as the percentage of the average pay level of male employees, irrespective of their role, seniority, function, or location.[^2] The target total remuneration for the Allianz SE Board of Management is determined by the Allianz Supervisory Board based on a fully disclosed remuneration system approved by shareholders (see also the **Remuneration Report**). In 2024, the annual total remuneration ratio of the CEO[^3] to the median annual total remuneration for all Allianz employees, as defined by ESRS, is 139.9. ### Gender pay gap and remuneration ratio We strive for equitable and fair remuneration across the organization, as defined in our **Allianz Group Code of Conduct** and **Group Remuneration Policy**. In 2024, the entity-specific unadjusted gender pay gap is 25.2%.[^1] It is defined as the difference of average pay levels between female and male employees, expressed as the percentage of the average pay level of male employees, irrespective of their role, seniority, function, or location.[^2] The target total remuneration for the Allianz SE Board of Management is determined by the Allianz Supervisory Board based on a fully disclosed remuneration system approved by shareholders (see also the **Remuneration Report**). In 2024, the annual total remuneration ratio of the CEO[^3] to the median annual total remuneration for all Allianz employees, as defined by ESRS, is 139.9.
  • # Gender At Allianz, we have already attained overall numerical parity of women and men in our workforce (see table S1-6.1). The ASPC includes the principles with which gender representation is managed in the Allianz Group. Our actions for higher inclusion help us achieve our targets on gender. These include: - We put measures in place to staff leadership positions with the most suitable candidates, ensuring equal opportunities for all, regardless of gender. - We promote equal pay for equal work in the same or comparable work for all genders. - Allianz NEO, our employee network for gender inclusion, has 21 local networks in place, with one of those launched in 2024. # Gender At Allianz, we have already attained overall numerical parity of women and men in our workforce (see table S1-6.1). The ASPC includes the principles with which gender representation is managed in the Allianz Group. Our actions for higher inclusion help us achieve our targets on gender. These include: - We put measures in place to staff leadership positions with the most suitable candidates, ensuring equal opportunities for all, regardless of gender. - We promote equal pay for equal work in the same or comparable work for all genders. - Allianz NEO, our employee network for gender inclusion, has 21 local networks in place, with one of those launched in 2024.

  • # Allianz SE Supervisory Board: Sustainability Committee The Supervisory Board of Allianz SE established a Sustainability Committee in 2021 which meets at least two times per year. Its core objectives include: - Advising the Supervisory Board on sustainability-related matters to support the sound and sustainable development and positioning of the Allianz Group. - Monitoring and supporting oversight of the Management Board’s sustainability strategy, particularly the management and execution of the strategic framework for Group-wide sustainability measures. - Preliminary examination of the Sustainability Statement. - Supporting the Personnel Committee in preparing the sustainability-related target-setting process and reviewing the fulfillment of these targets for the Management Board’s remuneration. # Allianz SE Supervisory Board: Sustainability Committee The Supervisory Board of Allianz SE established a Sustainability Committee in 2021 which meets at least two times per year. Its core objectives include: - Advising the Supervisory Board on sustainability-related matters to support the sound and sustainable development and positioning of the Allianz Group. - Monitoring and supporting oversight of the Management Board’s sustainability strategy, particularly the management and execution of the strategic framework for Group-wide sustainability measures. - Preliminary examination of the Sustainability Statement. - Supporting the Personnel Committee in preparing the sustainability-related target-setting process and reviewing the fulfillment of these targets for the Management Board’s remuneration.
  • We monitor our legal proceedings with our Litigation Proceedings Data Base and our Supervisory Proceedings Data Base. The Litigation Proceedings Data Base covers civil and administrative proceedings that pose reputational risks or exceed a financial threshold and criminal cases against Allianz leaders or subsidiaries. The Supervisory Proceedings Data Base includes administrative fines and administrative proceedings which could lead to administrative fees above a specified threshold, e.g., involving employees tied to their work or internally defined sensitive issues, as well as criminal proceedings against Allianz personnel that is related to their work or against subsidiaries of the Allianz Group without a threshold. The corresponding overall amount of material fines, penalties, and compensation for incidents connected to own workforce from proceedings relating to human rights incidents registered in these data bases can be found in table S1-17. We monitor our legal proceedings with our Litigation Proceedings Data Base and our Supervisory Proceedings Data Base. The Litigation Proceedings Data Base covers civil and administrative proceedings that pose reputational risks or exceed a financial threshold and criminal cases against Allianz leaders or subsidiaries. The Supervisory Proceedings Data Base includes administrative fines and administrative proceedings which could lead to administrative fees above a specified threshold, e.g., involving employees tied to their work or internally defined sensitive issues, as well as criminal proceedings against Allianz personnel that is related to their work or against subsidiaries of the Allianz Group without a threshold. The corresponding overall amount of material fines, penalties, and compensation for incidents connected to own workforce from proceedings relating to human rights incidents registered in these data bases can be found in table S1-17.

  • ## BASIS FOR PREPARATION ### Allianz Group approach to sustainability reporting Allianz’s purpose – *We secure your future* – guides our actions across the Allianz Group and drives us to pursue constant innovation and collaboration. It also guides our interactions with our customers, partners, employees, investors, governments, regulators, society, people with disabilities, and next generations across all our businesses. Our ambition is to actively support the transition toward a more sustainable economy in collaboration with our value chain, focusing on measurable actions, transparent reporting, and long-term positive impacts across societies, economies, and the environment. ## BASIS FOR PREPARATION ### Allianz Group approach to sustainability reporting Allianz’s purpose – *We secure your future* – guides our actions across the Allianz Group and drives us to pursue constant innovation and collaboration. It also guides our interactions with our customers, partners, employees, investors, governments, regulators, society, people with disabilities, and next generations across all our businesses. Our ambition is to actively support the transition toward a more sustainable economy in collaboration with our value chain, focusing on measurable actions, transparent reporting, and long-term positive impacts across societies, economies, and the environment.

Je ne sais pas. Les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur la répartition par sexe du personnel dans l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Gender distribution in executive positions as of 31 December 2023: The table compares gender distribution across executive positions for the years 2021 and 2023. It includes data for "Executive positions (top management)," "Allianz Global Executive (AGE) positions," "Allianz Senior Executive (ASE) positions," and "Allianz Executive (AE) positions." For "Executive positions (top management)," the total number of executives increased from 6,677 in 2021 to 6,788 in 2023. Male representation rose from 60.9% to 65.7%, while female representation decreased from 39.1% to 34.3%. In "AGE positions," the total increased from 213 to 235, with male representation growing from 70.0% to 74.0% and female representation declining from 30.0% to 26.0%. For "ASE positions," the total rose slightly from 793 to 803, with male representation increasing from 68.0% to 72.1% and female representation dropping from 32.0% to 27.9%. In "AE positions," the total grew from 5,671 to 5,750, with male representation rising from 59.5% to 64.5% and female representation decreasing from 40.5% to 35.5%. The categories "Other" and "Not reported" were not disclosed for both years across all positions.
  • We regularly monitor and report the percentage of our female executives to the Allianz SE Board of Management. Our 2024 targets are to have 30% women in Allianz Global Executive positions, 30% women in Allianz Senior Executive positions, and 40% women in Allianz Executive positions.1 The targets are set and calibrated every three years. The levels of female representation achieved in our executive clusters for 2024 are detailed in table S1-9.1.

  • ### We strive for equitable and fair remuneration across the organization, as defined in our Allianz Group Code of Conduct and Group Remuneration Policy. In 2024, the entity-specific unadjusted gender pay gap is 25.2%.1 It is defined as the difference of average pay levels between female and male employees, expressed as the percentage of the average pay level of male employees, irrespective of their role, seniority, function, or location.2 The target total remuneration for the Allianz SE Board of Management is determined by the Allianz Supervisory Board based on a fully disclosed remuneration system approved by shareholders (see also the Remuneration Report). In 2024, the annual total remuneration ratio of the CEO3 to the median annual total remuneration for all Allianz employees, as defined by ESRS, is 139.9.

La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en investigación, desarrollo, demostración y despliegue de instalaciones innovadoras de generación de electricidad que producen energía a partir de procesos nucleares con residuos mínimos del ciclo de combustible. **Estado:** NO. 2. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción y operación segura de nuevas instalaciones nucleares para producir electricidad o calor de proceso, incluyendo calefacción distrital, procesos industriales como la producción de hidrógeno, y mejoras de seguridad utilizando las mejores tecnologías disponibles. 3. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la operación segura de instalaciones nucleares existentes que producen electricidad o calor de proceso, incluyendo calefacción distrital, procesos industriales como la producción de hidrógeno a partir de energía nuclear, y mejoras de seguridad. **Actividades relacionadas con el gas fósil:** 4. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción u operación de instalaciones de generación de electricidad que producen electricidad utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. 5. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción, renovación y operación de instalaciones de generación combinada de calor/frío y electricidad utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. 6. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción, renovación y operación de instalaciones de generación de calor/frío utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. ### END TABLE
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos relacionados con los KPI de Taxonomía para las inversiones del Grupo Allianz en el año 2024. Los encabezados incluyen "Additional, complementary disclosures: breakdown of denominator of the KPI" y "Monetary amounts (€ bn)". Los porcentajes y proporciones se desglosan de la siguiente manera: 1. El porcentaje de derivados respecto al total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 3.0%. 2. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas financieras y no financieras no sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU sobre el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 29.2% para empresas no financieras y del 16.7% para empresas financieras. 3. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas financieras y no financieras de países fuera de la UE no sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU es del 22.8% para empresas no financieras y del 10.2% para empresas financieras. 4. La proporción de exposiciones a empresas sujetas a los Artículos 19a y 29a de la Directiva 2013/34/EU es del 9.9% para empresas no financieras y del 28.5% para empresas financieras. 5. La proporción de exposiciones a otros contrapartes y activos sobre el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI es del 12.6%. 6. La proporción de inversiones distintas de las mantenidas en contratos de seguros de vida donde el riesgo de inversión es asumido por los asegurados es del 81.4%. 7. El valor de las inversiones que financian actividades económicas no elegibles según la Taxonomía, en relación con el total de activos cubiertos por el KPI, es del 31.1% para el "Turnover" y del 30.5% para el "CAPEX". 8. El valor de las inversiones que financian actividades económicas elegibles según la Taxonomía, pero no alineadas, es del 17.8% para el "Turnover" y del 18.3% para el "CAPEX".
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre "Economic activities" y su alineación con la taxonomía en términos de "Turnover" para el año 2024. Las columnas incluyen "Amount and proportion (the information is to be presented in monetary amounts and as percentages)", desglosadas en "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila 1, las actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía según la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 2. En la fila 2, las actividades según la Sección 4.27 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 3. En la fila 3, las actividades según la Sección 4.28 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.4 (2.4% para CCM). 4. En la fila 4, las actividades según la Sección 4.29 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 5. En la fila 5, las actividades según la Sección 4.30 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.3 (0.3% para CCM). 6. En la fila 6, las actividades según la Sección 4.31 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 7. En la fila 7, otras actividades alineadas con la taxonomía no incluidas en las filas 1 a 6 reportan un "Turnover" de 15.5 (97.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA). 8. En la fila 8, el total de actividades alineadas con la taxonomía reporta un "Turnover" de 16.0 (100.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA).
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta los requisitos de divulgación y puntos de datos relacionados, clasificados por "Materiality" y "Sub-section/sub-sub-section". Los años no están especificados en el contenido. 1. **ESRS S2-1** aborda el incumplimiento de los principios de los UNGPs sobre Empresas y Derechos Humanos y las directrices de la OCDE (párrafo 19), así como las políticas de diligencia debida relacionadas con los convenios fundamentales de la OIT (párrafo 19). Ambos son materiales y se relacionan con las políticas de ESRS y el modelo de negocio estratégico para los trabajadores en la cadena de valor. 2. **ESRS S2-4** trata temas de derechos humanos e incidentes en la cadena de valor (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos para remediar impactos negativos. 3. **ESRS S3-1** incluye compromisos de políticas de derechos humanos (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs, OIT u OCDE (párrafo 17), ambos materiales y vinculados al modelo de negocio estratégico para comunidades afectadas. 4. **ESRS S3-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos de interacción con comunidades afectadas. 5. **ESRS S4-1** sobre políticas relacionadas con consumidores y usuarios finales (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs y OCDE (párrafo 17) no son materiales. 6. **ESRS S4-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 35), considerado material, con enfoque en acciones. 7. **ESRS G1-1** sobre la Convención de las Naciones Unidas contra la Corrupción (párrafo 10 (b)) y la protección de denunciantes (párrafo 10 (d)) no son relevantes, ya que las políticas ya están implementadas. 8. **ESRS G1-4** sobre multas por violación de leyes anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (a)) y estándares anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (b)) son materiales, con enfoque en incidentes confirmados de corrupción o soborno. 9. Se menciona la aplicación de la cláusula de salvaguarda según ESRS 2.5(e) en relación con §§ 289e y 315c HGB para la brecha salarial de género en S1-16, sin más detalles.

La répartition par sexe dans les positions d'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise pour l'année 2023 est la suivante :

  • Dans les "positions de direction (encadrement supérieur)", il y a 65.7% d'hommes et 34.3% de femmes.
  • Dans les "positions Allianz Global Executive (AGE)", il y a 74.0% d'hommes et 26.0% de femmes.
  • Dans les "positions Allianz Senior Executive (ASE)", il y a 72.1% d'hommes et 27.9% de femmes.
  • Dans les "positions Allianz Executive (AE)", il y a 64.5% d'hommes et 35.5% de femmes.

This broader scope ensur es a more accurate reflection of leadership/management across all levels.   • adequate and effective measures to address any confirmed incidents. We monitor our legal proceedings with our Litigation Proceedings Data Base and our Supervisory Proceedings Data Base. The Litigation Proceedings Data Base covers civil and administrative proceedings that pose reputational risks or exceed a financial thresh old and criminal cases against Allianz leaders or subsidiaries. The Supervisory Proceedings Data Base includes administrative fines and administrative proceedings which could lead to administrative fines each above a specified threshold, e.g., involving em ployees tied to their work or internally defined sensitive issues, as well as criminal proceedings against Allianz personnel that is related to their work or against subsidiaries of the Allianz Group without a threshold. The corresponding overall amount of material fines, penalties, and compensation for incidents connected to own workforce from proceedings adequate and effective measures to address any confirmed incidents. The Supervisory Proceedings Data Base includes administrative fines and administrative proceedings which could lead to administrative fines each above a specified threshold, e.g., involving em ployees tied to their work or internally defined sensitive issues, as well as criminal proceedings against Allianz personnel that is related to their work or against subsidiaries of the Allianz Group without a threshold.   • Committee The Supervisory Board of Allianz SE established a Sustainability Committee in 2021 which meets at least two times per year. Its core objectives include: − Advising the Supervisory Board on sustainability -related matters to support the sound and sustainable development and positioning of the Allianz Group . − Monitoring and supporting oversight of the Management Board’s sustainability strategy, particularly the management and execution of the strategic framework for Group -wide sustainability measures. − Preliminary examination of the Sustainability Statement. − Supporting the Personnel Committee in preparing the sustainability -related target -setting process and reviewing the fulfillment of these targets for the Management Board’s remuneration. The Supervisory Board of Allianz SE is responsible for defining and assessing targets for the Board of Management. The Sustainability Committee advises on setting and assessing sustainability -related Committee The Supervisory Board of Allianz SE established a Sustainability Committee in 2021 which meets at least two times per year. Its core objectives include: − Advising the Supervisory Board on sustainability -related matters to support the sound and sustainable development and positioning of the Allianz Group . − Monitoring and supporting oversight of the Management Board’s sustainability strategy, particularly the management and execution of the strategic framework for Group -wide sustainability measures. − Preliminary examination of the Sustainability Statement. − Supporting the Personnel Committee in preparing the sustainability -related target -setting process and reviewing the fulfillment of these targets for the Management Board’s remuneration. The Supervisory Board of Allianz SE is responsible for defining and assessing targets for the Board of Management. The Sustainability Committee advises on setting and assessing sustainability -related
  • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management
  • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
G1-44

Quelle est la valeur monétaire totale des contributions politiques en nature apportées directement et indirectement par l'entreprise ? Indiquer les bénéficiaires des dons en nature effectués. Indiquer si la politique de lobbying de l'entreprise exclut les dons en nature. Les contributions en nature incluent la publication, l'utilisation d'installations, la conception et l'impression, le don de matériel, l'adhésion à un conseil d'administration, l'emploi ou 1 la consultance pour des responsables politiques élus ou des candidats à un mandat.

nan

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur la valeur monétaire totale des contributions politiques en nature apportées directement et indirectement par l'entreprise. De même, les bénéficiaires précis des dons en nature ne sont pas mentionnés, ni les détails sur la politique de lobbying de l'entreprise concernant l'exclusion ou non des dons en nature.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Our quantitative disclosures on political contributions take financial as well as in-kind contributions into consideration. For our financial contributions, our disclosures include the monetary value of direct donations to any individual politician or individuals running for office, political parties, and directly affiliated organizations, as well as the monetary value of indirect financial political contributions made to any political party through an in-kind contributions, our disclosures include the use of facilities, design, and printing, as well as the Allianz SE Board members’ contributions, the provision of Allianz SE Board memberships to representatives of political parties, and the provision of non-monetary support to any political cause or entity through an intermediary. One example of an in-kind contribution of an Allianz SE Board member could be the monetary value of their working time spent holding a speech at a political panel discussion. Our quantitative disclosures on political contributions take financial as well as in-kind contributions into consideration. For our financial contributions, our disclosures include the monetary value of direct donations to any individual politician or individuals running for office, political parties, and directly affiliated organizations, as well as the monetary value of indirect financial political contributions made to any political party through an in-kind contributions, our disclosures include the use of facilities, design, and printing, as well as the Allianz SE Board members’ contributions, the provision of Allianz SE Board memberships to representatives of political parties, and the provision of non-monetary support to any political cause or entity through an intermediary. One example of an in-kind contribution of an Allianz SE Board member could be the monetary value of their working time spent holding a speech at a political panel discussion.
  • ### END TABLE 1_The majority of political contributions, around 80 %, originates from Europe, while the rest is from Asia Pacific and the Americas. Additionally, about two-thirds of the political contributions are financial, with the remaining one-third being in-kind contributions. According to our Group policy, in-kind contributions are measured based on market values whenever possible, mainly for real estate (e.g., providing office space) or donation of equipment. Further, Allianz SE board members’ in-kind contributions are measured based on business hours spent. To calculate the monetary value of the business hours spent, we use the following formula, according to the calculation method for the German Lobby Register: Share of hours spent by 147 G1 Business Conduct Allianz SE Board members in their total working hours* (base salary + annual bonus). Main lobbying activities Our lobbying activities in 2024 included the following main topics: ### END TABLE 1_The majority of political contributions, around 80 %, originates from Europe, while the rest is from Asia Pacific and the Americas. Additionally, about two-thirds of the political contributions are financial, with the remaining one-third being in-kind contributions. According to our Group policy, in-kind contributions are measured based on market values whenever possible, mainly for real estate (e.g., providing office space) or donation of equipment. Further, Allianz SE board members’ in-kind contributions are measured based on business hours spent. To calculate the monetary value of the business hours spent, we use the following formula, according to the calculation method for the German Lobby Register: Share of hours spent by 147 G1 Business Conduct Allianz SE Board members in their total working hours* (base salary + annual bonus).
